webTitle: Lewis under pressure to name names

fields.headline: Lewis under pressure to name names
fields.trailText: England players have joined ranks to challenge Chris Lewis to identify the "famous" international trio that he has alleged are implicated in the match-rigging scandal.
fields.body:
England players have joined ranks to challenge Chris Lewis to identify the "famous" international trio that he has alleged are implicated in the match-rigging scandal.

Lewis's evidence of English involvement is drawn solely from claims made by the sports promoter, Ashim Kheterpal, while allegedly pressing him to act as a go-between in a proposed £1m scam during the England Test series against New Zealand last summer.

Angus Fraser, the veteran Middlesex seam bowler, yesterday joined England's captain, Nasser Hussain, in calling for a lifetime ban for any player found guilty of match-fixing, and insisted that it was Lewis's responsibility to reveal the "three household names" who Kheterpal claimed had taken back-handers.

"I was shocked and surprised to hear of the Lewis allegations," said Fraser. "He has to come forward with names. If any England players are involved it implicates us all.

"There is a shadow over all of us. Whether it is true or not, if there are three England players involved their names should be produced."

Fraser said he remained oblivious to any match-rigging within the England set-up. "I never suspected this was going on, if it was. I have never been approached. I have never had anyone on the other end of the telephone asking me to do anything."

Alan Mullally, along with Alec Stewart, was one of the players that, according to Lewis, had been identified by Kheterpal last summer as a potential target.

"I never knew anything about it last time and it will be interesting to see if there's anything in it this time around," Mullally said. "I've been around the England set-up for a few years and never seen or heard something like this but, after Cronje, people are prepared to believe anything. I've always got along fine with Lewis but he's quite fond of the limelight and let's say he's a bit eccentric."

Darren Gough also urged Lewis to go public. "If he's going to say there are three players doing this, let him name them," he said. "Let's get this whole thing out in the open."

Lewis has surrendered much sympathy by making his accusations exclusively in a Sunday tabloid newspaper. But it should be recognised that his reluctance to name the three England players that he alleges Kheterpal named as match- fixers is entirely understandable.

The danger is that Lewis is increasingly regarded with disdain by players and officials primarily concerned with maintaining England's untainted reputation.

 Herschelle Gibbs and Nicky Boje, two players named with Hansie Cronje in match-fixing charges by Indian police , were yesterday offered new two-year contracts by the South African cricket board. Pieter Strydom, a third player named, has not been including in the squad for the tour to Sri Lanka because of a loss of form.

fields.headline: Lewis hauled before Lord's
fields.standfirst: Police also wait to question the former England bowler
fields.trailText: Chris Lewis has been called to appear before an England and Wales Cricket Board investigative panel today to expand on his allegations that three England Test players are implicated in match rigging.
fields.body:
Chris Lewis has been called to appear before an England and Wales Cricket Board investigative panel today to expand on his allegations that three England Test players are implicated in match rigging.

In addition the police team who investigated Lewis's original claims last summer, and to date have disclosed no firm evidence of such activity involving England players, confirmed yesterday that they are urgently seeking fresh talks with the Leicestershire player.

Lewis's manner of revealing his suspicions - an exclusive interview in a Sunday tabloid - has not assisted his cause. Neither has the vagueness of his allegations, which are based entirely on what he says are the claims of an Indian businessman, Ashim Kheterpal, whom Lewis claims tried to entice him to become an intermediary in a £1m sting during England's Test series against New Zealand last summer.

Lewis has been summoned before an ECB two-man panel of Gerard Elias QC, chairman of the disciplinary committee, and the international teams director Simon Pack.

"This is an extremely serious issue and therefore we shall be meeting with Chris Lewis tomorrow to discuss his comments in detail," Pack said. "The ECB sought the assistance of the police as soon as it became aware of the match-fixing allegations concerning the England v New Zealand Test series last summer.

"We co-operated fully with the police in their inquiries, which included the interview of all England players, team management and match officials involved in the series. As a result, the police found nothing to implicate any player, member of management or match official in match fixing. However, we have today contacted the police investigation team regarding the News of the World article and they have confirmed that they too will be seeking to interview Chris Lewis about this matter with some urgency."

The ECB's penchant for secrecy, not for the first time, does not encourage total faith in its investigative powers. It attempted to keep last summer's internal inquiry confidential - a summer that began with England's failure to qualify for the final stages of the World Cup and ended with them being ranked as the worst Test team in the world. For an Asian bookmaker, bribing them to win might have been a more attractive proposition.

Lewis will stand by his story: that Kheterpal, a sports promoter, perhaps in an effort to persuade him to become involved, named three England players who had taken bungs amounting to "thousands of pounds". Kheterpal, Lewis alleged, then promised him £1m to help fix the New Zealand series, and suggested that he offered £300,000 each to Alec Stewart and Alan Mullally to underperform.

"I nearly fell off my chair in shock when he told me who the names were," Lewis said. "The amounts the three received ran into thousands. I was told everybody was at it including players from South Africa, India and Pakistan."

Lewis accurately predicted the furore that would descend on him when he said: "I know I'll get serious stick by effectively implicating three England players."

But his insistence that he will never reveal the players' names to the authorities might sound a little insouciant by the weekend. If the ECB does not persuade him to reveal the names, the police will be only too anxious to jog his memory.

webTitle: Vialli points Chelsea the way to the wide blue yonder

fields.headline: Vialli points Chelsea the way to the wide blue yonder
fields.trailText: At various times this season Gianluca Vialli has spoken about the credibility that comes from winning the Premiership and the emotional pull of lifting the FA Cup. But whenever he mentioned the Champions League the Chelsea manager tended to play down its importance, dismissing it as a sort of lucrative sideshow.
fields.body:
At various times this season Gianluca Vialli has spoken about the credibility that comes from winning the Premiership and the emotional pull of lifting the FA Cup. But whenever he mentioned the Champions League the Chelsea manager tended to play down its importance, dismissing it as a sort of lucrative sideshow.

Now the mind games are over. "This," says Vialli without hesitation, "is the most important match in the history of the club." A Champions League quarter-final, second leg. At the Nou Camp. In front of 100,000 baying Catalans. Against a team down on its luck but riddled with quality. A far cry from Tranmere on a wet Tuesday night at Prenton Park.

But that is how far Chelsea have travelled in an impressively short space of time. And the large amounts of cash and credibility that will accompany victory over Barcelona can only increase the angle of that upward curve. Until, maybe, Chelsea arrive at a point few have reached.

Vialli is one of the few, and yesterday the former Juventus European Cup-winning captain decided the time was right to tell his players the rules of high-altitude football.

"I have been lucky," he said. "I have never looked on football in terms of one point here and one point there. I am used to winning games and winning things. That's my mentality. That's what Chelsea have to have. Maybe years ago the club had an inferiority complex. That doesn't exist for me.

"To be in the Champions League quarter-final is part of the learning curve for a club like Chelsea. But perhaps in two years' time only the final will be good enough. The aim has to be to get to where I and Marcel Desailly have been."

The vast experience within the team can cope with the atmosphere. What Chelsea must devise is a tactic to protect their 3-1 lead from the first leg while trying to score themselves.

Not as easy as it sounds, the more so as Vialli's trusted lieutenant Graham Rix has been unable to travel due to "a virus". With their away goal, Barcelona need win only 2-0 to go through. But if Chelsea can find the net, it would almost certainly guarantee them a semi-final place.

"We must be fearless," said Vialli. "We can't think: 'Let's defend and play on the counter.' It's not an option. We want to play our own game."

His use in the first leg of Jody Morris's harrying skills in midfield helped Dennis Wise and Didier Deschamps cut off much of the supply to Barca's five-star attack. A similar ploy is likely tonight, especially with the return of the Spaniards' playmaker Pep Guardiola.

"We have to force them into mistakes," says Gianfranco Zola. "We have to pressurise them."

Zola was at his devilish best in the first leg and he and Tore Andre Flo can expect similar space to exploit behind the Barcelona defenders as they push forward in search of goals. In an attempt to reduce defensive frailties, the Barca coach Louis van Gaal is likely to change three of his back line, bringing in Michael Reiziger, Frédéric Déhu, and Boudewijn Zenden or Sergi.

But Chelsea just need that one goal. That is the bottom line this evening.

Barcelona (4-3-3): Hesp; Reiziger, Déhu, F de Boer, Sergi or Zenden; Litmanen or Xavi, Guardiola, Cocu; Figo, Kluivert, Rivaldo.

Chelsea (4-4-2): De Goey; Ferrer, Desailly, Leboeuf, Babayaro; Petrescu or Poyet, Morris, Wise, Deschamps; Zola, Flo.

webTitle: Barca in disarray as Camp fire splutters

fields.headline: Barca in disarray as Camp fire splutters
fields.standfirst: Victory over Chelsea is a must if they are to salvage their season
fields.trailText: Barely two weeks ago, before their Champions League encounter with Chelsea, the Catalan champions were being hailed as the best team in Europe, if not the world. If their current form continues, they will have a fight on their hands to stay the best team in Barcelona.
fields.body:
Barely two weeks ago, before their Champions League encounter with Chelsea, the Catalan champions were being hailed as the best team in Europe, if not the world. If their current form continues, they will have a fight on their hands to stay the best team in Barcelona.

In a nightmare 11 days Barcelona have lost four times, conceding three goals on each occasion with only Luis Figo's goal at Stamford Bridge to their credit. It is as if the former Champions League favourites have given up winning for Lent.

Saturday's humiliation was at the hands of the relegation-threatened Real Oviedo and courtesy of a hat-trick by the Panamanian Dely Valdes. Barcelona's challenge for the Spanish league has faded, leaving them five points behind Deportivo La Coruna (and only 11 points ahead of their city neighbours Espanyol). Suddenly, Barcelona's entire season is hanging on tonight's quarter-final, second leg against Gianluca Vialli's side in the Nou Camp.

Frank de Boer, one of the numerous Dutch internationals brought to the club by the coach and former Ajax manager Louis van Gaal, made a bleak assessment of the team's predicament even before the weekend's latest defeat. "We have to be aware of the situation," he said. "We've almost lost everything. To get out of this situation it's better to be realistic."

The defender is one of the few players with whom Van Gaal has not clashed publicly in recent weeks. Run-ins with the strikers Luis Enrique and Patrick Kluivert and the world footballer of the year Rivaldo have contributed to the atmosphere of discord and disarray that hang about the club.

"The truth is that Van Gaal's relationship with the players could be better, above all at the present time," Kluivert was quoted as saying in the Spanish press on Friday.

Kluivert's comments came two days after Van Gaal had called a team meeting to stress the importance of discipline. The Dutch coach observed of the above newspaper article that "a player of his age should know when to speak". Kluivert was duly dropped for the game against Oviedo.

For Chelsea, their 3-1 victory in the first leg was followed by a league win over Leeds United and an FA Cup semi- final victory over Newcastle. For Barcelona, however, in a curious parallel, it was followed with a 3-0 loss at home to Real Mallorca and a Spanish Cup semi-final first-leg defeat by the same score at Atletico Madrid.

Barcelona's losing streak has coincided with the injury and subsequent absence of their midfield linchpin, Pep Guardiola, whose influence on the team can be compared to that of Dennis Wise and Chelsea. "It's obvious we're missing Pep," the goalkeeper Ruud Hesp said. "He has so much individual quality."

Guardiola came on as a second-half substitute on Saturday and Van Gaal will be keen to pitch him in against Chelsea. "Only he can help the team," said the coach. "He hasn't trained for eight or nine days and we'll see how long he can last."

When things were going well for the reigning champions, the fact that Van Gaal had opted to rebuild his Ajax team at the expense of Catalan players such as Albert Ferrer could be overlooked. Barcelona were playing some dazzling football and looked on course for a possible treble. Before the game with Chelsea, they had won their previous nine matches and in some style.

But as the team's form has plummeted, the supporters' interest in the players' passports has surfaced once again, fuelled by the rumours that the Catalan left-back, Sergi, could be on his way out in the summer. On internet bulletin boards, the first "Van Gaal must go!" messages have appeared.

Three consecutive defeats normally constitute a suicide note for the men in charge in Spain, so Van Gaal may already be on borrowed time. But Chelsea would be foolish to underestimate the task facing them tonight.

Despite a fortnight from hell that he has admitted is his worst time at the club, Van Gaal remains upbeat. "After four defeats it's all very disappointing, but I'm going to try to use that disappointment to bounce back against Chelsea. With 100,000 in the Nou Camp anything is possible."

webTitle: Neville jibes led to death threats

fields.headline: Neville jibes led to death threats
fields.trailText: The Manchester United and England defender Gary Neville has disclosed that his public admissions that he dislikes Liverpool supporters have led to his receiving death threats.
fields.body:
The Manchester United and England defender Gary Neville has disclosed that his public admissions that he dislikes Liverpool supporters have led to his receiving death threats.

He has also revealed that he was fortunate to escape injury after Liverpool's visit to Old Trafford last month. During the match Neville was constantly barracked after antagonising visiting supporters. Then, as he waited in traffic after the game, his car was attacked half a mile from the stadium.

"I think I'm probably better off keeping my mouth shut about Liverpool from now on because I keep getting myself in trouble and I keep getting death threats," he said. "I tend to leave pretty quickly after games and after the Liverpool match my car was nearly turned over as I went through Salford Quays by about five scousers."

Despite confessing to being shaken by the incident, Neville added: "I remember growing up watching Manchester United and I didn't like Liverpool because they were winning everything and they were our rivals. It's the same now; people don't like us because we're winning everything. Hopefully we will be disliked for a long time to come.

"We always get a bad reception wherever we go and to be honest I wouldn't have it any other way. I want to play for a team that opposition fans feel threatened by and people are threatened by us."

 Robbie Fowler last night scored his first goal for almost four months and put himself in line for a Liverpool comeback in Good Friday's derby at Everton. The England striker played 81 minutes of the reserves' 2-0 victory at Manchester United, and had a hand in the second goal, scored by Vladimir Smicer. Liverpool's midfielder Patrik Berger, suspended for the first two games of Euro 2000, has been left out of the Czech Republic's team to face Israel in Prague on April 26.

fields.headline: Kanu driven to distraction
fields.standfirst: BBC puts foreign invasion under the spotlight
fields.trailText: If you spot a tall, lean fellow driving aimlessly around London one afternoon and think he bears a striking resemblance to Nwankwo Kanu, do not be surprised. The chances are it is the Arsenal striker.
fields.body:
If you spot a tall, lean fellow driving aimlessly around London one afternoon and think he bears a striking resemblance to Nwankwo Kanu, do not be surprised. The chances are it is the Arsenal striker.

The Nigerian has not taken up mini-cab driving to make ends meet but a rare glimpse inside his life reveals that all chez Kanu is not glitz and glamour. The vast house, the spacious garden and the picture on the wall of him with Ronaldo only accentuate the loneliness.

"It's difficult," he says, "because this place is very big and you feel alone here. It's boring. I have to go in the city, just driving around to do something to pass the time.

"The most difficult thing I'm going through is that my family is not here with me. I need them." A photo graph of a young Kanu in the dusty streets of Nigeria shows how far he has come.

The 23-year-old's tale is one of several featured on a BBC documentary charting the impact of the foreign invasion of the Premiership. And loneliness does not appear to be a problem for all the imports.

The narrator, Alan Hansen, finds Chelsea's Bernarde Lambourde and Manchester United's Dwight Yorke squeezing in a spot of modelling. A chat away from the catwalk suggested arithmetic is not Yorke's strong point.

How many foreigners did he reckon there were in the top flight, Hansen asked. About 50, the striker ventured. In fact there are almost 200, compared with 33 when the Premiership started in 1992. Kevin Keegan sounded worried.

"I honestly think the next England manager, whoever he is, will be watching First Division football for a lot of his players," he says. Keegan believes many homegrown youngsters are not working hard enough.

"We think we are working hard but half the time we are just playing at it," he says.

Hansen echoes the need for emerging English talent to sweat more. "It's too easy in the game now," he insists, "to be comfortable without trying very hard . . . to think I can't get a break here I'll go elsewhere."

fields.bodyText: If you spot a tall, lean fellow driving aimlessly around London one afternoon and think he bears a striking resemblance to Nwankwo Kanu, do not be surprised. The chances are it is the Arsenal striker. The Nigerian has not taken up mini-cab driving to make ends meet but a rare glimpse inside his life reveals that all chez Kanu is not glitz and glamour. The vast house, the spacious garden and the picture on the wall of him with Ronaldo only accentuate the loneliness. "It's difficult," he says, "because this place is very big and you feel alone here. It's boring. I have to go in the city, just driving around to do something to pass the time. "The most difficult thing I'm going through is that my family is not here with me. I need them." A photo graph of a young Kanu in the dusty streets of Nigeria shows how far he has come. The 23-year-old's tale is one of several featured on a BBC documentary charting the impact of the foreign invasion of the Premiership. And loneliness does not appear to be a problem for all the imports. The narrator, Alan Hansen, finds Chelsea's Bernarde Lambourde and Manchester United's Dwight Yorke squeezing in a spot of modelling. A chat away from the catwalk suggested arithmetic is not Yorke's strong point. How many foreigners did he reckon there were in the top flight, Hansen asked. About 50, the striker ventured. fields.headline: Durkin: 'I got it wrong'
fields.trailText: The referee Paul Durkin faces suspension after confessing to the Premier League in his match report that he should have sent off Chelsea's goalkeeper Ed de Goey at Hillsborough on Saturday.
fields.body:
The referee Paul Durkin faces suspension after confessing to the Premier League in his match report that he should have sent off Chelsea's goalkeeper Ed de Goey at Hillsborough on Saturday.

Durkin will make his admission of blame even though he knows a ban could be imposed for his rare and uncharacteristic error.

His only consolation is that his mistake did not affect the result, a 1-0 Chelsea defeat by Sheffield Wednesday through a Wim Jonk penalty.

Durkin awarded the penalty but he now admits he should also have shown De Goey the red card for his professional foul on Gilles de Bilde.

The World Cup official from Dorset decided on a yellow card instead, in direct contravention of Fifa and Premier League directives.

He could now receive a one-match suspension in line with Dermot Gallagher's punishment for failing to dismiss Arsenal's Steve Bould, now with Middlesbrough, in similar circumstances.

Mike Lee, a Premier League spokesman, said: "We are awaiting the report of both the referee and the match observer. It would be wrong to prejudge the situation."

The observer's verdict will be crucial to Durkin. Gallagher's suspension was imposed because of his poor general handling of the match, not merely because he let Bould off.

Durkin's performance at Hillsborough will be taken as a whole, although he cannot be encouraged that some of his decision-making drew criticism from Gianluca Vialli, the Chelsea manager.

Vialli will be glad to learn, however, that his goalkeeper's indiscretion will not be punished by a retrospective red card despite Durkin's candour over the incident.

Last night, the FA said the yellow-card verdict will stand. Judgment on Durkin comes at a delicate time because the footballing authorities are at pains to demonstrate even-handedness by dealing with errant referees as firmly as misbehaving players and managers, something to which another Premier League official, Rob Harris of the Tranmere Cup fiasco, will testify.

After past experience, Roy Evans seems unwilling to risk cohabiting with a Frenchman at Fulham; he confirmed yesterday that he will leave this summer when Jean Tigana takes the reins.

Evans, the assistant to the caretaker Karlheinz Riedle, said yesterday: "No offence to Gérard Houllier but I've already had one alliance with a Frenchman and I don't think it will happen here."

The Charlton midfielder Matt Holmes has ended his fight to come back after breaking his leg in February 1998. He has taken legal action against Wolves' Kevin Muscat, who made the challenge in which Holmes was injured.

 The European Commission yesterday rejected the proposal by the Uefa president Lennart Johansson to limit the number of foreign players that clubs can field and again rebuffed calls to change the Bosman ruling. Johansson had recommended that clubs should be obliged to select at least six nationals and restrict the number of imported players to five.

fields.headline: Brown lacks leading man
fields.trailText: Craig Brown rather admitted that he was waiting for something to turn up as he produced a Scotland squad for next week's game in the Netherlands: like a Denis Law, a Joe Jordan or a Kenny Dalglish.
fields.body:
Craig Brown rather admitted that he was waiting for something to turn up as he produced a Scotland squad for next week's game in the Netherlands: like a Denis Law, a Joe Jordan or a Kenny Dalglish.

The manager was hardly in the mood to throw any new lambs to the slaughter. He picked a pool that reflected his best option after a sound beating by the world champions France at Hampden Park last month.

The quality of the Dutch determined his selection and he will use a friendly in Arnhem's Gelredome stadium to pull together a side that will start its World Cup campaign with matches in Latvia, San Marino and Croatia in the autumn. With only one further "trial" in Dublin between now and then his room for manoeuvre is rapidly diminishing.

"I hope that in the early weeks [of next season] someone, especially a striker, will run into a bit of form," he said.

Brown was willing to name names. Kenny Miller of Hibernian and Gary Wales of Hearts are in an Under-21 squad that plays the Dutch on Tuesday. Motherwell's Lee McCulloch has also attracted his attention.

In the meantime he has to play a safe team against the likes of Kluivert, Overmars and Bergkamp. Scotland will seek goals through Billy Dodds and Kevin Gallacher, with Mark Burchill his preferred choice among the younger generation of goalscorers.

This is all in theory, of course. Next Wednesday's friendly comes at the end of the usual Easter crush of fixtures in England with Blackburn's Christian Dailly and Callum Davidson and Derby's Craig Burley not due to start training with Scotland in the Netherlands until 36 hours before the game.

Scotland could more or less field the side that beat England at Wembley in the last of the Euro 2000 qualifiers. But with the manager talking about the possible use of seven substitutes, the outcome is hardly considered important.

The side will be captained by Colin Hendry of Coventry City, whose team-mate Paul Telfer was called up as a late replacement and made his debut against France.

Hendry will need to marshal his troops especially well if Scotland are to give any hint that they are beginning the march towards Japan and South Korea in good stride.

fields.headline: Bosnich unlikely to face Real
fields.trailText: Mark Bosnich's hopes of being fit for United's Champions' League quarter-final second leg at home to Real Madrid tomorrow are looking increasingly unlikely. The Australian goalkeeper has aggravated a stomach injury that he picked up while swimming and was forced off at half-time in Saturday's 4-0 win over Sunderland.
fields.body:
Mark Bosnich's hopes of being fit for United's Champions' League quarter-final second leg at home to Real Madrid tomorrow are looking increasingly unlikely. The Australian goalkeeper has aggravated a stomach injury that he picked up while swimming and was forced off at half-time in Saturday's 4-0 win over Sunderland.

"He didn't train today and he will have to do something really special tomorrow - but he has a chance," Sir Alex Ferguson said yesterday, contradicting his verdict on Saturday that Bosnich would be fit.

Recalling the guessing game that Internazionale played over Ronaldo's fitness in the build-up to the first leg of last year's quarter-final, Ferguson keenness to play down rumours that Roberto Carlos would miss the game with tendinitis in his right kneecap was justified when the Brazil left-back reported fit yesterday.

He missed Real's last two games but will travel to Old Trafford, claiming he only sat out Real's 1-0 win at Real Zaragoza at the weekend to make sure he would be fit for tomorrow.

"I think we should just wait and see what their team is," Ferguson said. "They tend to do things like this and it's all part of their psychology - but we've got used to that."

fields.headline: Barclays considers pruning call centres
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Barclays bank is considering reducing the number of its call centres as part of an aim to introduce a single phone number for customer queries.
fields.body:
Barclays bank is considering reducing the number of its call centres as part of an aim to introduce a single phone number for customer queries.

The move, outlined to senior call centre staff at a secret meeting in London yesterday, raised fears of further job losses in rural areas and another wave of negative publicity after the unpopular decision earlier this month to axe 171 branches. Barclays has 100 call centres around the country.

The bank insisted last night that the move to streamline the call centres was unrelated to the branch closures and was intended to improve the service to its 13m customers.

However, the timing of yesterday's meeting, just hours before Matt Barrett, the bank's chief executive, faces scrutiny from MPs along with his counterparts at HSBC and Lloyds TSB, is likely to pressurise the bank further to clarify its strategy.

A Barclays spokeswoman said: "We have been meeting people who work in customer services centres and showing them the way forward".

Explaining that the plans were at an early stage, she said that no date had been set for the introduction of a single phone number for Barclays customers who ring a variety of different numbers at present. "We want to make it easier for people to contact us," she said.

The changes are most likely to impact on the more than 100 "customer contact centres" around the country which provide back-up services to branches in dealing with customers.

These may be amalgamated into larger centres although ther bank said yesterday that the plan was at such an early stage it was impossible to clarify its impact on jobs.

The plans might also lead to the expansion of the bank's centres for Barclaycall telephone banking service in Coventry, Manchester and Sunderland.

Many other banks have already streamlined their back office operations to set up call centres around the country.

webTitle: David undaunted as Goliath dismisses 'laughable' bid

fields.headline: David undaunted as Goliath dismisses 'laughable' bid
fields.standfirst:
Totalise insists the Chelsea must take its offer seriously
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: An unlikely power struggle is threatened between one of Britain's biggest building societies and a tiny internet company which launched nine months ago and specialises in selling cars and flowers online.
fields.body:
An unlikely power struggle is threatened between one of Britain's biggest building societies and a tiny internet company which launched nine months ago and specialises in selling cars and flowers online.

Chelsea building society might have assumed it had shaken off the unwelcome advances of Totalise, an internet service provider whose out-of-the-blue merger proposal landed on its doormat early last week only to be rejected as "laughable" by the society on Friday.

The dot.com minnow yesterday threatened a hostile takeover attempt if the society's board does not agree to sit down to calmly discuss the proposal.

Totalise said it was launching an internet bank later this year and claimed there was a strong case for bringing the two organisations together.

Michael Bage, the society's chief executive, described the proposal as "absurd" and completely lacking credibility.

He added: "There is nothing compatible between our organisations in terms of business focus, financial strength or management expertise. Totalise's approach to Chelsea is blatant opportunism."

Certainly, when the statistics are compared the proposal looks more than a little ridiculous.

The Chelsea was founded in 1875, has 500,000 members, assets approaching £5bn and announced profits for last year of £38.9m.

Totalise has been operating as a free internet service provider for less than a year, has no obvious track record in financial services and reported a loss of £922,000 in its first seven months of trading.

Based in Leeds, the company was set up by former GP Peter Gregory and launched on the Ofex market last July with an offer of free tradeable shares for anyone using its service.

At the launch a besuited Mr Gregory, 43, was photographed with a surfboard surrounded by bikini-clad young women.

The company attracted further publicity when it launched a net-based service, called Totalise Eurekar, which allows people to import cars from the continent at much lower prices than they can buy them here.

Totalise has also found time to launch Flowers2send, described as "the UK's first fully virtual flower shop," and buy the company that owns Carpetbagger.com, the website for those seeking to force societies to demutualise and pay windfalls, which last year mounted an attack on the Chelsea and two others.

While Totalise's chances of a deal look slim, the possibility cannot be completely dismissed.

Last year Stephen Major, a plumber from Northern Ireland, took on the Bradford & Bingley and won, putting forward a conversion resolution which was approved by members and is now being enacted by the board.

Perhaps the Chelsea's best tactic is to stall Totalise and rely on market meltdown to sap its strength.

The company has lost almost a third of its value in little more than a week, its share price dropping from 69.5p on April 10 to 50.5p yesterday, a far cry from its 142.5p high.

Mr Gregory said yesterday that the society "have an obligation to their members to talk to us" about the proposal.

"We are going to go back to them and say, 'There's a bit more to this than you suggested, can we at least spend half-an-hour going through our proposal?'."

What if the Chelsea simply slams the door in his face again, as seems likely? "Then we have to bring in professional advisers and move the thing forward on a more formal basis," he said.

"That would mean putting a formal proposal supported by a merchant bank to the members of Chelsea building society."

He indicated the ways his company could mobilise support for the merger proposal.

An estimated 3,000 to 4,000 members of Chelsea also use Totalise's net service, and another 5,000 or so are registered with Carpetbagger.com.

One idea under consideration is staging a leaflet drop outside Chelsea branches.

webTitle: Markets pull back from the brink

fields.headline: Markets pull back from the brink
fields.trailText: Wall Street's "bulge bracket" investment banks were sticking to their long term bullish market forecasts yesterday and private investors were advised to "sit tight" after share prices rallied during the day.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor, Dan Atkinson, Larry Elliott and Jane Martinson in Washington
fields.body:
Wall Street's "bulge bracket" investment banks were sticking to their long term bullish market forecasts yesterday and private investors were advised to "sit tight" after share prices rallied during the day.

As a sense of relief mixed with continuing caution settled over dealing rooms in both London and New York, the FTSE 100 index finished the day 183.5 points lower at 5,994.6, having fallen as low as 5,915 early in the morning in reaction to the 616 point slump on America's Dow Jones index on Friday night and a rout on the technology-heavy Nasdaq.

Damage in London, while still heavy at £35bn off the face value of the market, was limited by the fact that both the Dow and the Nasdaq turned in mild, albeit volatile, recoveries as trading resumed in New York.

The mood was helped by Abbey Cohen, the highly-regarded strategist who chairs Goldman Sachs' investment committee. She repeated her year-end forecast of 1,575 for the S&P 500, the broad-based stock market, in spite of Friday's 6% decline.

"We are making no changes to these elements of equity valuation and, therefore, no change to our price targets," she said.

Goldman's rival, Merrill Lynch, issued a similarly upbeat assessment after a week when the Nasdaq fell by more than 25% - sparking fears of panic selling among America's army of private stock market speculators.

Some more sanguine economists said investors welcomed signs that a re-evaluation of share prices actually put them on a firmer footing. Ian Waters, director of Credo, said: "Going forward, this could provide a more secure basis for growth in the hi-tech economy."

Other market experts warned of "aftershocks" in the week ahead, amid anecdotal evidence that thousands of amateur investors have overextended themselves, borrowing money to speculate. Many may be forced to liquidate their shareholdings.

Such nervousness was compounded by bouts of fresh weakness in US stocks. Some investors used the fleeting rally to extricate themselves, the opposite of previous corrections, when investors used the dip to rush back into shares.

It was only towards the close of trading in New York that the Dow put in a convincing recovery, sitting 170 points higher at 10,475 in late afternoon, while the Nasdaq composite rose 65 points to 3,386. Ms Cohen at Goldman Sachs reckons the Dow is still on track to end the year at 12,600.

Against this, British economists Andrew Smithers and Stephen Wright, who have just published Valuing Wall Street, a book charting the extraordinary performance of share prices over recent years, reiterated warnings that investors face a 1929-style crash that will halve equity values.

Mr Smithers said yesterday that "panic early" was the soundest advice anyone could give to investors. Valuing Wall Street has been endorsed by two members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee - Charles Goodhart and Sushil Wadhwani - and Mr Wright is himself a former bank economist.

Mr Smithers said there was no way of knowing if the turmoil marked the beginning of the end for the great bull market, but noted that prudent people "will of course have got out already".

The most serious aspect of the boom, he said, was the "tremendous pace" of debt accumulation in the US.

Mr Smithers also blames the recent stock market surge on the "buying-in" by companies of their own shares to help executives meet short-term targets for performance bonuses based on share prices.

It was only towards the close of trading in New York that the Dow put in a convincing recovery, sitting 170 points higher at 10,475 in late afternoon, while the Nasdaq composite rose 65 points to 3,386. Ms Cohen at Goldman Sachs reckons the Dow is still on track to end the year at 12,600. Against this, British economists Andrew Smithers and Stephen Wright, who have just published Valuing Wall Street, a book charting the extraordinary performance of share prices over recent years, reiterated warnings that investors face a 1929-style crash that will halve equity values. Mr Smithers said yesterday that "panic early" was the soundest advice anyone could give to investors. Valuing Wall Street has been endorsed by two members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee - Charles Goodhart and Sushil Wadhwani - and Mr Wright is himself a former bank economist. Mr Smithers said there was no way of knowing if the turmoil marked the beginning of the end for the great bull market, but noted that prudent people "will of course have got out already". The most serious aspect of the boom, he said, was the "tremendous pace" of debt accumulation in the US. Mr Smithers also blames the recent stock market surge on the "buying-in" by companies of their own shares to help executives meet short-term targets for performance bonuses based on share prices.

fields.headline: Correction: this is not Armaggedon
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: "Armageddon!" yelled the amateur punters in the internet chatrooms when the London stock market opened with a 250 point fall. Yet only three hours later the message was "buy, buy, buy" as the anticipated meltdown in tech stocks failed to materialise.
fields.body:
"Armageddon!" yelled the amateur punters in the internet chatrooms when the London stock market opened with a 250 point fall. Yet only three hours later the message was "buy, buy, buy" as the anticipated meltdown in tech stocks failed to materialise.

As Wall Street recovered some of its spectacular losses, small investors heaved a sigh of relief. "It was a large correction - that's all folks!" proclaimed an investor on hemscott.net, one of the largest internet bulletin boards where small traders swap share tips.

Hi-tech stocks at the forefront of the trading boom, such as BATM and QXL, closed down more than 10% yesterday - an improvement on the 20-25% markdown seen soon after trading began.

Signs of panic selling were minimal but nerves were frayed and trading volumes heavier than usual. Stockbroker Charles Schwab did 11,000 trades yesterday, compared to 8,000 on a normal day, with heavy selling in the morning succeeded by strong buying.

"We've had lots buying back into technology in the afternoon, led by buying of Baltimore, Sage and Kingston Communications," said a Schwab spokeswoman.

Small traders reported waits to contact internet-based stockbrokers stretching to as much as three hours.

Tension heightened when the biggest internet chat room, iii, failed to update early share prices and left some investors' portfolios reading zero. "I almost had a heart attack," said one.

In the initial shares markdown, small investors lashed out at market makers and the media for fomenting a crash. "Brokers make money, the media have something to report," said one investor on the MotleyFool bulletin board.

Some even blamed big institutions for offloading stock ahead of a crash predicted by a financial astrologer ahead of a six-planet line-up on May 4.

Despite the late upturn, many small investors have been left bruised. In the run-up to the end of the tax year, small investors piled hundreds of millions of pounds into technology-based unit trusts but are now sitting on losses of up to 30%.

Aberdeen Technology, the biggest UK hi-tech fund, with more than £1bn, is down 33% since its peak on March 10, while Jupiter Technology, which pulled in more than £250m in a few weeks after its launch in February, is already down by £50m.

Aberdeen fund manager Ben Rogoff said he was selling consumer internet stocks such as Freeserve and "internet enablers" but remained a believer in the internet as a business-to-business tool.

fields.headline: Alchemy plans new MG model
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Alchemy, the venture capital firm seeking to acquire Rover from BMW, said yesterday it had asked Lotus to develop a new MG sports car by 2002.
fields.body:
Alchemy, the venture capital firm seeking to acquire Rover from BMW, said yesterday it had asked Lotus to develop a new MG sports car by 2002.

Jon Moulton, Alchemy's managing partner, said that if his firm's bid for the bulk of Rover is successful he would relaunch the MG marque in the United States.

MG would also return to motor sports and aim to compete at Le Mans. The new models would use the latest aluminium and composite technology.

Mr Moulton was outlining the business plan for the MG Car Company, the vehicle for Alchemy's Rover bid.

Alchemy has agreed in principle to buy the Rover and MG marques from BMW and take over Rover's main Longbridge plant in Birmingham.

But a consortium headed by former Rover executive John Towers has made a counterbid which would result in fewer job losses.

Mr Moulton said his company had been advised by its lawyers not to give details of likely redundancies at Longbridge because this might pre-empt the consultation process with unions.

But he reiterated that all the contractual redundancy rights of Longbridge workers would be "fully honoured" and steps would be taken to protect pension rights.

The MG Car Company has already approached Lotus Engineering, part of Lotus Cars, to develop a new MG sports car.

New variants of the MGF, already in production at Longbridge, will also be introduced.

Mr Moulton said that as soon as the Rover acquisition was completed MG would rapidly re-enter the US market after an absence of 20 years.

The US market, where there was a big MG enthusiast base, offered "a significant volume opportunity".

The company was already in talks on carrying out contract production work at Longbridge to limit job losses.

He described current Rover car sales as very good and promised innovative sales arrangements. He also said Alchemy would cooperate fully with the government's task force on employment in the west Midlands once the deal with BMW was completed.

Alchemy withdrew its co-operation earlier this month following a row over potential conflicts of interest.

fields.headline: Kick your man out
fields.trailText: 18 April: My partner expects me to do his work - but he said I coudn't use him as reference and then wouldn't let me apply for the job I was doing.
fields.body:
The problem

Over the past year I have spent a lot of time helping my partner with work - report writing, proposals, etc. It has been excellent experience and taught me that I am very business focused and intelligent.

I am now looking for a new job but my partner says I can't call on him or any of his team members for a reference. The final straw came this weekend when I was asked to put together a job description for the type of work I have been doing (creating my perfect job) and was then told I could nor apply or be reccommended for it.

The solution

Hang on a minute - this is just not on. Maybe you can't put your partner down as a reference since this could look a bit dodgy if it was discovered that you and he were romantically involved (but would anyone ever know?). But, why on earth can't you put someone else in his team down as a referee? And why can't you apply for the job that you are already doing?

I think this is more about your relationship with your partner than anything else. He has made great use of your skills, but is not prepared at even the most basic level to help you get so much as a toe in the door. Why not? Is he threatened by you and the obvious success that you are going to be? Is he frightened of mixing business with pleasure? (bit late for that now). He certainly seems adamant that although you have helped him, you have to stand on your own two feet without him.

I suggest two things. Firstly, kick your man out and let him stand on his own two feet both professionally and personally. Secondly, approach one of his team yourself and ask if they will be your referee. If you don't get anywhere with his team-mates, you can still put this experience down on your CV, but will have to explain that the work was carried out for your (ex?) partner.

It might be harder for you to move up the career ladder without your partner's support, but you will do it - if only to show him that you can. Also, look within your current post and see if you can volunteer for more skilled tasks to further boost your CV.

Good luck - you show him!

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: T-Online lift off defies doubters
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's largest internet flotation got away to a comfortable premium yesterday despite the continuing market turmoil over hi-tech shares.
fields.body:
Europe's largest internet flotation got away to a comfortable premium yesterday despite the continuing market turmoil over hi-tech shares.

Shares in T-Online, the internet service provider owned by Deutsche Telekom, were offered in Frankfurt at €27 (£16.26), opened at €28.50 and closed at €37.50.

The company's ability to buck the market trend stemmed mainly from the very low price that Deutsche Telekom was asking for the shares.

The former German telecommunications monopoly originally hoped to be able to sell 10% of T-Online for €50. But institutional shareholders balked at the price.

The price range was then lowered to €26 to €32 a share. The collapse in the new-tech share bubble then forced the group to offer the shares at the lower end of the range, reducing its take from $3.1bn to $2.6bn.

The offer, which had attracted widespread public interest in Germany, was 20 times oversubscribed.

The gradual rise in the T-Online share price helped to steady the German stock exchange and restore a measure of public confidence in new technology stocks.

T-Online is the world's largest internet service provider after America Online. It has 5.3m customers, against AOL's 23m, and is some way ahead of Britain's Freeserve.

Ron Sommer, Deutsche Telekom's chief executive, called T-Online the "Daimler of the internet world".

He said investors who did not get shares in the ISP would receive preferential treatment in an upcoming sale of new Deutsche Telekom shares.

Yesterday Hans Eichel, the German finance minister, insisted that T-Online had a strong future.

"It has switched the track in the direction of expansion," he said. "The goal is to become strongly anchored in the international markets, especially in western Europe."

He said Germany was poised to continue strong growth next year and reclaim its role as Europe's economic powerhouse.

"Next year, Germany has the chance to become the growth motor in Europe and Europe overall could take over from the United States as a growth engine," he added.

Financial analysts were somewhat more cautious about T-Online's prospects, pointing out that ongoing deregulation of the German telecoms market would lead to new entrants eating into its market lead, while falling phone bills would further reduce its ability to generate profits.

However the sale of T-Online shares, dubbed "the people's stock", has generated an unprecedented interest in new technology stocks among ordinary Germans.

Surveys showed that about one in five Germans applied for T-Online shares.

But Reinhild Keitel, from the German Institute of Private Investors, played down the company's suitability for private investors, most of whom are used to making long term investments in the country's top 30 blue chip companies.

"Most people expect a steady dividend payment to replace the interest payments from the savings account," he said.

"With T-Online, there is no dividend in sight. T-Online will also be far too volatile to be a people's share."

The German share institute has estimated that more than 5m Germans actively trade in stocks.

Millions more have been buying into equity investment funds as their faith in the federal government's once rock-solid pension scheme has waned.

fields.headline: A relentless litany of self-abuse
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle visits three major exhibitions of British art - and wishes he hadn't
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle visits three major exhibitions of British art - and wishes he hadn't
fields.body:
The fifth British Art Show has just opened its year-long tour in Edinburgh, in venues across the city. The whole thing is exhausting and confusing, and its more than 50 artists do not present us with an overall picture of the state of British art, or a map of its preoccupations. Among it all, in a glass display cabinet in the Dean Gallery, is a simple ceramic pot by the artist Grayson Perry. It's the way that Perry - who doubles as a transvestite called Claire - decorates his pottery that counts. Perry's pots are usually alive with tawdry bacchanals, weird sex, visual puns, people, poo and guns. This particular pot, by contrast, is decorated with a simple glazed list. I paraphrase: "Video installation with home-made soundtrack... broken kinetic sculpture... everyday item transformed in witty way... seemingly casual photographs... found objects arranged in a pattern... vitrine with kitsch model... fibreglass figure... neon sign... elemental form...".

The pot is called Masturbate and Be Proud, a slightly bitchy satire on art manners of the moment. It is, necessarily, an empty vessel. Perry's work normally leaves me cold; this time he had me laughing sarcastically. It is just another art-about-art joke, of course.

I would have preferred a smaller, more singular and even partisan look at art in Britain. On the other hand, the British Art Show does serve to remind us that there is far more going on in the country than the YBA tribe. But do we really care about Britishness, or the next British big thing? The past two decades have made London and Glasgow (in particular) good places to make art. There's a healthy milieu, lots of opportunities to see and be seen.

Which brings us to the opening this week of White Cube 2, in London's Hoxton Square, and to the new exhibition at the Saatchi Gallery, Ant Noises, which opens to the public later this week. Already, these exhibitions have overshadowed the larger survey of British art in Edinburgh, because they focus on the collector, the dealer and their artists. It is a neat package. It lets everyone get a handle on the relationship between art and money, it is a tale with lots of gossip and nice images. Off we go.

White Cube 2, an extensively remodelled industrial building facing onto the square, is the latest, super-elegant venture of gallerist Jay Jopling. White Cube 2 is an impeccable, museum-quality space, filled with entirely artificial daylight, and a selection of work by the gallery's roster of artists. Commercial galleries are shops, and what we've got here is the full product range. An Antony Gormley Man, a deflated rubber body cast by Marc Quinn (a serendipitous, tragi-comic alignment), Gavin Turk's deathly, ultra-realistic corpse of Che Guevara, who lies in state, in his tattered army fatigues, on what looks like a Rachel Whiteread mortuary slab. It is Gavin-as-Che on a modern art bier. Nude men lounge about in Sam Taylor-Wood's montaged photo-work, which is dominated by a portrait of a blindfolded man. As if there weren't enough talk of death, decrepitude and the drama of the body's plight, there is also a very funny Damien Hirst, which includes a real skeleton. The skeleton floats above the floor on a crucifix of glass sheets. He has ping-pong ball eyes, which jiggle and roll about on air-jets inserted in the empty sockets in the skull. This is a Jim Carrey Christ, with a skeleton's grin.

Just because all this stuff intimates mortality doesn't necessarily make it rich as art. The Hirst is only a clever gag - and a reworking, at that, of things he was doing almost a decade ago. We want artists to get better at what they do. They don't always, and developing in public, as so many of Hirst's generation have had to do, doesn't always helped. The market, and the media, wants a constant stream of novelties (as both Harold Rosenberg and Walter Benjamin had already pointed out by the middle of the last century), rather than an increase in creative sophistication or thoughtfulness. More depth and more complexity aren't as sexy or attention-grabbing as ever-wackier objects, more extreme measures.

The best things here are Turk's Che and a perfectly executed model of a McDonald's drive-thru burger bar by Jake and Dinos Chapman. The brickwork is stained, the gravel on the flat roof sprouts weeds, the ivy climbing the walls is rank. The interior is deserted. The place is brooding and nasty, corporate, banal and vile. We already know this, of course, but the re-creation focuses the mind on precisely how grim it is.

Cerith Wyn Evans's quotation of Gertrude Stein's famous line, "Before the flowers of friendship faded, friendship faded", written in a trellis of fireworks high on the wall, seems to acknowledge that the bubble might burst, that fame is transient. Before the flowers of friendship fade, staleness sets in.

Jay Jay Jay, Saatchi Damien Tracey. Isn't the constant reiteration of the roll-call unutterably void, without meaning or consequence? Aren't the artists as sick of it as the rest of us? Nowadays, you have to collude with the media or be forgotten, so the story goes. Yet it is difficult not to be seen to collude in the personality game, even while trying to be critical and responsive to the art rather than the personalities, the lifestyles, the gossip and sensationalism.

The Saatchi Gallery's latest exhibition, Ant Noises (anag: Sensation), has already had a mountain of coverage, mostly due to Damien Hirst's megaton, half-flayed gigantic man, an anatomical toy blown up 20ft tall and cast in polychromed bronze, which Charles Saatchi has apparently bought for a cool million. Hymn - derived from a Humbrol toy - is a very 80s, post-Duchampian appropriation. It is unavoidably present - on account of its size - but, as one would expect from a scaled-up toy, it has no sense of scale at all, apart from bigness. It is an inert icon, already reproduced everywhere, because it is by Hirst, because it cost an iconic round sum, and because the huge bronze is a borrowed form, rather than one invented by the artist. It fits neatly into the rhetoric of modern art, and supercharges the mythology of artist and patron alike.

Icons aren't necessarily inherently interesting, and they aren't necessarily art either. As a thing in itself, Hymn is pretty dull, so much so that it makes you think of all its secondary readings first. Compared, too, with 18th-century wax anatomical models (lifelike men and women, whose guts spill out unnoticed), or the lifesize Transparent or Glass Man, a clear plastic-skinned man produced in the late 20s for a hygiene museum in Dresden, Hirst's man really palls. Hirst's is an economic, rather than plastic, manipulation of the model he took it from. If it were to be placed in a public place - on the vacant plinth in Trafalgar Square, say - it might then start to work rather differently, telling us something about our self-image as ultimately inscrutable biological beings. But here it is only big, a monument to folly.

Ant Noises is utterly incoherent. The catalogue (which promises us a part two to the show) has a drivelling essay, written in heady PR-speak by Gemma de Cruz, and the show is unaccountably sponsored by the Independent. Here, Saatchi seems to be saying, are some things I own. What do Rachel Whiteread's 1995 resin-cast spaces under 100 chairs, her homage to Bruce Nauman, have to do with anything else here? Saatchi's latest acquisition from Chris Ofili shows that the collector doesn't always get the good ones, even by good artists.

There aren't any good Jenny Savilles, because her paintings are all equally bad. Saville paints acres of female flesh, but hasn't a clue how to render it: her brush just paws about indeterminately, tonally approximating fullness and roundness without actually describing the form or substance of the female body. Her paint is dead, the drawing is lousy. It is all held together by little illustrational tricks, and enlivened by lumbering painterly tics, in an attempt to make the surfaces of her paintings, if not the figures she paints, more lively and believable. Saville's paintings would in every sense be flattened by Lucian Freud's paintings of the voluptuous Sue the Benefit Superviser.

But is she as bad as Ron Mueck? Mueck is sentimental and twee. His little disconsolate angel, his huge, glowering self-portrait head, his googling giant babies, are incredibly unsophisticated, in terms of how they manage extreme jumps in scale. Given their ultra-realism, you expect his works to command and occupy the space around them, but his sculptures have no personal space. You just get up close and say ooh-er, and move on. Nor do his figures seem to have much dialogue or drama between one another. His is a purely technical, mawkish realism. So much skill, so little talent for art. This is art as baby food and bedtime stories.

It doesn't help the artists to be seen, again and again, in this context; nor does it help viewers engage with current art in any interesting way. Constantly banging on about the Britishness of it all, the home-grown, media-friendly excitement of it all, the gossip and high-life and grooviness of it all, helps no one. Put Mueck next to Charles Ray or Robert Gober (both of whom have used the ultra-realist mode) and his work would die. Put Hirst's Hymn next to Wilder Graves Penfield's 1952 Human Sensory Humunculus and it would fade away, however much it cost, however big it is, whoever bought it.

The work with the most presence is the simplest and cheekiest. It is a cast of a woman's lower half, perched on a table, by Sarah Lucas. The vaginal lips have been teased apart and slightly extruded, and a cigarette lodged between them. It is horrible and crude and utterly melancholic. You Know What, from 1998, hit me in the gut. It is crashingly obvious and extremely subtle, abject and throwaway, poetically and metaphorically rich and allusive.

It is all a matter of presence, and the possibility of generating meaning. It is all about a certain kind of artistic generosity, which includes dealing with doubt. There's so little doubt here, only products to be consumed, pages to be filled. We need another way of looking at this art, other contexts, by which it will stand or fall. Let's not forget, too, that there are artists who don't depend on Saatchi's patronage, and artists who actively refuse to allow their works to enter his collection, both here and abroad. You have to see through the hype and the art gossip and look at the things people make. All this is a very British affair.

 The British Art Show is at venues across Edinburgh till June 4, then tours. Details: 0131-529 3795. Out There is at White Cube 2 , London N1 (020-7930 5373), till July 1. Ant Noises is at the Saatchi Gallery, London NW8 (020-7624 8299), from Thursday.

I paraphrase: "Video installation with home-made soundtrack... broken kinetic sculpture... everyday item transformed in witty way... seemingly casual photographs... found objects arranged in a pattern... vitrine with kitsch model... fibreglass figure... neon sign... elemental form...". The pot is called Masturbate and Be Proud, a slightly bitchy satire on art manners of the moment. It is, necessarily, an empty vessel. Perry's work normally leaves me cold; this time he had me laughing sarcastically. It is just another art-about-art joke, of course. I would have preferred a smaller, more singular and even partisan look at art in Britain. On the other hand, the British Art Show does serve to remind us that there is far more going on in the country than the YBA tribe. But do we really care about Britishness, or the next British big thing? The past two decades have made London and Glasgow (in particular) good places to make art. There's a healthy milieu, lots of opportunities to see and be seen. Which brings us to the opening this week of White Cube 2, in London's Hoxton Square, and to the new exhibition at the Saatchi Gallery, Ant Noises, which opens to the public later this week. Already, these exhibitions have overshadowed the larger survey of British art in Edinburgh, because they focus on the collector, the dealer and their artists. It is a neat package. It lets everyone get a handle on the relationship between art and money, it is a tale with lots of gossip and nice images. Off we go. White Cube 2, an extensively remodelled industrial building facing onto the square, is the latest, super-elegant venture of gallerist Jay Jopling. White Cube 2 is an impeccable, museum-quality space, filled with entirely artificial daylight, and a selection of work by the gallery's roster of artists. Commercial galleries are shops, and what we've got here is the full product range. An Antony Gormley Man, a deflated rubber body cast by Marc Quinn (a serendipitous, tragi-comic alignment), Gavin Turk's deathly, ultra-realistic corpse of Che Guevara, who lies in state, in his tattered army fatigues, on what looks like a Rachel Whiteread mortuary slab. It is Gavin-as-Che on a modern art bier. Nude men lounge about in Sam Taylor-Wood's montaged photo-work, which is dominated by a portrait of a blindfolded man. As if there weren't enough talk of death, decrepitude and the drama of the body's plight, there is also a very funny Damien Hirst, which includes a real skeleton. The skeleton floats above the floor on a crucifix of glass sheets. He has ping-pong ball eyes, which jiggle and roll about on air-jets inserted in the empty sockets in the skull. This is a Jim Carrey Christ, with a skeleton's grin. Just because all this stuff intimates mortality doesn't necessarily make it rich as art. The Hirst is only a clever gag - and a reworking, at that, of things he was doing almost a decade ago. We want artists to get better at what they do. They don't always, and developing in public, as so many of Hirst's generation have had to do, doesn't always helped. The market, and the media, wants a constant stream of novelties (as both Harold Rosenberg and Walter Benjamin had already pointed out by the middle of the last century), rather than an increase in creative sophistication or thoughtfulness. More depth and more complexity aren't as sexy or attention-grabbing as ever-wackier objects, more extreme measures. The best things here are Turk's Che and a perfectly executed model of a McDonald's drive-thru burger bar by Jake and Dinos Chapman. The brickwork is stained, the gravel on the flat roof sprouts weeds, the ivy climbing the walls is rank. The interior is deserted. The place is brooding and nasty, corporate, banal and vile. We already know this, of course, but the re-creation focuses the mind on precisely how grim it is. Cerith Wyn Evans's quotation of Gertrude Stein's famous line, "Before the flowers of friendship faded, friendship faded", written in a trellis of fireworks high on the wall, seems to acknowledge that the bubble might burst, that fame is transient. Before the flowers of friendship fade, staleness sets in. Jay Jay Jay, Saatchi Damien Tracey. Isn't the constant reiteration of the roll-call unutterably void, without meaning or consequence? Aren't the artists as sick of it as the rest of us? Nowadays, you have to collude with the media or be forgotten, so the story goes. Yet it is difficult not to be seen to collude in the personality game, even while trying to be critical and responsive to the art rather than the personalities, the lifestyles, the gossip and sensationalism. The Saatchi Gallery's latest exhibition, Ant Noises (anag: Sensation), has already had a mountain of coverage, mostly due to Damien Hirst's megaton, half-flayed gigantic man, an anatomical toy blown up 20ft tall and cast in polychromed bronze, which Charles Saatchi has apparently bought for a cool million. Hymn - derived from a Humbrol toy - is a very 80s, post-Duchampian appropriation. It is unavoidably present - on account of its size - but, as one would expect from a scaled-up toy, it has no sense of scale at all, apart from bigness. It is an inert icon, already reproduced everywhere, because it is by Hirst, because it cost an iconic round sum, and because the huge bronze is a borrowed form, rather than one invented by the artist. It fits neatly into the rhetoric of modern art, and supercharges the mythology of artist and patron alike. Icons aren't necessarily inherently interesting, and they aren't necessarily art either. As a thing in itself, Hymn is pretty dull, so much so that it makes you think of all its secondary readings first. Compared, too, with 18th-century wax anatomical models (lifelike men and women, whose guts spill out unnoticed), or the lifesize Transparent or Glass Man, a clear plastic-skinned man produced in the late 20s for a hygiene museum in Dresden, Hirst's man really palls. Hirst's is an economic, rather than plastic, manipulation of the model he took it from. If it were to be placed in a public place - on the vacant plinth in Trafalgar Square, say - it might then start to work rather differently, telling us something about our self-image as ultimately inscrutable biological beings. But here it is only big, a monument to folly. Ant Noises is utterly incoherent. The catalogue (which promises us a part two to the show) has a drivelling essay, written in heady PR-speak by Gemma de Cruz, and the show is unaccountably sponsored by the Independent. Here, Saatchi seems to be saying, are some things I own. What do Rachel Whiteread's 1995 resin-cast spaces under 100 chairs, her homage to Bruce Nauman, have to do with anything else here? Saatchi's latest acquisition from Chris Ofili shows that the collector doesn't always get the good ones, even by good artists. There aren't any good Jenny Savilles, because her paintings are all equally bad. Saville paints acres of female flesh, but hasn't a clue how to render it: her brush just paws about indeterminately, tonally approximating fullness and roundness without actually describing the form or substance of the female body. Her paint is dead, the drawing is lousy. It is all held together by little illustrational tricks, and enlivened by lumbering painterly tics, in an attempt to make the surfaces of her paintings, if not the figures she paints, more lively and believable. Saville's paintings would in every sense be flattened by Lucian Freud's paintings of the voluptuous Sue the Benefit Superviser. But is she as bad as Ron Mueck? Mueck is sentimental and twee. His little disconsolate angel, his huge, glowering self-portrait head, his googling giant babies, are incredibly unsophisticated, in terms of how they manage extreme jumps in scale. Given their ultra-realism, you expect his works to command and occupy the space around them, but his sculptures have no personal space. You just get up close and say ooh-er, and move on. Nor do his figures seem to have much dialogue or drama between one another. His is a purely technical, mawkish realism. So much skill, so little talent for art. This is art as baby food and bedtime stories. It doesn't help the artists to be seen, again and again, in this context; nor does it help viewers engage with current art in any interesting way. Constantly banging on about the Britishness of it all, the home-grown, media-friendly excitement of it all, the gossip and high-life and grooviness of it all, helps no one. Put Mueck next to Charles Ray or Robert Gober (both of whom have used the ultra-realist mode) and his work would die. Put Hirst's Hymn next to Wilder Graves Penfield's 1952 Human Sensory Humunculus and it would fade away, however much it cost, however big it is, whoever bought it. The work with the most presence is the simplest and cheekiest. It is a cast of a woman's lower half, perched on a table, by Sarah Lucas. The vaginal lips have been teased apart and slightly extruded, and a cigarette lodged between them. It is horrible and crude and utterly melancholic. You Know What, from 1998, hit me in the gut. It is crashingly obvious and extremely subtle, abject and throwaway, poetically and metaphorically rich and allusive. It is all a matter of presence, and the possibility of generating meaning. It is all about a certain kind of artistic generosity, which includes dealing with doubt. There's so little doubt here, only products to be consumed, pages to be filled. We need another way of looking at this art, other contexts, by which it will stand or fall. Let's not forget, too, that there are artists who don't depend on Saatchi's patronage, and artists who actively refuse to allow their works to enter his collection, both here and abroad. You have to see through the hype and the art gossip and look at the things people make. All this is a very British affair.  The British Art Show is at venues across Edinburgh till June 4, then tours. Details: 0131-529 3795. Out There is at White Cube 2 , London N1 (020-7930 5373), till July 1. Ant Noises is at the Saatchi Gallery, London NW8 (020-7624 8299), from Thursday.

fields.headline: A driving urgency
fields.standfirst:
David Liebman
Pizza Express, Dean Street, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
David Liebman
Pizza Express, Dean Street, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.body:
Those fortunate enough to have witnessed more than one of the American saxophonist David Liebman's recent UK performances reported that his shows were remarkably different from night to night. Liebman, whose reputation rose in the 70s when he was hired by Miles Davis for the trumpeter's early crossover adventures, has been developing in the 90s as an immensely sophisticated performer of a Coltranesque persuasion. Yet his public profile (despite Downbeat heralding him as "one of the most important saxophonists in contemporary music") remains modest compared to Michael Brecker's or Joshua Redman's. Maybe that's due to change.

Liebman's current quartet has stayed together for much of the past decade and in its alertness and ensemble cohesiveness it sounds like it. A fine guitarist, Vic Juris proved himself to be just as adventurous as his boss, and just as adept at occupying idiosyncratic spaces somewhere between loose improvisation and familiar idioms. When Liebman called for an Elvis tribute, hurling himself into a ferocious free-tenor barrage over drummer Jamey Hadad's headlong rock'n'roll beat, Juris played a string of riffs the 50s Nashville session guitarists would have been proud of. His own solo, echoing John Scofield in its muscular chording, was full of left-field phrasing and unexpected turns. Then he became reflective on Wayne Shorter's Fall, a smoky ballad that Liebman gracefully embellished with softly elided sounds and meticulous control of tone.

The band took on Miles Davis's classic All Blues at a fast, funky clip, with Liebman initially stretching its minimalism on soprano saxophone, and Hadad's drumming intensifying to a storm of polyrhythms that were forceful and springy at once. The leader took a second and more abrasive solo on tenor, and when he returned to the familiar theme it was to pack its phrasing with laconic mutterings and glittery trills. Hadad then abandoned the regular kit for a spectacular Airto Moreira-like percussion display on Coltrane's The Drum Thing, and Liebman continued the tribute to his biggest influence with My Favourite Things, which drew a solo of harmonic adventurousness coupled with a driving, metallic urgency. A lot of the material may be familiar, but this is a band that gives the notion "cutting-edge" some resonance. Fortunately, Liebman seemed to enjoy working here enough to want an immediate invitation back.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Avoid the pick'n'mix
fields.standfirst:
State of the Nation
South Bank Centre, London
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText:
State of the Nation
South Bank Centre, London
Rating: * * *
fields.body:
Each year the South Bank's showcase of young composers seems to grow in scope and ambition. What began as an initiative by the London Sinfonietta is now a joint venture between eight organisations, and stretches to include sound installations, improvisation sessions, even a film of music for the catwalk. Boundaries are deliberately blurred, recognising the fact that for the generation born in the 70s new music draws upon a wider frame of reference than it has ever done before, and that the London Sinfonietta itself is an ensemble born out of a much narrower concept of radicalism.

Whether by being opened out like this State of the Nation manages to be more inclusive, or whether it is just paying lip service to fledgling traditions at the expense of the tradition that is its natural constituency, is another question. More crucially, one wonders if the new music audience is as catholic in its tastes as this year's programme would have us believe, or whether those who turned up for the late-night electro-mix preview of the Hayward Gallery's Sonic Boom exhibition were the same faithful who had attended the more conventional concerts earlier in the day. If not, then maybe boundaries are less transparent than some would like to believe. Perhaps it's not a coincidence that among the pieces I heard over the weekend, the least convincing and most pretentious were those that tried to cross those boundaries, combining live music with film and electronics, for instance, to the disadvantage of all three mediums.

It's in the nature of events like this that the indifferent music is likely to outweigh the genuinely worthwhile, though all of the composers will have benefited enormously from hearing their work performed by the expert Sinfonietta players under Pierre-André Valade. There were some striking exceptions. Alberti Addict, by the 28-year-old Joe Duddell, was confidently shaped, even if its language was an unlikely amalgam - a mixture of Glass, Andriessen and Copland. Ouroboros by Jonathan Cole (born 1970) may have been slightly too long, but was remarkably well imagined.

Among the shorter works, Dai Fujikura's Frozen Heat was a propulsive brass study in jagged accents, and Mary Bellamy's Stellar a disciplined exploration of a single thematic process. Tom Ingoldsby's Fanfare "from the back of beyond" was a bubbling array of rhythmic figures that got form and content just about in balance. Too many of the pieces in the programmes really didn't manage that at all.

 Hear and Now on Radio 3 will broadcast highlights from the weekend on Friday evening.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
