webTitle: Tax man suffers as firms take out inquiry insurance

fields.headline: Tax man suffers as firms take out inquiry insurance
fields.trailText: A £220m hole could be blown in the Treasury's annual yield from tax investigations as more small businesses insure themselves against the expense of an inquiry, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
A £220m hole could be blown in the Treasury's annual yield from tax investigations as more small businesses insure themselves against the expense of an inquiry, it was claimed yesterday.

Such insurance covers the cost of hiring accountants and lawyers to mount a defence against the Inland Revenue.

Boosting the exchequer by cracking down on tax dodging of all kinds is a key policy of chancellor Gordon Brown.

But one insurer said yesterday that the hoped-for harvest of £444m this year from inquiries into smaller businesses and the self-employed could prove illusory, with insured businesses preferring to fight rather than settle.

Ultimately, said Abbey Tax Protection, supplier of professional fees insurance (PFI), yields from such inquiries could drop from the present level by £220m, to just £75m. .

"With the average cost of fighting the taxman estimated at £2,000, many businesses previously made a commercial decision to pay up when asked for a similar amount from the revenue," said Abbey, adding the insurance allowed them to defend themselves.

A rolling 18-month survey of its own clients found just 50% of insured businesses that had been investigated had to pay any additional tax, against a more usual figure of 90%.

And only 16% of clients were charged interest and penalties, against an Inland Revenue average of 50%.

The Inland Revenue said it did not recognise the figures, adding that whether to employ a professional adviser during a tax inquiry was entirely up to the company.

Insurance of this type, unheard of 20 years ago, still covers less than 20% of the self-employed and small businesses, but the total is rising.

Abbey managing director Colin Davison denied the company was simply banging the drum for its own product pointing out its figures had left out Corporation Tax, which is not paid by the majority of small-scale enterprises, despite the fact that Abbey offers insurance against Corporation Tax investigations.

The Abbey figures include additional income tax from full company inquiries last year (£60.9m), full inquiries into business self-assessment (£24.6m), inquiries into self-assessment by high net worth individuals (£81m) and full reviews of employers in terms of paying tax and national insurance and reporting perks and benefits (£127.7m).

fields.headline: Beneath the surface
fields.standfirst:
The House
Abbey Theatre, Dublin
Rating: * * * * *
fields.trailText:
The House
Abbey Theatre, Dublin
Rating: * * * * *
fields.body:
Irish playwright Tom Murphy has long been a dark, lyrical presence on the Abbey main stage. He writes literature from a fragmented vernacular rubble of Hiberno-English, making vast dramatic canvases of small town folk who navigate their fate alone.

Like its loose companion piece The Wake, The House mixes familial alienation with tragic small-town property deals. It's set in the 50s and witnesses the annual holiday of the town's tough navvies and fearsome Irish wide-boys, briefly returned from the building sites and criminal underworlds of England and the US.

Some of the boys are determined to crow it over the small-minded, Church-and-law-ridden place that spat them out - but which, somehow, they can't let go. One, Christy Cavanagh, is a moody, sensitive young sociopath who left his heart in the Big House wonderland of the old Anglo-Norman family of Mrs de Burca and her three daughters. The de Burcas are selling the house and, dubiously wealthy, Christy resolves to buy the place. But talking to the convalescent Mrs de Burca, the class difference between them resurfaces, and Christy must try other devious means. Already complicated by a former dalliance with the youngest, married daughter, he goes down another dark, destructive road, not entirely of his choosing.

Although the key violence happens offstage, this is actually a more disturbing play, if that is possible, than The Wake, what with the simmering bloodlust of its male characters. As usual, there are no straight lines, morally, logically or plot-wise.

Conall Morrison's direction is keen and forceful. If incoherent at first, the situation builds into furious focus: the violent contrasts between the delicately traumatised de Burca dinner table and the raucous codes of the pub. There are many deeply affecting performances: Jane Brennan's pained, "sensible" de Burca sister; Andrew Bennett's gormlessly philosophical labouring man; and as Christy, the monstrous, troubled anti-hero, Patrick O'Kane.

It's a huge piece. Murphy is probing into an understratum of Irish society, with all its personal dereliction, atavistic male aggression, and into what some people endure at the hands of others.

 Until May 20. Box office: 00 353 1 873 7222

webTitle: Watford left to plead for mercy

fields.headline: Watford left to plead for mercy
fields.trailText: Southampton 2 - 0 Watford
fields.body:
In a merciful world, Watford's season would end now so as to terminate the slow water torture of their descent. It would spare Graham Taylor conducting yet another lengthy post-match inquest.

Taylor admits it. "Some players looked shattered and after these away defeats the journey home seems to get longer and longer," he said.

Watford looked again what they imminently will be, a First Division team, in a poor, error-strewn game in which Southampton, all but confirming their Premiership status, appeared little better.

There was little to arouse the Dell until Marians Pahars emerged from the bench again and scored late on. It was a doubly nasty twist for Watford, the club rejected by the Latvian striker in favour of the Saints last season.

Southampton's leading scorer had suffered from flu for three days, Glenn Hoddle explained. Matthew le Tissier, meanwhile, lasted a rare 90 minutes despite a throat infection in addition to his need of a hernia operation. Not surprisingly his presence was of little more than psychological benefit to Saints.

As a club, Southampton are enjoying a healthy, tension-free spring. Hoddle believes the longer-term picture can be even rosier. "I never had my mind on relegation; I pitched it higher. And now expectations can be a lot higher as well. There's no reason why we can't do a Leicester City."

Mid-Premiership Leicester seem a long way away for Taylor, who is already planning for journeys to the likes of Grimsby and Stockport. He hopes his players will be stronger for this season's traumas but knows that some will not fancy the First. "One or two will think they're better than they are," he said.

Hoddle and Taylor, England managers in former lives, will soon be operating in different divisions. Taylor can take the fall. "I wouldn't have changed the last three years for anything," he insisted, soon amusingly contradicting himself. In 1997, he said, "we had a three-year plan to reach the Premiership. Then the players go and spoil it."

Watford reached the prom- ised land a season too soon and, Taylor warned, can expect further rapid swings in status. "We're developing into a top-30 club. If you look at Watford's stature and history, for it to be a yo-yo club would be a great achievement."

On Saturday his team's fortunes swung abruptly in the first four minutes, a passage which "summed up our whole season", according to Taylor. Micah Hyde made a "pig's ear of a wonderful chance and then we conceded after a misunderstanding". Kevin Davies was the beneficiary, calmly angling his low shot past Alec Chamberlain, who then remained unbeaten until an unchallenged Pahars headed in a soft second goal 15 minutes from time.

Remaining games: Southampton: Apr 22 Man Utd (h); Apr 24 Derby (a); Apr 29 Leicester (h); May 6 Liverpool (a); May 14 Wimbledon (h). Watford: Apr 24 Leeds (a); Apr 29 Man Utd (h); May 6 Middlesbrough (a); May 14 Coventry (h).

Watford looked again what they imminently will be, a First Division team, in a poor, error-strewn game in which Southampton, all but confirming their Premiership status, appeared little better. There was little to arouse the Dell until Marians Pahars emerged from the bench again and scored late on. It was a doubly nasty twist for Watford, the club rejected by the Latvian striker in favour of the Saints last season. Southampton's leading scorer had suffered from flu for three days, Glenn Hoddle explained. Matthew le Tissier, meanwhile, lasted a rare 90 minutes despite a throat infection in addition to his need of a hernia operation. Not surprisingly his presence was of little more than psychological benefit to Saints. As a club, Southampton are enjoying a healthy, tension-free spring. Hoddle believes the longer-term picture can be even rosier. "I never had my mind on relegation; I pitched it higher. And now expectations can be a lot higher as well. There's no reason why we can't do a Leicester City." Mid-Premiership Leicester seem a long way away for Taylor, who is already planning for journeys to the likes of Grimsby and Stockport. He hopes his players will be stronger for this season's traumas but knows that some will not fancy the First. "One or two will think they're better than they are," he said. Hoddle and Taylor, England managers in former lives, will soon be operating in different divisions. Taylor can take the fall. "I wouldn't have changed the last three years for anything," he insisted, soon amusingly contradicting himself. In 1997, he said, "we had a three-year plan to reach the Premiership. Then the players go and spoil it." Watford reached the prom- ised land a season too soon and, Taylor warned, can expect further rapid swings in status. "We're developing into a top-30 club. If you look at Watford's stature and history, for it to be a yo-yo club would be a great achievement." On Saturday his team's fortunes swung abruptly in the first four minutes, a passage which "summed up our whole season", according to Taylor. Micah Hyde made a "pig's ear of a wonderful chance and then we conceded after a misunderstanding". Kevin Davies was the beneficiary, calmly angling his low shot past Alec Chamberlain, who then remained unbeaten until an unchallenged Pahars headed in a soft second goal 15 minutes from time. webTitle: Wanchope stays cool amid the flak

fields.headline: Wanchope stays cool amid the flak
fields.trailText: Derby 1 - 2 West Ham
fields.body:
There were many intriguing elements in this fixture, only one of which involved Paulo Wanchope, whose goals made him a target of abuse from the home supporters to go with that from the visiting fans.

Take, as one example, the West Ham bench, who looked as if they were involved in a private contest for Mr Angriest of Upton Park. In turn they rose to stride to the touchline and remonstrate - with their own team.

They were clearly unhappy with its shape, yet West Ham were already a goal to the good, were about to make it two and were facing a Derby side who enjoy the adrenalin charge of flirting with their Premiership status so much that they are reluctant to stray far from the exit.

Then there was the sight of Paolo Di Canio arguing vociferously with his team-mate Javier Margas as they left the field at half-time. Trevor Sinclair had to shepherd the Italian away. Even the fight for Intertoto Cup places tends to shorten fuses these days.

Fortunately tempers cooled in the dressing room. "You know what Paolo's like," said Harry Rednapp. "He shouts and carries on but we ignore him and he eventually shuts up. The man's a winner, he's no different in five-a-sides."

The manager had given him the captaincy and Di Canio responded with some delightful cameos. He could not quite get on the scoresheet but Wanchope had already done the damage. A near-post header and a firm drive struck from amid generous penalty-area space added to his two in midweek against Newcastle.

Rednapp wants to keep Frédéric Kanouté is plotting to sign Davor Suker but insists that neither will compromise his regard for Wanchope. "He is so laid-back that people get on his case," he said of the criticism this most unorthodox striker has attracted from the club's own fans. "He's got size and strength and he's difficult to play against."

Derby, robbed by injury of Georgi Kinkladze's inventiveness and the steadying influence of Horacio Carbonari, could hardly get in a blow before half-time but remembered the seriousness of their position in the second half.

With six minutes remaining, Dean Sturridge made up for the disappointment of seeing an earlier effort ruled offside by sweeping home a corner. But unlike Wanchope they failed to find another goal and so Sheffield Wednesday moved to within five points of them.

webTitle: Tottenham tormented by lack of class

fields.headline: Tottenham tormented by lack of class
fields.trailText: Tottenham 2 - 4 Aston Villa
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
The 150 or so fans demonstrating outside the main gate said it all. Not with their chants of "Sugar out" but by their numbers. One hundred and fifty from an attendance of 35,000; the Spurs chairman is not alone in finding it hard to stir things at Tottenham.

Hotspur means a rash person, but it is Alan Sugar's prudence which heads the supporters' list of criticisms. George Graham has been given money to bring in four "high class" players this summer, but the fans are sceptical.

Perhaps the newcomers can strengthen the brittle team spirit which contributed to the spectacular loss of a 2-0 lead after a dodgy penalty decision on Saturday.

But that depends on how high is high class. If the new arrivals are just another job lot from the Norwegian branch of Asda one can foresee disillusionment from those with loftier ambitions such as Sol Campbell, not to mention the supporters.

However Graham, due out of hospital this week after suffering arthritis problems, knows the problems of attracting the best, never mind affording them. He would like to sign Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, the striker he brought to Leeds. The Dutchman is undoubtedly top class, scoring goals aplenty for Atletico Madrid, who are willing to sell. But why should Hasselbaink choose a club not even in Europe next season?

According to reports, Spurs have made a £2.5m bid for the Nigerian striker Julius Aghahowa, currently playing for the Tunisian club Esperance. In other words, the African branch of Asda.

In Graham's absence it was the No2 Stewart Houston who witnessed a 2-0 lead disappear into the leaden skies. Steffen Iversen's header and a second from Chris Armstrong seemed to have guaranteed Spurs a third win in 13 games. But on 62 minutes the game turned on its head. The linesman spotted that Dion Dublin's goal-bound shot had been handled on the line, though could not identify the culprit. A video replay proved it was Iversen, but also showed the player raising his arms more in self-protection than intent.

Even so the penalty was given and Dublin converted it. Spurs never recovered. Dublin scored with an overhead kick and a minute later Benito Carbone guided a 20-yard half-volley into the top corner. Soon afterwards Alan Wright's 25-yarder brought the FA Cup finalists' fourth goal in 12 minutes, his first in three years.

Tottenham were stunned; John Gregory praised his side's resilience and then left to show his own in the London marathon.

fields.headline: Spanish eyes see warning lights
fields.trailText: Man Utd 4 - 0 Sunderland
fields.body:
The two seats occupied by Real Madrid infiltrators were vacated shortly after Sunderland's goal had been breached for a fourth time. Spanish eyes had seen enough.

Not only were the champions-elect in a class of their own in demolishing Peter Reid's bewildered team but it would not have gone unnoticed by Vicente del Bosque's informants that the rout was accomplished with the sort of team Sir Alex Ferguson usually sends out in the Worthington Cup.

There was no mistaking his priorities, standing down six players before Wednesday's Champions League quarter-final. That their second string orchestrated this destruction with such contemptuous ease warrants a shudder among the lesser lights in England's top tier.

In truth, with none of United's rivals capable of sustaining anything more than a lukewarm challenge the bunting was ordered several weeks ago. If results go their way, preparations for the open-top bus parade can begin in earnest next weekend.

Until spring United were spluttering. Now, with impeccable timing, the mechanism has been fine-tuned and their sixth title in eight years has become an awesome procession.

Here their movement, fluidity and undiluted class were too much for Sunderland to comprehend, let alone counter, and there could have been many more than the two goals from the talismanic Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and those from Nicky Butt and Henning Berg.

"It was a slow killing," rued the Sunderland striker Niall Quinn. "They must have 16 world-class players while Chelsea and the rest have six to eight; that's the difference."

United have now broken the Premiership record of 82 goals in a season, established by Kevin Keegan's Newcastle six years ago. Another 16 goals from their last five games would make them the first side since Tottenham in 1961 to amass 100 in the top echelon.

That may seem improbable but remember whom we are talking about: United have five players in double figures and 12 who have scored more than once. They have hit West Ham for seven, put five past Newcastle and Everton, and this was the seventh time they have rattled in four. Twenty-one goals have come in the past five league games and they have not failed to score in their last 30 matches at Old Trafford.

"We can play a lot better," insisted Ferguson. "That's not my team for Wednesday and you will see us play better then, be sure of that." When the report lands on Del Bosque's desk he should be worried, very worried.

webTitle: Savage completes Robson's bad week at the office

fields.headline: Savage completes Robson's bad week at the office
fields.trailText: Newcastle 0 - 2 Leicester
fields.byline: Martin Kelner at St James' Park
fields.body:
It is not often you find Bobby Robson looking as weary and crumpled as he did at five o'clock on Saturday. You could almost have mistaken him for a man of 67. His team, he insisted, did not deserve the dreadful week they had just endured, the worst since he took over at Newcastle.

If he was blaming the gods, the good news is that should St James' Park continue to expand skywards he will be able to take it up with them personally. After undeserved morale-sapping defeats against Chelsea in the FA Cup and West Ham in a midweek league match the last thing Robson needed was an encounter with Leicester, among the Premiership's most awkward customers.

This time, though, Newcastle were the authors of their own downfall. As Robson conceded, if you allow a team such as Leicester to take an early lead you are assured a testing afternoon, which United certainly had after some supine defending had given Tony Cottee a free shot at goal from Andy Impey's teasing cross after only seven minutes.

If it was a game for journeyman players with big hearts, no one was better equipped than Robbie Savage, whose tireless midfield performance was topped by the clinching second goal early in the second half. "Savage kept us going," said his manager Martin O'Neill. "I sometimes say to him that the only thing he lacks is ability."

Which seemed a little unfair on a player who had won him the match. But unlike Robson, O'Neill was in skittish mood.

fields.headline: McAllister rues away-day blues
fields.trailText: Coventry 2 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Safe by the spring, an exceptional home record and a youth side in their cup final: Coventry's season appears to have been a resounding success. Yet Gordon Strachan remains flummoxed by two seemingly deep-rooted problems. First and foremost Coventry's manager needs to find the answer to an appalling away record; second, and more long-term, he must ensure that his current crop of youngsters continues to flourish.

This was Coventry's 11th home win, matching Liverpool, yet they are the only team in the top four English divisions without a win on their travels. Three chances remain to put that right and a trip to Watford on the last day of the season may have more riding on it than expected.

"It's hard to put a finger on what's gone wrong," the captain Gary McAllister said. "Whether it's the formation or the way we approach the games or whatever, it needs to be sorted.

"The manager's tried everything, leaving on the day of the match, staying in different hotels, but we just don't seem to be getting the results. Even if we'd had two or three results away from home we might have been looking at the top six or top eight."

Their cause has not been helped by Robbie Keane's absence through injury, although the young Irishman's winner on Saturday suggests the spark is returning. Strachan hopes his swift acclimatisation to the Premiership since his move from Wolves can be an inspiration to the club's FA Youth Cup finalists, although the portents are not good.

Only Marcus Hall has risen successfully through the ranks in the past decade, although John Eustace showed encouraging signs on Saturday that he may make the grade.

It was his mistake, however, which sparked Middlesbrough and the game to life. He bundled over Andy Campbell and Christian Ziege scored the penalty, three minutes after Keane had coolly given Coventry a two-goal cushion.

Paul Ince, who inadvertently gave Coventry the lead with a first-half own-goal, was left seething by Boro's inadequate performance. "The whole event was a shambles. They were a shambles, we were a shambles and the officials were a shambles. It was like a pre-season game with two teams who had nothing to lose, can't go down and can't get into Europe. It's an attitude problem, really: all a bit half-hearted and after-you-Claude kind of stuff. I just apologise to the fans."

fields.headline: Heskey fuels Red uprising
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 1 - 2 Liverpool
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier's broad smile and clenched fists were understandable, and not just because his new £1m-a-year contract ought to keep him off the streets. Victory yesterday edged Liverpool closer to the Champions League and featured two more goals from Emile Heskey. Not bad from a striker who allegedly does not score enough.

True, the 22-year-old should have had a hat-trick. But a brace was enough to see off Wimbledon, who produced a welter of pressure after the substitute Martin Andresen had pulled a goal back, yet rarely came close to an equaliser. Liverpool - brilliant at times, resilient at others - deserved their fifth straight win.

Chants of "Gérard Houllier" filled the air, which was fitting. Liverpool's outstanding contributors were his buys. At the back Stéphane Henchoz and Sami Hyypia stood firm as the high balls rained down. Up front Heskey more than earned his corn before departing with a back injury.

Houllier paid Leicester £11m for Heskey last month rather than wait for a cheaper deal in the summer, because he believed "Bruno" would add punch to his team's Champions League ambitions. How right he was. Heskey's partnership with Michael Owen showed more flashes of promise, including a neat link for the opening goal.

"There was a lot of scepticism when Emile was bought," Houllier said. "But we knew what he would bring to us. He's not only a good striker but a good team player. He could believe in himself more, but his contribution today was fantastic."

Heskey's heading and finishing have improved since his arrival, and his pace offers a useful outlet down the channels. In the first half, when Liverpool knocked the ball around smoothly and quickly, Wimbledon could barely touch them. Didi Hamman was excellent. Only Neil Sullivan kept the score down.

The Wimbledon manager Egil Olsen said that, for 45 minutes, Liverpool looked "the best team we have met this season". He could be proud of the spirit his players showed in a rousing second half as Liverpool lost their fluency. But it needed more than they offered to deny the visitors.

Houllier's work has given Liverpool the Premiership's best defensive record away from home (14 goals conceded in 16 matches), and their form since October suggests second spot should be theirs. In the past 24 matches they have taken 54 points to Manchester United's 55. "I said before the game: 'We have got 540 minutes to play and we must have 540 minutes of Champions League football', Houllier said. "We have to be prepared to die on the pitch."

The choice of phrase was unfortunate the day after the anniversary of the Hillsborough disaster. But Liverpool have the fight the manager needs.

His players certainly looked fresh to begin with. Heskey hit Sullivan's legs from a one-on-one created by Hamman, but made no mistake with his second opportunity in the 34th minute. Accelerating on to a pass by Owen, he finished emphatically.

Hamman and Owen went close before Heskey headed in a Patrik Berger corner at the near post just past the hour. By then, though, Wimbledon had rediscovered their passion. Sander Westerveld saved well from Hermann Hreidarsson before Andresen headed in a Trond Andersen cross to reduce the arrears. And although Westerveld made a low stop from Michael Hughes, Liverpool withstood the pressure to secure their first league win at Wimbledon since 1990.

Liverpool's outstanding contributors were his buys. At the back Stéphane Henchoz and Sami Hyypia stood firm as the high balls rained down. Up front Heskey more than earned his corn before departing with a back injury. Houllier paid Leicester £11m for Heskey last month rather than wait for a cheaper deal in the summer, because he believed "Bruno" would add punch to his team's Champions League ambitions. How right he was. Heskey's partnership with Michael Owen showed more flashes of promise, including a neat link for the opening goal. "There was a lot of scepticism when Emile was bought," Houllier said. "But we knew what he would bring to us. He's not only a good striker but a good team player. He could believe in himself more, but his contribution today was fantastic." Heskey's heading and finishing have improved since his arrival, and his pace offers a useful outlet down the channels. In the first half, when Liverpool knocked the ball around smoothly and quickly, Wimbledon could barely touch them. Didi Hamman was excellent. Only Neil Sullivan kept the score down. The Wimbledon manager Egil Olsen said that, for 45 minutes, Liverpool looked "the best team we have met this season". He could be proud of the spirit his players showed in a rousing second half as Liverpool lost their fluency. But it needed more than they offered to deny the visitors. Houllier's work has given Liverpool the Premiership's best defensive record away from home (14 goals conceded in 16 matches), and their form since October suggests second spot should be theirs. In the past 24 matches they have taken 54 points to Manchester United's 55. "I said before the game: 'We have got 540 minutes to play and we must have 540 minutes of Champions League football', Houllier said. "We have to be prepared to die on the pitch." The choice of phrase was unfortunate the day after the anniversary of the Hillsborough disaster. But Liverpool have the fight the manager needs. His players certainly looked fresh to begin with. Heskey hit Sullivan's legs from a one-on-one created by Hamman, but made no mistake with his second opportunity in the 34th minute. Accelerating on to a pass by Owen, he finished emphatically. Hamman and Owen went close before Heskey headed in a Patrik Berger corner at the near post just past the hour. By then, though, Wimbledon had rediscovered their passion. Sander Westerveld saved well from Hermann Hreidarsson before Andresen headed in a Trond Andersen cross to reduce the arrears. And although Westerveld made a low stop from Michael Hughes, Liverpool withstood the pressure to secure their first league win at Wimbledon since 1990. webTitle: Faith may not move Jewell's mountain

fields.headline: Faith may not move Jewell's mountain
fields.trailText: Everton 4 - 0 Bradford
fields.body:
Paul Jewell's ebullience could lead the less discerning to believe that he is one of those unfortunate managers who proffer blind faith in a bunch of under-achievers as some sort of substitute for honest assessment. He isn't.

In tumbling haplessly to a sixth consecutive defeat, Jewell's Bradford City played like a Nationwide side, prompting the more mischievous to suggest they were simply readying themselves for next season.

Afterwards Jewell seemed to suggest that if his clearly tired and seemingly dispirited players could somehow gather seven more points they would survive, but a more realistic target is probably nine points, which leaves a team who have forgotten how to win requiring three more victories to step off the trap door.

With Derby County and Wimbledon still to visit Valley Parade the light at the end of the tunnel continues to flicker, but the Yorkshire team could take neither optimism nor reassurance from Saturday's wretched contribution to a game which trotted merrily, almost unapologetically, towards anticlimax from the moment in the second minute when Mark Pembridge's low shot nudged Everton into a lead they never looked like surrendering.

"It is difficult for me to sit here and look positive but positive is what we all must be if we are to avoid the drop," said Jewell. "The mountain is now bigger than it was last week but I think we can still climb it."

If Jewell is to be proved right, Bradford will probably need a guide of Sherpa Tenzing's calibre to show them where salvation lies. In their case the label "experienced" is a euphemism for old and ungainly. Ponderously slow in those departments where Everton excelled, they were creaking, limping and stumbling long before David Unsworth sealed their fate with a penalty awarded after Phil Jevons conned Matthew Clarke into upending him.

Nick Barmby and John Collins added smart second-half goals but the sight of a wounded animal being kicked so savagely will have provided entertainment for only the most ghoulish.

webTitle: Chelsea caught on the hop by Shreeves

fields.headline: Chelsea caught on the hop by Shreeves
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 1 - 0 Chelsea
fields.body:
Having had any faith in their team's chances of staying in the Premiership all but demolished by an 8-0 defeat at St James' Park last September, Sheffield Wednesday supporters will not put much credence in a last-minute messiah with the voice of Bluebottle.

The probability remains that Peter Shreeves, for all his optimism, will end the season echoing that famously indignant cry: "The dirty rotten swines have deaded me again!"

Nevertheless Sky television, with the title race over, suddenly became excited on Saturday afternoon by the idea of a great escape, and claimed that four of Wednesday's last five matches would be at Hillsborough. Only three, in fact, but why spoil a good story?

For Chelsea, who play Barcelona tomorrow, Hillsborough represented the Gnu Camp, except that Gianluca Vialli's side were not the predators. Perhaps they hadn't noticed that Wednesday had beaten Wimbledon in midweek. Clearly Chelsea believed their superior collective skills would speed them to a languid kill.

Such thoughts were quickly swept aside. And in no sense did Wednesday rough them up. Indeed there was so much engaging freedom about the home side's attacking play that they did not seem in any sort of trouble at all.

Such spontaneity may be more difficult to reproduce, now that there really is a possibility of escape. Shreeves believes three wins out of five would be enough, and with Wimbledon losing to Liverpool yesterday he may be right.

Peter Atherton and Des Walker were superb in the middle of Wednesday's defence, although the problems have been at the other end all season, notably at home. The kindest explanation for Paul Durkin not sending off Ed de Goey, only booking him after he had pulled down Gilles de Bilde, was that the referee did not believe the Wednesday striker was capable of hitting an empty net at three paces.

It was only after Wim Jonk's penalty that Chelsea, with Barcelona so patently on their minds, became animated, with two sublime efforts by George Weah hitting the post and bar, and with Kevin Pressman's deft save denying Gustavo Poyet.

Wednesday deserved to win; Chelsea's travelling fans deserved better and are now unlikely to see their team in the Champions League next season unless the Blues win it this year.

On a disappointing note, the Wednesday programme had no mention of the Hillsborough tragedy, 11 years ago to the day.

webTitle: Wizard of Oz slippers and Superman cape for sale

fields.headline: Wizard of Oz slippers and Superman cape for sale
fields.trailText: A pristine pair of ruby slippers made for Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz is to be auctioned at a Christie's East (New York) sale of Hollywood and television memorabilia on 24 May. Collectors estimate the shoes, one of seven or eight pairs made for Garland, could sell for $750,000.
fields.body:
A pristine pair of ruby slippers made for Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz is to be auctioned at a Christie's East (New York) sale of Hollywood and television memorabilia on 24 May. Collectors estimate the shoes, one of seven or eight pairs made for Garland, could sell for $750,000.

Also included in the auction are the Cowardly Lion's Oz costume, a Rolls-Royce from the James Bond classic Goldfinger and Christopher Reeve's Superman capes and body stockings.

The Lion getup, worn by Bert Lahr in the 1939 family classic, could fetch $600,000, and the Roll-Royce, a 12-cylinder, dual-ignition 1937 Phantom 111, might well fetch up $200,000.

Costumes worn by Reeve in 1978's Superman and the 1980 follow-up, Superman II, are expected to sell for about $40,000 each.

Television memorabilia up for sale include the black wool yachting cap worn by Alan Hale, as the Skipper, in Gilligan's Island (estimate $10,000) and a cigarette lighter inscribed with a love note that Lucille Ball gave to Desi Arnaz ($1,000).

fields.headline: Sorrowful Leeds proves Shankly wrong
fields.standfirst: Northern editor Martin Wainwright sees football put in perspective at the funeral of supporter Kevin Speight
fields.trailText: Northern editor Martin Wainwright sees football put in perspective at the funeral of supporter Kevin Speight
fields.body:
Vespas, Lambrettas and other scooters dear to Kevin Speight¹s heart formed a moving guard of honour this morning at the funeral of the Leeds pub landlord murdered in Istanbul .

Like the wreath spelling "Dad" in Leeds United's white, blue and gold, they said everything about the cruel accident of time and place which brought a peaceable and genial man to such an awful end.

By rights, Mr Speight should have been serving pints in the Bay Horse Farsley over lunchtime (or dinner as the midday meal is universally called in this part of the world). It would have been a bit of a wake in the smoky public bar, certainly, after United's 4-0 drubbing by Arsenal on Sunday. But then, without the horrors of Istanbul, would that scoreline have been so grim?

Beyond the sorrow of Susan Speight and the couple's two young children, George and Holly, a sense of brimming confidence and limitless opportunity has been temporarily knocked out of Leeds. Not just the team but the city too.

You can feel it. A lot of promising doors seem to have shut as firmly as the shops which closed in Farsley town street this morning as mourners including the Earl of Harewood, Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale and manager David O'Leary arrived.

We go through it all again tomorrow when Christopher Loftus's family say farewell to him at Leeds Parish church in the centre of town; and then only two days later, the return leg against Galatasary has to be played at Elland Road. Overturning the Turkish team's 2-0 advantage would be in theory be fantastic, but the counter-sense of "who cares?" is remarkably strong.

Several messages among the mounds of flowers left by fans at the ground and in Farsley say how wrong Bill Shankly of Liverpool was to rate football as more important than life or death. It is perhaps the greatest tribute to Speight and Loftus, and the ordinary, sport-loving fans they represent, that their deaths have hit a whole community so hard.

webTitle: Blair follows Thatcher with Russian affair

fields.headline: Blair follows Thatcher with Russian affair
fields.standfirst: Blair defends 'reformer' Putin's visit to No 10
fields.trailText: Tony Blair, who privately describes Margaret Thatcher as a "great" leader, appears to have taken a leaf out of the former prime minister's book by embracing the new Russian president, Vladimir Putin, with such eagerness.
fields.body:
Tony Blair, who privately describes Margaret Thatcher as a "great" leader, appears to have taken a leaf out of the former prime minister's book by embracing the new Russian president, Vladimir Putin, with such eagerness.

In the 1980s Mrs Thatcher ensured that Britain wielded a disproportionate amount of influence in Moscow when she took the gamble of praising Mikhail Gorbachev as a man she could "do business with" even before he had become Soviet leader.

Two decades later, Mr Blair took a personal risk by paying a high profile visit to Mr Putin in his home city of St Petersburg before he had been elected president and while Russian forces were bombarding Chechnya. Mr Putin has now returned the gesture by paying his first overseas visit as president to Britain.

Human rights groups say that the prime minister's determination to pay homage to a leader whose forces were responsible for horrific outrages in Chechnya represents another blow to Labour's much-vaunted ethical foreign policy. They say they are dismayed that the Foreign Office's traditional policy of "constructive engagements" with hardline states - which appears to involve turning a blind eye to excesses - has won through once again.

Downing Street was swift to reject these criticisms. The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said that Mr Blair was "not going to apologise for developing a good relationship with an important world leader".

Ministers, who will have been encouraged that only a few protestors turned out today, believe that Mr Blair's endorsement of Mr Putin will pay handsome dividends. It will ensure that Britain will continue - in Douglas Hurd's memorable phrase - to "punch above its weight" in Moscow, increasing Britain's political and economic clout in Russia.

Russia may have been written off in recent years, but ministers believe the west should never make the mistake of under-estimating the former superpower. Moscow's behaviour at the tail end of the Kosovo conflict, when Russian troops blocked Nato forces from entering Pristina airport, provided a powerful lesson which has not been forgotten.

Mr Putin's admiration of Mr Blair also provides a considerable personal boost for the prime minister. Ministers are delighted that the Russian president has chosen London for his first overseas trip, rather than Germany which has far greater economic links with Russia.

fields.headline: Education body to go private
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Government efforts to push local education authorities into partnership with the private sector will receive a fillip this week if, as expected, a council becomes the first outside London to opt to surrender control.
fields.body:
Government efforts to push local education authorities into partnership with the private sector will receive a fillip this week if, as expected, a council becomes the first outside London to opt to surrender control.

Labour-run Bradford is on course to vote to hand over its entire education department to private consultants, supervised by an appointed board with only two councillors.

To date only the Islington's education authority in north London has gone wholly private, but Bradford is volunteering for change, rather than facing a breakdown of services.

A highly critical Ofsted report on the LEA is expected, however, before the local elections on May 4 when Labour is in danger of losing overall control.

The "partnership board" would monitor the contractor chosen through tendering to run central education services. Bradford council would retain only power to approve broad budget decisions and to use scrutiny groups of councillors to review aspects of the private company's work.

webTitle: Yes Television puts today's planned flotation on hold

fields.headline: Yes Television puts today's planned flotation on hold
fields.trailText: Yes TV, which was due to make its £600m stock market debut this morning, has put its flotation on hold and is likely to reduce the price of its shares to reflect today's expected market turmoil.
fields.body:
Yes TV, which was due to make its £600m stock market debut this morning, has put its flotation on hold and is likely to reduce the price of its shares to reflect today's expected market turmoil.

The company, which aims to offer pay television, internet access and video-on-demand over the phone, will issue a statement this morning clarifying its position and may consider delaying the float further.

Yes closed its book-building exercise run by investment banks Robert Fleming and Investec Henderson Crosthwaite on Friday and was due to price its shares ahead of conditional dealing beginning today.

Directors for the company met with advisers at Fleming yesterday and are expected to make a firm decision before the close of the market today. Steve Garvey, Yes TV's head of marketing, said: "As of Friday night we had a very good order book but then the US market took a bath. We could just push it through but that would not be in the best interests of our investors."

He said both price and timing were at issue but insisted the flotation would still go ahead.The price range had previously been set at between 225p and 275p.

Yes has also been rocked by the cancellation of a key contract to supply video-on-demand services over the cable network of NTL while relations have soured with another client Kingston Communications.

Yes was forced by Kingston to put a statement out on Friday clarifying the relationship between the two companies. "NTL and Kingston have had an effect but only a marginal one," Mr Garvey said. "Rather it's a market movement which has gone hugely against us."

Cheques for retail investors who had to apply for shares by last Wednesday have not yet been cashed because of the uncertainties.

fields.headline: Market meltdown fails to materialise
fields.standfirst:
Despite a fall in share prices on the FTSE 100 this morning, the hi-tech Nasdaq index began to climb after a 10% fall on Friday, postponing the much-predicted world market crash, reports the Money Unlimited editor, Marianne Curphey.
FTSE plunges to six-month low
fields.trailText: It could have been worse. The spectre of a meltdown in world markets, long predicted and much feared, appears to have been postponed for a little bit longer.
fields.body:
It could have been worse. The spectre of a meltdown in world markets, long predicted and much feared, appears to have been postponed for a little bit longer.

Share prices in London opened much lower this morning, and the FTSE 100 fell 4% by early afternoon, dipping well below the psychologically important 6,000 level. Then the US came to the rescue. In the first hour of trading, the technology-based Nasdaq index began a slow climb back upwards - after having fallen 10% on Friday.

For investors with a large exposure to technology stocks who did not sleep well at the weekend (in anticipation of their savings being wiped out this morning), this was the news they had hoped for.

The fate of London share prices in general, and technology stocks in particular, has been closely tied to the rise and fall of the Nasdaq. The valuations of US tech stocks, and consequently of UK technology companies, have seen a net fall since an all-time high in March. Since then there have been days of volatility, when even experts confessed to being bewildered by the market's extremes.

The shock for seasoned investors was the rate at which the Nasdaq and the Dow tripped up at the end of last week. Many professional investors - especially those whose portfolios were heavily invested in "old economy" stocks - had welcomed the gradual fall in tech stocks, arguing that the correction took much of the heat and the hype out of an overvalued sector.

But they were unnerved that the Dow and the FTSE 100 both fell on Friday, because this blew apart the theory that the correction applied only to overvalued net companies and that the underlying market was still robust.

Much of the recent selling in the UK has been by private investors wanting to cut their losses. The pension funds have sat on their hands, waiting for confirmation that this is either a real crash or an attempt by market makers, who set the prices, to test investors' nerves.

Either way, private investors who have bought shares for the right reasons - to hold them over the long term - should resist the temptation to panic-sell. But with the bank holiday on Friday this will be a short week, and will probably be a very bumpy one.

Since then there have been days of volatility, when even experts confessed to being bewildered by the market's extremes. The shock for seasoned investors was the rate at which the Nasdaq and the Dow tripped up at the end of last week. Many professional investors - especially those whose portfolios were heavily invested in "old economy" stocks - had welcomed the gradual fall in tech stocks, arguing that the correction took much of the heat and the hype out of an overvalued sector. But they were unnerved that the Dow and the FTSE 100 both fell on Friday, because this blew apart the theory that the correction applied only to overvalued net companies and that the underlying market was still robust. Much of the recent selling in the UK has been by private investors wanting to cut their losses. The pension funds have sat on their hands, waiting for confirmation that this is either a real crash or an attempt by market makers, who set the prices, to test investors' nerves. Either way, private investors who have bought shares for the right reasons - to hold them over the long term - should resist the temptation to panic-sell. But with the bank holiday on Friday this will be a short week, and will probably be a very bumpy one.

webTitle: Blair defends 'reformer' Putin's visit to No 10

fields.headline: Blair defends 'reformer' Putin's visit to No 10
fields.trailText: Tony Blair this afternoon hit back at critics who condemned the official visit to Britain of the Russian president-elect, Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
Tony Blair this afternoon hit back at critics who condemned the official visit to Britain of the Russian president-elect, Vladimir Putin.

The prime minister ignored Tory and Liberal Democrat claims that the trip was "premature" and said the best way to press home the west's concerns about alleged human rights abuses in Chechnya was to "engage" in a proper dialogue.

Speaking at joint press conference with Mr Putin, who is on his first foreign visit since he was elected president, Mr Blair said the Russian leader wanted a strong relationship with the west and "talks our language of reform".

Mr Blair said that during their meeting they had discussed a number of issues including the war in Chechnya, economic matters and the forthcoming G8 summit.

"I believe that Vladimir Putin is a leader who is ready to embrace a new relationship with the European Union and the United States, who wants a strong and modern Russia and a strong relationship with the west," Mr Blair said.

The prime minister said he had discussed with Mr Putin the concerns of human rights groups over the Russian occupation of Chechnya and the brutal way in which the army had dealt with Chechen rebels.

Mr Putin said he and Mr Blair had differing views over the Chechen crisis, but stressed that closer relations with the EU was one of his priorities.

Earlier, a small but noisy group of protesters gathered outside Downing Street to demonstrate against Mr Putin's visit. At least one demonstrator was taken away in a police van.

Dr Ghayasuddin Siddiqui, the leader of the Muslim parliament and one of the protest organisers, said: "The people are feeling disgusted that once again business is taking precedence over concerns for human rights violations and war crimes.

"We are not against Tony Blair talking to Mr Putin but the rules of engagements have to be clearly defined and laid down. Tony Blair said human rights will be top of the agenda - but we want some firm commitment and some kind of timetable about what precisely is going to happen."

Another protester, Sarfraz Hedni, said: "The whole nation is being destroyed and the world community should get up and stop it."

Members of Amnesty International were also at the demonstration. Spokeswoman Amanda Barnes said: "We know that Tony Blair has said he is going to be talking to Putin about Chechnya, but we want him to stop human rights violations immediately and implement international human rights laws straight away."

But the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, defended the visit. He said Mr Blair "was not going to apologise for developing a good relationship with an important world leader". He added: "What we won't do is allow the entirety of our relations with Russia and a new Russian president to be defined by only one issue."

Earlier today, the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, and the Liberal Democrats' foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, also expressed concern. Mr Campbell said: "Mr Putin's visit to London remains both premature and inappropriate while human rights violations continue in Chechnya."

Before visiting Downing Street Mr Putin addressed business leaders at a Confereration of British Industry seminar in Whitehall. Urging greater investment in Russia, he told them: "We are very optimistic about improvements in our bilateral relationship."

Mr Putin was scheduled to visit the Imperial War Museum this afternoon, where he will lay a wreath at the Soviet war memorial, before meeting the Queen at Windsor castle tonight.

fields.headline: Classic children's library: teens
fields.trailText: One minute they are children, the next they are adults. One minute they are reading Frances Hodgson Burnett and the next Angela Carter. Five years ago, most bookshops didn't even have a young adult or teenage section. Now they are bursting to the seams with TV tie-ins and spinoffs and fantasy horror novels. More encouragingly, the last few years have also seen a huge increase in quality writing for young people. Writers such as Melvin Burgess and Phillip Pullman are not simply writing bridging books, but novels that stand alone in their own right and deserve to win prizes in any category of fiction. From these books it is no leap at all into the big pond of adult fiction, merely a swallow dive
fields.body:
One minute they are children, the next they are adults. One minute they are reading Frances Hodgson Burnett and the next Angela Carter. Five years ago, most bookshops didn't even have a young adult or teenage section. Now they are bursting to the seams with TV tie-ins and spinoffs and fantasy horror novels. More encouragingly, the last few years have also seen a huge increase in quality writing for young people. Writers such as Melvin Burgess and Phillip Pullman are not simply writing bridging books, but novels that stand alone in their own right and deserve to win prizes in any category of fiction. From these books it is no leap at all into the big pond of adult fiction, merely a swallow dive.

Troy by Adele Geras (Scholastic, £14.99)

You thought mythology was dull? It isn't in this chunky retelling of the most famous Greek story of the all. Geras takes a below-stairs and strongly female perspective to weave an epic drama that she tells with wit, wisdom and a fresh-minted straightforwardness that reminds the reader of an oral storytelling tradition.


Little Soldier by Bernard Ashley (Orchard, £4.99)

The world of the child soldier is evoked in this challenging novel that tells the story of Kaninda, a former rebel soldier in an African war, brought to London as a refugee. But Kaninda is determined never to forget what has happened to him and here he finds a different kind of war going on between street gangs on the Docklands streets. This is one of those rare novels that shows you a familiar world through the eyes of an outsider. A strong, uncompromising book.

Make Lemonade by Virginia Euwer Wolff (Faber Children's Classics, £4.99)

How do young women build lives for themselves when struggling in difficult circumstances? What do we mean by friendship and family? Some of the answers can be found in this American novel, a book about free form lives written in a free form verse style. There is something exquisitely delicate, but also very tough, about it as it recounts the relationship between a fourteen-year-old girl desperate to escape the poverty of her upbringing, and the struggling single mother for whom she babysits.


Over Sea, Under Stone by Susan Cooper (Puffin, £5.99)

A holiday in Cornwall, an ancient treasure map and a search for lost Arthurian treasure. This is the first book in Cooper's terrific The Dark is Rising fantasy sequence, in which the triumph of good against evil is always in the balance. These are books in which the writing is infused with the wildness of the elements. You can buy all five novels in one volume, which is good value at £11, but the print is a bit on the small side. Better to buy each novel as a singleton.


Northern Lights by Phillip Pullman (Scholastic, £5.99)

Lyra must overcome terror and life-threatening perils in her quest to find a friend who has disappeared. Like a modern more grown-up version of Hans Christian Anderson's The Snow Queen, Pullman's beautiful, sparely written book is a real page-turner that even the most sophisticated adult would find hard to resist. With the help of her friendly daemon, Lyra travels to the dark North, where armoured bears rule the ice and witch queens fly through the frozen skies. A fantasy book to rival the very best, this is the first in the Dark Materials trilogy. We guarantee they'll read the next two, The Subtle Knife and The Amber Spyglass.


The Hobbit by JRR Tolkien (Collins, £5.99)

Whisked from his hobbit hole by Gandalf the Wizard and a band of dwarves, Bilbo Baggins finds himself unwillingly caught up in plans to seize the treasure of Smag, a big and dangerous dragon. Originally published in 1937, this was one of the first fantasy novels, and it stands up well against the modern ones: it may not be as scary, but it has wit in its favour. Older readers will move with ease on to The Lord of the Rings.


Flour Babies by Anne Fine (Puffin, £4.99)

Simon and his class are given six-pound bags of flour to look after as though they were real babies. Through this curious school project Simon begins to understand something about the strains of parenthood and why his parents behave as they do.


Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry by Mildred D. Taylor (Puffin, £5.99)

A memory novel set in Mississippi during the 1930s. Cassie, a young black girl, doesn't understand why the farm means so much to her father. Cassie is a really memorable creation, a determined and strong-willed girl who learns to fight for both her family and her principles in a world of racial hatred and destruction.


The Final Journey by Gudrun Pausewang (Puffin, £4.99)

Alice has spent two years hiding in a basement, shielded by her loving family from all knowledge of the Nazi persecution of the Jews. But now they have been discovered, and Alice and her grandfather are in a cattle truck being herded with hundreds of others towards their final destination. Pausewang's remarkable book, surely inspired by the Anne Frank story, is cool and uncompromising, as much about Alice's journey of self-discovery towards adulthood as about the holocaust. Like so much in this novel, your heart cracks at the final image of Alice raising up her arms, unwittingly embracing death.


The Diary of a Young Girl by Anne Frank (Puffin, £4.99)

Nobody should grow up without reading what is perhaps the most famous diary of them all. Written between July 1942 and August 1944, it details the growing pains of a young (13 at the start of the diary) Jewish girl hiding with her family from the Nazis in an Amsterdam attic. The diary ends abruptly: the family were discovered and Frank was sent to a concentration camp, where she died of typhus. It is impossible not to respond to the guilelessness of the writing and the portrait of a young woman so vividly alive for such a short time.

Goodnight Mister Tom by Michelle Magorian

(Puffin, £5.99) Willie is evacuated to the country as Britain is on the brink of war. A sad, deprived child, he slowly begins to thrive under the care of old Tom Oakley. But then his mother summons him back to London. A wonderful, warm book in which the emotion is always beautifully controlled but deeply felt as it charts the mysterious ways of adults and the pain of growing up.


The Call of the Wild by Jack London (Puffin, £2.99)

Classic adventure story about Buck, a dog born to luxury who is betrayed and sold as a sledge dog. He escapes captivity to become the leader of a wolf pack.


River Boy by Tim Bowler (OUP, £3.99)

"You are not the same person at the end of this book" was the verdict of the Carnegie judges who awarded Bowler's book the Gold Medal back in 1998. There is something distanced yet intense about Bowler's writing style, as though the ordinariness of everyday life has been lifted into a kind of hyper-reality. And that is what it feels like for Jess, whose grandpa is dying in hospital and who refuses to let go.

Brother in the Land by Robert Swindells (Puffin, £4.99)

Swindells's thought-provoking novel deservedly won the Children's Book Award. It is a tough story about Danny, who survives a nuclear holocaust and has to find a way to survive in the most desolate of circumstances.


The Friends by Rosa Guy (Puffin, £4.99)

A powerful story about friendship set in New York, where newly arrived West Indian Phyllisia Cathy strikes up a friendship with the dynamic Edith.


Wuthering Heights by Emily Bronte (Puffin, £3.99)

Great bleak, romantic novel. Hit your teenage girls with this and they'll never start on Mills & Boon.

Jane Eyre by Charlotte Brontë (Puffin, £3.99)

Ditto everything said about Wuthering Heights.

The Hound of the Baskervilles by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle (Puffin, £3.99)

A great way in to Sherlock Holmes, the faithful Watson and the dastardly Moriarty.

The Scarecrows by Robert Westall (Puffin, £4.99)

Intelligent and menacing novel from another Carnegie award-winner, which tells of a boy and his family brought to the brink of destruction by sinister external forces.


Jacob Have I Loved by Katherine Paterson (Puffin, £5.99)

A tale of sibling rivalry between twin sisters Caroline and Louise, seen from the point of view of the latter, who feels that her sister - the elder by just a few minutes - gets everyone's love and attention.


The Outsiders by SE Hinton (Collins, £4.50)

Published in 1967 when Hinton was 17, this book became an overnight classic. It captures all the terror and excitement of being an American teenager, which feels here like being a cowboy in the Wild West. The violent ganglands of America was also the setting for another Hinton classic, Rumblefish (Collins, £3.99), the tragic story of Rusty Jones, whose one ambition is to be like his elder brother, Motorcycle Boy.

A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens (Puffin, £3.99)

The great thing about getting hooked on Dickens is that there are so many of them. In my experience teenagers either love or hate him, and there is absolutely no in between. Puffin also do abridged versions in this series of Great Expectations, Oliver Twist and A Tale of Two Cities. Audiobooks are a good way in - Hugh Laurie does a superb rendition of Great Expectations (Puffin, £7.99).


Talking in Whispers by James Watson (Puffin, £4.99)

A tense, political thriller set in Chile about an outlawed teenager who flees oppression at the hands of the Junta.


To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee (Arrow, £5.99)

Harper Lee's great novel about race and class in the Deep South of the 1930s is seen through the eyes of Scout and Jem Finch, two youngsters whose father is a lawyer defending a black man charged with raping a white woman. A really good read, and a wise and compassionate book.


Junk by Melvin Burgess (Penguin, £4.99)

"A love affair you'll never forget" is the promise on the cover of Burgess's brutally honest book about teenage runaways Tar and Gemma - who love each other, and heroin. Burgess doesn't try to hide anything, dress drug addiction up, preach or moralise. He simply writes it as it is from the point of view of 14-year-olds who see all the attractions of heroin and none of the dangers. This isn't an issue book, it is a great novel that you consume in one great adrenaline rush. If you ike this you'll also love Burgess's The Baby and Fly Pie (Puffin, £4.99), a thriller about a group of children living on the streets, and Burning Issy (Hodder, £4.99), a haunting nightmarish tale set in the 17th century when the witchfinder scoured the countryside looking for women to burn.

Dear Nobody by Berlie Doherty (Collins, £4.50)

Helen and Chris are on the brink of adulthood, and should have been looking forward to starting college. Instead they are coping with the idea of becoming parents. Carnegie Medal award-winning novel that captures all the intensity of teenage first love and its consequences.

Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen (Puffin, £2.99)

Puffin's slightly abridged version helps bring out the pointed wit of Austen's tale. Some just don't get the point until they are in their 20s, although Colin Firth and co have led to a run on this in households with teenage girls.

webTitle: M&S opens door to credit cards

fields.headline: M&S opens door to credit cards
fields.trailText: The ailing Marks & Spencer chain breaks with tradition today and will start taking credit cards at its 297 UK stores.
fields.body:
The ailing Marks & Spencer chain breaks with tradition today and will start taking credit cards at its 297 UK stores.

The company's decision to start accepting cards has been prompted by its recent downturn in sales and is one of a raft of measures designed to woo back shoppers who have deserted the brand.

Until now M&S has resolutely refused to take credit cards as a way of encouraging customers to use its own Chargecard. Some analysts believe the group's profitable chargecard operations are bound to be undermined by the new choices.

The group announced last November that it had decided to end its ban on credit cards - only weeks after John Lewis, the only other big retailer which had also operated such a ban, also reversed its policy.

M&S shoppers will now be able to use a wide range of payment cards including Visa, Mastercard and American Express as well as debit cards.

Carol Stockill, Marks & Spencer's Credit Card Programme manager said: "We are committed to delivering the highest levels of service to our customers and making the shopping experience as easy as possible.

"We're very confident that our customers will welcome being able to use credit cards in our shops".

M&S will also accept credit card payment for online and mail order sales.

"We're very confident that our customers will welcome being able to use credit cards in our shops". M&S will also accept credit card payment for online and mail order sales.

webTitle: Sikh murder in Wales treated as race attack

fields.headline: Sikh murder in Wales treated as race attack
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A popular Sikh shopkeeper was beaten to death at the weekend in a street attack which police are treating as racially motivated.
fields.body:
A popular Sikh shopkeeper was beaten to death at the weekend in a street attack which police are treating as racially motivated.

Santokh Singh Fandhu, 42, known to customers in Port Talbot, south Wales, by his adopted name of Peter Singh, was ambushed on his way out for an evening drink with friends at his favourite pub.

A man aged 57 and another man aged 48 are being questioned at separate police stations about the attack on the father of three, whose family was in a state of shock yesterday. The killing has devastated a community that has seen few incidents of racial violence and considers itself tolerant and friendly.

The mayor of Port Talbot, Malcolm Harris, said: "I am very, very surprised and shocked that something like this has happened here. We don't have that sort of problem in the town. All my sympathies go out to the family."

Mr Singh was described by neighbours as "very nice and popular on account of that". He was universally known as Peter, a name he had adopted 20 years ago because he felt it was easier on all the customers who visited his women's fashion shop, called Emphasis, in Port Talbot High Street. He had moved to the area from Cardiff 30 years ago.

On Saturday, at about 9pm, Mr Singh was taking the short walk from his home to the Red Lion with his friend, Bob McQuaide, (who is white) when the attack took place. Mr McQuaide was punched in the face and lost consciousness. When he came round he found Mr Singh at his side on the pavement unconscious and bleeding. A third man raised the alarm at the police station immediately close by.

Paramedics tried to revive Mr Singh but he died where he lay on the pavement. It is thought one of the assailants fled the scene in a taxi. A cab driver informed the police after hearing about the attack.

Terry Coughlan, 48, the landlord of the Red Lion where Mr Singh was going after an evening at a local club with his friends, said: "He was a lovely guy and had been in the town so long that no one thought of him as being anything but a local man. He was just Peter to everyone, a family man with a lovely wife and three children - as far as I was aware no one had any reason to dislike him, he was a just nice chap."

Richard Davies, 22, who works at the Grand Hotel as a barman, said: "It was dreadful, the paramedics were trying to revive him but it was no good. No one could believe what was happening. This is a quiet town and there are no real racial problems."

Mr McQuaide was too distressed to speak about his friend's death.

A spokesman for the South Wales police said the incident was being treated as racially motivated - which has been standard practice since the Macpherson report on the Stephen Lawrence tragedy for any incident that may have a racial dimension because of those involved.

Detectives investigating the death are being helped by officers from the force's minorities support unit.

The 57-year-old who was arrested is being questioned at Neath, five miles from the scene of the murder, and the 48-year-old is being questioned at a police station 10 miles away at Bridgend.

A spokesman for Port Talbot's Asian community said that Mr Singh's family was "shocked and devastated" and was receiving counselling. He said: "If this is a racially motivated murder, then I think it is very, very sad - 99% of the people in this town just want to live in peace and we do not want to have any problems of this kind. It is tragic to think that someone may have lost his life because he comes from a different culture. I am sure this has shocked everyone in Port Talbot."

The South Wales police authority, whose area includes Port Talbot, meets today to discuss Home Office recommendations following the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.

webTitle: Farmers stay away as Zimbabwe violence continues

fields.headline: Farmers stay away as Zimbabwe violence continues
fields.trailText:
About 80 white farmers and their families were today refusing to return to their properties in Zimbabwe, in fear for their safety after black squatters killed a white farmer over the weekend and badly beat five others.
 
With violence occurring throughout the Macheke district, 75 miles east of Harare, farmers said they would stay out of the area until police and military officials could guarantee their security.
fields.body:
About 80 white farmers and their families were today refusing to return to their properties in Zimbabwe, in fear for their safety after black squatters killed a white farmer over the weekend and badly beat five others. With violence occurring throughout the Macheke district, 75 miles east of Harare, farmers said they would stay out of the area until police and military officials could guarantee their security.

"Right now, the farmers are adamant they are not going back until they are assured of their safety. There's no faith in the police," said Harry Orphanides, a spokesman for the Commercial Farmers Union. Its head is due to meet Dumiso Dabengwa, the government home affairs minister.

The body of farmer David Stevens, 50, was found yesterday dumped beside a river bridge and an autopsy was being carried out before it could be released to his family, police said. Mr Stevens and his Swedish-born wife, Maria, were the parents of four young children.

Meanwhile, worried white Zimbabweans were queuing outside the British high commission in Harare today to reclaim their British citizenship. President Robert Mugabe has refused to condemn the killing of Mr Stevens by veterans of the 1970s guerrilla warfare in Zimbabwe (then Rhodesia) to secure independence from the UK.

Foreign office minister Peter Hain has said that Britain would be prepared to provide asylum for up to 20,000 white Zimbabweans. Around 25,000 are thought to be entitled to reclaim the British citizenship they were forced to give up after a Zimbabwean law banned dual nationality.

At least 500 white-owned farms have now been occupied by Mr Mugabe's supporters. "I know there is an expectation that I will say to the war veterans get off the land. I will not say or do that," he told chanting supporters at the weekend.

Mr Hain summoned the Zimbabwe high commissioner yesterday to demand an explanation for the violence.

fields.headline: Can I play VoteMonkey?
fields.standfirst: Play VoteMonkey
fields.trailText: Let VoteMonkey choose your London mayor. But, before you click, check you fit the following technical requirements:
fields.body:
Let VoteMonkey choose your London mayor. But, before you click, check you fit the following technical requirements:

To play VoteMonkey or The Grinder, you need a Java-enabled Browser.

Please make sure your configuration is correct, otherwise there is a possibility that VoteMonkey might not run properly.

PC Users:

Please do not use a browser version other than the following:

1. Windows 95/98/NT 2. Internet Explorer, version 4 or higher 3. Netscape Navigator, version 4.05 or higher

Mac Users:

Please use Internet Explorer Version 4.5. or later. Do not use Netscape Navigator! Its Java VM is not working properly with most java applications.

In case you experience problems, please check under Edit/Preferences/Java that your browser is configured in the following way:

- Activate Java VM (Apple MRJ 2.2) - choose "Network Permission: unrestricted" - uncheck the option "restrict access to non-java classes"

The optimal screen configuration is 800 x 600 screensize and Vote Monkey will re-size your screen.

fields.headline: Marketing muscles in
fields.standfirst: Things are looking rosier for the Sunday Mirror. Was it the Barbara Windsor wedding story and the free Pokémon poster? Unlikely, says  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Things are looking rosier for the Sunday Mirror. Was it the Barbara Windsor wedding story and the free Pokémon poster? Unlikely, says Roy Greenslade.
fields.body:
The great battle between News International and Trinity-Mirror is usually viewed through the daily skirmishes between the Sun and the Mirror. But, quietly, a very different kind of campaign has been fought between the groups' Sunday titles, and the latest news from the front tells a very interesting story indeed.

It would appear that the Sunday Mirror, which had grown used to being in a state of seemingly perpetual decline, has been enjoying a period of stability unknown for several years. Meanwhile, the triumphant News of the World, long the favoured red-top among the masses, has been suffering from the kind of reverse which is making it harder week after week to maintain its 4m-plus sale.

As the chart detailing the latest officially audited figures from ABC shows, the gap between the two remains immense. I would be surprised if News of the World editor Phil Hall is overly worried just now. But that shouldn't detract from the achievement of his rival, Colin Myler, at the Sunday Mirror. Everyone knows that trying to reverse a downward trend is infinitely more difficult than holding a paper steady on course when it's at the top of the market.

An analysis of Sunday Mirror circulation over the past couple of years shows a clear upward trend. It has slowed the rate of decline which from July to September 1998 was running at 15% year-on-year, to barely 1% in the past three months. Over the same period, the News of the World's year-on-year figures have been running at an average 3% loss. It is important to note that the NoW is nothing like as reliant on bulk sales as the Sunday Mirror and discounts proportionately fewer copies too, but Myler's performance is surprising all the same.

So how has he done it? By editorial content or promotions? By marketing or journalism? Last week, for example, did readers buy the paper because of the "world exclusive" on Barbara Windsor's secret wedding - picked up, incidentally from the New of the World's first edition - or because there was a free Pokémon poster on offer?

Is Ian Hyland's diary a big draw or the columns by Johnny Vaughan and Carole Malone? With the greatest of respect to all involved, I think the reason is altogether more mundane and nothing to do with journalism. For months now, Trinity-Mirror has been running a huge direct mail campaign, aimed specifically at News of the World readers, inviting them to buy discounted copies of the Mirror, for 10p, and the Sunday Mirror for 30p.

This well-planned marketing initiative is far less costly, and more effective, than TV advertising, so the company has probably spent far less than News International to win sales. But will they stick?

Given the state of the overall Sunday newspaper market, I doubt it. Look at all those minus signs in the chart. An objective analysis of the 10-year trend shows how very difficult it is to sell any Sunday paper nowadays, and doubly so if it's a red-top. Traditional red-top readers have been lured away by the broadsheet titles and by the Mail on Sunday, all of which offer better value-for-money packages that include a great deal of entertainment and lifestyle content.

More significantly, the increasingly comprehensive sports sections in these papers have become much more attractive to football fans frustrated by the relatively low sports pagination in red-tops. The News of the World, once a must for sports-lovers, just doesn't offer enough material any longer. I realise this is more subjective, but I also detect that the News of the World is suffering from public reaction against intrusive stories about big-name celebrities, such as the controversial Lawrence Dallaglio saga.

That hostility should also be a warning to the People, a Trinity-Mirror title which has yet to enjoy any hint of a turnaround in its decline, because it seems to try too hard to imitate the NoW. Despite editor Neil Wallis's undoubted energy and drive, it is the wrong road to take.

The News of the World has two other problems: first, it is published the day after the bumper Saturday issue of its stablemate, the Sun; second, the NoW hasn't offered readers any additional value in a long time. Isn't it time that News International's highest-selling paper got a large, or a different, magazine for instance?

Turning to other sectors, the story of the grim fight to attract readers is remarkably similar. Last week, as I went to catch a train at London's Victoria Station, I was handed a glossy 20-page brochure by a woman clad in a T-shirt bearing a Telegraph logo. Use the enclosed vouchers, urged managing director Jeremy Deedes, and save yourself £2.30 a week on the normal cover prices of the Daily and Sunday Telegraph. The cost of producing and distributing these booklets, which include examples of writing by several of the paper's stars - one of whom is 88, and two of whom are freelance contributors - is a costly way of winning extra sales.

But the problem for the Telegraphs is that a reliance on pre-paid subscriptions has led their audience to understand that there is no reason to pay full price for the papers. How their owner Conrad Black must rue the day he decided to offer subscriptions as a way of coping with Rupert Murdoch's price war.

Price-cutting is now so ingrained in the culture of newspaper-buyers that they are happy to shop around for the best buy without any sense of loyalty. I understand that the Express - soon to be the Daily Express once more - has benefited from its latest cut with rumours of a Saturday sale approaching 1.55m and the Sunday title attaining 1m once again. This is heartening for a paper about to celebrate its centenary when we will be reminded of its glory days in the 1950s and 60s, under its legendary owner Lord Beaverbrook, when it regularly sold more than 4m. It is doubtful, though, that this ploy will halt the long-term downward trend. What the Express needs, just as it has for 20 years, is intelligent investment in editorial. All the rest, the marketing and the promotions, is a support act. Promoting a product which isn't fully competitive with the opposition is a waste of money.

In spite of the Daily Mail falling foul of ABC last month for failing to declare its own price-cutting activities, and thereby having its sale revised downwards, it remains - page for page, section for section - infinitely better value than the Express.

One little black cloud for Lord Rothermere is the recent performance of the Mail on Sunday. Its effortless rise of the past few years has finally come to a halt and, in the past three months, has found it difficult to sustain the 2.3m average achieved throughout 1999. As the second highest-selling Sunday, it is so well placed there is hardly a need for panic.

The same cannot be said about the situation north of the border. Vicious rivalry has cut the ground from under Scotland on Sunday, while its flagship stablemate, the Scotsman, is also finding it hard going. At the other end of the Scots market, the Daily Record and the Sunday Mail are finding it increasingly difficult to sell copies. Now a Swedish company, Bonnier, is planning to launch a financial daily from Edinburgh. Rarely can so small a population have been wooed by so many newspaper titles.
