fields.headline: Audi A2
fields.trailText: Small cars are not always as green as you think. Take, for instance, a 1.4 litre Vauxhall Corsa: it'll do no more to the gallon than the bigger Vauxhall Astra 1.4, even though the Astra will carry more passengers in greater comfort. And if you buy a 1.6 litre Astra, it'll not only be quicker, it'll drink a bit less fuel.
fields.body:
Small cars are not always as green as you think. Take, for instance, a 1.4 litre Vauxhall Corsa: it'll do no more to the gallon than the bigger Vauxhall Astra 1.4, even though the Astra will carry more passengers in greater comfort. And if you buy a 1.6 litre Astra, it'll not only be quicker, it'll drink a bit less fuel.

But with the A2, Audi have come up with a totally new approach, spending five years looking at what makes a small car worth getting into. Choosing an engine that sips like a shy teetotaller will get you only so far down the road to economy. A more fundamental remedy is to shed the workload. Steel might be strong and abundant, but the price of its strength is its weight.

The alternative lies in a chance discovery by a Provence peasant. Toiling away with a spade in a field at Les Baux, he noticed that the rock contained something that looked handy for wrapping around an oven-ready chicken. Okay, that's a gross approximation, but Bauxite rock is where the aluminium story starts. Aluminium soon became steel's foil - and car makers have grown increasingly interested in it. It's 43% lighter than steel and can be stretched so that you only need make it thick where the thickness is really necessary.

Having played around with the substance for the frame of the AL2 concept, it was just a short move for Audi to produce what you see here: a car that weighs just 895kg. With a handicap like that, either choice of engine (petrol or diesel turbo, both 1.4) has a flying start. The petrol car's average is 46.3mpg, while the diesel offers an aggregate 67.3. And an aluminium car will never rust.

The A2 is a head-on challenge to the Merc A-class. When it gets here in September (the diesel will come next January) it will cost from around £13,500 - a premium price for anyone who's not afraid of displaying willingness to invest in advanced technology.

Keen to show off the idea, Audi plans to build 60,000-70,000 A2s in year one and says the project is profit-making, even though many maintain that such claims are PR bravado. Whatever the truth, there's no doubt that you'll be paying an R&D premium.

However, this is no rip off. The A2 is a fine showcase for zero-year styling - something like an Audi TT that is halfway through a mangle. Check the wiperless rear window, the gawky angular door glass and peak-a-boo glimpses of brushed aluminium buried in the trim. For anyone still scarred by the Metro, it's proof that small is sexy.

Some limits, however, call into question its ability to blood the Merc A-class's nose. The third seat in the back will be an optional extra while, up front, the gearstick is a little close to the passenger seat and could lead to accidental groping. Storage is adequate and the dash is skinned in a pleasant, grippy surface that prevents phone slippage on most corners. In the back, deep footwells are made possible by delving into the sandwich floor construction, thus allowing lanky adults to ride unconfined. It's roomy, but no A-class killer.

The posh looks are complemented by a polished drive. It's smooth, refined and (apart from wind noise around the single front wiper), hushed. The petrol version falls flat a little in third and is no lunger, but the diesel is a tremendously thrilling alternative. It has so much torque in any gear, at any time, that you'd be barmy to buy September's petrol option, and should wait for the new year for the TDI. The diesel does make a bit of a racket because Audi's quest for low weight led them to omit the same degree of soundproofing (so saving a fiver on build costs). But after the chorus of groans from media guinea pigs, they say they will be coughing up the cash and muffling the thing. When that's done the diesel option's charm, practicality and class-leading fuel economy will make it a small wonder.

Audi A2 1.4 petrol/TDI

For: futuristic, stylish, swanky

Against: Only four seats

Top speed: 107mph

Acceleration: 0-62mph in 12 secs (diesel 12.3)

Engine: 1.4 petrol or turbodiesel, both 75bhp

On the stereo: No heavy metal

In the holdall: Organic sandwiches, wrapped in foil

It's 43% lighter than steel and can be stretched so that you only need make it thick where the thickness is really necessary. Having played around with the substance for the frame of the AL2 concept, it was just a short move for Audi to produce what you see here: a car that weighs just 895kg. With a handicap like that, either choice of engine (petrol or diesel turbo, both 1.4) has a flying start. The petrol car's average is 46.3mpg, while the diesel offers an aggregate 67.3. And an aluminium car will never rust. The A2 is a head-on challenge to the Merc A-class. When it gets here in September (the diesel will come next January) it will cost from around £13,500 - a premium price for anyone who's not afraid of displaying willingness to invest in advanced technology. Keen to show off the idea, Audi plans to build 60,000-70,000 A2s in year one and says the project is profit-making, even though many maintain that such claims are PR bravado. Whatever the truth, there's no doubt that you'll be paying an R&D premium. However, this is no rip off. The A2 is a fine showcase for zero-year styling - something like an Audi TT that is halfway through a mangle. Check the wiperless rear window, the gawky angular door glass and peak-a-boo glimpses of brushed aluminium buried in the trim. For anyone still scarred by the Metro, it's proof that small is sexy. Some limits, however, call into question its ability to blood the Merc A-class's nose. The third seat in the back will be an optional extra while, up front, the gearstick is a little close to the passenger seat and could lead to accidental groping. Storage is adequate and the dash is skinned in a pleasant, grippy surface that prevents phone slippage on most corners. In the back, deep footwells are made possible by delving into the sandwich floor construction, thus allowing lanky adults to ride unconfined. It's roomy, but no A-class killer. The posh looks are complemented by a polished drive. It's smooth, refined and (apart from wind noise around the single front wiper), hushed. The petrol version falls flat a little in third and is no lunger, but the diesel is a tremendously thrilling alternative. It has so much torque in any gear, at any time, that you'd be barmy to buy September's petrol option, and should wait for the new year for the TDI. The diesel does make a bit of a racket because Audi's quest for low weight led them to omit the same degree of soundproofing (so saving a fiver on build costs). But after the chorus of groans from media guinea pigs, they say they will be coughing up the cash and muffling the thing. When that's done the diesel option's charm, practicality and class-leading fuel economy will make it a small wonder. Audi A2 1.4 petrol/TDI For: futuristic, stylish, swanky Against: Only four seats Top speed: 107mph Acceleration: 0-62mph in 12 secs (diesel 12.3) Engine: 1.4 petrol or turbodiesel, both 75bhp On the stereo: No heavy metal In the holdall: Organic sandwiches, wrapped in foil

fields.headline: Auto parts
fields.trailText: A flat reception
fields.body:
A flat reception

Hyundai will launch a new 4x4 vehicle, the Santa Fe, later in the year. Normally on occasions like this, the manufacturer will take motoring journalists to an appropriate location to test out the new model; a luxury convertible might be launched in the Cte d'Azur for example. So in which country are Hyundai going to launch the Santa Fe? Somewhere with wild mountain roads and steep inclines to test out the its ruggedness - Wales perhaps? Bhutan? Erm no... the Santa Fe is to be launched in Holland.

Quote of the week
"You know what matters most? Product. You could build the most modern factory in the world, have government backing up to your ears, and employ a sales team with teeth so white they could bring down airliners, but it wouldn't make a jot of difference if you were making the Rover 25."
Jeremy Clarkson, Top Gear magazine

Subarubydoo!
This year's JD Power/Top Gear survey into customer satisfaction has Subarus filling the top two spots and another in the top ten. The survey takes into account performance, fuel economy, customer care, dealer charges, mechanical problems, electrical problems, and body and interior problems. The top ten goes like this: Subaru Legacy, Subaru Impreza, Skoda Felicia, Toyota Starlet, Jaguar XJ Saloon, Honda Shuttle, Toyota Corolla, Subaru Forester, Toyota Picnic, Volvo S70. And the bottom ten (worst last): Rover 800, Alfa Romeo 156, Peugeot 106, Peugeot 306, Fiat Bravo, Ford Escort, Ford Explorer, Rover Mini, Vauxhall Frontera, Vauxhall Sintra.

webTitle: 'Tom and I are going to kill each other'

fields.headline: 'Tom and I are going to kill each other'
fields.standfirst: Instructor Tom Taylor took  Bibi van der Zee  on an intensive driving course to get her through her test in just one week. Well, at least that was the idea...
fields.trailText: Monday This then, is my new home. A red V-reg Vauxhall Corsa, with a plastic Bugs Bunny on the dashboard, and Mozart in the tape machine. This will be where I spend most of my waking hours for the next five days.
fields.body:
Monday This then, is my new home. A red V-reg Vauxhall Corsa, with a plastic Bugs Bunny on the dashboard, and Mozart in the tape machine. This will be where I spend most of my waking hours for the next five days.

Tom Taylor doesn't allow me a moment's contemplation. "D'you think you can reverse out of this space?" he asks cheerfully, having come to meet me at Chester station. Tom Taylor is to be my instructor for the week. He's got controls on his side too, I notice with relief, trying to work out where reverse is. "The week ahead is going to be hard on both you and me," he tells me, sitting back as we judder out onto Chester's highways, and pausing to ease me away from a couple of menacing bollards. "I'm going to work you as hard as possible for the first couple of days, then I'll start to ease off a bit on Wednesday, and hopefully, by Thursday, when you do your mock test, you'll be feeling pretty confident. But I warn you now, we'll both be knackered before it's all over."

He's right, and if I'd thought about it all a bit more, I would have realised that a concentrated course was not going to be a week's relaxation. It seemed a brilliant idea to just get the bloody thing out of the way in one go, after years of people saying incredulously "You mean you can't drive at all!" A concentrated course meant I'd start on Monday, have my licence by Saturday, and not have to faff around with the practising and booking lessons bit that had always foiled me before. As I jerk to a halt at the traffic lights, and stall for the third time in 10 minutes, it begins to dawn on me that perhaps slightly more time to absorb the bits and pieces of a pretty complicated activity might help. But sod reflection. Why have the windscreen wipers come on?

Tom and I get on well: his slight resemblance to the dad in the Royle Family (with the same fondness for dodgy jokes) helps. He folds his hands over his tummy, and is totally relaxed: it doesn't seem to matter what I do (apart from some of my closer parked-car passes), nothing fazes him. Within a few hours of arriving, I'm stalling on a dual carriageway, instead of just stalling on a driveway. Ah, progress.

Tuesday Having spent Monday night strolling in a relaxed way round Chester I wake up in my little bed and breakfast full of energy. The Corsa seems like a familiar and welcoming place, and it turns out that I'm a natural at emergency stops. "Perfect, that was, absolutely perfect," says Tom happily.

I also seem to have a natural talent for reversing, even uphill. Trundling round the gorgeous little village of Ecclestone, my hill starts are truly horrible, but I can reverse up anything. Tom thinks it's got something to do with left brain/right brain balances, which is especially interesting because I've been reading Oliver Sacks and thinking about brains ever since I got here. I try to explain about this man whose sight was restored after 40 years of total blindness, and how hard he found it to adapt and make sense of what he was seeing, and how that reminded me of trying to adjust to using mirrors. But the car stalls, as usual when I start thinking about anything other than the clutch. Tom rolls his eyes and puts the handbrake on.

But it's true, I do seem to be able to reverse much better than I can go forward. We both consider the possibility of just going everywhere backwards. After a day of stalling at almost every junction I've come to, it has a certain appeal.

Wednesday Tom and I are both getting a little snappy with each other. "Use your bloody mirror," Tom hollers at me. "I did," I scream back, swerving round a car slightly more energetically than intended. "You just weren't looking." I always forget how much I hate being told what to do - it makes me very short-tempered indeed. Perhaps tiredness is also making me short-tempered. Yesterday's eight hours driving, after Monday's eight hours, have taken their toll. My shoulders ache, and I've got a funny nagging feeling in my left hip from pumping the clutch all day.

Doing reverse parking in the morning is fine but I've developed an infuriating habit of jerking my foot off the clutch in first. "There's that suspender belt again," says Tom, as we bounce out of a set of traffic lights, and then die on the turning. "I know," I snap irritably. Fortunately the Guardian photographer arrives for the afternoon, a very nice, calm man, whose presence makes us both behave ourselves. Although sensing him wincing from the back seat as I kangaroo hop through a green light is a little disconcerting - as is the hasty way in which he does up his seatbelt.

Thursday Tom and I are going to kill each other soon. I think he feels that his career and the reputation of BSM depends on him getting me through, and as a result it's worse than being out with my dad. And the quiet suppers for one with a good book and a single glass of red wine that had so much charm on Monday night are just boring now, especially as I'm desperate for someone to have a really good moan at.

I take a mock test today, and am so ridiculously tense that the tester actually talls me to stop the car and please, please, please relax. I keep hearing Tom's voice telling me what I'm doing wrong, but once I've let go of that the driving is fine - things click. But I still fail the test on six counts: it's well and truly dawned on me that I'm going to fail again tomorrow.

Friday I think we both feel a bit guilty for getting in such a snit yesterday. When Tom comes to pick me up this morning, he decides to take me off to the Welsh hills for a little run. The roads are beautiful - magical valleys and wonderful views, and my driving improves exponentially, the gears gliding up and down until I start to feel like Mika Hakkinen. We get back to town (the test is at 2.30) both well-pleased and glowing with the fresh air. "You'll be fine, love" says Tom. "I know I've hammered you a bit this week, but you're a nice little driver, so don't worry too much." I find out later that he's told everyone in the office he thinks I'm going to pass.

My stomach has bunched itself up, and I feel knackered at the same time. Tom waves me off, looking as nervous as I feel (I hope I don't let him down), and for the first five minutes, things seem OK. And then disaster strikes: one of my classic lurching gear changes means I lose control for a second. It's only a second, but that's long enough. I keep going, but feel so tired I can hardly sit upright. Eight hours of utter concentration on driving every day this week is making itself felt in every inch of my body.

Tom looks so disappointed. I get a bit teary for a second, then pull myself together. We go for a quick lemonade together, slumping disconsolately in the pub, trying to cheer each other up, and I give him a bottle of whisky for thanks. "Now love," he says affectionately. "I want you to book your next test as soon as possible, and you're sure to pass this time." We say goodbye and hug, and I promise to let him know what happens. The cabbie who takes me to the station failed his first time, he tells me. Which makes me feel a bit better. But, he tells me thoughtfully, his wife passed. Bother.

fields.headline: Eritrea: the forgotten famine
fields.trailText: Nearly a third of Eritrea's population will need food aid this year - but the international community has barely responded to the famine that stalks the small African state, a UN official said today.
fields.body:
Nearly a third of Eritrea's population will need food aid this year - but the international community has barely responded to the famine that stalks the small African state, a UN official said today.

Agricultural production in the key grain-producing highlands has been disrupted by a war with Ethiopia, its neighbour and former ally, while the situation has been aggravated by drought in the northern lowlands, a UN report said.

The report, prepared by the UN's children's agency, Unicef, for the weekend visit of the UN special envoy Catherine Bertini, said 850,000 Eritreans would need food aid out of a population of just 3m.

While attention has been focused on Ethiopia, where 7.7m are threatened with starvation, the World Food Programme (WFP) estimates that another 8m people are also in danger in nine other east African countries.

Ms Bertini, who heads the WFP, visited Giset, a village in northwestern Eritrea at the weekend, and said she was very disappointed with the lack of response to a WFP appeal earlier this month for £5m to feed 212,000 Eritreans.

"This is exactly the kind of situation we are talking about in much of the region," said Ms Bertini, who is on a week-long tour of Ethiopia, Djibouti, Eritrea and Kenya. "These people have been able to cope until now, but their own resources have almost gone."

The villagers of Giset have borne about three years of drought which have left them perilously short of food. But Giset's problems are not just about a lack of rain. The two-year-old border conflict with Ethiopia has magnified the villagers' problems and stretched their ability to cope to the limit.

Under normal circumstances, Eritrea's government buys surplus grain from the highlands and sells it cheaply to people of lowland villages such as Giset during the dry season. But this year, hundreds of thousands of people in the highlands have been forced from their homes because of the border war, and are now living in camps.

Tens of thousands of Eritrean nationals who have been deported from Ethiopia simply add to the mouths to feed. The surplus has disappeared.

"The people who were producing the food are now themselves reliant on food aid," a UN official said. The effect of the war is a sensitive subject for a country which, since independence from Ethiopia in 1993, has always prided itself on its self-reliance. Eritrea's economy, which used to depend partly on trade with Ethiopia, is also in trouble after nearly two years of war. Because of the debilitating cost of the conflict on the tiny Red sea state, the government has little money left.

"The government is not able to purchase whatever food is there, and what it does have it is using to feed people at the front," the UN official said. The net result of drought and the government's inability to respond is that the price of the staple food, sorghum, has doubled since August last year.

fields.headline: Protests in Washington
fields.standfirst: Demonstrators have disrupted the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Washington. Mark Tran explains what the protests are all about.
fields.trailText: Demonstrators have disrupted the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Washington. We explain what the protests are all about.
fields.body:
Who are the protesters?
A coalition of about 50 groups, from environmentalists to trade unions, student organisations to Aids activists. The groups, which include American Federation of Labour, Friends of the Earth, United Steelworkers of America, United Students Against Sweatshops and Act-Up, are protesting under the umbrella of Mobilisation for Global Justice.

As in the protests against the World Trade Organisation (WTO) in Seattle last year, the demonstrators in Washington had weeks of training and appeared to be well-organised. But unlike Seattle police, those in Washington responded quickly to attempts by protesters to disrupt the meetings, and have been mostly successful in keeping the demonstrations under control.

What are they protesting about?
Pretty much the same issues as at the WTO summit. The protesters accuse the IMFand the World Bank of pursuing policies that favour big corporations while squeezing workers. Most of the world's most impoverished countries have suffered under IMF/World Bank programmes, they argue, with rising debt levels, increasing unemployment, more poverty and environmental devastation.

What does the IMF say about world economic development? The IMF says the past 100 years have seen a huge increase in economic output, with goods and services exceeding everything that was produced between the dawn of time and 1900. But inequality between the world's richest and poorest regions has also increased dramatically. Output per capita in Africa is lower today than it was in the rich countries in 1900, the IMF says.

How do the World Bank and the IMF defend themselves against the protesters' accusations?
Michael Moore, the director general of the WTO, said: "Blaming the World Bank for poverty is a bit like blaming the Red Cross for starting world wars one and two."

The World Bank admits that it has in the past focused too much on how much money it could lend to poor countries instead of the quality of the loans - a situation it says it is rectifying. The IMF says it steps in to help countries with financial difficulties.

Should these institutions get off so easily?
The World Bank and particularly the IMF have come under attack from economists as well as the street protesters. Joseph Stiglitz, formerly the World Bank's chief economist at the Bank, asserted recently that when the IMF sends economic teams to help a country, they frequently lack experience of the country, and are more likely to have knowledge of its five-star hotels than the rural communities.

The IMF has also been criticised for pushing poorer countries to liberalise their financial systems in the 1980s, arguing that efficient markets will attract capital. The problem is that freer movement of capital can lead to a rapid inflow of funds or "hot money" for speculation rather than long-term investment.

Are any other institutions at fault?
While calling the IMF a "flawed institution", Seth Amgott of Oxfam also blamed the US congress for holding up plans to reduce debt to poor countries. "The US congress is the biggest obstacle to funding debt relief," he said. Congress has yet to approve the US administration's request for the money it will need to pay America's share of the debt-reduction programme being promoted by the World Bank and the IMF.

Did anybody see any humour in the protests?
Asked if any of the protest slogans had caught his eye, Laurent Fabius, the French foreign minister, said: "There were two slogans, 'Death to capitalism', which is a large subject all by itself, and 'Down with Red Meat.' Of course,there is no connection in my mind between the two."

The IMF has also been criticised for pushing poorer countries to liberalise their financial systems in the 1980s, arguing that efficient markets will attract capital. The problem is that freer movement of capital can lead to a rapid inflow of funds or "hot money" for speculation rather than long-term investment. Are any other institutions at fault? While calling the IMF a "flawed institution", Seth Amgott of Oxfam also blamed the US congress for holding up plans to reduce debt to poor countries. "The US congress is the biggest obstacle to funding debt relief," he said. Congress has yet to approve the US administration's request for the money it will need to pay America's share of the debt-reduction programme being promoted by the World Bank and the IMF. Did anybody see any humour in the protests? Asked if any of the protest slogans had caught his eye, Laurent Fabius, the French foreign minister, said: "There were two slogans, 'Death to capitalism', which is a large subject all by itself, and 'Down with Red Meat.' Of course,there is no connection in my mind between the two." Useful links Mobilisation of Global Justice International Monetary Fund World Bank Larry Elliott on the IMF

fields.headline: Disgruntled of Hampstead
fields.standfirst: The editor's out, redundancies loom and policy changes are on the cards.  Claire Armitstead  on dark days at her former paper
fields.trailText: The editor's out, redundancies loom and policy changes are on the cards. Claire Armitstead on dark days at her former paper.
fields.body:
Devotees of the 140-year-old Ham & High responded to the news as they have responded many times over the years - with a letter-writing blitz by the great and the good. One of the first was signed by all 59 members of Camden council. So began the first local campaign in living memory that the Ham & High (the Hampstead & Highgate Express) itself will not be promoting in its pages.

What most appalled journalists at the weekly paper was the speed and brutality with which the axe came down. Matthew Lewin, who has worked for the north London paper for 27 years and took over as editor nearly six years ago, was summoned to St Albans, where the paper's management are based, to be told not only that he was redundant, but that he would only be allowed back into his office to clear his desk by appointment. His acting replacement is 29-year-old Ross Lydall, who had been editing the Ham & High's baby-sister title, The Highbury and Islington Express, since January.

Morale has been sinking for some time on the Ham & High which has already lost three editorial jobs in the past year. The 15 remaining journalists are now bracing themselves for more job cuts, and are upset by what they see as moves to cut overheads and drive the paper downmarket. A management memo said that the paper could "best achieve its true potential and deserved success by the introduction of new ideas and concepts which will more closely serve the needs of potential readers and advertisers".

In some ways the story of the Ham & High is a tale of the times. Its circulation has drifted down in the past decade. Some of its long-serving staff feel it lost heart with the retirement of Gerald Isaaman, editor for 25 years. Others look sadly back to the 1980s, when the paper left its mews offices in Hampstead Village for the bustle of Finchley Road, and later for the concrete jungle of Swiss Cottage. Yet the paper still has a devoted local following and it still makes a healthy profit.

The Ham & High has always been a paradox: founded and run on liberal principles, it has catered to its constituency with an impeccable political stroppiness. As long-time reader and contributor Michael Foot says: "It is a real independent paper that fights with the council and fights with just about anyone else." It has always refused to glam-up or dumb-down.

Its other great editorial strength has always been its devotion to books and the arts. When I joined in the early 80s, it was regarded as the only place to go for any young journalist with arty aspirations. No celebrity was too important to "do" the Ham & High.

Reporters who arrived from daily regionals en route for Fleet Street often complained at first that it was stuffy and self-satisfied, but would come to understand that its editorial policy chimed with the self-image of the area it represented.

Its scruples were sheltered by the profits made out of a hugely prosperous area: shortly after I joined, the first Hampstead house went through the £1m barrier; the pages were plump with property ads - as they are again today, after the lean years of the house price slump.

So what has gone wrong? Unfortunately for the "old" Ham & High, the delicate ecology of commerce and principle has been upset by a series of changes in ownership. Even in the "good old days", when it was part of the family-owned Home Counties Newspapers, there were grumbles that it was the spoilt child of the family. The grumbles became louder when it was floated on the stock market. Two years ago, after a tussle which went to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission, it was sold to Eastern Counties Newspapers, which recently devolved management of the paper to its newspapers division, Community Media Limited.

Though revenue is buoyant, its profit margins do not satisfy a company which runs 60 local newspapers, including 37 freesheets. "For years we've been fighting off the cost-cutters. They've now come in and decided this is it," said one senior staff member. "They've just looked at the figures and said we were underperforming. They look on everything as a percentage return on sales - which means that it pays to run papers on a shoestring."

The new model would seem to be the Highbury and Islington Express, the High & I, which is more "buzzy" than its parent paper and run by a smaller staff. CML declined to comment on Lewin's redundancy, which is being challenged by the NUJ. But Enzo Testa, CML managing director, said: "In line with the company's philosophy of continual change and improvement, we are adding more local news and sport to maintain the market position of the Hampstead & Highgate Express". As letters of outrage begin to pour in to ECN's Norwich headquarters, they may yet rue the day they crossed swords with the epistolatory classes.

fields.headline: Life after Greg
fields.standfirst: After just 11 weeks at the helm of Pearson TV and Channel 5, Richard Eyre is already keen to 'move on' - and reshape what he inherited from Greg Dyke. He tells  John Dugdale  about his plans for new genres, riskier programmes, and acquiring comedy indy Talkback
fields.trailText: After just 11 weeks at the helm of Pearson TV and Channel 5, Richard Eyre is already keen to 'move on' - and reshape what he inherited from Greg Dyke. He tells John Dugdale about his plans for new genres, riskier programmes, and acquiring comedy indy Talkback.
fields.body:
On the top floor of Pearson Television's HQ, a stone's throw from the electronic souk of London's Tottenham Court Road, only a huge Baywatch surfboard and a classy stereo system signal that Richard Eyre, not Greg Dyke, now occupies the boss's office. Eyre, who ran Capital Radio before his previous post as ITV chief executive, is a rock fan currently playing CDs of Steely Dan, Moby and Eels while plotting the next deal.

But, naturally, it's the garish orange surfboard which attracts photographer David Sillitoe as a potential prop when he arrives to take shots. Eyre, though, can see how that would look and wryly dissuades him, saying Pearson has "moved on".

Though playful and offhand, it's a revealing remark. After only 11 weeks in the twin jobs of chief executive of Pearson TV and chairman of Channel 5 - linked because the first is a major shareholder in the second - Eyre seems already keen to move on, to reshape what he's inherited from Dyke's spells in both posts: a producer and a broadcaster associated with the kind of cheap and cheerful television for export (some would say "schlock") that Baywatch epitomises. Perhaps to make a shift not unlike the classier rebranding of Jack Cohen's pile-'em-high Tesco by Cohen's successor, Ian MacLaurin.

At Channel 5, where industry observers forecast clashes with chief executive David Elstein and programming head Dawn Airey, he stresses that "the chemistry's fine, and anyway as chairman my role is not executive - Channel 5 is moving in the right direction, and I'll be guided by David and Dawn". Although he has talked of increasing Airey's puny budget, what's envisaged does not apparently go beyond Elstein's commitment to a less-than-spectacular hike from £120m pa to £150m pa over three years ("it's highly successful, and doesn't need emergency funds").

Asked what overall audience share he'd like to achieve - partly, of course, at the expense of ITV - Eyre replies that "that begs the question of how you shape Channel 5 going forward. At the moment it's very clearly branded, it's got on people's radar, it's feisty, it's fun, it's the enfant terrible of British television. And it's great to have a billion-pound company. But there's an interesting question of whether you move on from being the enfant terrible to the mainstream - whether you can change that and continue to grow."

It sounds like he favours that option? "Well, the other side to that argument would be that it has clear brand recognition, and if you change you could become bland, just an also-ran. I'm not in any way frustrated by that brand as it currently is. Channel 5's in very good shape, compared to... no, I won't say that." No prizes for guessing which other commercial channel he was about to compare it to.

"Feisty and fun" is one way of characterising Channel 5, but Airey herself celebratedly preferred "football and fucking", gleefully laying on movies for masturbators and factual series about porn. Isn't that starkly at odds with Eyre's own Christian values? "Yes." And the implications of that are... ? "People know what I stand for, and I wasn't appointed to be heavy-handed, to swirl in and insist on what should be done. There was material at ITV that was not to my personal tastes." At 5, though, some of it must be really repugnant? "Yes. But it never happened at ITV that I said I couldn't allow something. David Liddiment [director of programmes] gave me early warnings, and I can't remember that happening.

"But, anyway, I'm not heading up the channel. I'll be a light-touch, low-profile chairman, like... can you put a name to my predecessor?" Erm, no. "Well, there you are. He was called Remy. Remy's my role model."

Eyre can be more definite about his plans for Pearson, where in his four-year stint as boss Dyke turned the TV arm into a company claiming to be the world's largest independent entertainment producer, adding to the Thames portfolio (The Bill, This Is Your Life, Des O'Connor) by acquiring Grundy (Neighbours), Alomo (Goodnight Sweetheart, Dirty Work) and Baywatch's US makers.

"We're building on a base of great strength in drama and entertainment, especially gameshows," he says. "That's not going to be thrown away, but I'd like us also to be represented in other genres. For example, a key challenge is engaging young people, who have so many competing leisure options and are the least 'loyal' viewers. A phenomenon like Ali G is very hard to create, but it can build very fast and it's very important to free-to-air broadcasters.

"There's programming for children, who are the next least loyal group, which involves getting licensing and merchandising right as well as the programmes. And people in this country may say docu-soaps are dead, but broadcasters worldwide still have voracious appetites for them."

Pearson's UK output has so far been focused on BBC1, ITV and Channel 5 (Night Fever, Family Affairs), so its likely next acquistion is significant. Talkback specialises in offbeat BBC2/C4 comedy such as Big Train, Smack the Pony, Jam and the 11 O'Clock Show, with BBC1's They Think It's All Over a rare mass channel commission. The indy's boss Peter Fincham told his staff on Friday that he is now negotiating exclusively with Pearson and expects agreement.

Eyre is more guarded, but inspired to flights of metaphor by his enthusiasm for a company he calls "a bit of a peach". Will they move into Pearson's HQ? "No, I don't think so. The danger is if you take the unique culture they've created and squash it with your corporate fatness. The challenge is to give them the resources they may currently lack, but not to create a kind of soup and pour that culture into your own, losing its specialness. What you want is, um, two dishes, not a stew."

Do this potential deal and the advance into new genres signal a strategic break away from the Dyke years, when the output of the companies under the Pearson umbrella was typically high-volume, durable and exportable, but not exactly a byword for quality? "This may sound pedantic, but I balk at the word 'quality'. You can make high-volume stuff that has quality, and a series like The Bill is a great training ground for writers. But, beyond that, yes, one is talking about sometimes having shorter runs, especially in drama, and programmes that take bigger risks."

Any idle moments can be devoted to his third job, as director of strategy and development in the company formed by the recent merger of Pearson Television with CLT-Ufa, creating a north European behemoth with combined revenues of £3.8bn, higher than rival media giants such as Canal Plus, Kirch and BSkyB. Eyre sees "the quality of the fit" as the deal's big attraction: Pearson is predominantly a producer, while CLT-Ufa is a broadcaster with 22 TV channels and 18 radio stations.

There was speculation before Michael Green slipped into bed with Clive Hollick that Pearson might bid for Carlton, and the new monster company has far more clout should it want to make a play for one of ITV's Big Three. Would ownership rules allow it to? "We could, yes." Any plans? "I wouldn't rule it out. But this is a global enterprise and I don't want our thinking to be UK-centric. The great strategic focus will be north America, where Pearson already has a foothold."

Meanwhile, there's the task of preparing for possible flotation, and picking a name for the would-be "global powerhouse": in the short term the businesses will be pooled in a holding company called Audiofina, but that sounds too much like a petrochem firm, and adding yet more initials to CLT-Ufa's equally underwhelming monicker is only a "default option". So drop Eyre a line, if you've got any ideas - unless you're one of the company branding wizards who came up with such inspired wheezes as Diageo and Chorus.

fields.headline: Border controls
fields.standfirst: Overlooked for years, plucky Border TV has suddenly found itself in the sights of the media big guns. David Teather  reports
fields.trailText: Overlooked for years, plucky Border TV has suddenly found itself in the sights of the media big guns. David Teather reports.
fields.body:
For most of the nation, Border Television remains fondly remembered for producing ITV's Mr & Mrs. That long-running gameshow apart, it was often regarded in the industry as something of a joke - the region that had more sheep than people (around 650,000).

It's a strange beast, unreplicated by the BBC, and often referred to as the no man's land of ITV. It covers the largely rural area around the borders between England and Scotland, plus the Isle of Man. The station has always drawn criticism, particularly from Scots who complain of being force fed English-oriented programming.

Border, which has held the franchise unopposed since 1961, was one of just three remaining independent ITV companies. The only others to have avoided being swallowed up are the even smaller Channel and Ulster. But in the past four weeks, it has at last enjoyed its time in the sun - although, sadly, because of its radio business which is less than five years old.

While the main event is staged elsewhere, the fate of Border TV is being fought over no less fiercely.

Directors from Scottish Radio Holdings were meeting at the weekend to decide whether they should come back to Border with a third offer after Capital waded in with an agreed bid which valued the business at £146m last Thursday. Insiders claim that Chrysalis is still not entirely out of the frame either.

Border chief executive Paul Corley accepts the company's fate: "There is intense pressure to consolidate in both the TV and radio worlds and it would have been very difficult for Border to resist the forces of change," he said after spending Friday presenting the Capital deal to staff.

Scottish Radio began the proceedings five weeks ago with what it hoped might be a friendly approach. Chief executive Richard Findlay met Corley over a pint and the Border boss agreed to take the offer to his board. But Border's directors refused to entertain the bid and Scottish Radio, which had failed in a takeover approach to Border two years earlier, went hostile.

In a relatively short time, Border has built a valuable portfolio of radio assets which account for 40% of group revenues, up from 20% two years ago. It has four stations, including three on air under the Century brand and Sun FM in Sunderland, which together have a potential audience of 9.2m.

For Capital, it plugs holes across the north west, north east and midlands. Capital chief executive David Mansfield described the acquisition as the perfect deal: "We are a radio group and we want to grow our analogue business in the UK. This adds some very large licences with very good growth prospects."

The TV franchise is not what it once was. In the 80s, Lord Melvyn Bragg was running the show and the company was trying to carve itself a role as a programme maker. During a previous stint at the company as programme controller, Corley sold a number of shows to the network and Channel 4.

But with the introduction of quotas on the amount of airtime that needs to be filled by independent producers and the rest of the network getting bigger and wealthier, Border found itself squeezed out. Today it produces between just five and six hours a week, largely of local news. In a bow to the sensibilities of the new Scottish parliament, Border began splitting frequencies between England and Scotland to offer opt-outs in local programming.

Local newspaper business CN Group has demonstrated an admirable lack of dewy eyes. It has committed its 14% stake to Capital, as has Scudder Threadneedle Investments, which has around 7%. Border chairman James Graham was said to be keen to keep a role in the business, and leaving him in charge of the television arm is viewed by insiders as a possible palliative.

Mansfield says "it would be wrong to assume" that the TV franchise has simply been parked for 18 months or so until the other ITV companies are in a better position to do a deal - though he clearly has to say that to avoid a fire sale of the business. Analysts also point out that earnings would be diluted without the TV station because the radio stations are still largely at an early stage of their lives. But given Capital's stated ambition to be a pure radio company, it is difficult to see the company hanging onto the business for any length of time.

The natural home for Border is always seen as Granada which handles national advertising sales for the station and holds neighbouring franchises. While ITV's big three vie for supremacy, though, it is unlikely they would hamper themselves with more national audience share by acquiring Border - although the franchise's share of the national audience is only 0.5%.

Scottish Radio, which like Capital would add a series of neighbouring radio stations to its 15 franchises across Scotland, has also said it would retain the TV channel. The battle could yet be swayed in a different direction. Both bids have been muddied by the volatility of share prices across the sector. When Scottish Radio launched its bid for Border, Capital shares were worth more than £19 each. At the launch of its offer of 92 shares for each 100 Border shares it valued the target at £13.52 a share. By yesterday the offer was worth just £12.05 a share.

Scottish Radio's most recent offer was worth £12.20 per share at the market's close on Friday. The cash alternatives might be a better yardstick, and as of Friday, Capital, with £13 a share compared to the £12.75 for Scottish, still has the upper hand.

Insiders claim that Chrysalis is still not entirely out of the frame either. Border chief executive Paul Corley accepts the company's fate: "There is intense pressure to consolidate in both the TV and radio worlds and it would have been very difficult for Border to resist the forces of change," he said after spending Friday presenting the Capital deal to staff. Scottish Radio began the proceedings five weeks ago with what it hoped might be a friendly approach. Chief executive Richard Findlay met Corley over a pint and the Border boss agreed to take the offer to his board. But Border's directors refused to entertain the bid and Scottish Radio, which had failed in a takeover approach to Border two years earlier, went hostile. In a relatively short time, Border has built a valuable portfolio of radio assets which account for 40% of group revenues, up from 20% two years ago. It has four stations, including three on air under the Century brand and Sun FM in Sunderland, which together have a potential audience of 9.2m. For Capital, it plugs holes across the north west, north east and midlands. Capital chief executive David Mansfield described the acquisition as the perfect deal: "We are a radio group and we want to grow our analogue business in the UK. This adds some very large licences with very good growth prospects." The TV franchise is not what it once was. In the 80s, Lord Melvyn Bragg was running the show and the company was trying to carve itself a role as a programme maker. During a previous stint at the company as programme controller, Corley sold a number of shows to the network and Channel 4. But with the introduction of quotas on the amount of airtime that needs to be filled by independent producers and the rest of the network getting bigger and wealthier, Border found itself squeezed out. Today it produces between just five and six hours a week, largely of local news. In a bow to the sensibilities of the new Scottish parliament, Border began splitting frequencies between England and Scotland to offer opt-outs in local programming. Local newspaper business CN Group has demonstrated an admirable lack of dewy eyes. It has committed its 14% stake to Capital, as has Scudder Threadneedle Investments, which has around 7%. Border chairman James Graham was said to be keen to keep a role in the business, and leaving him in charge of the television arm is viewed by insiders as a possible palliative. Mansfield says "it would be wrong to assume" that the TV franchise has simply been parked for 18 months or so until the other ITV companies are in a better position to do a deal - though he clearly has to say that to avoid a fire sale of the business. Analysts also point out that earnings would be diluted without the TV station because the radio stations are still largely at an early stage of their lives. But given Capital's stated ambition to be a pure radio company, it is difficult to see the company hanging onto the business for any length of time. The natural home for Border is always seen as Granada which handles national advertising sales for the station and holds neighbouring franchises. While ITV's big three vie for supremacy, though, it is unlikely they would hamper themselves with more national audience share by acquiring Border - although the franchise's share of the national audience is only 0.5%. Scottish Radio, which like Capital would add a series of neighbouring radio stations to its 15 franchises across Scotland, has also said it would retain the TV channel. The battle could yet be swayed in a different direction. Both bids have been muddied by the volatility of share prices across the sector. When Scottish Radio launched its bid for Border, Capital shares were worth more than £19 each. At the launch of its offer of 92 shares for each 100 Border shares it valued the target at £13.52 a share. By yesterday the offer was worth just £12.05 a share. Scottish Radio's most recent offer was worth £12.20 per share at the market's close on Friday. The cash alternatives might be a better yardstick, and as of Friday, Capital, with £13 a share compared to the £12.75 for Scottish, still has the upper hand.

webTitle: So do they all get $1m per show?

fields.headline: So do they all get $1m per show?
fields.standfirst: David Schwimmer's outburst last week over how much he  really earns in Friends is more than just the stuff of celebrity gossip.  Matt Wells  on the black art of phoney figures
fields.trailText: David Schwimmer's outburst last week over how much he really earns in Friends is more than just the stuff of celebrity gossip. Matt Wells on the black art of phoney figures
fields.body:
When Hollywood stars feel the need to whinge in public about a particularly fanciful tabloid tale, they usually turn to shockjock Howard Stern. Given the lack of a British equivalent, Friends heart-throb David Schwimmer had to make do with BBC London Live last week when he found himself on the wrong side of the Atlantic during a week of wild speculation over the size of his pay packet.

"People get this idea that we are this group of spoilt actors demanding ridiculous amounts of money," he pleaded last week to the listeners of the radio station formerly known as GLR, from his chauffeur-driven limo. "It's all rumour."

Schwimmer was referring to the seemingly endless stream of stories about the renegotiation of the cast's contracts. Over the past six months or so, the amount of money allegedly being demanded by the actors has spiralled. The latest rumour, kicked off by the Hollywood Reporter newspaper and picked up by the tabloids here, has the cast demanding a staggering $1m per episode for the next series - a pretty steep price tag for twentysomething eye candy, even by US television standards. At the moment, they receive a paltry $95,000 per show. If they didn't get their way, the reports said, the cast would walk out and the show would be no more.

It is a feeding frenzy which shows no sign of abating - and, whether the studios like it or not, it does the show's popularity no harm. Nor is it just Friends: virtually all the top-rated TV shows in the US are the subject of wild stories in the showbiz papers, keeping their profile high and the viewing figures even higher. The future of David Duchovny as Fox Mulder on the X Files is the subject of intense speculation, and there is the added spice of his lawsuit against the studio which makes the cult sci-fi show, Fox.

But Friends tops the rumour pack: its hot combination of sexy stars and off-screen drama is too good to miss.

The studios deny that they have any hand in stirring the stories, which began at the start of the autumn season last September. The stars were signed up to a five-year deal which is now coming to a close with the current series. Warner Brothers, which makes the show, is desperate to conclude a deal - it is watched in 50 countries and has made $1bn in repeat fees in the US. NBC, which broadcasts Friends in the US and pays $5m an episode to Warner for the privilege, is also under intense pressure: it is to showcase its new autumn schedule to advertisers in New York on May 15, and if Friends is not part of the portfolio, it stands to lose out in advertising revenue.

Cynthia Littleton, the television editor of the Hollywood Reporter and author of the story which so incensed Schwimmer, says that the interest in the Friends negotiations is insatiable. Like the Ford workers' pay round in Britain during the 1970s, the Friends deal will set the standard to which actors on other shows will aspire. "All eyes are on the Friends renewal negotiations at the moment because it is such a hot show. What the Friends cast makes will set a new industry benchmark. I'm sure they will see their salaries double or triple."

As the deadline approaches, the stories get wilder. Low-level public relations officers, agents and studio hangers-on all claim to know the latest twist. But Littleton believes that the senior studio executives are feeling the pressure. "Knowing the people at Warner that I do, I think they would like nothing more than a moratorium on these stories. The more we write, the tenser the negotiations become. It is at a very sensitive stage, and they are in a fishbowl."

Joe Adalian, the television editor at rival magazine Variety, believes that the gossip is being perpetrated by a lot of people who claim to have an inside track, but have little real insight. "There is a lot of buzz out there, but there are a lot of people who don't know anything," he says.

But he concedes that practitioners of the black arts of public relations frequently have a hand in leaking stories to suit their own agenda. A network may want to play down the amount of money it is paying for a particular show; while an agency might want to ratchet up the value of one of its stars. "Everyone has a different agenda."

Such practices are not just confined to the US, however. Channel 4 and Sky One are the principal rivals to show the series in Britain - it currently gets a first airing on the satellite channel - and each is happy to sling off-the-record mud at the other. And when Nicky Campbell was in negotiations with the BBC to join the Newsnight programme, the deal was spun out of all proportion by his own public relations machine. Unsourced stories began to appear suggesting that the former disc jockey was to become a regular presenter, when in the end he simply presented a few audience debates.

As the Friends negotiation nears its climax, it seems certain that the stories will get ever-more fanciful. But Littleton is convinced that such is the value of the show to Warner and NBC that a deal is certain to be concluded. "They want to keep the series going and they know they are going to have to do it one way or another." Knowing the strength of their situation, the Friends stars' negotiators are tightening the screws. "The lawyers are being very savvy, as the clock ticks. The white knuckle ride will go right up to the second week of May."

fields.headline: One big happy family?
fields.standfirst: Decisions are being made behind closed doors this week which will affect the whole of the TV industry. What are the repercussions of ITV's merger mania?  Maggie Brown  sifts the evidence and unmasks the decision makers
fields.trailText: Decisions are being made behind closed doors this week which will affect the whole of the TV industry. What are the repercussions of ITV's merger mania? Maggie Brown sifts the evidence and unmasks the decision makers
fields.body:
On Friday, Labour peer Clive Hollick was finally summoned across the Thames to the ugly hulk of the Competition Commission in central London. Flanked by his top TV executives, he gave evidence on what everyone acknowledges is the landmark media test case of the year. His aim, naturally, was to persuade the panel of the sheer "win-win" logic behind the merger of his United News & Media with Carlton, proposed last November.

This £8.3bn deal would, remember, create a dominant ITV player - six contiguous ITV franchises from Nottingham to Cornwall, in the south, west, east and centre of England. A prize indeed.

Behind closed doors, Hollick was bound to seize the chance to put across his vision of breaking with what he sees as the frustratingly parochial, tribal and divided heritage of ITV. So it could punch its weight - under his direction naturally - in new media, on the world stage, just like the BBC.

As if there wasn't enough at stake already, Charles Allen of Granada, the third big force in ITV, muscled onto the pitch on January 8 with an enigmatic statement indicating that the company was minded to bid for either Carlton or United. Since then silence has fallen. The commission is taking the two merger proposals together, will grill Granada in May, but has yet to receive its fleshed-out case.

Meanwhile, the media industry is in turmoil. The outcome affects shareholdings in Channel 5, maybe GMTV, ITN, and the commercial interests of Channel 4, Flextech, BSkyB, OnDigital and the BBC.

But Hollick and Carlton's Michael Green as well as Allen are running smack up against two existing rules governing media concentration - at a delicate moment when a government white paper on communications and media ownership is being drafted for publication later this year.

One restricts any company to 15% of the total TV audience, and cannot be relaxed without new legislation. (In fact the two players can comply with it fairly easily.) Sophisticates Hollick and Green don't want to frighten the horses with talk of one ITV just yet: they are now arguing for a carved up "bi-polar" ITV, with Granada as a northern counterweight; an argument which, sources say, senior government figures seem inclined to listen to. The second, less robust restriction, the current focus of immense lobbying, imposes a 25% limit on the share of all TV advertising by any one owner.

The merger was referred to the commission in January: the report is to be completed on June 16. Some time in July, nine months after the deal surfaced, Hollick and Green should get their answer from trade secretary Stephen Byers - unless he decides (as with the current Vivendi/BSkyB inquiry) to sit on it.

Ten days ago the commission published a formal letter, setting out the issues it was addressing. It is fair to say that the document is providing comfort to all sides, especially a section floating the possibility of making 5% incremental rises to the 25% ceiling, thereby creating a device to allow some further concentration of ownership.

Much of March was devoted to ad industry lobbyists preparing and giving evidence. The commission has written to scores of agencies and advertisers. The advertisers, source of ITV's annual £1.8bn income, are the most obviously affected because the deal blatantly breaches the 25% undertaking (a United/Carlton merger would add up to a whopping 36%) and could spawn a monopoly reintroducing the power of the TV companies.

The IPA opposes the deal, but the advertisers, through their trade body, ISBA, are implacably hostile - and Hollick and Green failed to win them over during a month of intense wooing over the New Year.

Bob Wootton of ISBA says: "We at ISBA routinely seek meetings with the broadcasters. The trouble is, when you are used to being cold-shouldered, and then they are all over you like a rash, so very keen to persuade you of the siren benefits of their deal to UK media, my God, you think, 'they want it, but what's in it for us?' We had more contact with them in a week than we normally have over a year." A meeting in which Lord Hollick rhapsodised about leveraging from ITV into new media didn't help. "We were deeply suspicious," says Wootton. "We're rooted in the present."

Jim Marshall of the IPA adds this perspective: "ITV had an appalling 1990s, only salvaged in the last two years by [ex-chief executive] Richard Eyre. ITV was run by accountants in the 1990s. They made a hash of programming. There's a real issue here. Is a United News & Media with Carlton an attractive proposition? Will ITV forget about programming again? You need stability. Neither United nor Carlton are impressive programme suppliers."

The merger explains United and Carlton's efforts to talk up the value of their programming: it's why Carlton's production director Lord (Waheed) Alli was trumpeting its adaptation of The Railway Children in last week's Media Guardian, and enthusing about his plan to bring back Crossroads.

Why? Because the contribution of the two companies to ITV's schedule is dwarfed by the input of Granada, which makes 50% of networked programmes. Whether or not this is a "legacy" of the past, as United insists, the advertisers' instincts are correct: ITV would not function without Granada. So the would-be merger partners argue that Granada's big programme business should be factored into any assessment of network dominance.

"It's not so much about what share they have of ITV advertising, it's about control of ITV. We currently have a reasonable balance that works quite well." Marshall adds what a great many are thinking: "Everyone expected ITV to reduce to two [big companies]. But not quite yet."

And that's the crux. The regulators who police the rules know there is going to be change, and so do the merchant bankers who factor deals. The radio industry has big groups like GWR breathing fire because they are bang up against separate media concentration rules. Last week the Radio Authority's newish chairman and chief executive effectively said they were waiting to see what the Competition Commission said, and the government's reaction, to divine what degree of future media concentration is deemed politically acceptable.

But the sheer nerve of the ITV players still shocks hardened rivals. Should jumping the gun be a legitimate way of forcing de facto changes in public policy, before a full review conducted by parliament?

Last week, the ITC gave its formal response, asserting that the parliamentary process was "the most secure basis" for change. Yet it too sat on the fence, noting that it has been "clear for some time that the pressure for more radical concentration of channel three ownership would grow". Then the key point: "At this stage is it not easy to see how a convincing case could be made for increasing the present maximum percentage [of advertising share] from 25% to as much as 40%". It dubs this a "significant relaxation". Brave leadership this was not.

Another key to the Competition Commission's decision is its view of how important ITV is. When the ad sales limit was set in 1994, ITV took 74% of all television advertising. Now it is down to 60%. By 2003, the share will have declined further, to perhaps 57%. Channel 4 has told the Commission that the 25% threshold is right and 40%, "far too high". But it could probably live with 30%.

At the heart of this debate is whether ITV is still special, providing unique mass-market access. The advertisers say its strength is that it is the only channel which can reach three quarters of the population within a week, while using a combination of other channels would take three weeks. Where else, they ask, would you advertise the News of the World on a Saturday?

Among the debates going on behind closed doors is whether, in a world where AOL/Time Warner and Pearson/Bertelsmann have merged, a United-Carlton combination will become a home-grown champion. One of commercial TV's top executives snorted with indignation at the suggestion: "Strong players! They were tiddlers before, tiddlers afterwards. And the moment ITV becomes one nice neat channel is the moment it will be bought up by a big European player.

"The arguments about it being necessary to prepare British media companies for the world stage is total baloney. We heard the same arguments after the Carlton merger with Central six years ago. And what have they done? Export a few more programmes? ITV is run for cash. Very simply, all this merger is about is stripping out overheads and making perhaps an extra £40m of profit."

What's the betting on the outcome? Well, while it's hard to see a United-Carlton marriage getting total clearance, the summer could witness something else: either hostile takeovers, or a big round of horse-trading as franchises or shareholdings switch hands. For viewers, the danger is simple - that a bout of instability affects programme quality.

Decision makers

Chris Smith, 48. Secretary of state for culture.
Ed: Watford, Edinburgh, Cambridge, Harvard. Councillor, then MP, Islington; held Culture post since election. Keen that ITV takeovers should not reduce regional diversity. Asked ITC to rethink permission to axe News at Ten. Cambridge speech signalled likely relaxation in ITV content regulation in long-awaited broadcasting bill. Wants more mountaineering programmes.

Stephen Byers, 47. Secretary of state for trade and industry since 1998.
Ed: Chester, Liverpool. Law lecturer Newcastle Poly 1977-92, councillor from 1980. Robo-Blairite whose luck with dice continued with Peter Mandelson's exit from DTI, but could have thrown first snake after stunned reaction to BMW's Rover pull-out. No time for recreations.

Kate Mortimer, 53. Member of competition commission panel leading inquiry into merger.
Independent financial consultant, advising government on central Europe and Russia. Ed: Oxford. Rothschild banker, then ran Walker Books 1988-89. Only woman on panel; like other three - ex-Eurotunnel director Graham Corbett, solicitor Bobby Bertram, ex-civil servant Charles Henderson - lacks media expertise, although involved with version of Crossroads for Kurdistan.

James Purnell, 30. Broadcasting pointman at No 10.
Ed:Oxford. From Guildford, like policy unit wonkette Liz Lloyd and ex-Downing Street spin doctor Tim Allan. Spell at IPPR, worked with Blair from 1995, until poached by John Birt for BBC policy and planning post. Joined No 10 after election. Said to want safe Labour seat.

Ruth Mackenzie, 42. Special adviser to Chris Smith.
Ed: Sorbonne, Cambridge. Former theatre director and Arts Council apparatchik. Troubled period at Scottish Opera (criticised by all-party committee for "wholly inadequate" management). Joined Smith to shape arts policy; now involved in media policy, but no relevant form. Key Culture officials on broadcasting: Andrew Ramsay, Diana Kahn. Lobbyists say too many Culture players still getting up to speed.

Saul Greyman, 21. Shadowy civil servant at Culture.
Said to be drafting broadcasting white paper. Culture unable to confirm or deny that he read PPE at Oxford, plays football with Purnell, lives in Islington and watches Hollyoaks.

"The arguments about it being necessary to prepare British media companies for the world stage is total baloney. We heard the same arguments after the Carlton merger with Central six years ago. Councillor, then MP, Islington; held Culture post since election. Keen that ITV takeovers should not reduce regional diversity. Asked ITC to rethink permission to axe News at Ten. Cambridge speech signalled likely relaxation in ITV content regulation in long-awaited broadcasting bill. Wants more mountaineering programmes. Stephen Byers, 47. Secretary of state for trade and industry since 1998. Ed: Chester, Liverpool. Law lecturer Newcastle Poly 1977-92, councillor from 1980. Robo-Blairite whose luck with dice continued with Peter Mandelson's exit from DTI, but could have thrown first snake after stunned reaction to BMW's Rover pull-out. No time for recreations. Kate Mortimer, 53. Member of competition commission panel leading inquiry into merger. Independent financial consultant, advising government on central Europe and Russia. Ed: Oxford. Rothschild banker, then ran Walker Books 1988-89. Only woman on panel; like other three - ex-Eurotunnel director Graham Corbett, solicitor Bobby Bertram, ex-civil servant Charles Henderson - lacks media expertise, although involved with version of Crossroads for Kurdistan. James Purnell, 30. Broadcasting pointman at No 10. Ed:Oxford. From Guildford, like policy unit wonkette Liz Lloyd and ex-Downing Street spin doctor Tim Allan. Spell at IPPR, worked with Blair from 1995, until poached by John Birt for BBC policy and planning post. Joined No 10 after election. Said to want safe Labour seat. Ruth Mackenzie, 42. Special adviser to Chris Smith. Ed: Sorbonne, Cambridge. Former theatre director and Arts Council apparatchik. Troubled period at Scottish Opera (criticised by all-party committee for "wholly inadequate" management). Joined Smith to shape arts policy; now involved in media policy, but no relevant form. fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Darren Johnson
fields.trailText: Newspapers: Since I was 19 years old, it's always been the Guardian and the Observer on Sundays. I also read the London Evening Standard. You can't get by in the campaign [for London mayor] without it. I don't like the tabloids. Very occasionally I buy the Telegraph but I get really angry reading the letters page. It's still a shock to the system that people think like that.
fields.body:
Newspapers: Since I was 19 years old, it's always been the Guardian and the Observer on Sundays. I also read the London Evening Standard. You can't get by in the campaign [for London mayor] without it. I don't like the tabloids. Very occasionally I buy the Telegraph but I get really angry reading the letters page. It's still a shock to the system that people think like that.

Magazines: I tend to buy the Big Issue each week and sometimes Red Pepper or New Statesman if I've got a long train journey. I always read my partner's copy of London Cyclist, which is very good.

Books: I like political biographies, but haven't had time to read for months. I started Alan Clark's History of the Tory Party but didn't finish it. For light reading, it's Noddy Holder's autobiography: I'm a closet fan. But my all-time favourite author has to be David Lodge.

Films: Haven't seen anything in ages actually. But my favourite film is Monty Python's Life of Brian.

TV: I watch news, comedy and soaps. If I'm home by 10.30pm, I watch Newsnight. If I get the odd evening break from the campaign I'll watch Coronation Street and EastEnders. I like Ali G. I watched the opening of the recent BBC drama, Nature Boy, and thought it was good, but I never got past the first episode. My schedule is just too hectic.

Radio: If I'm working from home I like to listen to London stations such as LBC, News Direct and the new BBC station London Live. If I want to listen for pleasure, I listen to music: I really like Supergrass and Blur, and old 70s rock such as the Rolling Stones and Pink Floyd.

Ads: You would expect a Green to say they are not into advertising and I genuinely don't think I am influenced by adverts. There are not many I find memorable except the old Levi jeans adverts, with the scantily clad young man who strips off in the launderette. But I do think that all car ads should carry a health warning - the advertising promotes speed and machismo but doesn't show the environmental damage.

Multimedia : I'm an absolute fan. I have used it far more for this campaign than ever before. It's really encouraging that journalists, pressure groups and members of the public have downloaded details of the Green party's key policies from our campaign site. So many important decisions are now made by email - which wasn't the case before. I've made amazing use of the internet.

 Darren Johnson is the Green party candidate in the forthcoming London mayoral election

fields.headline: We eat Today for lunch
fields.standfirst: Last week, he was named the best radio contributor ahead of his Today programme rivals.  Nick Clarke  of the World at One explains why his programme is Radio 4's true flagship
fields.trailText: Last week, he was named the best radio contributor ahead of his Today programme rivals. Nick Clarke of the World at One explains why his programme is Radio 4's true flagship.
fields.body:
Flagships do not set sail alone. Other vessels are needed before battle can be successfully joined. So when a commentator refers to the Today programme as Radio 4's flagship, the rest of us are not downhearted. There is still plenty of work to be done when Messrs Humphrys and Naughtie traipse past the World at One's morning meeting on their way to breakfast, and a day (as I imagine it) of gentle relaxation preparing for fatherhood or spent in a box at the Royal Opera House.

Indeed, the World at One offers its presenter many professional and personal advantages. Being able to sleep through the dawn chorus is one obvious benefit: at 6am, I can still growl at the radio through my stubble, rather than attempting to frame thoughtful and coherent sentences in the studio.

Less selfishly, there is a real sense of teamwork and common purpose involved in devising, constructing and delivering a programme in the space of a few hours - without the pre-planning of an overnight production team like the Today Programme. It is an intense and concentrated experience.

The World at One is the programme most people turn to for a proper review - in the middle of the news day - of all the relevant facts, in order to hold politicians and others to account; rather as a barrister might build up a case, drawing on expert witnesses where necessary.

On a typical day last week, we dissected the decision not to site a £500m science project in the north-west of England - and also the Foreign Office efforts to persuade Premier Oil to pull out of Burma. In both cases, the minister responsible was then subjected to forensic questioning on the basis of the evidence, very much in the Robin Day tradition.

This sequential approach is highly satisfying. The Today Programme - needing to serve an audience which changes frequently over three hours - is bound to be far more episodic.

It also has to look ahead to the coming day, which sometimes allows ministers to discuss the principles behind a policy initiative before the details have been released. They can then fall back on that stock defensive phrase: "You wouldn't expect me to answer that until parliament has been informed..."

By lunchtime, it has become much clearer which of the diary stories deserve further investigation, but our approach does not endear us to political planners and strategists. They have their own agendas which do not invariably coincide with ours. The man we now know to be Alastair Campbell - PMOS to his friends (Prime Minister's official spokesman) - regards any approach by the World at One as inherently malign. Lobby correspondents who raise questions in Downing Street on our behalf are likely to be greeted with laughter: "That sounds like another piece of Wato nonsense," would be an unusually polite response. (Wato is our everyday acronym: it rhymes, more or less, with Bertie Wooster's "What Ho!" It was Charlie Whelan, Gordon Brown's erstwhile sidekick, who once amended the acronym to read "Wankers at One", and I still have the T-shirt to prove it.)

Needless to say, Campbell has not rushed to proffer the Prime Minister for interview on our programme. Although I spoke to Tony Blair frequently before the election, I have been vouchsafed just one interview since May 1997.

And therein lies a tale. Adopting our normal approach, we thought we should decide our own news priorities each day of the 1997 campaign, and matters came to a head over the issue of air traffic. At the first hint that Labour in government might decide to carry out a Tory plan to privatise Britain's air traffic control system, we despatched a reporter in pursuit of Andrew Smith, the shadow minister who had so forcefully - and so recently - declared that Labour would never do any such thing.

The subsequent broadcast outraged Campbell and helped to define what has remained, ever since, a highly charged relationship with Downing Street. Hostilities break out sporadically. In July 1998, for example, the PMOS was writing to the Times, explaining why some ministers were opting for "Sofa TV" such as Richard and Judy in preference to programmes like Today, Newsnight and the World at One. "Very few people take the World at One seriously," he said, "so regular appearances by ministers are unlikely."

In the event, hardly a day goes by without the appearance of one - or more - ministers on World at One. Daily newspapers monitor our output assiduously, and we have even inspired cartoonists such as Matt and Steve Bell. So we continue to worry away at the stories we think are important, whatever efforts are made to deflect us, because that's what listeners say they want. The award from the Voice of the Listener and Viewer suggests we're on the right track, even if Alastair Campbell is never likely to vote for me.

webTitle: It's not the IMF: it's the policies, stupid

fields.headline: It's not the IMF: it's the policies, stupid
fields.standfirst: Protesters' calls to abolish global economic institutions risk leaving the world even more at the mercy of untrammelled capitalism, says economics reporter Charlotte Denny
fields.trailText: Monday, 1pm: Protesters' calls to abolish global economic institutions risk leaving the world even more at the mercy of untrammelled capitalism, says economics reporter Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
It was dubbed the battle of Seattle East by the demonstrators. And sure enough, the television pictures of the protests surrounding the weekend's meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund were a re-run of the demonstrations which rocked the World Trade Organisation's gathering in the west coast city last November. A rag-tag coalition of environmentalists, Third World activists, anarchists and trade unionists facing ranks of baton-wielding police had succeeded in if not actually shutting down the IMF, then at least preventing some of the participants - including the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius - from getting to its main spring meeting.

For multilateral organisations who are more used to appearing on the City pages than heading the Nine O'Clock news, this has all come as a bit of a shock. The mandate of the Fund and the Bank is to keep the world economy on course and promote third world development. Normally their pronouncements attract minimal interest from outsiders aside from financial journalists and market analysts. The accusation that they are widening the global gap between rich and poor - let alone the more extreme charge that they are killing poor people - is met with baffled incomprehension. But even their critics are somewhat dismayed by the calls from the protestors for the abolition of the two organisations.

Aid agencies like Oxfam, who have spent years lobbying the Bank and the Fund to relax their rigid policies for economic reform in the developing world, say the protestors are in danger of throwing out the baby with the bathwater. In an increasingly integrated world economy, the institutions which are supposed to keep the system on track are more important than ever. The Bank and the Fund can be rightly criticised for their economic prescriptions they have foisted on the third world, but the solution is not to scrap them but to reform them. In other words, it's not the institutions, it's the policies, stupid.

The opposition to the Bank and the Fund has created some strange bedfellows even by the standards of US politics. Anarchists on the left have been joined by the neo-liberals on the right in their call for the abolition of the institutions designed to manage the world economy. The right wants to let market forces rip untrammelled by any kind of global regulation. If this weekend's protests cast a spotlight on the Bank and Fund's activities and brings a little humility to their approach, then the protestors will have achieved something. But there is a real danger that if they destroy the multilateral organisations, they may end up making the world a safer place for global capitalism.
