fields.headline: Barca are humbled again
fields.trailText: SPAIN
fields.body:
SPAIN

After their 3-1 mauling at Chelsea, and successive 3-0 thrashings by lowly Mallorca and Atletico Madrid, Barcelona's coach Louis van Gaal held an emergency meeting with the players to discuss the club's problems. In his usual blunt way, he accused them of being solely responsible for the spate of bad results and dropped four of his star players (Puyol, Gabri, Abelardo and Kluivert) for the match against Real Oviedo.

It made not one iota of difference. Barca suffered their third successive 3-0 defeat at the hands of the relegation-threatened Oviedo, and are now third in the Primera Liga. The home side dominated the first half and deservedly took a 1-0 lead just after the half-hour through a header from Dely Valdes. Barca improved after the break but found themselves 2-0 down on 55 minutes through Pompei, Valdes beating the static Bara defence late on to finish the job.

One consolation for Barca is that league leaders Deportivo La Coruna were also beaten, succumbing to a surprise 2-0 defeat at Rayo Vallecano. Michel Sanchez scored the first from the penalty spot after 23 minutes and Jordi Ferron clinched all three points for the Madrid side.

Real Madrid moved into second place with a fortunate 1-0 win at Real Zaragoza. The home side dominated a drab game for long periods, but five minutes from time sub Nicholas Anelka was controversially adjudged to have been fouled in the area, and Raul slotted home the penalty.

Roberto Carlos missed the match with a knee injury and looks doubtful for the Champions League clash against Manchester United on Wednesday night. "I always want to play but the injury has got worse," he admitted. "The problem is that we're playing too many games. No-one can cope with this amount of football and travel. I really need a month to rest the knee but my plan is to be ready in three days."

Deportivo are five points clear of Real and Barcelona with just five games remaining.

ITALY

After barely getting a game during his time at Sheffield Wednesday, Darko Kovacekic is now one of the hottest strikers in Europe. His two second-half strikes in a 2-1 win at Inter Milan yesterday helped Juventus stretch their lead at the top of Serie A to five points.

The first, a superb lob over Angelo Peruzzi followed good work from Filippo Inzaghi and Antonio Conte, while the second was a fierce header from a Conte cross.

The result left Inter feeling hard done by after they dominated the game for long periods. Javier Zanetti had a 25 yard drive superbly saved by Edwin van der Saar; and Clarence Seedorf and Alvaro Recoba also wasted good chances. Seedorf eventually reduced the arrears with seven minutes remaining, but Juve held on.

Meanwhile Lazio's scudetto ambitions look to be over after their amazing 3-3 draw away at Fiorentina. Gabriel Batistuta opened the scoring midway through the first half, but two goals in three minutes from Pavel Nedved and Alen Boksic put Lazio ahead. Enrico Chiesa then made it 2-2 to set up an incredible last ten minutes.

In the 83rd minute Sinisa Mihajlovic missed a penalty, and it looked like Lazio had squandered their opportunity. But then - incredibly - with just a minute left Lazio were awarded another spot-kick. This time Mihajlovic made no mistake.

The game looked over, but deep into injury time Batistuta crashed home the equaliser.

Parma moved into third after scoring two goals in the last minute to beat Venezia 3-1 at the Tardini stadium. Igor Budan put the visitors in front after 19 minutes but Argentinian striker Hernan Crespo quickly equalised. The match looked to be pittering out into a draw, but the two late strikes from Crespo and Marco Di Vaio snatched the three points.

GERMANY

The chances of Bayern Munich emulating Manchester United's treble suffered a severe blow when they were beaten 2-1 by 1860 Munich on Saturday.

The Bundesliga's top scorer Martin Max put 1860 ahead after 22 minutes after he capitalised on a defensive mix-up - but seven minutes later German international Mehmet Scholl equalised with a stunning free-kick. Just before half time 1860 secured all three points when Jen Jeremies put through his own net. Bayern were also left to rue an injury to Steffen Effenberg, which could keep their playmaker out of action for a month.

Bayer Leverkusen moved three points clear at the top with a convincing 4-1 win against lowly Arminia Bielefield. Stefan Beinlich opened the scoring after only 11 minutes and further goals from Ulf Kirsten, Michael Ballack and Paulo Rink put Bayer 4-0 ahead. Bielefeld managed a consolation when Silvo Meissner scored from the penalty spot in the 65th minute.

fields.headline: Sir Giles Shaw
fields.standfirst: Popular one-nation Tory minister, sacked by Thatcher and denied cabinet support for the speakership
fields.trailText: Popular one-nation Tory minister, sacked by Thatcher and denied cabinet support for the speakership.
fields.body:
Tiny, genial Sir Giles Shaw, the Conservative MP for Pudsey from 1974 to 1997, who has died of a stroke aged 68, was probably the most popular man of his time in the Commons. This might have been put beyond question in 1992, when many on all sides wanted him as speaker, but the Tory cabinet insisted on backing his senior, Peter Brooke. Consequently, 74 Tory MPs, led by John Biffen, voted for Betty Boothroyd as the first woman speaker.

Sir Giles's popularity derived both from his warm, witty, affable personality and his role as a consensus-seeker, in the best tradition of one-nation Toryism. It was certainly his lack of right- wing zealotry and europhobia that led to his otherwise inexplicable sacking by Mrs Thatcher in 1987, with the consolation of a knighthood. He had played the game as a loyal Tory, restricting his deviations to backing joining the ERM, and opposing capital punishment and curbs on abortion.

Because everyone agreed he had proved himself a shrewd and highly skilled minister in five departments, it was thought remarkable that he did not seem to bear a grudge for his unfair dismissal, when he should have been promoted to the cabinet. Fellow Tory MPs showed their admiration by electing him treasurer of the 1922 Committee the following year.

Born in York, Shaw was the son of a qualified motor engineer in fiercely partisan Yorkshire. It was probably education which broadened Giles's viewpoint beyond that of his party and Commons colleague, the Yorkshire Thatcherite Marcus Fox. He went to Sedbergh school and St John's College, Cambridge, joining its Conservative association and becoming president of the Cambridge union. On returning to York, he became an executive of the confectionery firm Rowntee Mackintosh, rising to advertising manager, then marketing director. After fighting hopeless Hull West in 1966, he defeated Keith Hampson for selection for safe Pudsey, in the Leeds suburbs, after Joe Hiley retired.

Arriving in parliament in March 1974, when Labour under Harold Wilson unexpectedly returned to power, Shaw did not have a chance to show his abilities until Mrs Thatcher made him parliamentary under-secretary for industry in Northern Ireland in 1979. He helped slim down Harland and Wolff, but was over-optimistic about De Lorean's car scam.

In 1981, he followed Marcus Fox as under-secretary for environment. He stuck to the Thatcherite line, abolishing the Noise Advisory Council, resisting better access for the disabled to public buildings and insisting that dumping sewage at sea was acceptable. He also disclosed that licensed brothels and sex shops were under consideration. But he did make chimes on ice cream vans a nuisance, and resisted the privatisation of the Ordnance Survey.

His brief stint as energy under-secretary included the beginning of the miners' strike and his stunt of swimming off the coast at Sellafield to demonstrate the safety of nearby bathing waters. He was promoted to minister of state at the Home Office in 1984, taking over from Douglas Hurd the Police and Criminal Justice Bill, whose stop-and-search provision he defended. He refused to rule out advertising on the BBC, and reduced the levy on ITV companies. But he resisted pressure to birch football hooligans.

After replacing Peter Morrison as minister for industry in 1986, Shaw showed an aversion to intervention. He was one of three ministers at the Departyment of Trade and Industry who opposed its secretary of state, Paul Channon, when he wanted to protect Pilkington from takeover. He also refused to guarantee a longterm steelmaking future for Ravenscraig, and relaxed the ban on alcoholic drink in directors' boxes.

Sacked in the wake of Mrs Thatcher's third victory in 1987, he urged flexibility on the poll tax and opposed the freezing of child benefit. He was a member of the 1922 Committee delegation in 1989 that urged Mrs Thatcher to moderate her stance.

In 1990, Shaw became a director of British Steel and Yorkshire Water - after strongly supporting privati sation as "the natural way to improve the water supply". The Friends of Water group that he led campaigned for immunity from prosecution for polluting water and freedom to meet the costs of new pollution standards from higher charges.

The 1992 refusal of the cabinet to back him for speaker took the shine off parliament for him. He was appoined to the prestigious liaison committee in 1992, and the privileges and intelligence and security committees in 1994. But he announced he would not stand again and retired at the 1997 general election.

Shaw leaves his wife of 38 years, Dione, and their son and two daughters.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: A brimming cup of gossip, with a lump of two of fact
fields.trailText: Daily Star Aston Villa have joined the chase for Ruud van Nistelrooy and hope to use his PSV strike partner Luc Nilis as bait. Nilis has already agreed to join Villa on a Bosman in the summer and he told the press: "I'm excited about playing for Villa, and if Ruud were to come too, that would be fantastic."
fields.body:
Daily Star Aston Villa have joined the chase for Ruud van Nistelrooy and hope to use his PSV strike partner Luc Nilis as bait. Nilis has already agreed to join Villa on a Bosman in the summer and he told the press: "I'm excited about playing for Villa, and if Ruud were to come too, that would be fantastic."

West Ham, Leicester and Huddersfield are all keen to sign Temuri Ketsbaia from Newcastle this summer. The oddball Georgian will be available for £1m.

Leeds' expected summer pursuit of Robbie Fowler could spell the end of Alan Smith's Elland Road career. David O'Leary will offload the England Under-21 international if Fowler agrees to a move to Yorkshire.

The Mirror Leeds have opened negotiations to take Olivier Dacourt to Elland Road. The £7m-rated former Everton star, currently playing for Lens, is also a target for Arsenal.

Planet football Bobby Robson was in Portugal this weekend in the company of three agents, heightening speculation that he is attempting to sign the Portuguese international winger Sa Pinto this summer.

Rangers skipper Lorenzo Amoruso could be a summer target for Bayern Munich. Amoruso has stressed that he would only leave Ibrox for London or Italy, but a £5m offer from the German champions could change his mind.

Daily Mail Guus Hiddink has dropped a hint that he may still become Celtic's new manager. Hiddink has been offered a new contract at his current club Real Betis, but yesterday he said: "Celtic have a big history, the culture of the club is huge - not just in Glasgow, but all over the world."

Ipswich's highly-rated goalkeeper Richard Wright will stay at the club if they achieve promotion to the Premiership this season. "The ideal place for me to play is the Premier League," the 22-year-old said yesterday, "but, hopefully, I will be there with Ipswich next season."

Teamtalk Sheffield Wednesday captain Peter Atherton is being linked with a move to Manchester City should the Owls be relegated.

webTitle: Livingstone pledges fares freeze in manifesto for mayor

fields.headline: Livingstone pledges fares freeze in manifesto for mayor
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone's website
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone, the frontrunner in the race for London's first elected Mayor, launched his manifesto on the internet today, promising a four-year freeze on Tube fares and a commitment not to sell off the Underground network.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, the frontrunner in the race for London's first elected Mayor, launched his manifesto on the internet today, promising a four-year freeze on Tube fares and a commitment not to sell off the Underground network.

Mr Livingstone, the MP for Brent East, also pledged to forge close alliances with the Green party to set targets for air, water and noise pollution in the capital. If he wins, Mr Livingstone has hinted he may ask a member of the Greens to act as his deputy. At the weekend, Mr Livingstone said he hoped that the Green party would do well in the elections on May 4.

Mr Livingstone, running as an independent after his expulsion from the Labour party, also intends to ban political lobbyists from the Greater London Authority building and from meeting members of his staff.

Today's launch is a chance for Mr Livingstone to refocus the campaign on policy issues. Although his opinion poll lead over his main rivals - the Conservative Steve Norris, Labour's Frank Dobson and Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer - remains strong, Mr Livingstone has been damaged in recent weeks by a series of disclosures about his finances and controversial remarks.

Last week, Mr Livingstone told the New Musical Express that capitalism killed more people every year than Hitler. He also suggested that consideration should be given to the decriminalisation of ecstasy and cannabis.

In an opinion poll last week, Mr Livingstone's support had dropped 12 points to 49%, but he still commanded a 33-point lead over Mr Norris, who pushed Mr Dobson into third place.

fields.headline: The latest casting news
fields.trailText: On the casting couch: Heath Ledger, Peter O'Toole, Kevin Costner, and Frances O'Connor
fields.body:
 Australian Heath Ledger, last seen in the UK in 10 Things I Hate About You, is in advanced talks to play the lead role in Four Feathers, a remake of the famed 1939 Zoltan Korda picture. Ledger would portray a British officer who resigns his post just before battle and has to deal with accusations of cowardice. Helmed by Shekhar Kapur (Elizabeth), Feathers was originally to have starred Jude Law, but talks over his salary broke down last month. The Paramount/Miramax co-production will be shot in Morocco this spring.

 Peter O'Toole is to join Aidan Gillen, star of the Channel 4's Queer as Folk, in a show business comedy feature titled The Final Curtain. It will be made by DNA Films and financed by Universal Pictures International and the National Lottery. The story of rivalry between a showbiz veteran and an upstart newcomer, will be directed by first-timer Patrick Harkins from a screenplay by John Hodge (The Beach, Trainspotting).

 Director Kevin Reynolds and Kevin Costner, two pals who had a major falling out during the logistically challenged Waterworld, may reunite on another maritime drama. The $80m project is called Okracoke, and was written by Marc Norman, who shared the best screenplay Oscar with Tom Stoppard for Shakespeare in Love. It tells the true story of Robert Maynard, a disgraced British naval captain who seeks to redeem himself by hunting down the notorious pirate Blackbeard.

 A spy for Ain't It Cool News reports today that Australian actress Frances O'Connor, currently starring as Fanny Price in Mansfield Park, has just been signed as the female lead for Steven Spielberg's A.I. She joins Jude Law and Haley Joel Osment who are now confirmed. O'Connor has just finished shooting the remake of Bedazzled with Brendan Fraser and Elizabeth Hurley. Principal photography on A.I. begins in July.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Working Title likes the sound of Birdsong, Antonio Banderas and Adam Sandler win awards and Arnold Schwarznegger on Terminator 3
fields.body:
 Working Title Films is lining up an adaptation of Sebastian Faulks' best-selling world war one story Birdsong, with Iain (Wings of a Dove) Softley tentatively attached to direct, reports Screen International. This is the second Faulks adaptation in the pipeline: FilmFour is currently working on Faulk's loose sequel to Birdsong, Charlotte Gray, which is expected to be directed by Gillian Armstrong and to star Cate Blanchett.

 The 5th Annual American Latino Media Arts (ALMA) Awards yesterday evening named Antonio Banderas Outstanding Actor in a Feature Film for his work in The 13th Warrior. On Friday night, the Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards gave Adam Sandler and his comedy movie Big Daddy best actor and best film, while Will Smith gained Best Song award for Wild Wild West.

 While talking to Scifi.com, Arnold Schwarzenegger revealed that he would only be interested in Terminator 3 "if Jim Cameron does it." Regarding the Terminator sequels currently in development, he said, "I have not been approached, because there is no script. So until I see a script, I cannot comment on it. There is nothing here. There is no financing for it, there is no script for it, there is no director for it. There is nothing."

fields.headline: Show me the money
fields.standfirst: Who wants to be an e-millionaire? Channel 4 is launching a week-long competition which invites you to pitch your idea for a new website to its viewers (and win £2m).  Imogen O'Rorke  reports
fields.trailText: You can hear the jingle already: "You too can join the internet revolution! You can become Britain's next e-millionaire!" From today, there will be trails all over Channel 4 for a national competition and gameshow, The E-Millionaire Show, which aims to bring the new economy to the masses, right there into your front room.
fields.body:
You can hear the jingle already: "You too can join the internet revolution! You can become Britain's next e-millionaire!" From today, there will be trails all over Channel 4 for a national competition and gameshow, The E-Millionaire Show, which aims to bring the new economy to the masses, right there into your front room.

The website www.emillionaireshow.com (it only went up this morning), spells it out in simple terms for those who are still bamboozled by the new-fangled economy. "Have you got a fantastic idea for a website?" says the blurb. "Well, we've got £2m to invest. We want you to tell us about it ... just click on the button below".

It's an e-dream alright. But don't bother if you've got a business plan, or if you've so much as crossed the threshold of a First Tuesday meeting - The E-Millionaire Show is not for the likes of you. It is for your granny, who has long harboured a scheme to launch an international family photo swap-shop over the internet, or your little brother, who has been beavering away on that interactive skateboard in his bedroom, or your postman, who dreams of digitally delivering parcels from the comfort of his armchair.

The old joke about the digital revolution used to be that it never happened. Now you can't get in a lift without meeting a teenage paper millionaire, dot.com fever is plastered all over the walls of the tube and BBC2 has commissioned a drama about a group of yetties - young, entrepreneurial and net-based flatmates - from the team behind This Life.

The E-Millionaire show will be Who Wants to be a Millionaire? with digital knobs on. "We're basically conducting a massive talent scout - it's a star search of the internet world," says Henrietta Conrad, co-executive producer and co-director with Sebastian Scott of Princess Productions. Scott and Conrad are known for turning mass-market solutions out of fringe culture: first the Big Breakfast (Scott at Planet 24), then Light Lunch with Mel and Sue and most recently, dotcomedy, which has received indifferent reviews.

"There's a huge amount of creativity that we can tap into that will thrive in the new economy," says Conrad. "We are trying to create the people's e-millionaire." Scott allegedly came up with the idea because everywhere he went he was regaled with people's ideas for dot.com start-ups.

"First Tuesday [the networking event on the first Tuesday of every month] is fantastic but we don't want white, middle-class, well-educated people. We want to find a granny in Huddersfield who's got an idea but not the first clue how to go about it," says Conrad.

Princess are expecting tens of thousands of applications to be processed through the website next week. Only 15 of those will be chosen, and will end up having to pitch their brilliant ideas to the British public on a live gameshow hosted by "the incomparable" Jon Snow in May.

As in a gladiatorial knock-out, only five will go through to the final. The winner will get £1m and the runners-up will get to share the rest of the cash, which has been provided by a consor tium of venture capitalists. If the business is a success, neither Princess nor Channel 4 will profit. The entrepreneur keeps a shareholding of (33%), with one member of the audience to win a 1% stake. The rest of us can always buy shares.

But then - and this is the hitch - a year down the line the entrepreneur has to face the wrath or approbation of the public, as the documentary is broadcast and voters and shareholders will get to see how their little ship has fared in the tempestuous seas of e-commerce. According to David Lloyd, Four's head of news, current affairs and business programmes, Channel 4 has been looking for a mass-market internet solution for months: "We've lived in the new economy for a while and television hasn't yet delivered a programme that will engage a large audience - and yet out there it's all buzzing ... you can't overestimate the way in which the new economy will convert business, particularly business-to-business relationships," says Lloyd. "I was looking around for a way of bringing a sense of event to the area. Princess came up with a way of detonating the subject.

"This is something I as a viewer can learn about, I can relate to the competitive ups and downs, think the thought processes of venture capitalists, and then there is a lot of interactivity in terms of electing the finalists," says Lloyd. The E-Millionaire Show is about as interactive as TV and commerce can get without fitting set-top boxes with smart credit cards in all homes across the UK.

Conrad hopes the series of shows, strung out over a seven-day period and shown at peak time, will also be educational. "We take people through the whole revolution, the risks and pitfalls involved. In the last few weeks we have seen that it's not that easy to be a success, you have to have a fundamentally sound idea and plan."

If The E-Millionaire Show is a hit, Channel 4 will have done what no television programme has yet managed to do - make the internet revolution comprehensible, let alone tangible. Panorama's recent attempt to 'go inside' the new economy was derided by anyone who was within it. It focused on the sensational cyber-crimes of "ramping" and "bashing" and gave a warped overall picture of the biggest economic change to hit Britain since the industrial revolution.

So it is only fair that everyone in Britain gets a slice of the action. Revolutions are for everyone and they will be televised. Lloyd has great faith in the show's success. "Make no mistake, this is a very bold move. If it works it will locate Channel 4 where it wants to be - right in the swing of the new economy. Others have yet to make a stir in this area and it's right that Channel 4 does - sometimes it takes one programme to change the landscape."

If The E-Millionaire Show is a hit, Channel 4 will have done what no television programme has yet managed to do - make the internet revolution comprehensible, let alone tangible. Panorama's recent attempt to 'go inside' the new economy was derided by anyone who was within it. It focused on the sensational cyber-crimes of "ramping" and "bashing" and gave a warped overall picture of the biggest economic change to hit Britain since the industrial revolution. So it is only fair that everyone in Britain gets a slice of the action. Revolutions are for everyone and they will be televised. Lloyd has great faith in the show's success. "Make no mistake, this is a very bold move. If it works it will locate Channel 4 where it wants to be - right in the swing of the new economy. Others have yet to make a stir in this area and it's right that Channel 4 does - sometimes it takes one programme to change the landscape."

webTitle: Dunaway likes Almodovar's way with women

fields.headline: Dunaway likes Almodovar's way with women
fields.trailText: Faye Dunaway has said that she plans to make a film with Spanish director Pedro Almodovar
fields.body:
Faye Dunaway has said that she plans to make a film with Spanish director Pedro Almodovar. "He's one of the few directors with the sensitivity to direct actresses, and in films nowadays, it is not easy to find good roles, especially for women," Dunaway said, declining to reveal more details about the venture.

"It's unusual for a man to know how to understand and direct women in films," she added.

Almodovar is working on three scripts but has not said which film he intends to make first. However, the director of the Oscar-winning All About My Mother has said his next film will include roles for Antonio Banderas and Penelope Cruz.

webTitle: Depp and Paradis could be together on screen

fields.headline: Depp and Paradis could be together on screen
fields.trailText: Johnny Depp could be playing opposite his real-life partner Vanessa Paradis, and reuniting with Terry Gilliam in The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
fields.body:
Johnny Depp could be playing opposite his real-life partner Vanessa Paradis, and reuniting with Terry Gilliam in The Man Who Killed Don Quixote.

Depp is in advanced talks to play Sancho Panza, the servant of Don Quixote, a wandering knight who battles both windmills and reality itself. In a twist on Miguel de Cervantes' 17th century classic, Depp's character is a modern-day advertising executive who travels back in time to meet Don Quixote.

Paradis would play Aldonza, a kitchen-wench whom Don Quixote sees as the most beautiful woman the world.

The production, which would reunite Depp and Gilliam after Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas, is thought to be the largest-scale picture backed by the UK National Lottery to date. The project's other European backers include Le Studio Canal Plus, French production outfit Hachette Premiere and German film fund KC Medien.

Pathe Pictures is aiming for a September shoot in the UK and Spain. France's Rene Cleitman is producing, while Los Angeles-based sales operation Pathe International is handling international sales.

webTitle: Marching to a first milestone in brand awareness

fields.headline: Marching to a first milestone in brand awareness
fields.trailText: Last week, we reached a milestone. We issued our first press release and secured good coverage in the retail press. We have received some great feedback - although we were not entirely surprised, given the response we have already received from this column.
fields.body:
Last week, we reached a milestone. We issued our first press release and secured good coverage in the retail press. We have received some great feedback - although we were not entirely surprised, given the response we have already received from this column.

The aim of the release was to build awareness of the Rools brand prior to the launch of the service. It represents the first public step in a well-planned marketing programme for Rools, an online debit facility which will enable young people to shop online with a network of partner retailers without them needing a credit card.

Building a brand will be a huge challenge, particularly as we will be communicating with so many different groups - teenagers, their parents, retail partners and other strategic and marketing partners.

We are also subject to the more generic challenges facing the marketeers of online brands. At this embryonic stage of the business, we are acutely aware of two of these. Firstly, how do you create a virtual brand, one that customers experience primarily onscreen and that has little real world representation?

Secondly, the explosion of new businesses, new brands and new services means that the marketing arena is more crowded than at any time before. How do you get your message across effectively to potential customers who are subjected to hundreds of similar messages each week?

Unfortunately, there are no simple answers. We can learn something from the successes and failures of some of the commercial pioneers of the internet, such as Amazon and Yahoo. But it is difficult to work out how successful more established players have been in building sustainable long-term brands when customer disloyalty is only a click away.

The struggle to market a virtual brand effectively and to cut through the dot.com clutter can be illustrated by the industry's reliance on advertising. Advertising through "old" media, whether on TV, posters or buses has, ironically been the cornerstone of many "new" media marketing strategies. But its effectiveness is not always apparent and has led to lively debate in the marketing press.

The need to stand out from the crowd has also led to increasingly bizarre activities - such as last week's attempt on the custard pie throwing record to mark the launch of a new online business.

We are very clear about what the Rools brand should stand for, but we need help devising and implementing a truly effective marketing strategy. We have therefore spent weeks recruiting a team of media, advertising, design and public relations specialists that can help. As we mentioned last week, it is vitally important that these partners demonstrate a good understanding of the Rools brand, the service itself and the level of ambition we have for the business.

It is also important that the team works well together, possesses experience of youth and dot.com markets and is sufficiently innovative to meet the challenges identified.

Our first press release represented some of the first fruits of the considerable work that has gone into launching the Rools service. Building a valuable brand will take far longer to achieve.

 Adam Handy and Guy Mallison are co-counders of Rools.com

webTitle: Schoolboy creator of Soccernet in £40m new venture

fields.headline: Schoolboy creator of Soccernet in £40m new venture
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The schoolboy who created Soccernet, one of the world's most popular football websites, has had his second internet venture valued - at £40m.
fields.body:
The schoolboy who created Soccernet, one of the world's most popular football websites, has had his second internet venture valued - at £40m.

Seventeen-year-old Tom Hadfield's online education company Schoolsnet has attracted £5.75m second round funding from backers, including regional newspaper group Newsquest and technology company fdm.

A £2m investment by fdm was negotiated in the changing room of Sussex county football side Saltdean United. Tom plays in goal for Saltdean under-19s, while fdm's chairman Rod Flavell is also chairman of Saltdean United.

The funds will be used to build content on the schoolsnet website ahead of its official launch on May 3 and in the run up to GCSEs and A-Levels.

Schoolsnet aims to become the preferred online educational tool for pupils, parents and teachers by offering schools guides, an online library, educational news, interactive classroom resources and schools sports news.

Tom, who is studying for his A-levels in his home town of Brighton, spends two days a week at Schoolsnet's London offices. During the rest of the week, he works from his bedroom and communicates with staff by email.

His father Greg, a former Sunday Times education correspondent, is schoolsnet's full-time editor in chief. Together, they hold some 40% of the equity.

The duo conceived and built Soccernet with financial backing from Associated Newspapers. However, when Associated sold the site to Disney for £60m last year, the Hadfields are thought to have received only a six-figure sum.

Mr Hadfield senior said the alliance with Newsquest would allow Schoolsnet to take local school news into the communities served by the newspaper group's 185 publications nationwide. A series of Wap products and alliances, with promotions with other publishing groups, are also planned.

webTitle: Rules of Engagement still on top

fields.headline: Rules of Engagement still on top
fields.trailText: Reigning US box office champ Rules of Engagement held onto its top slot this weekend, but against severe competition from the new Sandra Bullock drama 28 Days, in which Bullock plays a good time girl sent to alcohol rehab after one too many drunken escapades.
fields.body:
Reigning US box office champ Rules of Engagement held onto its top slot this weekend, but against severe competition from the new Sandra Bullock drama 28 Days, in which Bullock plays a good time girl sent to alcohol rehab after one too many drunken escapades.

Rules, the William Friedkin military legal drama starring Tommy Lee Jones and Samuel L. Jackson, took $10.9m for the Friday-to-Sunday period, taking its 10-day total to $30.6m. 28 Days overcame mixed reviews to attract a predominantly female audience, aged over 25. The $30m film was directed by Betty Thomas from a script by Susannah Grant, who also wrote recent box-office leader Erin Brockovich.

At the other end of the romance scale, the already notorious American Psycho performed well, taking $4.9m which was on par with Lions Gate's expectations. Rave reviews from such outlets as the New York Times and Rolling Stone played a bigger part in attracting audiences to the $7m satire than did the controversy about its subject matter, said Lions Gate co-president Tom Ortenberg. He predicted the movie would end up grossing about $15 million, a good figure for what Lions Gate is billing as an art house release.

webTitle: Big was not always beautiful at Barclays

fields.headline: Big was not always beautiful at Barclays
fields.standfirst: Short memories or changing times prompt a radical shift in advertising strategy
fields.trailText: The big bank for the big world has not always believed big is best.
fields.body:
The big bank for the big world has not always believed big is best.

Only a few years ago, Barclays warned customers against size. Now it is under fire for the closure of 171 branch closures, coinciding with a high-profile advertising campaign fronted by stars such as Sir Anthony Hopkins trumpeting the virtues of being big.

In the 1980s, Barclays advertising campaign slogan was: "Do you sometimes think the bigger a bank gets, the smaller your problems will seem to them?"

Whether the about-turn is a reflection of changing times or short memories, the directors of the two advertising campaigns should have realised the contrast.

The first set of adverts was made by Ridley Scott, the famed-director of Blade Runner, while his brother Tony was the director behind the latest Barclays advertising campaign.

The new campaign is the first time the bank has launched a "corporate" image, rather than product-specific adverts.

Matt Barrett - the bank's chief executive who wrote to staff last week to hit out at the "hype and lunacy" surrounding his pay - described the new adverts at their launch last month as a move to help the bank "stand out out from the crowd as a modern bank that has the stature to lead and embrace change for the benefit of customers". What Barclays describes as "mini-films" are rumoured in the industry to have cost £4.5m, higher than campaigns run by other banks. That is probably because of the prices demanded by Sir Anthony and his co-stars Nick Moran from Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and Pulp Fiction's Tim Roth. They are also being shown in prime viewing time, in print, internet and cinemas and also across Europe.

Barclays proclaimed the commercials as marking a departure from the traditional style of adverts by banks, which it pointed out provoked cynical reactions.

Emphasising size, the bank said, was based on research that showed people became customers of the bank because of its stature, authority and size.

Advertising experts have pointed out that advertising campaigns can make or break an organisation, citing the Sainsbury "value to shout about" campaign as one of the first pointers to the supermarket's fall from grace.

The store's staff complained that the adverts made them look stupid and Sainsbury later admitted that the campaign had cut sales by alienating its traditional middle England shoppers. Of the shift in strategy, Barclays said: "Banking has changed enormously over the years and the advertising campaign at the moment is about today and the future".

fields.headline: Washington DC
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the protest-hit US capital on the web
fields.trailText: 1. Ten thousand protesters flooded on to the streets of Washington yesterday and shut the city down for six hours.
fields.body:
1. Ten thousand protesters flooded on to the streets of Washington yesterday and shut the city down for six hours.

2. Like the demonstrators in Seattle last year, they are protesting against globalisation and, in particular, a spring meeting of the IMF and World Bank.

3. The US government has now taken the unusual step of shutting down its Washington offices and requested that only emergencies workers come in on Monday.

4. Washington DC replaced Philadelphia as the capital of the United States in 1790.

5. Congress carved out a territory at the head of navigation of the Potomac river (which separates Washington DC from the neighbouring state of Virginia). The new territory took 68 square miles from Maryland, and to this day, the city'ssuburbs encroach on the neighbouring states.

6. The president of the USA, George Washington, after whom the city is named, wanted it to be a commercial hub drawing on the prosperity of the Virginia tobacco plantations.

7. But Washington is a political centre: it has neither the stability nor the continuity that feed a great city. Its affluent workers are the most transient in the country and the poorest face some of the worst social problems on the Eastern seaboard.

8. Even the architecture is political: the classical domes and columns of Washington's government buildings were part of a 1901 plan to ally the American republic with its Greek and Roman predecessors.

9. The White House is much older - construction started in 1790 - but the original structure was burned by British soldiers in the 1812 war.

10. The 1812 destruction happened because the capital had been left undefended. Not a mistake the DC local police are looking likely to repeat this week.

fields.headline: True believers
fields.standfirst: The academic success of church-run schools has made them extremely popular. They may even take over failing local authority schoolsReligion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The days are long gone when church pews were packed at Easter. A newspaper poll at the weekend suggested huge numbers, especially children, have no idea of the significance of the festival to Christians. Yet as regular attendance at Christian churches continues to plummet there is no sign of an end to the middle-class stampede for places at hugely popular schools based on religious faith.
fields.body:
The days are long gone when church pews were packed at Easter. A newspaper poll at the weekend suggested huge numbers, especially children, have no idea of the significance of the festival to Christians. Yet as regular attendance at Christian churches continues to plummet there is no sign of an end to the middle-class stampede for places at hugely popular schools based on religious faith.

The Church of England and the Roman Catholic Church are fiercely proud of the undisputed academic success of the establishments under their control. They boast above-average scores in assessment tests (SATs) for 11-year-olds and GCSE and A-level results which propel them to the top of performance league tables, as well as an unrivalled disciplinary record and "community ethos". Often the schools work against the odds by achieving exceptionally good results despite their location in some of the most socially deprived areas.

Some parents claim false religious credentials in order to give their children the very best state education. At the same time, bizarre anecdotes circulate about parents being urged to show more "religious commitment" in order to secure admission - resulting in them pulling on their rubber gloves to help clean the local church buildings.

The issue of selection on religious grounds has also become fiercely controversial since the government's decision to extend state support beyond Anglican and Roman Catholic schools to other denominations. David Blunkett wants to encourage "diversity" outside the mainstream state sector. This has led to formal recognition of the role of minority faith schools with the maintained sector. But critics claim that by denying admission to children on grounds of their faith, sectarian schools practice a covert form of selection which will now be spread even wider. The very roots of free education by the state lie with the Church of England, which in the early 19th century was first to provide Sunday schools with instruction in reading and writing. These were then expanded into a free, if basic, education for the "poor of the parish". The Church of England built 17,000 schools between 1811 and 1851 alone. The power of the church schools - and the resentment of non-Anglicans - has shaped education policy well beyond the 1944 Education Act.

Now the Church of England is to focus on secondary schools. The chart gives the breakdown between the different denominations showing how, relatively speaking, the Anglicans are poorly represented compared with their strength in the primary sector. The Church of England runs one in four primary schools - a total of 4,550. Parents want their children to go on into church schools, leading to fierce demand for places at secondary level where the Anglicans provide only one in 20 schools.

By contrast, the Roman Catholic Church has many more secondary schools than the Anglicans. There could be fewer church secondary schools in five years time than at present because of the likely recategorisation of middle schools to primary schools.

Behind the scenes, the Church of England is at work on a long-term review of its role in education, examining the achievements of the church's schools and assessing how it should provide in the future. Set up by the archbishops' council and chaired by that redoubtable troubleshooter Lord (Sir Ron) Dearing who has tackled so many education crises, the review is to take a long-term view of future needs. It hopes to redress the balance between provision in the primary and secondary sectors, possibly doubling the number of secondary schools over a 10-year period. As an alternative to the expensive option of setting up schools from scratch, the Anglicans may consider taking over failing local authority-run schools, which would otherwise have to close. This could result in its ownership of more schools in deprived areas.

The review group will also look at ways of making teaching more attractive to young Christians and how the church might best support teachers. It has had three meetings so far, recognising that the new legislative framework is "favourably disposed" towards the church and the development of its role in education - it offers official support for the maintenance of the present proportion of church school places. The group is not due to issue its final report until next year but hopes to publish an interim statement in the summer.

Roman Catholic schools in England were first given financial support by the state 150 years ago and the church now spends around £20m a year on its schools and colleges. Recognition of the Catholics' role and influence is also evident from the fact that both they and the Anglicans have been given places on the new general teaching council - still a fledgling but due to start work in September as the new, professional voice for all teachers.

The religious impulse in education continues to face strong opposition from non-believers, especially the British Humanist Association and the National Secular Society. Keith Porteous-Wood, its general secretary, says "The very concept of pupils being selected with reference to their parents' belief is abhorrent in a secular society in the 21st century. Instead of opening more church schools we should be concentrating on improving mainstream schools open to all pupils".

 Rebecca Smithers is The Guardian's education correspondent.

Set up by the archbishops' council and chaired by that redoubtable troubleshooter Lord (Sir Ron) Dearing who has tackled so many education crises, the review is to take a long-term view of future needs. It hopes to redress the balance between provision in the primary and secondary sectors, possibly doubling the number of secondary schools over a 10-year period. As an alternative to the expensive option of setting up schools from scratch, the Anglicans may consider taking over failing local authority-run schools, which would otherwise have to close. This could result in its ownership of more schools in deprived areas. The review group will also look at ways of making teaching more attractive to young Christians and how the church might best support teachers. It has had three meetings so far, recognising that the new legislative framework is "favourably disposed" towards the church and the development of its role in education - it offers official support for the maintenance of the present proportion of church school places. The group is not due to issue its final report until next year but hopes to publish an interim statement in the summer. Roman Catholic schools in England were first given financial support by the state 150 years ago and the church now spends around £20m a year on its schools and colleges. Recognition of the Catholics' role and influence is also evident from the fact that both they and the Anglicans have been given places on the new general teaching council - still a fledgling but due to start work in September as the new, professional voice for all teachers. The religious impulse in education continues to face strong opposition from non-believers, especially the British Humanist Association and the National Secular Society. Keith Porteous-Wood, its general secretary, says "The very concept of pupils being selected with reference to their parents' belief is abhorrent in a secular society in the 21st century. Instead of opening more church schools we should be concentrating on improving mainstream schools open to all pupils".  Rebecca Smithers is The Guardian's education correspondent. rebecca.smithers@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Jonathan Hale and Christopher Walken join Star Wars team
fields.trailText: News posted late last week on the Star Wars official site reveals that as the Episode II script nears completion, George Lucas has enlisted the aid of screenwriter Jonathan Hales.
fields.body:
News posted late last week on the Star Wars official site reveals that as the Episode II script nears completion, George Lucas has enlisted the aid of screenwriter Jonathan Hales.

Hales and Lucas have had a previous association through The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles: Hales wrote or co-wrote several episodes of the critically-acclaimed television series, including the feature-length Young Indiana Jones and the Curse of the Jackal, Young Indiana Jones and the Scandal of 1920, and Young Indiana Jones: Tales of Innocence.

Principal photography (using digital cameras) for the next SW instalment begins this summer.

Also on the much debated topic of SW2, Harry Knowles reports on his Ain't It Cool News site that Christopher Walken has signed to join the cast, although in what role remains to be seen.

fields.headline: Meriel Forbes
fields.standfirst: Actress of wit and charm, with and without Ralph Richardson
fields.trailText: Although Meriel Forbes, who has died aged 86, later became better known as Sir Ralph Richardson's beloved wife, "Mu" - famous for tolerating his assorted whims, from motorcycles to uncaged pet parrots - she had earned a reputation on the West End stage as one of its busiest and most accomplished actresses long before they met.
fields.body:
Although Meriel Forbes, who has died aged 86, later became better known as Sir Ralph Richardson's beloved wife, "Mu" - famous for tolerating his assorted whims, from motorcycles to uncaged pet parrots - she had earned a reputation on the West End stage as one of its busiest and most accomplished actresses long before they met.

She was also one of the stage's most attractive exponents of light comedy. After ending her engagement to the actor Robert Morley, who considered her insufficiently ambitious, she took up with the matinée idol Robert Donat, and played his wife on tour and in the West End - during the same season that she first encountered Richardson.

Meriel was born into one of the best-known British acting families. The daughter of Frank Forbes-Robertson and niece of the great Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson, she was educated in Eastbourne, Brussels and Paris. No one was surprised when, at 16, she made her professional debut with her father's touring company in York, as Mrs De Hooley in Jerome K Jerome's The Passing Of The Third Floor Back.

Then came two stints in rep, one in Dundee, the other in Birmingham, before touring in Ronald Mackenzie's Musical Chairs, and understudying (and playing) the fluffy and flirtatious Kitty Packard in Kaufman and Ferber's Dinner At Eight (1933). For the next seven years, Forbes was never out of work, which ranged from comedies and thrillers to musicals and Terence Rattigan's first play, First Episode, in 1934.

It was two years later, while auditioning with another actress at the Haymarket theatre for The Amazing Dr Clitterhouse, that Ralph Richardson chose her for the part of a gangster's moll. He was to star as a psychologist-turned- criminologist, and pointing to the vivacious Forbes, he said: "I like that one." As Clitterhouse's "dark and spirited, and smartly dressed assistant, Daisy" Forbes caught critical attention in a production which ran for nearly 500 performances.

The Richardsons did not act again together for another 12 years. He was already married to Muriel "Kit" Hewitt, an actress but an invalid. She had developed the disease encephalitis lethargica (sleeping sickness).

Although Forbes might not possess high ambition or wide range, as Morley had once brusquely pointed out, she was always in work, and her vivacity held an irresistible charm for an actor of Richardson's artistic standing and domestic predicament. Besides, she had won admiration over the years for her lightness of touch, exquisite timing, spirited personality and her way of humanising otherwise over-sweet characters, like Sheridan's Julia in The Rivals at the Old Vic in 1938.

Forbes had also shown an engaging, caustic line in dry comedy as Crystal Allen in The Women (1940), and had stolen notices in the small part of the housemaid Milly Smith in Reginald Beckwith's A Soldier For Christmas (1944). As the barmaid opposite Richardson in RC Sherriff's Home At Seven (1950), her part may only have lasted 10 minutes, but within that time she was said to have "unlocked with charm and vivacity the key to the plot". In another play by Sherriff, The White Carnation, Forbes drew from Kenneth Tynan the epithet "winsome", as a London librarian with whom Richardson fell in love.

Indeed, the Richardsons, who married in 1944 (two years after the death of Muriel Hewitt), were to play many parts together, from Romilly Cavan's ruritanian comedy, Royal Circle (1948) to a tour of Australia in two Rattigan plays, Separate Tables and The Sleeping Prince, and Robert Bolt's Flowering Cherry, in which Forbes took over from Wendy Hiller as the long-suffering wife of Richardson's dreamy suburban husband.

They were together again in the West End in The School For Scandal in 1962, with her as Lady Sneerwell to his blustering Sir Peter Teazle, roles which they also acted on Broadway. In 1964, they played Bottom and Titania in A Midsummer Night's Dream on a tour of South America and Europe.

One of their last plays together came in the 1970s, Lloyd George Knew My Father, with Forbes replacing Peggy Ashcroft. Among her own personal successes were The Philadelphia Story (1949), Shaw's The Millionairess (1952), and The Waltz Of The Toreadors (New York, 1957). Forbes's film appearances included Oh! What A Lovely War, and, on television, she was Lady Constance in the series Blandings Castle.

Sir Ralph Richardson died in 1983. Their only son, Charles, also predeceased Forbes.

 Meriel Forbes, actress, born September 13 1913; died April 7 2000

fields.headline: Waiting for the bad balls
fields.standfirst: NEW SERIES: every Monday throughout the English season, wisden.com will be  getting the inside story of one of the week's best performances. We begin  with MICHAEL BURNS of Somerset, who made 160 against Oxford Universities on  April 7. It was the first century of the season - and the earliest ever  recorded in England
fields.trailText: "I had two months in Tasmania during the winter and then some time in South Africa with Somerset, so I felt in good nick. Going abroad is great because it gives you the chance to get some good practice on decent, grass-pitches. I had never made a century against Oxford before, though I did make 70-odd [78] against Cambridge on my debut for Warwickshire.
fields.body:
"I had two months in Tasmania during the winter and then some time in South Africa with Somerset, so I felt in good nick. Going abroad is great because it gives you the chance to get some good practice on decent, grass-pitches. I had never made a century against Oxford before, though I did make 70-odd [78] against Cambridge on my debut for Warwickshire.

On the day, despite a good pitch at Taunton, we lost some early wickets and it was 28 for 3 when I came in. I didn't have a hundred on my mind, I just wanted to keep ticking along - that's the best way to play it. I didn't really play any big shots, it was more a test of concentration than anything else. There were plenty of bad balls flying around, so it was only a matter of waiting for them. I was batting with Peter Bowler so he acted as a bit of a handbrake for me. It wasn't a race, there was no way Peter was going to take a risk and get out (he made 140 not out against Cambridge last year), but once I got to 99 I was always going to get a single off the next ball. I felt pretty fluent and put one ball from Scot Weenink into the St James's Street car park, which was reassuring because I thought I'd lost all my power.

The lads obviously realised we weren't up against first-class opposition but they were pleased for me, after all someone has got to get in and do the business. I felt really sorry for Rob Turner who had his pads on from about quarter to 12 to tea time.

Oxford were pretty poor really. They would have been a very average club side. But to be fair they'd just come back from Pakistan and had a few players missing with stomach trouble.

Our team spirit at the moment is very good. The boys enjoyed Cape Town and everyone seems to have done something pre-season. Coxy [Jamie Cox], Mark Lathwell and Marcus [Trescothick] got runs in the second innings and Ian Blackwell has fitted in well.

I hope that this [the 160] has set me up for the rest of the season, it should keep me on teletext for a while anyway. I beat John Crawley to the first century of the season by about ten minutes Make sure you put that one in Wisden, then they'll have to believe it."

Michael Burns was talking to Tanya Aldred

fields.headline: Moore back for more spying
fields.trailText: Fifteen years after giving up his license to kill as James Bond, Roger Moore will be returning to our screens as a spy.
fields.body:
Fifteen years after giving up his license to kill as James Bond, Roger Moore will be returning to our screens as a spy.

The Express newspaper reports today that the 72-year-old actor is to star in a thriller about biological warfare called The Enemy.

"I need to make a film occasionally, otherwise people say, 'He must be retired' and I liked this script,'' said Moore. "I really don't think there will be any James Bond antics. These days I'm more likely to be dozing off in my trailer.''

fields.headline: You've got to have faith
fields.standfirst: Quarantine, Jim Crace's novel about Jesus in the desert, won the Whitbread Best Novel Prize. Ben Payne thinks he can turn it into a good play.  Chris Arnot talks to both of them
fields.trailText: Quarantine, Jim Crace's novel about Jesus in the desert, won the Whitbread Best Novel Prize. Ben Payne thinks he can turn it into a good play. Chris Arnot talks to both of them
fields.body:
The author Jim Crace is sitting with rock-like stillness on the edge of a grubby yellow sofa in the far corner of the rehearsal room. Perched on an adjacent chair, the literary manager of Birmingham Rep, Ben Payne, is almost motionless too. But the way he fiddles with his earring every now and then suggests he might not be quite as calm as he appears.

A little apprehension would be understandable. It was Payne's idea to adapt for the stage Crace's novel Quarantine, about Jesus's 40 days in the Judean wilderness. What's more, he volunteered to take on the task himself - a heavy responsibility considering the critical praise heaped on the book, winner of the 1997 Whitbread Prize.

Any worries that the novelist would heap criticism on his adaptation evaporate as Crace's face breaks into a grin. "He's a great choice," he whispers to Payne, gesturing towards Terence Corrigan, the youthful actor who plays Christ. Corrigan is standing on a table talking to God with a discernible Northern Ireland accent. Crace likes the way he speaks and the way he looks: dark rather than blond.

"The western view of Christ is usually of a stainless being with fair hair who appears to have come from Oslo," he says after we have left the rehearsal room and settled in the cafe downstairs. "This bloke looks and sounds like an over-zealous 19-year-old you might find in a church group or wandering down my street in Moseley."

Crace has lived in the cosmopolitan Birmingham suburb for over 20 years. Like Payne, he moved to the Midlands from London. The two met when Payne rang Crace and suggested his widely acclaimed novel would make a great play.

"I hope I didn't sound churlish when I said I didn't want anything to do with it," Crace recalls. "My craft is writing novels. I've done the odd play for Radio 4, but this is theatre. Writers who want to interfere with adaptations of their work are basically undemocratic. The book still stands as an entity on its own. And if the play's a total failure, then I want everyone to know that it's Ben's fault," he adds with another characteristic grin.

Crace's mischievous sense of humour is never far from the surface, tempering the earnestness of his staunch socialist convictions. All the same, he gives the impression of being more serious about politics than about literature. "There has been a film script of Quarantine," he reveals. "It was reasonably well received, but the bottom line was that it would only be bankrolled if the story was relocated to a survivalists' camp in modern America. I was rather keen on the idea, but the bloody scriptwriters wouldn't go ahead with it. They were too respectful to me. A writer can't expect to keep control."

Payne acknowledges Crace's generosity. "If I'd had the sense of needing to have my homework marked all the time, I could never have got on with the script. But it was important to me for Jim to see what I'd done."

Like the film scriptwriters, he had too much respect to take liberties with the novelist's work. His aim, he says, has not been to improve on the novel but to give live audiences a different yet equally rewarding experience of the story.

Easier said than done. "There is a clear dramatic shape to the book but not much dialogue," he says. "And a lot of the action is internalised. In fiction, you can hide behind the narrative voice. I feared that wouldn't work for the stage. The challenge was to translate the language of the book into dialogue."

Most stage and screen adaptations are of classics, which become costume dramas, he says. Quarantine "offers the chance to create a very different and remote world on stage while bringing it into close proximity with contemporary audiences."

As Crace points out, theatrical representations of biblical stories are hardly unfamiliar to us. "This is the costume drama we've all been in," he says. "Almost everyone who's been to primary school in Britain has had towels put on their heads to play the shepherds in the nativity play."

He is pleased with the way Payne has approached the dialogue. "When I listened to the read-through, I thought I could have written every word," he says. "Ben has even taken a phrase from elsewhere in the book and put it at the end in a way that is packed with meaning and irony. A cold lizard ran up my spine when I heard that."

Both author and adapter have come at the story from a similar standpoint on religion. They are both atheists. But "that doesn't mean I set out to write a Salman Rushdie annihilation of Christianity," Crace insists. "It's a work of fiction, not a didactic pamphlet. In fact, I've had a lot of letters from Christians who've told me that the book has underscored their faith."

Payne can foresee church groups coming to see the play and finding it uplifting - particularly now that the decision has been taken not to have Jesus on stage stark naked, as he is for most of the novel. "Although there's irony in the book, it isn't cynical about religion," he says. "All the characters have belief, yet it's not being mocked. And it's important for a modern audience to understand their motivation."

Surely, though, there will be aspects that are lost in translation from page to stage? "The main loss will be the landscape as a character in itself," Crace concedes. "But there will be gains as well when the intervening narrative is stripped away, allowing an extra layer of more direct humour."

He is particularly pleased by what he foresees will be a witty portrayal of Musa, the vast and venal merchant who promotes Christ as a miracle-worker capable of healing the sick and rising from the dead. Crace's ultimate ironic twist was to have news of these talents, highly ambiguous in the context of the novel, carried to a wider world by a devilish figure.

"I always meant Musa to be monstrously witty," he says. "When he claims, 'These are my caves, this is my water' in the novel, there's nobody to say: 'Ooh, you fibber!' But in the stage version, there will be." He hopes there will be some audience reaction as well. "If they don't make noises in the right places, then I will."

Crace may have given away control of Quarantine the play, but his enthusiasm suggests he's not quite as detached from the end product as he likes to appear.

 Quarantine is at Birmingham Rep (0121-236 4455) from April 27-May 20.

webTitle: Oscar-winner Michael Caine to be knighted

fields.headline: Oscar-winner Michael Caine to be knighted
fields.trailText: Saturday's Sun newspaper reported that Michael Caine was to be knighted in the Queen birthday honours list in June, on the personal recommendation of Prime Minister Tony Blair
fields.body:
Despite his pronouncements at last week's Bafta ceremony on the innate snobbery of the British film industry (see our news story, double Oscar-winning actor Michael Caine could be set to receive the ultimate establishment seal of approval.

On accepting his fellowship of the academy award, the 67-year-old actor caused a controversy by telling the audience he had "never really felt I belonged in my own country, in my own profession."

Quoting government sources, Saturday's Sun newspaper said the actor was to be knighted in the Queen birthday honours list in June, on the personal recommendation of Prime Minister Tony Blair.

fields.standfirst:
Follow the FTSE 100 on Money Unlimited
Follow Lastminute.com
fields.trailText: The UK's FTSE 100 index plunged to a six-month low in the opening minutes of trade today as the UK shares were sucked into the global market maelstrom sparked by Friday's record-breaking sell-off on Wall Street.
fields.body:
The UK's FTSE 100 index plunged to a six-month low in the opening minutes of trade today as the UK shares were sucked into the global market maelstrom sparked by Friday's record-breaking sell-off on Wall Street.

By 0708 GMT, the FTSE had dropped 235 points or 3.8 percent to 5,942.9, its lowest level since October 18.

Insurer Allied Zurich was the only gainer in the headline index by this time, with technology, media and telecoms stocks bearing the brunt of the sell-off.

Vodafone fell 6.2 percent to its lowest since January 7, knocking off 50 points on its own. New entrants Psion Baltimore and Logica all fell 20 percent or more.

The techMARK 100 index plunged 11 percent to 3,135 - a level not seen since December 2.

webTitle: Big is beautiful for new breed of liner

fields.headline: Big is beautiful for new breed of liner
fields.trailText: The new £200m British superliner, one of the biggest built, sailed into her home port of Southampton for the first time yesterday.
fields.body:
The new £200m British superliner, one of the biggest built, sailed into her home port of Southampton for the first time yesterday.

The 76,000 ton Aurora docked after first anchoring in the Solent off Cowes, on the Isle of Wight, as a fleet of 40 classic tall ships, gathering for their annual race, sailed by.

The 14-deck superliner, which can cruise at 24 knots, was built at the Meyer Werft shipyard in Papenburg, Germany. It will be named officially by the Princess Royal in Southampton on April 27.

The P&O vessel is only the second cruise liner - after its sister ship Oriana - to be built specially for the booming British cruise market and will carry 1,874 passengers and 850 crew when it sets sail under the Red Ensign on its maiden season with a 14 night voyage to the Mediterranean on May 1.

The sheer scale of the Aurora attracted large crowds at Southampton yesterday. At 270 metres, it is as long as three Statues of Liberty lying torch-to-toe, while its 32-metre width would allow the liner to squeeze through the Mall in London with only three metres to spare.

It has 934 cabins, 400 of them with balconies, and luxury penthouse suites offering personal butler service.

There are five lounges, 12 bars, five restaurants, a theatre, a concert hall, a cinema and numerous shops - all of which use enough electrical power to supply a city the size of Oxford.

Its 9,200 square metres of deck space, capable of accommodating 35 tennis courts, also offer passengers willing to pay fares starting at £2,345 three swimming pools, including one with a retractable glass roof, as well as a health and beauty centre, gym and sauna and a business centre. There are also club rooms for children and teenagers.

webTitle: Death haunts nomads of the dustbowl

fields.headline: Death haunts nomads of the dustbowl
fields.standfirst:
Drought has killed their livestock and now the people of Ogaden rely on aid agencies for survival

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Abdi Farah's father sat in the back of the pick-up truck cradling his son's tiny body in his arms while his tears formed a dark circle on the purple shroud.
fields.byline: David Gough  in Danan, south-east Ethiopia
fields.body:
Abdi Farah's father sat in the back of the pick-up truck cradling his son's tiny body in his arms while his tears formed a dark circle on the purple shroud.

Two-year-old Abdi spent the final two months of his life in a feeding centre in Gode, south-east Ethiopia, the victim of a drought which has already claimed hundreds of lives.

He finally gave up the struggle early yesterday morning and later that day he was buried in a shallow grave next to his older sister, who died of hunger last month. Abdi's parents have now lost four of their 10 children to starvation.

Three years of drought have cost the nomadic peoples of Gode district everything - their livestock are dead, their crops withered.

For the last six months thousands of these fiercely proud people have made the trek out of the barren dustbowl toward this town in Ogaden.

The Ogaden Welfare Society, with help from the Save the Children Fund, has set up the feeding centre in Gode, but food and medicines are limited. Since it was established two months ago, 10% of the children admitted have died - most of them from hunger-related diseases like diarrhoea.

"We simply don't have any drugs," said Yibell Shibabaw, a nurse at Gode hospital.

For months the OWS has been pleading for help from the Ethiopian government and the outside world, but until the harrowing pictures began appearing on television screens its SOS fell on deaf ears.

Now the international community has responded with generous pledges of aid, which if delivered promptly should avert catastrophe.

"The promises they have made are adequate but the future for these people depends on when it gets here," said Mahmoud Ugas, the OWS area manager.

In the village of Danan, 45 miles away, more than 3,000 people who have lost everything they own survive "by the grace of God alone", according to one community elder.

There are no feeding centres here in Danan - just suffering. Médecins Sans Frontières plans to open one soon, but for now there is little respite for the thousands sheltering here.

They live in dome-shaped huts built from animal skins, cardboard, cloth - anything they can scavenge that will shelter them from the heat and the dust that blows incessantly across these desolate plains. The rotting carcasses of livestock emit a foul smell.

Hani Abdi holds her one-year-old son. She does not know where her husband is and was driven here when the last of their livestock died. Her son's skin clings to his bones like an undersized shirt and his eyes are sunk inside a head that lolls from side to side.

Half a mile from the camp Abdi Sheikh wanders away from one of hundreds of freshly dug graves, breaks a few branches from a nearby thorn brush and lays them on top of the mound of earth. "I do this to stop the jackals and hyenas from eating my son's body," he said.

Back at his hut, he pulls aside a stretch of cloth and points to the body of his wife. She has not eaten for more than a month and not spoken for four days. She is too weak to wave away the flies feeding at the corner of her eyes.

The drought has already cost Abdi Sheikh 200 of his cows, sheep and goats and two of his children. "Only God can save my wife," he said.

But now as donations of aid pour in and aid agencies set up feeding centres, optimism is growing that the worst consequences of three years of drought may be averted.

"These people have lost everything they own and their coping mechanisms have been exhausted," Mr Ugas said. "It will take years for them to recover but at least we should be able to keep them alive if the food comes in."

OWS staff go on daily patrols through the bush looking for communities too weak or desperate to make the long walk to help. "Because these people are nomads it's very difficult for us to know the true scale of this disaster," he said.

Mr Ugas, who has spent the day driving to watering holes, is trying to determine the health of the last livestock left alive in Ogaden - the camels. If they start dying, the long-term consequences of the drought could be catastrophic.

"These people are pastoralists and depend entirely on livestock. This drought has killed their livestock and pushed them into a cycle of aid dependency that will take years to change," he said.

fields.headline: Old dogs and new tricks
fields.standfirst:
When the Open University began a course to turn beginners into website whizzkids, the response was overwhelming. Dolly Dhingra on the desire for retraining
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: When the Open University began a course to turn beginners into website whizzkids, the response was overwhelming. Dolly Dhingra on the desire for retraining
fields.body:
It takes a lot of effort these days to keep up with developments in software and information technology, and the language of the office has become virtually unintelligible to those who work in other fields. But the message for large numbers of workers, particularly those in the declining manufacturing industry, is that they resist adapting at their peril.

David Blunkett's announcement last week that £5.5m is to be pumped into a computer-training package for redundant Rover workers at Longbridge highlights the fact that IT is the yellow brick road the government wants workers to follow. But how easy is it to teach an old dog new tricks?

A previous government attempt to retrain manufacturing workers was targeted at staff made redundant at the Fujitsu plant in Newton Aycliffe, Co Durham. When more than 500 employees at the microelectronics plant lost their jobs in September 1998, the government set up a group comprising local agencies, Fujitsu representatives and central government members to look at retraining opportunities. A fund of £415,000 supported a programme of new learning opportunities and education links with industries. After nine months, 97% of the workforce was resettled in employment, training or education.

It is not just former manufacturing workers who want to develop more saleable skills. Whether the desire to learn is from choice or necessity, huge numbers of workers are attempting to update their knowledge. In February, the Open University launched "You, your computer and the net", a one-year course equivalent to the first year of a degree.

The course is taught online so that students learn while using the new technology. It is designed to turn absolute beginners into website creators in a year, and within months of its launch it has become the most popular IT course in the world, catering for 14,000 students. Intake to the course had to be staggered as the OU attempted to deal with the deluge. "The government keeps talking about an era of lifelong learning," says Gary Spink, a spokesperson for the university. "That's exactly what the OU has always stood for."

Who should take the responsibility for skills retraining remains a grey area - since opening its books to students in 1971, only 5,000 employers have paid for workers to take courses there. Employers in the UK are notoriously bad at updating workers' skills, but staff are starting to demand more from their bosses. Ian Marshall, of online employment agency webrecruitment.com, says: "Skills training within a job is a strong motivator for those looking for employment. People no longer consider money as the biggest priority. Increasingly, self-development is becoming the main reason for taking a post."

Unfortunately, he says, employers prefer to take on staff who are already skilled rather than retrain their own. "Small to medium-sized firms seem to think that it will cost them too much, so they prefer to recruit skilled staff who can hit the ground running. But this approach is not necessarily cheaper since companies have to pay recruitment fees, and interviews take up the time of senior staff members."

Perhaps surprisingly, it is not only older workers who feel the need to retrain. Recent research shows that the average age of OU students has dropped dramatically, and now includes a large number of thirty-something professionals. "People are coming to us because they want to acquire skills that were never offered to them during their school years or during their degree," says Spink.

Before they can develop advanced computer literacy, however, IT course tutors are aware that many first need to change their view of IT, and lose the fear that computer skills are too complicated to acquire. All it takes, says Spink, is a shift in attitude. "Rather than say, 'if you press this button, this happens,' we need to make people aware of how computers work and what they can do for us. We believe that anyone can learn anything. Regardless of on whom the responsibility for training falls, the only thing necessary for an individual to learn is a certain degree of self-motivation."
