fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

BT is planning dot.com-style bonus packages to keep top staff. The new scheme could reward top managers with bonuses equal to their annual salaries.

The sale of Rover Cars to venture capital group Alchemy could threaten thousands of jobs and at least one manufacturing plant at Corus, previously known as British Steel. Concerns are focused on the Llanwern and Port Talbot strip mills in south Wales, which together employ 6,200 workers

Taxpayers could land windfalls from further mobile phone licence auctions, on top of the £20bn bonus to the Treasury's coffers the government is set to earn from the sale of the first five licences to operate the new generation of mobile phones. The new money would come from selling more frequencies on the radio spectrum.

Sunday Telegraph

Deutsche Bank has asked David Simons, the ousted chief of ailing supermarket Somerfield, to consider heading a £500m bid to take the grocer private.

Interbrew, the family-owned Belgian Stella Artois beer company, is considering an $8bn (£5bn) float to raise some cash for acquisitions.

John Moulton's Alchemy is on the verge of signing a deal with luxury car maker Jensen to use some of the Rover facilities at Longbridge that it is buying from BMW

Sunday Business

The planned flotation of the US Alta Vista internet portal has been postponed. The loss-making portal, which started free internet access in Britain last month, has attempted to go public before, in 1996. But that attempt was also postponed due to weak market conditions.

Tour operator Thomson Travel may be ready to agree to a 160p takeover from Germany's C&N Touristic. The deal would make C&N Europe's biggest holiday company.

IoS

BT is considering linking its managers' bonuses to City analysts' valuations of its new business operations.

WPP advertising boss Sir Martin Sorrell is ready to launch a $4bn hostile takeover bid for rival Young & Rubicam.

German carmakers BMW, already under fire over the proposed sell-off of Rover, have transferred the assets of Land Rover to Jersey to avoid a stamp duty bill on its sale to Ford which could total as much as £700m.

Sunday Times

The government is to announce a £1bn partial privatisation of the Defence Evaluation Research Agency. The sale of up to 40% of the shares of the agency, which employs 9,000 scientists, is expected to attract keen investor interest.

Whitbread is ready to sell its brewing operations. It could fetch up to £400m.

Ragdoll Productions, creator of the Teletubbies, is considering a partial or total sale to a media company.

Mail on Sunday

The government is planning a review of the fund management business. The inquiry will look at charges and commissions, the way investment decisions are made and could also embrace managers' pay packages.

Rupert Murdoch is planning a £31bn flotation of satellite operations and investments. News Corp will retain a 60% stake in the new company which will include Murdoch's 40% stake in BSkyB, his Asian satellite service, Star TV and minority stakes in several other companies.

Sunday Express

Virgin head Sir Richard Branson plans to refinance £150m he pumped into Our Price and Virgin Megastore last month, repaying the banks from whom he borrowed the purchase price of the two high-street chains when he bought them off WH Smith two years ago.

Internet company Totalise is looking to go hostile after its merger offer for the Chelsea building society was rejected last week. Chelsea's 450,000 savers and borrowers are set to vote on demutualisation at their annual meeting later this month.

Wednesday

Today

UK CBI pay databank survey. US Fed's Parry speech on economic outlook.

Tuesday

webTitle: Third world still can't see past western self-interest

fields.headline: Third world still can't see past western self-interest
fields.trailText: The strains generated by international free trade in global markets surfaced on the streets of Seattle and are resurfacing again in Washington.
fields.body:
The strains generated by international free trade in global markets surfaced on the streets of Seattle and are resurfacing again in Washington.

Globalisation has spread fear throughout the world. Economic power is being concentrated through massive mergers. It is easy to understand why the World Trade Organisation, perceived as an instrument of wealthy corporations, incurs opposition.

As rapid economic change spreads insecurity, General Motors packs more punch than some European Union member states. In the United States, many fear that their jobs will be exported to the developing world. British workers share their concerns. At the end of 1999, the livelihoods of some 6,000 GMB union members employed in the clothing industry were jeopardised by Marks & Spencer's decision to terminate long-standing contracts with British suppliers. The jobs were to move to the developing world where workers would be paid 4% of British labour rates.

In more than 70 of the world's poorest nations, nearly 30m workers are employed in so-called free trade zones, making goods such as jeans for western markets. These employees, mainly women, work up to 16 hours a day in brutal conditions. Accidents are common. There are no trade unions and no labour regulations to offer basic protection.

The multinationals' search for cheaper labour does not stop at replacing a protected, developed-world workforce with sweated adult labour. There are some 250m economically active children aged between five and 14. The WTO has said that its members will respect International Labour Organisation core standards against the worst forms of child labour. But there has been little progress.

Labour standards are a fundamental human right. Yet, as demonstrated at Seattle, many developing countries oppose their introduction because they see them as disguised western self-interest. In their view, developed countries are attempting to narrow the labour cost gap to protect their jobs.

But if this is the motive, the policy will surely fail. Good health and safety standards are cheap compared with wages. For example, the GMB has developed a needle guard for sewing machines that costs only a pound.

No one is suggesting that factories in Sri Lanka should immediately pay the same wage rates as factories in the United States. The arguments about child labour and safety have to be based on principle.

The trade union movement has argued for minimum employment protection standards by which nations and transnational corporations must abide. The positive outcome at Seattle was that many countries previously opposed to discussing the issue began to reconsider. The challenge is to ensure that developing countries gain from the introduction of safety standards and the right to join independent trade unions.

A first step would be to set up a permanent ILO-WTO working group. This body should propose mechanisms to integrate labour rights into WTO rules and trade agreements. At the same time, industrialised countries should shun protectionist measures.

The ILO should be given authority to monitor compliance with labour standards and to develop incentives for encouraging good practice.

In a civilised society, we have to work together or each will suffer alone. The WTO rules must be reformed to enable governments and consumers to distinguish between products on ethical, environmental and health grounds.

 John Edmonds is General Secretary of GMB. This is an edited extract from his contribution to After Seattle: Globalisation and its discontents published tomorrow by Catalyst. Full details: www.catalyst-trust.co.uk

fields.headline: Defiant Putin flies in
fields.standfirst:
Blair promises to tackle Russian leader over alleged human rights abuse in Chechnya

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian president-elect, Vladimir Putin, flew into Britain last night ready to defy critics over his country's human rights record in Chechnya.
fields.body:
The Russian president-elect, Vladimir Putin, flew into Britain last night ready to defy critics over his country's human rights record in Chechnya.

On his first visit to the west since winning the election last month, Mr Putin faced condemnation from opposition politicians and human rights groups.

Mr Putin has prepared his defence in readiness for the issue being raised by the prime minister, Tony Blair, when the two meet for lunch at Downing Street today.

Mr Blair has been accused of being soft on Russian's actions in Chechnya compared with the reactions of countries such as France and Germany.

But Downing Street said yesterday Mr Blair will be "more pro-active than just dropping it into the conversation".

Mr Blair will press Mr Putin to allow access for UN human rights investigators trying to find out what has happened in Chechnya. Concern was raised recently that the UN high commissioner for human rights, Mary Robinson, was denied access to villages.

But Mr Putin will counter that some of the places she wanted to see either did not exist or were areas where her safety could not be guaranteed.

A Russian source said Mr Putin will argue that there has been no systematic violation of human rights. "There are unique cases by individual servicemen, but there are no war crimes," the source said.

Mr Putin, the former KGB chief who is keen to use the British visit to help establish international credibility, is to meet British businessmen in the morning before going on to Downing Street. In the early evening he will be received by the Queen at Windsor castle.

He will also lay a wreath at a memorial in south London for the 27m Soviet citizens who died in the second world war. He is to visit St Paul's cathedral but has dropped plans to go to Westminster abbey.

A short walkabout in the centre of London is expected, depending on how long the Downing Street talks last. But, according to the Russians, it may have to be cancelled if they feel Mr Putin's safety cannot be guaranteed.

The US-based group Human Rights Watch urged Mr Blair to do more than just express concern about Chechnya and warn Mr Putin that it would take Russia to the European court of human rights if it failed to properly investigate an alleged massacre in the Chechen town of Alkhan-Yurt in December.

A Human Rights Watch spokeswoman said: "There can be no question about what happened here. The only question is what Russia and its international partners are going to do about it."

A London lawyer, Gareth Peirce, is taking Russia to the European court of human rights on behalf of a Chechen nurse, Sasita Khasuyeva, who alleges five of her patients were killed in front of her and 61 others vanished.

The International Federation of Human Rights was unequivocal in its condemnation of the trip: "This visit constitutes an encouragement for the Russian government to pursue, in complete impunity, its murderous politics towards Chechens."

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, described the visit as premature given that human rights violations continued in Chechnya. The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, said there was justifiable concern about Russia's human rights record.

Labour MP Jeremy Corbyn expressed concerns about how Mr Putin might use his visit to Britain. "When Tony Blair went to St Petersburg recently that was certainly used by Putin as part of his election campaign. It was certainly used to indicate there was a sort of tacit approval of what the Russian government was doing in Chechnya," he said.

Apart from Chechnya, the main issues on the agenda will be Mr Putin's attempts to woo British investors back into the Russian market and his unease over the US proposal to build an anti-ballistic missile defence system, which Moscow sees as potentially fuelling a new arms race.

webTitle: Road rage fiancée fears Noye revenge

fields.headline: Road rage fiancée fears Noye revenge
fields.standfirst: New identity for witness with £1m price on her head
fields.trailText: The former fiancée of the man murdered by Kenneth Noye in the M25 road rage attack has spoken of her fear of an assassination attempt ordered by the gangster, after police warned her of a £1m price on her head.
fields.body:
The former fiancée of the man murdered by Kenneth Noye in the M25 road rage attack has spoken of her fear of an assassination attempt ordered by the gangster, after police warned her of a £1m price on her head.

Danielle Cable, who was with Stephen Cameron when Noye stabbed him to death at an interchange near Swanley, Kent, in May 1996, has been living under a new identity under the witness protection scheme since she helped police to identify Noye in 1998.

Speaking publicly for the first time since Noye was sentenced to life imprisonment at the Old Bailey last week, Ms Cable, 23, said she lived in constant fear of her life. "I have to live from day to day wondering if I'm being watched or followed. I will always live in fear of Kenny Noye and what he could do to me if he ever found out where I lived."

Two years after Mr Cameron's murder, detectives flew Ms Cable to southern Spain to identify the man suspected of killing her fiancé. She told the Mail on Sunday of spotting Noye in a restaurant: "There were lots of people, and I was shaking. I saw him straight away. I just looked at him. I felt hatred. My stomach was churning and my heart was pounding. I felt I wanted to say something, but no words would have come out anyway."

Two weeks after she returned, police told her to go on holiday for her safety. "I never went back home. I haven't been back since."

In her new life she often wears a wig to disguise herself and will be photographed only in silhouette. "I have lost twice - Stephen and my old life," she said. "I haven't seen two of my brothers since I was relocated, and I didn't see my mother for four months."

Ms Cable is planning to marry a soldier who has helped her to recover from witnessing the stabbing. "I always said I would never love anybody again. But I met someone, and although I love him in a different way he is brilliant."

Scotland Yard yesterday refused to comment on reports that Noye, 52, is being investigated in connection with a string of gangland murders.

According to the reports, detectives believe that the south London car dealer John Marshall, found shot dead in his Range Rover a few days after Noye fled to Spain, may have been killed on his orders.

Marshall is believed to have supplied Noye with false number plates and papers for the Land Rover he was driving when he killed Mr Cameron. Noye is said to have ordered Marshall's murder before he could be questioned by police.

Noye has also been linked to the shooting of Daniel Roff, found dead in his car outside his house in Bromley, Kent, in March 1997. Roff was suspected of being involved in the murder of Noye's close friend, the great train robber Charlie Wilson.

webTitle: Rampton under fire over care of women

fields.headline: Rampton under fire over care of women
fields.trailText: The care and treatment of women patients at Rampton high security hospital is to be scrutinised by outside experts after an internal report found a breakdown in management and registered "very serious concerns" about its services.
fields.body:
The care and treatment of women patients at Rampton high security hospital is to be scrutinised by outside experts after an internal report found a breakdown in management and registered "very serious concerns" about its services.

The external review is being arranged nine months after the report recommended it.

Since the start of this year, the staff say, one woman patient has been handcuffed to a bed while being treated, a second attempted to blind herself in solitary confinement, and a third was discovered to have been hoarding medication.

Rampton is acknowledging that there have been "difficulties" with services for women patients, but says action was taken to put things right. Unlike the other special hospitals Ashworth on Merseyside and Broadmoor in Berkshire, Rampton has been relatively free of recent controversy. But ministers are known to be considering generally the question of the suitability of 'special' hospitals for female patients.

An anonymous group of Rampton staff, described as "concerned insiders", has sent the Guardian a copy of the internal report, dated last July, and details of serious incidents.

According to the report, the 64 women at the Nottinghamshire hospital last summer were being treated in a culture of low morale and very limited clinical care and therapy. Staff sick leave was running at 8.5% and it appeared that only three new staff had been recruited in the previous 30 months.

While women represented only one in seven of all Rampton patients, women's wards were accounting for half the staff accidents and injuries sustained from assault, as well as 70% of all patient "incidents". The wards also showed most use of seclusion or solitary confinement.

The report says there was a lack of leadership on the wards and a perception of "lack of humanity" from staff. Many nurses were thought to show negative attitudes towards patients, labelling them "bad more than mad", and were "very markedly negative or frankly hostile" towards professional visitors.

Although no single incident or series of events justified a full-blown inquiry, the report concludes, only an external review could adequately address the issues raised.

Women patients spend, on average, six years at Rampton, although some have been there 25 years. Most, but not all, have committed serious offences. Several have been transferred from Ashworth.

Sean Payne, Rampton's director of nursing practice, said the report had prompted a wide range of action including a new management team for women's services, led by James Rooney, deputy director of nursing and co-author of the report. Sixteen additional staff had been hired, long-term sick leave had been halved, and use of seclusion had dropped by 70% since January.

Rampton has recruited a psychiatrist, a manager and a nurse who next month begin their review of the women's services.

fields.headline: Jobs surge as wages weaken
fields.standfirst: Millennium effect fades
fields.trailText: Employment prospects in Britain's booming labour market are at their best for eleven years, while wage inflation is declining, two new surveys reveal today.
fields.body:
Employment prospects in Britain's booming labour market are at their best for eleven years, while wage inflation is declining, two new surveys reveal today.

Nearly half of British firms plan to employ more staff over the next three months, according to analysts at Dun & Bradstreet.

Employers in the West Midlands are among the most optimistic in the country, despite the job losses expected to follow from BMW's sell-off of the PRover plant at Longbridge in Birmingham.

D&B surveyed 1,600 business and finance directors in the last week of March and the first week of April, just as the Rover decision was announced.

"The latest survey is very good news for employment prospects across the country," said Philip Mellor, senior analyst at Dun & Bradstreet. "We are however concerned that the increases in employment in the south east may tighten the labour market and create a labour shortage that could push up wages and fuel inflation."

But a separate survey showed that pay demands are moderating in the services sector despite the tightening job market. The latest Confederation of British Industry pay databank, published this morning, shows that service sector pay awards averaged 3.3% over the last quarter, compared with 3.7% over the same period a year ago.

Evidence that pay demands are falling will be welcome news for policymakers at the Bank of England, who are watching the labour market closely for signs of wage inflation.

"This data should ease concerns that service sector pay is in danger of spiralling upwards, putting pressure on inflation and triggering another hike in interest rates," said Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economic adviser. "It confirms our view that interest rates should not rise again."

The CBI's pay databank showed that wage settlements in manufacturing have picked up from recent lows. Awards averaged 2.6% in the first quarter of this year, higher than the 2.2% recorded in the previous quarter but below the 2.8% rate recorded a year ago.

Employers in the north east are the most optimistic, according to the Dun & Bradstreet survey. They are followed by those in the north west, London and the south east. The most buoyant sectors are wholesalers, construction and services.

Most of those surveyed expect the business climate to continue to improve, with 71% of respondents expecting increased sales and 61% expecting higher profits.

"The main clouds on the horizon are an expected increase in selling prices and continuing difficulties over exports due to the strength of the pound," D&B's report said.

The next official indicator of the temperature of the labour market will come this Wednesday with the release of the monthly unemployment and average earnings figures. Although the jobless total has fallen at a slower pace in recent months, analysts think that seven year decline which has taken unemployment to a twenty year low has yet to bottom out and that another fall of between 7,500-10,000 is likely.

Average earnings have been boosted by bonuses and special payments for millennium working since the turn of the year and should start to show some signs of easing off this month, according to analysts at HSBC markets.

fields.headline: To London without love
fields.standfirst: Blair should get tougher with Putin
fields.trailText: Blair should get tougher with Putin
fields.body:
The United Kingdom and Russia need good relations, but not at any cost. Tony Blair's rush to embrace Vladimir Putin, first with his visit to St Petersburg during last month's election campaign and now by hosting the Russian president-elect in London, is shameful, unseemly and surprisingly old-fashioned. It has disturbing echoes of the Soviet period when western statesmen often competed with each other to see who could develop the best special relationship with the Kremlin. That was the Old Diplomacy and it ought to have been discarded in an era when state planners no longer decide on contracts and European governments profess their aspirations to a common foreign policy. Mr Blair's infatuation with Mr Putin also has echoes of the Yeltsin years, when western governments invested too much in personalities rather than process. Instead of trying to encourage the growth of democratic institutions, the values of the parliamentary way, public accountability, and a system of checks and balances, they made the mistake of endorsing almost everything the increasingly vain and ailing autocrat in the Kremlin did, as long as he called it "reform".

With President Yeltsin's departure the west had a chance for a fresh start, yet Mr Blair did not even observe the niceties of meeting any other presidential candidates when he travelled to St Petersburg. What kind of message of respect for pluralism did that send? The precipitate invitation for Mr Putin to visit the United Kingdom is doubly misguided at a moment when international criticism from respected human rights organisations and independent observers over Russia's tactics in its war in Chechnya is mounting. The prime minister argues that he did raise his concerns over Chechnya during his visit and did ask Mr Putin to provide access to international monitors. His overtures failed. And when the Council of Europe debated Russia's suspension two weeks ago it was UK diplomats who sought the softest resolution.

It would have been much better for the UK to hold back until after Mr Putin is inaugurated next month. We do not want a freeze with Moscow, but nor do we want unseemly friendliness. Instead, we should stick to a cool and united European line which makes it clear to Moscow that the kind of brutalities being perpetrated by Russian forces in Chechnya are unacceptable on this continent. On Kosovo Mr Blair saw more clearly than some other leaders that the Serbian security forces' tactics of overkill and their wanton failure to distinguish between combatants and civilians were outrageous. It is strange he does not understand that Russian forces are acting similarly in Chechnya.

No one doubts that Chechens have also committed atrocities, but neither under international law nor under the values of the Council of Europe does that justify atrocities in return. Tony Blair's rush to embrace Vladimir Putin, first with his visit to St Petersburg during last month's election campaign and now by hosting the Russian president-elect in London, is shameful, unseemly and surprisingly old-fashioned. It has disturbing echoes of the Soviet period when western statesmen often competed with each other to see who could develop the best special relationship with the Kremlin. That was the Old Diplomacy and it ought to have been discarded in an era when state planners no longer decide on contracts and European governments profess their aspirations to a common foreign policy. fields.headline: Politicians blamed
fields.standfirst:
Warning on race hatred at Lawrence memorial service

Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: A congregation gathered yesterday to remember the murdered black teenager, Stephen Lawrence, was told that politicians who used "loaded" words in the debate about asylum seekers ought to be ashamed of themselves.
fields.body:
A congregation gathered yesterday to remember the murdered black teenager, Stephen Lawrence, was told that politicians who used "loaded" words in the debate about asylum seekers ought to be ashamed of themselves.

In his sermon at Trinity Methodist church, in Plumstead, south-east London, the Rev David Cruise praised the tireless work of Stephen's parents, Neville and Doreen in keeping his death in the public eye. He said it had reaped benefits for society as a whole.

The Rev Cruise told the 200-strong congregation: "We are thankful that there has been some progress, and more people are becoming equal in front of the law and the law is becoming less colour-blind."

But in a warning to politicians he said: "It is sad that in the last few weeks we have heard the use of loaded words, words such as bogus. Politicians who use those words ought to be ashamed of themselves. They do no credit to a just society. Those words will stir up a bad feeling. If the local government elections are tarnished by racism they will have themselves to blame."

Mr Cruise, a minister at the Marylebone Methodist church, central London, also criticised the police for failing to keep the Lawrences informed of developments in the search for their son's killers. Last week a knife and metal bar were discovered in the garden of a former address of two of the suspects in the murder inquiry. The congregation was told that the Lawrences had learned of this latest development from the newspapers.

The memorial service has been private since Stephen was murdered in April 1993 in Eltham, south-east London. The decision to allow in the public, Mr Cruise said, was to strike a positive note and allow more people to celebrate his life.

fields.headline: Kinski to head Hyder bid
fields.standfirst: Nomura calls ex-Stagecoach chief into talks
fields.trailText: Nomura, the Japanese investment bank with a reputation for turning around failing companies, has chosen Mike Kinski, the former head of Stagecoach, to spearhead its bid for the troubled Welsh utility group, Hyder.
fields.body:
Nomura, the Japanese investment bank with a reputation for turning around failing companies, has chosen Mike Kinski, the former head of Stagecoach, to spearhead its bid for the troubled Welsh utility group, Hyder.

Mr Kinski, who earned the nickname "Killer Kinski" for his ruthless cost-cutting approach, resigned from Stagecoach in a surprise move two months ago. Before he joined the bus company turned train operator, he was in charge of Scottish Power subsidiaries, ManWeb and Southern Water.

Nomura's talks with Hyder are at an advanced stage according to weekend press reports, which suggest the bank will offer a "small premium" on its £410m closing value last Thursday. An announcement is expected this week.

Bogged down with debt, Hyder's share price has sunk over the past year to a quarter of its 1998 high of £10.49. Adding to its woes, the water industry regulator, OfWat, ordered it to undertake a £1.7bn investment programme over the next five years and to cut prices by 12% this year.

The Nomura bid faces competition from Southern Company and Pennsylvania Power & Light, the owners of South West Electricity, but the US firms are only interested in Hyder's power distribution business. However, sources close to the board were quoted over the weekend as saying that the Nomura deal was by no means settled.

The Japanese bank's offer could face political hurdles, with Welsh politicians reluctant to see the principalities largest private sector employer in the hands of a financial institution. Welsh assembly leader, Rhodri Morgan, said he would be monitoring developments at Hyder.

webTitle: National Trust urged to abandon garden 'prudery'

fields.headline: National Trust urged to abandon garden 'prudery'
fields.trailText: The National Trust has been challenged to come clean about the passionate truth hidden beneath the smooth green curves of some of its most famous landscaped gardens.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The National Trust has been challenged to come clean about the passionate truth hidden beneath the smooth green curves of some of its most famous landscaped gardens.

"These gardens are all about sex, but their history is being covered up by National Trust prudery," said the architectural historian Dan Cruikshank. "This makes it impossible to understand their true significance and historical importance."

The sexual symbolism of the gardens - artificial hollows and mounds, temples and columns - would have been clear to an educated 18th-century audience steeped in classical culture, he said. The modern visitor needed a little extra help but none was offered by the guide books.

The most notorious garden, laid out as a naked woman beside a swan shaped lake to recall the legend of Leda, is primly described in the National Trust visitors' handbook as "a perfectly preserved rococo landscape garden".

Richard Wheeler, the trust's senior land agent for the region, said: "Our guide book is being rewritten. I'm sure it will be possible to incorporate a little more on the history of the garden."

Mr Cruikshank believes the censorship of the gardens reflects the blind eye turned to the sexual history of the 18th century. In a forthcoming programme in BBC2's One Foot in the Past series he stresses that tracts of Georgian London were built on the profits of the largest sex industry Britain has ever known. One in eight of adult females was a prostitute.

He suggested that the erotic gardens came not just from a time of unparalleled sexual frankness, but also from the interest in the classical culture of Greece and Rome, seen as an idyll of sexual licence and freedom as well as of great art and architecture.

The National Trust gardens at Stourhead in Wiltshire and Stowe in Buckinghamshire have temples to pagan gods, but the most blatant display was West Wycombe, laid out in the shape of a naked woman, centred on a Mound of Venus. It was created by Sir Francis Dashwood, politician, art lover, and founder of the Hell Fire Club and the Society of Dilettanti, devoted to pleasures of the flesh.

A regular guest, John Wilkes, an MP and mayor of London, fell out with the Hell Fire Club when he smuggled a baboon dressed as the devil into what was supposed to be a harmless Satanic ritual. "There is one remarkable temple in the gardens at West Wycombe, dedicated to the Egyptian hieroglyphic for **** [sic]. To this object his lordship's devotion is undoubtedly sincere, though I believe now not fervent," he wrote.

The entrance to the grotto within the mound, known as Venus's parlour, was described as The Gate of Life. Many of the most explicit aspects of the garden were swept away by the next generation of Dashwoods, who called in Capability Brown to restore order.

The temple with the statue of Venus, which tops the mound, was recently restored by the architect Quinlan Terry, commissioned by the latest Sir Francis Dashwood, who died three weeks ago and whose father gave the house and gardens to the National Trust.

In an article to be published in the New Arcadian journal, Mr Wheeler suggests that West Wycombe was planned as a parody of the nearby and far more famous Stowe, which was laid out as gardens of virtuous and vicious love: virtue was a chaste maiden pointing to a steep, stony, straight path; vice, though more picturesque, was ultimately deeply depressing.

Mr Wheeler said it would destroy the charm and mystery of the gardens to spell out their imagery in signs or guide books. "We are hiding nothing. These pleasures are here for people to stumble upon for themselves."

webTitle: IMF in need of a new faith

fields.headline: IMF in need of a new faith
fields.trailText: The timing could not have been better. Everybody, but everybody from the global financial community was in town for the spring meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund and what happens? Shares go crashing on Wall Street.
fields.body:
The timing could not have been better. Everybody, but everybody from the global financial community was in town for the spring meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund and what happens? Shares go crashing on Wall Street.

For someone who has long argued that America has been dangerously gripped by a stock-market mania, there was something utterly compelling about watching the US TV channels that have been complicit in whipping up the frenzy trying to explain to their viewers what had gone wrong.

Actually, it was quite simple. The technology sector - and to a lesser extent the whole of the US stock market - was ludicrously over-valued and was destined to fall. On Friday it did.

Eddie George appeared remarkably relaxed about the 25% weekly decline in the Nasdaq when he spoke after Saturday's meeting of G7 finance ministers and central bank governors. Privately, some of the foreign officials in Washington considered the puncturing of the bubble a healthy development and are keen for the market to fall still further.

Whether that will happen remains to be seen, but even if it doesn't, Wall Street's tumble highlighted some of the vulnerabilities of the international financial system and forced those charged with running it to explain exactly what they are doing.

Gordon Brown said there should be no retreat into isolationism and protectionism, and he's right about that. He also said that the world needs international institutions like the Fund and the Bank, and he's right about that too. Those who believe the Bretton Woods institutions are inherently corrupt are not only wrong, but are giving succour to extremists on the right who oppose all but minimalist government and despise internationalism.

Now, the Fund and the Bank need to re-think how to manage the global economy. For years, they have operated rather like the mediaeval Vatican, insisting on the one true faith. It should come as no surprise to find that they are now faced with a group of unruly heretics who not only refuse to believe but are prepared to resist.

Wounding attack

The heretics are not all eco-warriors and anarchists. Perhaps the most wounding attack on the Fund last week came from Joseph Stiglitz, until recently the chief economist of the Bank. The main thrust of Stiglitz's article in the New Republic magazine was that the IMF had woefully mishandled the financial crises of 1997-98, but he widened his argument with an attack on the Fund for its secrecy, its arrogance and its wrong-headed policies, describing it as full of "third-rank students from first rate universities". Ouch.

"When the IMF decides to assist a country, it dispatches a 'mission' of economists," he said. "These economists frequently lack experience in the country; they are more likely to have knowledge of its five-star hotels than the villages that dot its countryside." Ouch, ouch.

The second most compelling read of the week came from the Fund itself. In an overview of the world economy's development in the 20th century, it said that the past 100 years had been seen a stupendous increase in economic output, with goods and services exceeding everything that had been churned out between the dawn of time and 1900.

At the same time, however, inequality between the world's rich and poor regions, measured by output per capita, has also increased dramatically. GDP per capita in Africa is lower today than it was in the rich countries in 1900.

The Fund then divides the 20th century into four distinct periods - the Gold Standard era, the two world wars and the great depression, the 1950-73 boom, and the period of globalisation.

What the Fund believes is that "modern financial markets promote the mutually beneficial exchange between net savers and users of capital for productive purposes over increasing numbers of economic agents and ever larger territories, thus contributing to the optimal use of capital and the maximisation of world output."

Its figures, however, show that comfortably the most successful period of the past 100 years was 1950-73, "characterised by exceptionally rapid output per capita growth (2.9% per year on average) and the recovery of world trade under the Bretton Woods system of fixed exchange rates and widespread capital controls." The Fund says that pegged, but adjustable exchange rates and control of capital movements gave governments room to address domestic problems, while the IMF oversaw the international system, remarkably successfully too.

"During the Bretton Woods period, the stability of the real economy and of exchange rates reinforced each other. Wage pressures were moderate, reflecting the impact on labour markets of memories of high unemployment in the 1930s and rapid non-inflationary real wage growth, made possible by unexpectedly high productivity growth. Finally, capital controls remained in place, limiting the instability from disruptive international financial flows."

Golden Age a fluke

It may have been that the Golden Age was a fluke, a period of catch-up, with the world economy able to grow unusually rapidly due to the existence of a global output gap caused by the devastation of war. Some might say that growth would have been still faster, if trade and capital had been allowed to cross borders more easily. The alternative way of looking at things, however, is to say that the policies that worked so well once might work again. Indeed, the experience of Malaysia is that the sky does not fall in if countries re-impose capital controls. Malaysia's recovery has been as quick as any in south-east Asia.

The Fund fully accepts that "a pegged exchange rate, independent national monetary policy, and unrestricted international capital mobility cannot be achieved simultaneously." So, if one of the three has to be sacrificed, which? The argument in favour of liberalising capital flows is that more efficient markets enable money to flow where it is needed, and to countries without sufficient domestic savings to fund investment.

However, the tendency has been for removal of controls to be followed by a surge of capital inflows, much of which has been for speculation rather than long-term investment. The counterpart to a surplus on the capital account has been a deficit on the current account, which has precipitated a crisis, leading to capital flight and austerity programmes under the aegis of the IMF.

This is the way the Fund describes what has happened. " Starting in the 80s, controls on international capital movements were dismantled in many countries in pursuit of efficiency gains from deregulation. The resulting large increase in internationally-mobile capital flows combined with domestic policy imbalances and volatile exchange rate expectations to generate repeated international financial crises."

It seems a bit of a no-brainer. The Fund and the Bank agree that the priority is to tackle poverty and global inequality. But governments find it harder to pursue growth strategies and redistribution if they are in thrall to capricious global markets. So the solution should be to maximise domestic opportunity and provide the environment for countries to develop their own domestic financial institutions and create a flourishing market economy.

One would have hoped some of the eggheads at the Fund would be proposing this. But maybe Stiglitz is right and they're not so clever after all.

fields.headline: Growing right
fields.standfirst:
Are conservatives losing their best lines?

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: If generals are forever prone to fight the war before last, politicians too seem bent on policies that fit yesterday's circumstances rather than tomorrow's. Arguably, what the Labour high command did prior to the 1997 election was an excellent approximation to the circumstances of 1995 rather than 2001. It certainly seems to be characteristic of the Tories' feeble attempts to re-equip themselves for office. We can have it all, Michael Portillo announced yesterday: tax cuts and extra social spending. If the chancellor is awash with billions we, too, will benefit from the dissolution of age-old trade-offs between taking and giving. But you do not have to see Friday's "correction" on Wall Street, likely to reverberate around the City today, as a sign of the impermanence of present conjuncture. Nor to wonder whether counting the costs of such growth might not provide the Tories with political opportunity.
fields.body:
If generals are forever prone to fight the war before last, politicians too seem bent on policies that fit yesterday's circumstances rather than tomorrow's. Arguably, what the Labour high command did prior to the 1997 election was an excellent approximation to the circumstances of 1995 rather than 2001. It certainly seems to be characteristic of the Tories' feeble attempts to re-equip themselves for office. We can have it all, Michael Portillo announced yesterday: tax cuts and extra social spending. If the chancellor is awash with billions we, too, will benefit from the dissolution of age-old trade-offs between taking and giving. But you do not have to see Friday's "correction" on Wall Street, likely to reverberate around the City today, as a sign of the impermanence of present conjuncture. Nor to wonder whether counting the costs of such growth might not provide the Tories with political opportunity.

The Tories are, not for the first time, taking a leaf out of an American book. Republican nominee George W Bush is proposing a huge increase in defence spending plus big increases in education and health - guns, butter and tax cuts.

Perhaps, believing that public spending on social services is generally an at tribute of civilised society and can even be an agent of greater equality, we should welcome the right to the fold. But it is worth noting how conservatives (if that is what the right are) may be closing off useful political options by espousing "big growth". Staking your fortune, or at least your fiscal honesty, on painless revenue you effectively sign up to the turbo-capitalism that has been driving growth ...and the pain, job losses and dislocations that come as part of the package. Doesn't that rob "conservatives" of some of their best lines?

Were our Tories more European-minded (and of course anti-Europe has become their plank, somewhat problematic as growth in the euro-zone picks up) they might be swopping notes with the German conservatives, the Christian Democrats. In Angela Merkel they have a new president, but agonisingly face some old questions. Is the CDU the party of small business rather than growth-generating corporations, of xenophobes who for example oppose "green cards" for Indian software engineers? Glib assumptions about economics and revenues cannot wish away profound questions about what the right or conservative tag nowadays means.
fields.bodyText: If generals are forever prone to fight the war before last, politicians too seem bent on policies that fit yesterday's circumstances rather than tomorrow's. Arguably, what the Labour high command did prior to the 1997 election was an excellent approximation to the circumstances of 1995 rather than 2001. It certainly seems to be characteristic of the Tories' feeble attempts to re-equip themselves for office. We can have it all, Michael Portillo announced yesterday: tax cuts and extra social spending. fields.headline: Spring clean blues
fields.trailText: We were hoping to start the spring with a lovely new kitchen, but things have gone horribly wrong. Building work has flushed out the hidden wildlife and thrown it into turmoil. And Builder had to stop work halfway through because some vital bits of kitchen are missing.
fields.body:
We were hoping to start the spring with a lovely new kitchen, but things have gone horribly wrong. Building work has flushed out the hidden wildlife and thrown it into turmoil. And Builder had to stop work halfway through because some vital bits of kitchen are missing.

So before work can start again, Olga and I must go back into hell (Ikea) for all the bits that weren't available or were warped/missing/the wrong size when Builder went to collect them. Despite persistent warnings from the media, countless customers and our own experience, Builder has recommended this outfit. It has the largest range of sizes and is relatively cheap, says he.

No it isn't. Olga adds up the cost of our time as we queue for parking, exchanges, orders, collection and the one sluggardly lady in the canteen to slop out our Swedish meatballs. "Here we are, two professional women spending five hours each to get one door, one cupboard leg and two shelves," shouts Olga, who has come with me to save me from breakdown.

Perhaps I should have just stuck with the slum conditions. It has taken me two days to hoover my bedroom. Although I have a fierce and relatively new vacuum cleaner, it needs help with the carpet. It can swallow nails, sacks, coins and half the bedspread, but it cannot manage fluff. So usually I leave it for months, the dust mites multiply, my hay fever returns, my mother moans on about the filth, I forget why I haven't vacuumed and try once more. But unless one lives alone, slum conditions are not an option.

For years my mother and daughter have studied other homes, made comparisons and returned dissatisfied to our hovel. They have sulked, wept, screamed and demanded improvements. Now at last I have given in. Because, secretly, I also long to be smart, tidy and normal. So the improvements have begun, with the kitchen. But will they ever end?

webTitle: Biotechnology firms are running out of cash

fields.headline: Biotechnology firms are running out of cash
fields.trailText: Europe's biotechnology sector leapt in value to 17.8bn euros (£11bn) last year but many companies are still perilously short of cash, according to a report out today.
fields.body:
Europe's biotechnology sector leapt in value to 17.8bn euros (£11bn) last year but many companies are still perilously short of cash, according to a report out today.

The study, by accountancy firm Ernst & Young, finds that the sector's value jumped 66% in 1999, reversing two years of decline. It highlights the appearance of a "big tier" of companies worth more than 1bn euros - including Celltech, Bioglan and Oxford Glycosciences.

However, Ernst & Young has compiled a "survival index" showing that a fifth of companies have less than a year's worth of funds in the bank.

Senior consultant Glenn Crocker said: "The European life sciences industry is going through an evolutionary step change." He said a "new sense of urgency" was emerging, adding that "at a time when the industry is emerging from a range of harsh financial conditions, the fittest have survived and evolved into stronger entities."

A number of companies have already taken advantage in the stockmarket's revived interest in biotech to plug the gap in their bank balances. Gyrus and Cambridge Antibody Technology are among those which have recently completed major fundraisings.

Ernst & Young's survey finds that increased revenue will help keep companies above water. Industry revenue jumped 45% to 5.4bn euros last year, helped by 241 strategic alliances with big pharmaceuticals companies.

Dr Crocker said such deals were often true alliances with guaranteed funding, rather than tie-ups conditional on the achievement of milestones and royalties. He said: "Biotech took a major step up the evolutionary ladder in 1999."

webTitle: Granada on hand to snap up TV assets of Border

fields.headline: Granada on hand to snap up TV assets of Border
fields.standfirst: Further step in consolidation of network
fields.trailText: The consolidation of the ITV network took a further small step forward last night after Granada agreed to buy the TV assets of Border Television from Capital Radio for £50.5m.
fields.body:
The consolidation of the ITV network took a further small step forward last night after Granada agreed to buy the TV assets of Border Television from Capital Radio for £50.5m.

The sale depends on the conclusion of the agreed £146m takeover of Border by Capital which was announced at the end of last week. It could yet be scuppered by Scottish Radio Holdings which saw its offer for Border topped by Capital and is considering whether to return to the table.

Capital chief executive David Mansfield said on Thursday it would be "wrong to assume" that he would sell the TV assets as soon as practicable but the agreement is a neat exit for a company which avowedly has no interest in developing a presence outside radio.

Capital is acquiring Border for its four radio stations which together have a potential reach of 9.2m adults. Three operate under the Century brand in the north-east, north-west and east Midlands and the fourth at Sun FM.

Granada chief executive Charles Allen said: "This is a good deal for our shareholders and reinforces our determination to be at the forefront of ITV consolidation."

The acquisition of the TV assets has been structured so that it will not muddy Granada's larger ambitions - to buy either United News & Media or Carlton Communications. Granada has a three-year call option on Border which means the transaction need not go through, adding the franchise's 0.5% viewing share to Granada's total, until the bigger deal is done.

Granada was always considered the most obvious buyer of Border's TV business and is understood to have approached Capital on Friday.

It already handles national airtime sales and transmission for the franchise which covers the largely rural area between England and Scotland as well as the Isle of Man.

Border was one of only three independent ITV companies left and has held the franchise for almost 40 years.

Capital has secured a six-month exclusivity arrangement with Granada which means the ITV company would not be able to do a similar deal with any other rival buyers of Border.

Mr Mansfield said the agreement with Granada was "an excellent deal. This agreement further strengthens our bid for Border.

"It provides a long-term future for Border's TV business with a group which is committed to the development of TV assets and enables Capital to be totally focused on doing what we do best - building successful radio businesses," he added.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Heroin batch kills three users
The deaths of three drug users in Bournemouth in Dorset may be due to a batch of unusually pure or contaminated heroin.
fields.body:
Heroin batch kills three users
The deaths of three drug users in Bournemouth in Dorset may be due to a batch of unusually pure or contaminated heroin.

A woman, 32, was found dead on Saturday, together with a man, 39, who died in hospital. Later a man, 32, was found dead elsewhere in the seaside town. Tests are being done to establish any link.

TA corporal dies in range shoot
North Yorkshire police were yesterday investigating the death of a Territorial Army corporal during an organised shooting competition near Richmond. The man's identity is not being released.

Civic duty for Street's Vera
Coronation Street's Vera Duckworth gets a new part next month - as lady mayoress of Leeds. Actress Liz Dawn, 60, who lives in the city, has been picked by the incoming mayor, fellow thespian Bernard Atha. She said she would ask her soap counterpart, councillor Audrey Roberts, for tips.
Martin Wainwright

A good nose for memory
Smell is a better memory cue than words or pictures, the British Psychological Society conference in Winchester was told yesterday.

Simon Chu recounted how in China families registered an event by talking it over while passing a pot of pungent herbs between them, and years later the herbs would recall that day.

'Junk' finding on children's food
A study for the Food Commission says packaging for children's food - cartoon characters and gifts - cannot hid the fact it is "junk".

The lobby group surveyed 358 supermarket items: only four were found to declare their nutritional content and to be low in fats, sugar and salt - frozen vegetables with cartoons on them.

Two £10m wins on lottery
Two tickets won £10m each in Saturday's lottery draw, matching winning numbers 2, 23, 28, 31, 46 and 48; the bonus was 42. There was no top winner in the Thunderball draw, with 2, 14, 25, 30 and 33; the Thunderball number was 12.

fields.headline: Green revolution waged after death
fields.standfirst:
The growth in eco-friendly funerals and woodland burial sites is placing traditional undertakers under pressure

Natural Death Centre
fields.trailText: The fastest growing environmental business in Britain is disposal of the dead. Cardboard coffins, DIY funerals and woodland burial sites are taking an increasing slice out of the undertaker's business.
fields.body:
The fastest growing environmental business in Britain is disposal of the dead. Cardboard coffins, DIY funerals and woodland burial sites are taking an increasing slice out of the undertaker's business.

There are now 90 sites where headstones are banned and people are mostly buried in cardboard coffins so their passing leaves no mark on the environment. A tree is planted on each grave, creating woods in the countryside which are kept in trust for the enjoyment of future generations.

Environmentalists are being encouraged to book plots and make wills in a much cheaper method of disposal of the dead than the undertaker. Cremation is now frowned on because of the wasteful burning of expensive wood coffins and pollution to the atmosphere.

The new movement from traditional funerals is partly as a reaction to the high cost, now more than £2,300, and partly because of the impersonal nature of many crematoria. But it is mainly because it is seen as an environmentally responsible, according to the Natural Death Centre, a registered charity.

Yesterday's eighth National Day of the Dead celebrated the movement by urging supporters to light a candle for someone who has died and for the first time organised a visitors day at the woodland burial grounds that are opening at an accelerating rate around the country. Another 40 have applied for planning permission.

The internet is playing a large part in the revolution. All the information required to organise a woodland funeral, including coffin purchase and delivery and help with laying out the body and transport is available online. Costs are around £600.

All types of funerals are discussed and the legal and practical difficulties from burial in the garden to burial at sea which is difficult because of the red tape. Only around 40 a year take place as a result.

One internet tip adds: "Anyone with green pretensions should think twice about cremation - 437,000 wooden coffins are wastefully burnt in the UK each year, polluting the atmosphere with dioxin, hydrochloric acid, hydrofluoric acid, sulphur dioxide and carbon dioxide. Burial, even with a wooden coffin, locks the carbon underground and doesn't add to the greenhouse effect. And it helps to protect land from being used by humans, thus saving it for wildlife."

The best buys, tasteful cardboard coffins cost £55, and lists of helpful undertakers, crematoriums, carpenters and willow casket weavers are all available. The preferred option for this growing business appear to be graves in the countryside marked by a tree.

Woodland burials also allow families and friends to organise their own type of funerals. They can be religious or secular, last any length of time, be virtually silent, or involve music and even champagne.

There are some basic rules at woodland sites like no headstones and no metal. Wooden coffins, cardboard boxes, wicker baskets or simple woollen shrouds are all used with cardboard being the most popular. Trees are planted on each grave. The object is to create a natural woodland which in 30 years will not look like a graveyard but still provide a quiet unspoilt place to visit. By law each grave and the occupant of it must be recorded.

Yesterday's top prize for the best nature reserve ground went to Greenhaven woodland burial ground near Rugby, Warwickshire. The award was for exceptional value and friendly service. A complete funeral on the farm, including the grave, the digging, a carboard coffin, a tree and collection from London, costs £570.

Christine Atkin, who does the paperwork for the burials on the family farm in the village of Lilbourne, Northamptonshire, while her son, Nick, does the heavy work like digging the graves and collecting the dead, said she was delighted with the award. In four years there have been 300 burials in the two-acre plot on the farm and another 350 "bookings" for the 10ft by 6ft plots.

"We started it as a farm diversification. Daventry council was a little nervous but gave us planning permission and is now very enthusiastic, saying it is prepared to extend the plot if we need it."

Mrs Atkin said most of the burials come from a 50-mile radius. "We have a very large pile of letters from people who are delighted with the funerals service we have provided."

The cooperation of the local clergy has allowed Anglicans, Catholics, Quakers and Congregationalists to take advantage of the services.

Local churches are used sometimes for a pre-burial service or the clergy come to say prayers over the graves. "We do not go in for pomp and black hearses and black suits but we do have dignity. We have had guitars and bottles of champagne because people want to mark burials in different ways."

The family went to English Nature for advice on types of trees which would be suitable for a woodland and came back with a list including crab apple, wild cherry, oak and ash. Mrs Atkin added: "We do not have many woods in this part of the world because of intensive farming so burial ground will become a public amenity when it is full."

webTitle: Expulsion policy warning as third of pupils bullied

fields.headline: Expulsion policy warning as third of pupils bullied
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: One in three secondary pupils has been bullied in the last 12 months, according to a survey published today by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers.
fields.body:
One in three secondary pupils has been bullied in the last 12 months, according to a survey published today by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers.

Its poll of 2,600 pupils aged 11-16 also found that 26% said that they were threatened with violence, and 13% were attacked, over the same period.

The results were released as the association starts its annual conference in Belfast, where delegates are expected to warn the government that its policy of discouraging the expulsion of unruly pupils is causing problems for the obedient majority.

Peter Smith, the general secretary, said: "These findings are shocking. If young people are worried about their personal safety while at school, this begs the question how they are going to feel once they are in the big wide world.

"Schools do attempt to provide young people with a safe environment to learn. However, no matter how much a school tries to change its culture, bullying has a tendency to rear its ugly head. It seems that youngsters are increasingly becoming victims of violence."

The poll, conducted by Mori, showed younger secondary pupils were twice as likely to experience bullying as those in the GCSE year. More than half of 11-year-olds reported incidents, compared to a quarter of 15-16 year olds. But the older pupils were more likely to think their teachers were complacent about bullying, with 41% saying staff were unaware of the problem.

The survey found pupils' concern extended beyond the school gates, with 26% saying they were worried about travelling to and from school.

Girls were more likely to be concerned about their safety outside school, with 30% reporting fears compared with 22% of boys. Girls were also more likely to be worried about violence in school (44% compared with 39% of boys).

However, boys were more likely to have been threatened (33% compared with 19% of girls) and three times as many (19% compared with 6% of girls) reported being physically attacked in school.

The survey showed 43% of pupils were victims of bullying in the midlands, compared with 38% in the north-west. Pupils in Wales were the most likely to have had threats (31%) and south-west England had most actual attacks (16%).

Ministers have set targets to reduce the number of children excluded from school and playing truant by a third by 2002. However, teachers have warned that, if taken too far, "social inclusion" policies make it impossible for them to maintain discipline.

fields.body:
David Trimble yesterday staked his political future on an ambitious plan to sever the link between the Ulster Unionist party and the centuries-old Orange Order to strengthen the forces of moderation in the province.

The gamble, which has long been on the reformer's agenda, took most people by surprise. Critics declared that the Unionist leadership was risking a "witch hunt" or a "civil war" which could split the party before next year's likely general election.

The Unionist leader is already facing the threat of a challenge in his Upper Bann constituency at the election, made by Dennis Watson, a prominent Unionist and Orangeman who defected to Ian Pasiley's Democratic Unionist party (DUP).

Mr Trimble's allies and opponents both likened his declared modernisation to Labour's reshaping of its relationship with the trade unions. The Unionist leader is seeking changes to exclude four affiliated bodies - notably the Orange Order - from a reformed Ulster Unionist council (UUC).

At the moment the Orange Order has the right to send 120 delegates to the 860-strong UUC. The Young Unionist group - described by some as "very rightwing and untypical" - sends 34 with both the women and graduates' groups sending fewer.

If successful, the effect of the move would be to increase the freedom of manoeuvre enjoyed by Mr Trimble and his supporters in their search for a stable peace under the terms of the Good Friday agreement. The Orange influence has been blamed for divisions in the Unionist party and for Martin Smyth's leadership challenge last month.

Nationalists and republicans will welcome any moves that make the Unionist party less sectarian. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is giving Mr Trimble his backing as he struggles to get the suspended power-sharing executive back in operation.

In theory the leadership has a majority on the UUC which has backed his peace strategy. But Mr Trimble's critics warned that even grassroots Orangemen and their families who had backed their leader over the Good Friday agreement would not do so this time.

"It is wrong to cut off friends in the hope that enemies [Catholics] will join you," Mr Smyth said last night.

"David Trimble was happy to dance on the streets with these so-called fanatics and extremists in 1995," recalled another MP, Willie Ross, in a reference to Mr Trimble's support for the march to Drumcree church.

The Lagan Valley MP, Jeffrey Donaldson, claimed the move might be misinterpreted as an attempt to muffle voices opposed to the Good Friday agreement. "I would be concerned that the Unionist party would move to unilaterally break the link with the Orange Order at this time, especially given that the order has taken a particular position on the agreement.

Dermot Nesbitt, an ally of Mr Trimble, moved to reassure party members that they would be consulted. "The Ulster Unionist party, in order to survive, has to be seen to be pluralist, but it must also be mindful of its roots," he said. "What we want to do is strike a balance between knowing where our roots lie and reflecting a unionism for the 21st century."

The move was finally agreed in Belfast on Friday and only insiders have seen the detailed changes in rules. "These discussions have been ongoing for a number of months," Mr Trimble, himself an Orangeman, told the Sunday Telegraph.

Rebuffed on reform in 1995-96, Mr Trimble is expected to put his plans to his executive in May and to a special UUC meeting in June, before the start of the annual Protestant marching season in July. But reforms will have to be confirmed by the Unionists' annual meeting next March.

One critic in the UUP, David Brewster, said the reforms were the "first shot" in a civil war which could erupt between pro and anti-agreement voices in the Ulster Unionists.

"This move is a bit like a doctor faced with a patient who is haemorrhaging and who decides to rip out the backbone. It is foolish in the extreme," Mr Brewster declared.

webTitle: Resorts row over bussing of refugees

fields.headline: Resorts row over bussing of refugees
fields.standfirst: Fears of tension in coastal towns over 'freelance' placementsRefugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Abdul Waheed and five others arrived in Britain by lorry, stepping down at Dover to be met by handcuffs. In their 20s and 30s and of prime fighting age, they fled pressure from their fundamentalist government to take up arms in favour of the long flight by car, truck and foot to England.
fields.body:
Abdul Waheed and five others arrived in Britain by lorry, stepping down at Dover to be met by handcuffs. In their 20s and 30s and of prime fighting age, they fled pressure from their fundamentalist government to take up arms in favour of the long flight by car, truck and foot to England.

From the port, they were taken to Ashford in Kent and made their applications for asylum. Then they began the last leg of their long journey, as a a private agency paid by Kent county council loaded them on a bus and headed north.

Today, two months after arriving in the country they hope will give them sanctuary, they wait for news with 14 others in a Blackpool hotel.

Around them a row is brewing that is replicated in other resorts where accommodation is cheap and plentiful, amid concern that continuing "freelance" placement of refugees by authorities in the south of England that are acting outside official dispersal arrangements could lead to a summer of stretched resources and, potentially, worse in seaside towns.

According to the British Resorts Association, councils and MPs representing coastal constituencies, resorts continue to receive asylum seekers sent ad hoc and without notification by authorities in London and elsewhere in the south-east.

This is despite the launch this month of the Home Office's new centralised scheme designed to ensure a fairer distribution. Because it is being phased in over the year, and at first will deal only with the 40% who make claims at their point of entry, authorities reluctant to house refugees who apply "in country" in their areas can continue to take the legal but non-approved option of hiring private agencies to send applicants elsewhere.

Some 20 authorities, have pressed the home secretary, Jack Straw, to be permitted the special status granted to Kent, which from today will hand responsibility for both port of entry and in-country applicants over to the new national asylum support service. Their requests have been turned down, prompting concern that they may simply make freeelance arrangements.

Peter Hampson, director of the association, warns: "We are particularly worried about this summer season. Potentially, we could have high numbers of asylum seekers in resort towns competing for space with large numbers of UK visitors, some of whom may be less tolerant than others."

Refugee groups, meanwhile, fear that further "freelance" dispersal by authorities insistent that they, like Kent, have taken their fair share, will leave refugees isolated in areas with few appropriate services.

MPs, including those in Labour marginal seaside seats, are caught between constituents protesting at perceived preferential treatment given asylum seekers and the need to damp racist mudslinging in the run-up to local elections next month.

Gordon Marsden, MP for Blackpool South and secretary of the parliamentary "seaside group" of Labour MPs, has twice alerted the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, to the "ad hoc and apparently unplanned" placement, warning that the trend "jeopardises the success of planned dispersal by turning large sections of opinion locally in these towns against refugees". He said: "Credibility of the national system must be maintained, and unofficial arrangements make it easier for critics to condemn the system as a whole."

Councils sending seekers usually fail either to notify the receiving authority or to fulfil their obligations to continue to support refugees who applied for asylum in their area, according to Ivan Taylor, Labour leader of Blackpool council. "Our plea to southern councils is 'don't go round the back door, because you can find hoteliers who will take people'."

Blackpool has 23 "officially placed" asylum seekers including Iraqi Kurds and Kosovans, but is threatening legal action against hoteliers who accepted 150 refugees placed by agencies for London boroughs. Josie Hammond, secretary of Blackpool's Hotel and Guesthouse Association, acknowledged the agencies promised rich pickings. "The temptation was there for easy money, and, human nature being what it is, too many people never thought about the consequences ...

"There is no question there is a moral issue here concerning the plight of the asylum seekers, and they need care and protection. But how are they going to assimilate in a street of hotels whose population is changing every week?"

Blackpool is not alone. A Norfolk county council spokeswoman said: "We had a coachload of Kurds last week, just turning up [in Great Yarmouth] by bus. Kent had sent them and told us more or less as they arrived. There is no sign of this stopping."

On the south coast, one third of 800 asylum seekers in St Leonards near Hastings were sent from other authorities without notification, according to Labour MP Michael Foster. He said: "Unless there is a fairly quick move to a national scheme we will have to impose conditions on the support the government gives local authorities for asylum seekers."

Meanwhile, in their hotel beside the pleasure beach, Abdul and his friends are generally oblivious of the storm. Occupying themselves with English lessons, they have taught their landlady to make chicken with Afghani rice ("a bit spicy for me," she confides) and laugh about straightened circumstances that left one, Mohammed, wearing two left flip-flops.
