fields.headline: The means to an end
fields.standfirst:
Vladimir Putin's extraordinary rise from security services chief to Russian head of state stunned even his own supporters. But the credit goes to one man: Boris Berezovsky. Today, as Tony Blair becomes the first leader to welcome Putin to the west, George Soros reveals how the shadowy oligarch picked his own president

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin's extraordinary rise from security services chief to Russian head of state stunned even his own supporters. But the credit goes to one man: Boris Berezovsky. Today, as Tony Blair becomes the first leader to welcome Putin to the west, George Soros reveals how the shadowy oligarch picked his own president
fields.body:
The phenomenal rise of Vladimir Putin out of nowhere bore an eerie resemblance to the feat of political engineering that got Boris Yeltsin re-elected in 1996. From long experience with Boris Berezovsky, I saw his hand in both operations.

I first met the Russian financier and industrialist at the World Economic Forum in Davos in January 1996. The Communist candidate for the presidency of Russia, Gennadi Zyuganov, had been well received by the business community at Davos. I told Berezovsky that if Zyuganov was elected, he would not be safe in Russia.

I wanted him to support Grigory Yavlinsky, whom I considered the only honest reformer among the candidates, but I was naive. I did not realise to what extent Berezovsky was involved in dealings with Yeltsin's family. According to his own public statements, my warning about his safety concentrated his mind. He got together with the other leading Russian businessmen who were attending the Davos conference and they formed a syndicate to work for Yeltsin's re-election. That is how they became the oligarchs.

It was a remarkable piece of political engineering: Yeltsin started with an approval rating of lower than 10% and they succeeded in getting him re-elected. The campaign was managed by Anatoly Chubais. I do not know the details, but I can use my imagination. When one of Chubais's aides was caught leaving the Russian White House - the headquarters of the prime minister and his government - with some $200,000 (£125,000) in a suitcase, I am sure it was not play money.

The oligarchs extorted a heavy price for their support of Yeltsin. They received shares in the most valuable state-owned companies as security against loans they made to the state budget in an infamous "loans for shares" scheme. After Yeltsin won the election, these companies were put up for auction and the oligarchs divided them among themselves.

I know Chubais well. In my opinion he is a genuine reformer who sold his soul to the devil in order to fight what he called the red-brown menace - a combination of socialism and nationalism - which he believed would come to dominate Russia unless he did something to prevent it. After Yeltsin's re-election he again took charge of the economy, but he had difficulty controlling the oligarchs. I was greatly encouraged when Yeltsin brought Boris Nemtsov, the reformist governor of Nizhni-Novgorod, into the government and treated him as his adopted son. Chubais was tainted by the elections but Nemtsov was clean: he could stand firm where Chubais could not. I took this as a signal that the Yeltsin regime under the leadership of Chubais genuinely wanted to move away from robber capitalism toward legitimate capitalism.

The budget deficit and money supply were kept within bounds and back taxes began to be collected. Inflation and interest rates declined. Shareholder rights were better respected and the stock market boomed. It was against this background that I decided in 1997 to participate in the auction of Svyazinvest, the state telephone holding company. I agonised over the decision. I was aware of the pervasive corruption in Russia. It would have been easier to keep my hands clean by sticking to philanthropy, but I felt that Russia needed foreign investment even more than philanthropy. If Russia could not make the transition from robber capitalism to legitimate capitalism, all my philanthropy was in vain. So I decided to participate in a competing bid for Svyazinvest; it turned out to be the winning one. This was the first genuine auction in which the state was not short-changed. Although we paid a fair price, just under $2bn (£1.25bn), of which my funds put up nearly half, I calculated that it would prove to be a very rewarding investment if the transition to legitimate capitalism came to pass.

Unfortunately, that is not what happened. The auction precipitated a knockdown, drag-out fight among the oligarchs, a falling-out among thieves. Some of the oligarchs were eager to make the transition to legitimacy, while others resisted it because they were incapable of working in a legitimate manner. The main opponent of the auction and its outcome was Berezovsky. After his allies lost the auction, he vowed to destroy Chubais.

I had a number of heart-to-heart talks with him but I did not manage to dissuade him. I told him that he was a rich man, worth billions on paper. His major asset was Sibneft, one of the largest oil companies in the world. All he needed to do was to consolidate his position. If he could not do it himself, he could engage an investment banker. He told me I did not understand. It was not a question of how rich he was, but how he measured up against Chubais and the other oligarchs. They had made a deal, they must stick to it. He must destroy or be destroyed.

I came to witness at close quarters an astonishing historical spectacle in which powerful men tried to reverse the results not only of the auction but of the entire effort of the government to control the oligarchs. I was watching people fighting in a boat while the boat itself was drifting toward a waterfall. As part of a campaign of charges and countercharges, Berezovsky revealed that Chubais had received $90,000 (£60,000) from a book contract, which was in fact the other oligarchs' payment for his services as Yeltsin's campaign manager. Chubais was weakened and distracted by the constant need to defend himself. Tax collections required his personal intervention if they were to go forward, and tax revenues fell. There was a dangerous drift downward in the economy just as the Asian crisis of 1998 began to make its effects felt. It culminated in Russia defaulting on its internal debt in August 1998, which shook the international financial markets.

Yeltsin's family, under the guidance of Berezovsky, were meanwhile looking for a successor to Yeltsin who would protect them against prosecution after the presidential election. They finally found one in the person of Vladimir Putin, the director of the Federal Security Service (FSB). In the summer of 1999 he was made prime minister and selected as Yeltsin's candidate for the presidency. There was a flare-up in Chechen terrorist activity. When Shamil Basayev, one of the Chechen terrorist commanders, invaded neighbouring Dagestan, Putin reacted vigorously. The security forces attacked the terrorists and Putin issued an ultimatum, announcing that Dagestan would be cleansed of terrorists by August 25. The target date was met. The Russian population responded to Putin's handling of the situation enthusiastically and his popularity skyrocketed.

Then there was a series of mysterious explosions in Moscow in which entire apartments were blown up and some 300 people killed while they slept. In the panic that followed, fear and anger were directed against the Chechens, assisted by a carefully orchestrated campaign in the press and television. Putin invaded Chechnya and the Duma elections were held in an atmosphere of war hysteria. Very few candidates dared to oppose the invasion.

The Union of Rightist Forces, led by Chubais, Sergei Kiriyenko and other reformers, embraced Putin and scored quite well with 8.6%. Yevgeny Primakov, who had been considered the favourite candidate for the presidency, was decisively defeated. Yeltsin announced his resignation on New Year's Eve, virtually assuring the election of Putin as his successor. Primakov withdrew from the contest.

Back in 1996, Berezovsky and I had a number of very frank discussions about the election campaign. I got to know how he operates.

Then we became adversaries in the Svyazinvest auction, but we continued to talk to each other. I tried to convert him from robber capitalist to legitimate capitalist. He tried to use me in his campaign for the chairmanship of Gazprom - by far the most powerful commercial entity in Russia. In June 1997 he invited me to Sochi, on the Black Sea, to visit Viktor Chernomyrdin, who had been chairman of Gazprom before he became prime minister, and subsequently flew me back to Moscow in his private plane. He told me that both Chubais and Nemtsov supported his candidacy. I did not believe him, so I asked Nemtsov. That was the first he had heard about it. "Over my dead body," was his reaction.

Afterwards, I had lunch with Berezovsky at his "club", which was decorated, deliberately or not, in the way Hollywood would represent a mafia hangout. I was the only guest. I did not tell him what Nemtsov had said, but I did tell him that I had asked Nemtsov and that he had claimed that he did not know about Berezovsky's quest for the chairmanship of Gazprom. This made Berezovsky very angry and his anger gave me the chills. He did not say so, but he made me feel that I had betrayed him. It was a turning point in our relationship.

Berezovsky saw the world through the prism of his personal interests. He had no difficulty in subordinating the fate of Russia to his own. He genuinely believed that he and the oligarchs had bought the government by paying for Yeltsin's re-election and that the government had reneged on the bargain by allowing a genuine auction for Svyazinvest. He was determined to bring down Chubais for betraying him. When I warned him that he was pulling down the tent around him, he answered that he had no choice; if he showed any weakness he could not survive.

I could not understand this at the time, but in retrospect it makes perfect sense. Berezovsky could not make the transition to legitimacy; his only chance of survival was to keep people entangled in the web of illegitimate relationships that he had established. He had a hold on Yeltsin because of the favours he had arranged for Yeltsin's family. For instance, he had made Yeltsin's son-in-law a manager of Aeroflot, whose hard-currency revenues were diverted to a Swiss company called Forus, which, it was explained to me, meant "for us". This gave him power over Yeltsin that none of the other oligarchs had. Berezovsky also had a hold on Chubais, and when the chips were down he did not hesitate to use it. The money Chubais received for the book contract caused his temporary downfall.

Berezovsky and Yeltsin's family were looking for a way to perpetuate the immunity they enjoyed under Yeltsin's presidency. Berezovsky's situation became difficult when the scandal over the laundering of Russian illegal money in US banks broke in 1999. One way or another he had to find a successor to Yeltsin who would protect him. That is when the plan to promote Putin's candidacy was hatched.

On the flight from Sochi to Moscow in 1997, Berezovsky had told me stories about how he had paid off the anti-Russian military commanders in Chechnya and Abkhazia. So when the Chechens invaded Dagestan, I smelled a rat. I set up a test: would Basayev withdraw by the deadline set by Putin? He did.

There can be no doubt that it was the war in Chechnya that has propelled Putin to victory. Between 1994 and 1996, during the previous Chechen war, the Russian population was upset when it saw the devastation and suffering caused by the invasion of Chechnya. The protests by the mothers of enlisted soldiers and human rights activists helped to bring about a negotiated settlement. This time the reaction of the Russian population strongly contrasts with its earlier attitude. Admittedly, the Chechen terrorists must bear a large share of the blame. They captured aid workers and journalists, held them for ransom, and often killed them. There is hardly anybody left who dares to get involved with helping Chechens or with publicising the atrocities they have suffered. There has been a masterful manipulation of public sentiment against them.

At the beginning of the post-Gorbachev years, Russians had a positive aversion to violence. In fact very little blood was spilled in the early days, and on the rare occasions when people were killed - in the Georgian capital Tblisi, in Lithuania, and later in the siege of the Duma in October 1993 - public opinion turned against those who used force. Not any more. By electing Putin president, the Russians become more implicated than ever in the bloodshed in Chechnya.

There is a theory that a victim who has been sufficiently brutalised can become himself drawn to violence. The pattern seems to fit many violent criminals and it also seems to apply to ethnic violence. The Serbs have long considered themselves victims, and Milosevic could exploit this sentiment in pursuing a policy of ethnic cleansing. Something similar seems to have happened in Russia.

Putin will try to re-establish a strong state and he may well succeed. By accomplishing the transition from robber capitalism to legitimate capitalism Putin may well preside over an economic recovery; my investments in Russia, including the one in Svyazinvest, may finally pay off. But Putin's state is unlikely to be built on the principles of an open society; it is more likely to be based on the demoralisation, humiliation and frustration of the Russian people. It is likely to continue to exploit the sense of terror that people felt when the apartment buildings blew up, and seek to establish the authority of the state at home and the glory of Russia in the world. We are facing a prospect that could have been avoided if the open societies of the west had been more firmly committed to the principles of open society themselves.

In his farewell speech, Yeltsin asked for the forgiveness of the Russian people: for the fact that many of our hopes did not materialise; for things which to us seemed simple but turned out arduous.

"I want to ask forgiveness for the fact that I was not able to justify the hopes of some people who believed that we would be able to move forward in one swoop from a gray totalitarian and stagnant past to a bright, rich and civilised future. I believed it myself. But it did not work out like that."

What Yeltsin did not say is that he and many others put their faith in the west but the west did not live up to their admittedly exaggerated expectations. I can speak only for myself. At first I thought that western statesmen simply did not understand what was happening. That Gorbachev was willing to change the system was too good to be true, so they wanted to test it. They set hurdles, and when Gorbachev jumped over them, they set higher hurdles. Eventually they had to admit that the change was for real, but in the meantime they lost all respect for Russia as a superpower: they started treating Russians like beggars.

 This is an extract from George Soros's forthcoming book Open Society: the Crisis of Global Capitalism Reconsidered. It was first published in the New York Review of Books.

They received shares in the most valuable state-owned companies as security against loans they made to the state budget in an infamous "loans for shares" scheme. After Yeltsin won the election, these companies were put up for auction and the oligarchs divided them among themselves. I know Chubais well. In my opinion he is a genuine reformer who sold his soul to the devil in order to fight what he called the red-brown menace - a combination of socialism and nationalism - which he believed would come to dominate Russia unless he did something to prevent it. After Yeltsin's re-election he again took charge of the economy, but he had difficulty controlling the oligarchs. I was greatly encouraged when Yeltsin brought Boris Nemtsov, the reformist governor of Nizhni-Novgorod, into the government and treated him as his adopted son. Chubais was tainted by the elections but Nemtsov was clean: he could stand firm where Chubais could not. I took this as a signal that the Yeltsin regime under the leadership of Chubais genuinely wanted to move away from robber capitalism toward legitimate capitalism. The budget deficit and money supply were kept within bounds and back taxes began to be collected. Inflation and interest rates declined. Shareholder rights were better respected and the stock market boomed. It was against this background that I decided in 1997 to participate in the auction of Svyazinvest, the state telephone holding company. I agonised over the decision. I was aware of the pervasive corruption in Russia. It would have been easier to keep my hands clean by sticking to philanthropy, but I felt that Russia needed foreign investment even more than philanthropy. If Russia could not make the transition from robber capitalism to legitimate capitalism, all my philanthropy was in vain. So I decided to participate in a competing bid for Svyazinvest; it turned out to be the winning one. This was the first genuine auction in which the state was not short-changed. Although we paid a fair price, just under $2bn (£1.25bn), of which my funds put up nearly half, I calculated that it would prove to be a very rewarding investment if the transition to legitimate capitalism came to pass. Unfortunately, that is not what happened. The auction precipitated a knockdown, drag-out fight among the oligarchs, a falling-out among thieves. Some of the oligarchs were eager to make the transition to legitimacy, while others resisted it because they were incapable of working in a legitimate manner. The main opponent of the auction and its outcome was Berezovsky. After his allies lost the auction, he vowed to destroy Chubais. I had a number of heart-to-heart talks with him but I did not manage to dissuade him. I told him that he was a rich man, worth billions on paper. His major asset was Sibneft, one of the largest oil companies in the world. All he needed to do was to consolidate his position. If he could not do it himself, he could engage an investment banker. He told me I did not understand. It was not a question of how rich he was, but how he measured up against Chubais and the other oligarchs. They had made a deal, they must stick to it. He must destroy or be destroyed. I came to witness at close quarters an astonishing historical spectacle in which powerful men tried to reverse the results not only of the auction but of the entire effort of the government to control the oligarchs. I was watching people fighting in a boat while the boat itself was drifting toward a waterfall. As part of a campaign of charges and countercharges, Berezovsky revealed that Chubais had received $90,000 (£60,000) from a book contract, which was in fact the other oligarchs' payment for his services as Yeltsin's campaign manager. Chubais was weakened and distracted by the constant need to defend himself. Tax collections required his personal intervention if they were to go forward, and tax revenues fell. There was a dangerous drift downward in the economy just as the Asian crisis of 1998 began to make its effects felt. It culminated in Russia defaulting on its internal debt in August 1998, which shook the international financial markets. Yeltsin's family, under the guidance of Berezovsky, were meanwhile looking for a successor to Yeltsin who would protect them against prosecution after the presidential election. They finally found one in the person of Vladimir Putin, the director of the Federal Security Service (FSB). In the summer of 1999 he was made prime minister and selected as Yeltsin's candidate for the presidency. There was a flare-up in Chechen terrorist activity. When Shamil Basayev, one of the Chechen terrorist commanders, invaded neighbouring Dagestan, Putin reacted vigorously. The security forces attacked the terrorists and Putin issued an ultimatum, announcing that Dagestan would be cleansed of terrorists by August 25. The target date was met. The Russian population responded to Putin's handling of the situation enthusiastically and his popularity skyrocketed. Then there was a series of mysterious explosions in Moscow in which entire apartments were blown up and some 300 people killed while they slept. In the panic that followed, fear and anger were directed against the Chechens, assisted by a carefully orchestrated campaign in the press and television. Putin invaded Chechnya and the Duma elections were held in an atmosphere of war hysteria. Very few candidates dared to oppose the invasion. The Union of Rightist Forces, led by Chubais, Sergei Kiriyenko and other reformers, embraced Putin and scored quite well with 8.6%. Yevgeny Primakov, who had been considered the favourite candidate for the presidency, was decisively defeated. Yeltsin announced his resignation on New Year's Eve, virtually assuring the election of Putin as his successor. Primakov withdrew from the contest. Back in 1996, Berezovsky and I had a number of very frank discussions about the election campaign. I got to know how he operates. Then we became adversaries in the Svyazinvest auction, but we continued to talk to each other. I tried to convert him from robber capitalist to legitimate capitalist. He tried to use me in his campaign for the chairmanship of Gazprom - by far the most powerful commercial entity in Russia. In June 1997 he invited me to Sochi, on the Black Sea, to visit Viktor Chernomyrdin, who had been chairman of Gazprom before he became prime minister, and subsequently flew me back to Moscow in his private plane. He told me that both Chubais and Nemtsov supported his candidacy. I did not believe him, so I asked Nemtsov. That was the first he had heard about it. "Over my dead body," was his reaction. Afterwards, I had lunch with Berezovsky at his "club", which was decorated, deliberately or not, in the way Hollywood would represent a mafia hangout. I was the only guest. I did not tell him what Nemtsov had said, but I did tell him that I had asked Nemtsov and that he had claimed that he did not know about Berezovsky's quest for the chairmanship of Gazprom. This made Berezovsky very angry and his anger gave me the chills. He did not say so, but he made me feel that I had betrayed him. It was a turning point in our relationship. Berezovsky saw the world through the prism of his personal interests. He had no difficulty in subordinating the fate of Russia to his own. He genuinely believed that he and the oligarchs had bought the government by paying for Yeltsin's re-election and that the government had reneged on the bargain by allowing a genuine auction for Svyazinvest. He was determined to bring down Chubais for betraying him. When I warned him that he was pulling down the tent around him, he answered that he had no choice; if he showed any weakness he could not survive. I could not understand this at the time, but in retrospect it makes perfect sense. Berezovsky could not make the transition to legitimacy; his only chance of survival was to keep people entangled in the web of illegitimate relationships that he had established. He had a hold on Yeltsin because of the favours he had arranged for Yeltsin's family. For instance, he had made Yeltsin's son-in-law a manager of Aeroflot, whose hard-currency revenues were diverted to a Swiss company called Forus, which, it was explained to me, meant "for us". This gave him power over Yeltsin that none of the other oligarchs had. Berezovsky also had a hold on Chubais, and when the chips were down he did not hesitate to use it. The money Chubais received for the book contract caused his temporary downfall. Berezovsky and Yeltsin's family were looking for a way to perpetuate the immunity they enjoyed under Yeltsin's presidency. Berezovsky's situation became difficult when the scandal over the laundering of Russian illegal money in US banks broke in 1999. One way or another he had to find a successor to Yeltsin who would protect him. That is when the plan to promote Putin's candidacy was hatched. On the flight from Sochi to Moscow in 1997, Berezovsky had told me stories about how he had paid off the anti-Russian military commanders in Chechnya and Abkhazia. So when the Chechens invaded Dagestan, I smelled a rat. I set up a test: would Basayev withdraw by the deadline set by Putin? He did. There can be no doubt that it was the war in Chechnya that has propelled Putin to victory. Between 1994 and 1996, during the previous Chechen war, the Russian population was upset when it saw the devastation and suffering caused by the invasion of Chechnya. The protests by the mothers of enlisted soldiers and human rights activists helped to bring about a negotiated settlement. This time the reaction of the Russian population strongly contrasts with its earlier attitude. Admittedly, the Chechen terrorists must bear a large share of the blame. They captured aid workers and journalists, held them for ransom, and often killed them. There is hardly anybody left who dares to get involved with helping Chechens or with publicising the atrocities they have suffered. There has been a masterful manipulation of public sentiment against them. At the beginning of the post-Gorbachev years, Russians had a positive aversion to violence. In fact very little blood was spilled in the early days, and on the rare occasions when people were killed - in the Georgian capital Tblisi, in Lithuania, and later in the siege of the Duma in October 1993 - public opinion turned against those who used force. Not any more. By electing Putin president, the Russians become more implicated than ever in the bloodshed in Chechnya. There is a theory that a victim who has been sufficiently brutalised can become himself drawn to violence. The pattern seems to fit many violent criminals and it also seems to apply to ethnic violence. The Serbs have long considered themselves victims, and Milosevic could exploit this sentiment in pursuing a policy of ethnic cleansing. Something similar seems to have happened in Russia. Putin will try to re-establish a strong state and he may well succeed. By accomplishing the transition from robber capitalism to legitimate capitalism Putin may well preside over an economic recovery; my investments in Russia, including the one in Svyazinvest, may finally pay off. But Putin's state is unlikely to be built on the principles of an open society; it is more likely to be based on the demoralisation, humiliation and frustration of the Russian people. It is likely to continue to exploit the sense of terror that people felt when the apartment buildings blew up, and seek to establish the authority of the state at home and the glory of Russia in the world. We are facing a prospect that could have been avoided if the open societies of the west had been more firmly committed to the principles of open society themselves. In his farewell speech, Yeltsin asked for the forgiveness of the Russian people: for the fact that many of our hopes did not materialise; for things which to us seemed simple but turned out arduous. "I want to ask forgiveness for the fact that I was not able to justify the hopes of some people who believed that we would be able to move forward in one swoop from a gray totalitarian and stagnant past to a bright, rich and civilised future. I believed it myself. But it did not work out like that." What Yeltsin did not say is that he and many others put their faith in the west but the west did not live up to their admittedly exaggerated expectations. I can speak only for myself. At first I thought that western statesmen simply did not understand what was happening. That Gorbachev was willing to change the system was too good to be true, so they wanted to test it. They set hurdles, and when Gorbachev jumped over them, they set higher hurdles. Eventually they had to admit that the change was for real, but in the meantime they lost all respect for Russia as a superpower: they started treating Russians like beggars.  This is an extract from George Soros's forthcoming book Open Society: the Crisis of Global Capitalism Reconsidered. It was first published in the New York Review of Books.

webTitle: The fixer:  how Berezovsky pulls the strings in Russia

fields.headline: The fixer:  how Berezovsky pulls the strings in Russia
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The name of Boris Berezovsky, Russia's most notorious oligarch, arouses, at best, profound suspicion in Russia.
fields.body:
The name of Boris Berezovsky, Russia's most notorious oligarch, arouses, at best, profound suspicion in Russia. Many view the millionaire businessman - who became rich with the collapse of communism - with a loathing inspired by his influential backstage role in Russian politics.

Although he lost a significant part of his empire last year when he was distanced from the state airline Aeroflot, Berezovsky currently holds crucial stakes in two of Russia's main television channels and in several of the leading daily newspapers, as well as powerful chunks in the country's car-trade, oil and aluminium industries.

Since the mid-90s he has openly been using his business clout to exert influence over leaders in the Kremlin. Extremely charming and clever, he became a powerful figure in Boris Yeltsin's shadowy inner circle, "the family", a close associate of key presidential advisers and of Yeltsin's daughter and image maker, Tatyana Dyachenko.

Berezovsky makes no attempt to hide the role he played in ensuring Yeltsin's re-election in the 1996 presidential vote, when he and a group of other influential businessmen used their powers to pull the president back from certain defeat in the polls.

Russia's current president, Vladimir Putin, also owes a debt of gratitude to the tycoon. Putin's presidential victory was effectively secured during campaigning for last December's parliamentary elections, when a ferocious slur campaign run on Berezovsky's ORT TV channel eradicated his two main rivals. In a series of popular prime-time news shows, Moscow mayor Yuri Luzhkov was portrayed as a murderous conman, while gory footage of a hip operation was broadcast to demonstrate that the former prime minister Yevgeny Primakov (who had recently undergone surgery) was too frail to run the country.

Both men had been thought to be serious presidential contenders; both men later dropped out of the race. Berezovsky said that he was consulted by the show's producers and has freely admitted the role of his company in Putin's success. "I was extremely pleased [with ORT's work]," he said. "I believe they helped Russia with a historic task."

Berezovsky's involvement in the war in Chechnya is less clear. He was secretly recorded holding long negotiations with key warlords last year - although he claims he was trying to represent Russia's interests during the talks. Berezovsky's success at negotiating the release of hostages from Chechnya has also prompted suspicion about the closeness of his ties in the region. The Chechen president Aslan Maskhadov last week claimed that Berezovsky had helped finance warlords Shamil Basayev and Khattab in their separatist campaign.

Last December, the businessman was elected as the parliamentary representative for the nearby region of Karachevo-Cherkess - thereby securing himself immunity from prosecution. Swiss prosecutors continue to investigate the way two Berezovsky-owned companies in Switzerland handled revenues from Aeroflot's coffers.

Berezovsky's future under Putin remains unclear. Some commentators expect the new president to prove his independence by making a great show of cutting ties with the powerful tycoons who wielded so much influence over Yeltsin. In his election campaigning, Putin won himself much popularity by promising to exterminate the oligarchs as a class, but Putin may not have enough power yet to distance himself from his backer.

George Soros's feelings of hostility towards Berezovsky are reciprocated. The Russian responded with fury to Soros's description in this article of his club as a mafia hangout, pointing out the building had won a prize for the authenticity of its restoration. In a recent tirade he went on to describe Soros as a liar and a hypocrite who had blurred the line between business and philanthropy.

webTitle: Guilt may damage the immune system

fields.headline: Guilt may damage the immune system
fields.trailText: People who feel guilty about life's little pleasures may be damaging their health, psychologists claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
People who feel guilty about life's little pleasures may be damaging their health, psychologists claimed yesterday.

If you cannot eat a bar of chocolate or enjoy a long lie-in without it weighing on your conscience, you may suffer a weakened immune system, a new study has shown.

The research suggests that a positive outlook on life can have measurable health benefits, with guilt-ridden people more vulnerable to illness than hedonistic souls.

Researchers asked 30 students to list their favourite activities, giving them both a pleasure and a guilt rating from one to 10. Samples of saliva from the participants were then tested for levels of immunoglobulin A - an antibody which is the body's first line of defence against infection.

The team from Hull University found that high guilt ratings were accompanied by low immunoglobulin levels.

Geoff Howe, a chartered health psychologist who presented his findings to the British Psychological Society's annual conference in Winchester, said: "People with high pleasure ratios had high concentrations, and those beset with guilt feelings had lower concentrations."

The guilty volunteers would therefore be expected to suffer more colds, coughs, stomach upsets and other minor infections.

Eating chocolate, smoking, drinking alcohol and sleeping in very late were rated among the pleasures which provoked the most guilt, while reading a good book gave high levels of pleasure and no guilt. Sex had an average pleasure rating of nine and a guilt rating of just 1.6.

The activity which caused the greatest guilt feelings in some volunteers was watching the Australian soap Neighbours, which produced the top guilt rating of 10 against a pleasure rating of seven.

webTitle: Murdoch diagnosed with 'low grade' prostate cancer but keeps on working

fields.headline: Murdoch diagnosed with 'low grade' prostate cancer but keeps on working
fields.trailText: The billionaire media tycoon Rupert Murdoch has been diagnosed as suffering from "low grade" prostate cancer, his company said yesterday.
fields.body:
The billionaire media tycoon Rupert Murdoch has been diagnosed as suffering from "low grade" prostate cancer, his company said yesterday.

Mr Murdoch, 69, owner of the conglomerate News Corp Ltd, one of the most powerful media empires in the world, was diagnosed as suffering from the condition after a routine medical check in Los Angeles last week.

"His doctors have told Mr Murdoch the prognosis is very good and that it is an extremely low grade form of cancer. He has no intention of changing his work schedule," a spokesman for his company said in a statement released early yesterday.

The spokesman added: "He is to receive treatment. He will receive brief sessions of radiotherapy in a month's time. The treatment will last several weeks, and his doctors are confident that this will eliminate the problem."

Since his divorce from his second wife, Anna, last year, and his subsequent marriage to a former News Corp executive, Wendi Deng, 32, Mr Murdoch has been on what he described as a "serious health kick". In September he told Vanity Fair magazine he had been to an institute at UCLA where they had put him on a morning drink of frozen fruit and soya powder. He has also admitted to having a personal trainer who "tortures" him for an hour every morning in the gym at his LA home.

Mr Murdoch, who was born in Australia but has taken US citizenship, has four children. His empire spans newspapers, broadcast and satellite television networks, the Fox film studio and HarperCollins the book publishers.

Forbes magazine names him as one of the world's richest men, last year estimating his fortune to stand at $5bn (£3.1bn).

Despite the company's insistence yesterday that his illness will not alter his working schedule, the situation will be almost certain to re-ignite speculation about who will take over the reins at News Corp if he retires. His son, Lachlan, who now runs his father's operations in Australia, had been favourite to succeed at the top of the News Corp tree, but his chances appear to have been dealt a blow by Mr Murdoch's anointing of Peter Chernin, the president of the company, as the man most likely to take the helm.

fields.headline: Adoption support plan for councils
fields.trailText: Council social services directors are today promising to take personal charge of adoption work and to put it at the top of their agendas.
fields.body:
Council social services directors are today promising to take personal charge of adoption work and to put it at the top of their agendas.

They also plan jointly to assist councils which are struggling to succeed with adoption. One idea is to set up support teams to help them to learn from best practice elsewhere.

There has been relentless criticism of councils' stewardship of adoption services and calls for the work to be handed over to a national agency.

Directors of more than 150 English and Welsh social services authorities agreed on the plan at a private conference last week in Liverpool - as a group of MPs called on the Department of Health to send "hit squads" into councils performing poorly on adoption.

Under the directors' plan, they will review their departments' adoption services and advise their councils to strengthen arrangements and increase investment in them.

This will include providing extra resources for social workers once a child has been identified as ready for adoption; moving towards a targeted strategy for recruiting adoptive parents; improving support for new adoptive parents; and making adoption allowances more available.

The plan also calls for sharing "on a regional and national basis" of details of children available for adoption, and of families ready to adopt, and for smaller authorities to join together in adoption partnerships.

A report last week showed that about 2,400 children in England were awaiting adoption, while 1,300 families approved to adopt had not been matched with a child. Performance indicators suggest that while some authorities are achieving adoption rates of more than 10% others are managing less than 1%. The all-party parliamentary group on adoption says councils performing poorly should face intervention.

However, the Association of Directors of Social Services says it is a highly complex problem. Moira Gibb, its vice-president, said: "The action we have agreed to take will go some way to dispelling the myths and letting emerge a more balanced understanding of this terribly delicate and sensitive area of work."

webTitle: That little, brave man saved my life

fields.headline: That little, brave man saved my life
fields.standfirst: Few people apart from his constituents knew the name of the Lib-Dem MP for Cheltenham. Then a man walked into his surgery and attacked him with a sword. He talks to  Simon Hattenstone
fields.trailText: Few people apart from his constituents knew the name of the Lib-Dem MP for Cheltenham. Then a man walked into his surgery and attacked him with a sword. Nigel Jones talks to  Simon Hattenstone
fields.body:
Lost souls shuffle in and out of the Neighbourhood Resource Centre. They come here to find out what jobs are going, to get help with housing problems, share a cuppa. It's Friday afternoon, and on the quiet side even for Cheltenham. The locals can be defensive about the town's sleepy image. Many didn't like it one bit when the newspapers reported that this was the last place you'd expect someone to go crazy with a 3ft-long samurai sword.

On the wall are a series of mug shots under the heading Know Your Cheltenham Councillors. And on the bottom row is the smiling, kindly face of the Lib-Dem Andrew Pennington. Perhaps the shock is still so raw that no one has thought to replace it. Perhaps no one can bear to take his picture down.

It was on January 28 that Robert Ashman went to see local MP Nigel Jones and his part-time assistant Pennington. Ashman was unemployed, had recently lost his home and was on a downward spiral. He believed he was the victim of a conspiracy between the borough council and Lloyds bank. Ashman had visited the surgery many times, but this time he took a sword from under his coat and lunged at Jones's stomach. Ashman pinned him to a sofa with the weight of his body. The MP protected himself with both hands, which were shredded and needed more than 50 stitches, before escaping to call for help. When the police arrived they found Pennington dead with 11 stab wounds.

At the committal hearing, Jones said: "Rob landed on top of me. I can recall him growling and saying, 'Yes, Yes,' in a loud and disturbing manner. His eyes were bulging. From the moment the sword was out, I did not see Andrew again. I believe I was the intended victim of the attack."

Today, Ashman is due in court to make his plea. He is charged with the attempted murder of Nigel Jones and the murder of Andrew Pennington. At his committal a few weeks ago his lawyer argued there was insufficient evidence to sustain the charge of murder against Pennington - the implication being that Pennington had died after unfortunately getting in the way of Ashman's attempts to kill the MP.

There are reminders of the tragedy everywhere. While waiting for Jones I pick up a spring edition of the council paper, the Clarion. "A town in mourning," cries the sombre front-page headline. Jones arrives with two assistants. A big man with thick white hair and a hybrid beard, he looks rather jolly by nature. He holds out his hand to shake, and there is a neatly stitched crisscrossed patterning on his palm. Life lines. His little finger is somewhat littler than it used to be. It looks like a half-chewed saveloy. He says the police found his fingerprint on the floor of his office.

Jones, 51, is not working full time yet, but he is back doing most of his constituency work, including today's surgery. "I've been in parliament for a couple of days, but a couple of weeks back I had a very peculiar migraine and the doctor took a look at me and said I was doing too much... I haven't seen the loopy doctor yet." He smiles, tries to make a joke of it. I say it would be amazing if he didn't need psychiatric help. "I don't know. I'm probably being naive, trying to be brave although you know I'm no hero. But I'm aiming to talk to somebody to see if there's any way... it's the thought processes I need to get out of my system. Somehow I need to stop thinking about what happened."

Jones is a local lad. He speaks in a soft, comforting burr. You can sense those bewildered thought processes running ahead of the words, sometimes in opposition to them. "I wake up in the middle of the night. I used to get a good night's sleep." He has nightmares.

As well as learning to cope with the horror of the attack and the death of his close friend, Jones is currently living in a legalistic no-man's land. He repeatedly says that he can't talk about the incident or the alleged assailant in case it prejudices the trial. However frustrating, he can't yet answer the defence lawyer who asked why he "fled from the scene like a robber" - though the answer seems obvious enough to the rest of the world.

After the attack, he considered quitting politics, getting the hell out. Then the flowers and messages of support started coming, and he realised what had happened was a ghastly fluke rather than a reflection of the world he was now moving in. "I think it was summed up by the lady who wrote: 'Don't let evil win.' That struck home with me."

When did he find out that Pennington was dead? "The doctor told me..." He trails off.

Jones had known Pennington for almost 20 years. He tells me how Andy fell in love with a woman who died from multiple sclerosis; how it was Andy who convinced him to stand for parliament when they were holidaying in Portugal with Jones's family; how Andy masterminded the victory in 1992 when he acted as agent; how despite representing the prosperous conservative town of Cheltenham Andy's commitment had always been to the disadavantaged.

The day Pennington died, he had been to a meeting of a hospital trust to discuss the problem of how to maintain a secure environment for NHS workers dealing with the mentally ill. "Ironic," says Jones glumly.

The Neighbourhood Resource Centre is a makeshift while new offices are being prepared. Jones has not been back inside the old office. "I went and saw the flowers that generous people had put outside to commemorate Andy, and I just thought I can't go back in there." A man walks in to complain about the lack of playing fields for the local kids. Jones spends half an hour with him, weighing up the options. It's tedious, important work.

Since Pennington's death, his other assistant, David Fidgeon, has helped him with the surgeries. Has he noticed a change in his boss? "Mostly, no. But occasionally there is a mental absence when you're being spoken to," he tells Jones. "One of the jobs of an MP is to look interested when you're bored and I think you're less inclined to do that." Jones laughs long and hard: "It's a second chance," he says, "and I'm going to make the most of it."

Another man walks in, more distressed than the previous constituent. Like the alleged assailant, this man has also lost his job, his partner, and he can't see a way forward. After discussing the ways in which they can get his former company to pay him the money he's still owed, the man leaves, grateful and slightly more hopeful.

The surgery ends and we make our way towards the pub. Fidgeon points out the old office and says how shocked he was the first time he returned and found that the police hadn't cleared the place up. Jones turns away. Has he any sympathy for the assailant? "At some stage I will have to forgive him... that's the only way to put it behind me and get on with my life. I'm a long way from that, though."

Does he think Pennington saved his life? "Yes. I know deep inside that little, brave man saved my life. I wouldn't be here now if he hadn't been there." I ask him whether he feels guilty that he survived. "Not really. I've thought whether I could have done something else. But I don't think I could. My hands were ripped to pieces. There was no way I could have defended anybody. I knew I had to raise the alarm so that's what I did." We move away from the attack and Jones relaxes. He talks about football (his conflict of loyalties between Swindon Town and Cheltenham Town), beer (he is chair of the all-party parliamentary beer group but admits he's not much of a drinker), and eases into his favourite jokes.

His wife Katy has joined us. She throws her eyes towards the ceiling. "Oh, for God's sake! He does go on!" They offer me a lift to the station, introduce me to their 14-year-old twin daughters who are stuffing themselves with Kentucky Fried Chicken in the back of the people carrier. Katy says the next train isn't for a couple of hours so why don't I come home for a bite to eat. We knock back reheated KFC, talk politics and laugh about some of the presents Jones has been sent - a huge bouquet from the Daily Mail who were desperate for an interview, a crate of beer, frozen peas, a box of chocolates from that "nice" Tory Angela Browning, and a squidgy airplane from Manchester airport to help him regain his finger movement.

The two cats are resting on the window sill, the twins are checking their email, their oldest son Sam is out with his mates. Everything seems quietly contented. I ask Katy whether life has returned to normal. "Well, I don't feel sick in the stomach now like I did. For a time all I could do when I saw people was hug them and cry. I suppose I don't have much time to do my own thing at the moment - Nigel's frightened of going places by himself now."

He's doing pretty well, I suggest. It's not yet three months. Jones looks at his watch. "Eleven weeks and three hours," he says quietly.

fields.headline: Eve's legacy
fields.standfirst: When you walk in the garden...
fields.trailText: West Wycombe, Stourhead, Stowe and other 18th century landscaped gardens are "all about sex" but, so a story today goes, the prudish National Trust has covered it up. Like the proverbial Victorian table leg, the sexual metaphors on display in the gardens' contours, lakes, pathways and statuary have been censored. That ha-ha turns out to be a dirty joke. This swelling greensward is really flesh. And now we know why Sir Francis Dashwood, creator of West Wycombe park and mainstay of the Hell Fire Club was called a... rake.
fields.body:
West Wycombe, Stourhead, Stowe and other 18th century landscaped gardens are "all about sex" but, so a story today goes, the prudish National Trust has covered it up. Like the proverbial Victorian table leg, the sexual metaphors on display in the gardens' contours, lakes, pathways and statuary have been censored. That ha-ha turns out to be a dirty joke. This swelling greensward is really flesh. And now we know why Sir Francis Dashwood, creator of West Wycombe park and mainstay of the Hell Fire Club was called a... rake.

Apart from being the millionth time since The Interpretation of Dreams that sexual imagery has been unmasked beneath the most innocuous of surfaces (and of course sex itself is not "all about sex" at all) that storyline is not a bad opener for the spring visitors' season. You might even suspect the National Trust had itself planted it in time for Easter, envisioning charabancs full of mackintoshed men rushing out to Buckinghamshire, mattocks (ahem) in hand. Pity the custodians of West Wycombe. How long before they have to reseed - there we go again - the grassy bank that has now been outed as Venus's Mound once the curious and thrill-seeking start tramping all over it?

But we are not exactly talking novelty here. Gardens and sex have been associated since time immemorial, or at least as far back as the writers of Genesis could imagine. Charlie Dimmock is surely only a more explicit version of those figures adorning gallery walls, bestowing themselves in bowers and gambolling near gazebos. The cult of the shepherdess à la Marie Antoinette was never as pure as it seemed. The serpent has always lurked among the azaleas, beguiling Eve generation after generation (as male writers would have it). In how many Victorian novels did chaste heroines take a walk in the garden and emerge either betrothed or, worse, robbed for ever of their innocence?

fields.headline: £100m lifeline for coal mines
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to unveil a £100m rescue package this week to save coal pits in Labour's heartlands as the party battles to rally traditional supporters threatening to desert it.
fields.body:
The government is to unveil a £100m rescue package this week to save coal pits in Labour's heartlands as the party battles to rally traditional supporters threatening to desert it.

The two-year subsidy to be announced by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is intended to stave off colliery closures until after the general election.

Mr Byers had to overcome fierce opposition by senior civil servants in his own department, removing two mandarins from key posts.

Mike Atkinson, head of the Department of Trade's coal division, and Jonathan Green, head of power, who were seen as part of an "anti-coal" faction, were moved last week after objecting to the scheme.

Mr Byers' decision to push through the financial assistance, which is the first the mining industry has received since privatisation five years ago, underlines the government's determination to shore up its core vote.

Polls show many traditional Labour supporters feel they have been neglected in favour of middle Britain, and ministers are worried they could be hit by an "armchair revolt" at the election, with voters staying at home.

The lifeline will be warmly welcomed in mining communities and by many Labour activists and MPs who feared the government would abandon the Old Labour industry.

But a senior government source insisted it would also be well received by other groups and was intended to make the industry more productive, not just prop it up. "UK mines are now the most efficient in Europe, yet were losing out through not having any subsidies," said the source. "Coal is a real heartlands issue, but it does also bring in people who want to see a degree of fairness and not just let the market rule us. The broad coalition that Tony Blair put together will welcome this package."

Only 17 deep mines are left, 13 of them owned by RJB Mining, and nearly half are in trouble after a glut of coal on the world market sent import prices plummeting. The lack of subsidies in Britain contrasts with £2.3bn a year paid by the German government.

Ministers are confident the aid programme will save Ellington in Northumberland and Clipstone in Nottinghamshire after both were earmarked for closure. They also hope it will improve the prospects of Hatfield and the Selby complex in Yorkshire, Longannet in Scotland, and Betws and Tower in south Wales.

The Labour MP for Blyth Valley, Ronnie Campbell, an ex-miner who represents many of the Ellington men, said: "I'm relieved and delighted. At one time I was worried Labour would finish what the Tories started and kill off the industry.

"With a bit of push and a bit of shove we have managed to get the government there. Now we have to make sure the owners do it."

Ministers calculate the deal will safeguard more than 3,000 jobs by funding investment and underwriting output by as much as £5 a tonne until 2002 at pits unable to compete with low cost and subsidised imports.

The European Commission must approve the package but ministers claim they have been told it will enjoy a "fair wind", avoiding a repeat of the Longbridge fiasco when delays over aid in Brussels were overtaken by BMW's decision to sell the Rover plant.

Coal is not the dominant industry it was at the end of the 1984 strike when 180 collieries operated. But it remains a touchstone among Labour members and voters, and Mr Byers was aware that pit closures, coming after Rover, would have posed serious political problems.

Mr Blair and Gordon Brown, the chancellor, also beat opposition within Downing Street and the Treasury to approve the package. Civil servants in the DTI and other departments have long been accused of being anti-coal, dismissing it as an old smokestack industry not worth saving.

Mr Atkinson and Mr Green will be offered other jobs in Whitehall and the decision on the package represents the end of a bitter war within government that has lasted more than two years.

The DTI last night said the civil servants had not been removed because of a disagreement on policy with ministers. And government sources stressed they had been moved because of "a clear progression" in their careers.

Britain imports about 20m tonnes of coal a year, mainly from Colombia, Australia, Canada, South Africa, Poland and the US.

fields.headline: No:1616
fields.standfirst: Private Eye
fields.body:
Age: 39.

Description: Satirical magazine.

Beginnings: Issue one was cobbled together in Willie Rushton's west London bedroom in 1961 and hawked around local restaurants.

Contents (official): Penetrating satire; fearless exposés of corruption in high places; sidesplitting (yet topical) cartoons.

Contents (unofficial): "Diligent scraping of other people's wastepaper baskets and even more obscene receptacles" (historian David Starkey).

So which one's the truth? Well, there are those who say that Lord Gnome, EJ Thribb, Lunchtime O'Booze, Mr Justice Cocklecarrot, Sylvie Krin and friends just aren't as funny as they once were.

And who are these naysayers? Why, the handful of pathologically bitter former employees who've made second careers out of slagging the magazine off in print.

But the golden age is past? Inevitably. The Eye was launched in the satire-hungry time of the Profumo affair and Beyond the Fringe. Whereas, clearly, there are no manifestly preposterous charlatans in government today.

So what are we celebrating? Next week the magazine produces its 1,000th issue, something even its libidinous libel-trial foe Sir James Goldsmith couldn't manage. Despite sniping surrounding his appointment, crippling libel trials (Sonia Sutcliffe, Goldsmith, Maxwell) and acrimonious relations with the widow of ex-owner Peter Cook, editor Ian Hislop has ploughed on.

Hislop? He's that bloke off the telly, isn't he? Indeed. Private Eye's fortnightly production schedule means the diminutive quipster has plenty of spare time to appear on Have I Got News for You, screwing up his face and being ungentlemanly to Paula Yates.

Do say: "Renew my subscription."

Don't say: "Have you noticed how Pass Notes isn't as funny as it..." (continued on page 94).

Not to be confused with: Its chronically beleaguered ex-rival Punch, which really isn't as funny as it used to be. [That's enough - Ed.]

fields.headline: Zimbabwe slides into anarchy
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe: special report
Movement for Democratic Change
Commercial Farmers' Union
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe was in danger of descent into anarchy yesterday after its president, Robert Mugabe, brushed aside the murders of a white farmer and two members of the main opposition party and condoned the illegal land seizures.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
Zimbabwe was in danger of descent into anarchy yesterday after its president, Robert Mugabe, brushed aside the murders of a white farmer and two members of the main opposition party and condoned the illegal land seizures.

Seemingly unrepentant over the violence he had helped to unleash, he said: "We warned the white farmers: we cannot protect you if you provoke the war veterans. You must accept the consequences."

With the mood in Zimbabwe ugly yesterday, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, described the situation as "very grave" and expressed fear that "it will get worse unless there is a return to respect for the rule of law in Zimbabwe".

Alarmed by the spiral of violence, the foreign office minister, Peter Hain, called in the Zimbabwean high commissioner, Simbarashe Mumbengegwi, to lodge a formal protest over the lawlessness. He called on Mr Mugabe "to get a grip" and said Zimbabwe was on the "very brink".

The Foreign Office saw as a disturbing sign of the potential disintegration of Zimbabwe the fact that five white farmers were abducted from a police station where they had sought refuge after going to the aid of their murdered colleague, David Stevens.

The Foreign Office was equally alarmed over the assassination of the two members of the Movement for Democratic Change. The opposition leaders told Mr Cook and Mr Hain last week that they had firm evidence that MDC leaders faced assassination attempts.

According to Western intelligence sources, Mr Mugabe recently ordered a crackdown on the opposition. The intelligence sources had predicted that opposition members would be targeted.

The two opposition members killed were not leaders but one of them was personally close to Morgan Tsvangirai, the MDC leader, who has been in London for talks with Mr Cook and Mr Hain. The dead man had been Mr Tsvangirai's driver.

On arrival back from a conference of developing countries in Cuba yesterday, there had been hopes that Mr Mugabe might have backed his deputy who last week called for squatters to leave the land as a court had ruled.

Instead, Mr Mugabe declined to order the squatters to leave the farms and refused to tell the police to take action to protect the white farmers and their black labourers.

He told 1,000 supporters who went to greet him: "I know there is the expectation that I will say to the war veterans 'Get off the land'. I will not say or do that." He suggested the white farmers were MDC supporters.

Mr Stevens was shot dead on Saturday night by a gang of men who said they were supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party. Five other farmers who went to help him were beaten up. On the same day, the two MDC men died when a petrol bomb was thrown into their vehicle as they returned to Harare from a rally in the south-east of the country. According to the survivors, the MDC vehicle was followed by a car which pulled up alongside them and the petrol bomb was lobbed inside.

Speaking in India, where he is on an official visit, Mr Cook said the violence "is exactly what we feared would be the result of the breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe".

Less than 48 hours after the Zimbabwean opposition had urged Mr Cook and Mr Hain to tone down their criticism of Mr Mugabe, the foreign secretary gave vent to his feelings, outraged by the killings. He accused the Zimbabwean president of overseeing "the destruction of his own country".

He said Britain would demand "that the (Zimbabwe) government stops the occupation of the farms before there are any more deaths.

"We will also be demanding that those responsible for this murder are found and are charged".

Mr Cook said he will phone a number of African leaders urging them to give the same message to Mr Mugabe. The danger was that he would destroy not only his own country but damage others in Africa too.

In London, Mr Hain, called Mr Mumbengegwi to the Foreign Office in the afternoon, and told him "it was important for leadership to be given from the very top of government to prevent further lawlessness and violence".

Earlier, Mr Hain had been unequivocal about where the blame lay. "Unfortunately when you have a situation where the leadership of the country is not urging restraint and obedience to the law, then people start taking the law into their own hands," he said. "It is as if they have been given a green light to do so."

After his dressing down by Mr Hain, Mr Mumbengegwi attempted to play down Mr Stevens' killing: "There are over a thousand farms where there are sit-ins and demonstrations at present where the two sides are co-existing peacefully without any violence."

He said: "It is unfortunate that in this particular instance this has occurred, and this is something that everybody does regret."

Mr Mugabe promised in Cairo a fortnight ago that he would hold a general election in May but he has still to set a date.

The Foreign Office has been pressing for the election to be free and fair, and overseen by international monitors.

webTitle: 'They kept saying we were going to die'

fields.headline: 'They kept saying we were going to die'
fields.standfirst:
Neighbours of farmer shot dead by Mugabe supporters tell how they survived abduction and beatings
Zimbabwe: special report
Movement for Democratic Change
Commercial Farmers' Union
fields.trailText: Gary Luke's face was purple with bruising and caked with dry blood. Propped up in a hospital bed with a compressed fracture to his skull, he was one of six white farmers abducted by armed supporters of the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe.
fields.body:
Gary Luke's face was purple with bruising and caked with dry blood. Propped up in a hospital bed with a compressed fracture to his skull, he was one of six white farmers abducted by armed supporters of the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe.

He and another farmer, Steve Krynauw, were accused of supporting the opposition Movement for Democratic Change and were beaten unconscious with iron bars, car fan belts and rocks. They were among five farmers who had tried to rescue their neighbour, David Stevens, who was abducted and shot dead.

The killing of the first white farmer in Zimbabwe's long-running dispute over land and the deaths of two opposition party members marked a decisive moment in the country's descent into political violence and insecurity.

The complete absence of police protection prompted 46 white farming families, nearly 200 people, to flee their homes en masse and seek safety in Marondera, about 62 miles east of Harare.

Mr Stevens was shot dead on Saturday night by a gang of men who said they were supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party. They were retaliating because Mr Stevens's farm workers had chased them off his farm on Saturday morning. When they came back, they had reinforcements and were armed. They tied up Mr Stevens and drove off in his Land Rover.

Another white farmer, John Osborne, witnessed the shooting. He was beaten and may have met the same fate, but a woman told the gang that he had helped some black farmers. They decided to spare him. As he was led away, he saw David Stevens get shot in the face.

Yesterday Mr Osborne was in hospital recovering from concussion, broken ribs and severe bruising. He said that the assailants had insisted they confess to being MDC members. "They beat Dave very badly and shot him _ It's not about land. It's about politics," Mr Osborne said.

Mr Luke, 44, said: "We were trying to assist our neighbour, Dave Stevens, who had been taken away by the farm invaders. Our vehicle was shot at so we went to the Murewa police station for protection.

"Then 20 guys, some of them armed, walked in as if it were a Zanu-PF camp and not a police station. They tied us up and took us out. None of the police made any attempt to assist us.

"They took us up into the hills and beat us with iron bars, fan belts and rocks. They said we were supporters of the MDC and they kept telling us we were going to die."

Mr Luke and Mr Krynauw were put in the back of the Land Rover. "They drove us around and stopped to beat us now and then. They removed our watches and wedding rings. They kept beating us. Our hands were tied and our feet were tied and it felt like they were going to kill us. We lost consciousness and then we woke up.

"They threw something stiff and heavy on top of us so we couldn't move. It was the body of Mr Stevens," said Mr Luke. "They kept telling us we were going to die."

The vehicle eventually broke down and was abandoned beside a river. After a couple of hours, Mr Luke and Mr Krynauw realised they were alone and managed to untie themselves. At dawn they crawled out from under the corpse and headed for the nearest farm, where they radioed for help.

"I can't believe I'm alive," said a shaky Mr Krynauw from a wheelchair. "I thought they were going to kill me. I feel like I could burst into tears."

Farmers Stuart Gemmil and Ian Hardy had similar experiences and were eventually rescued and taken to the Marondera hospital.

Earlier on Saturday, two members of the MDC died when a petrol bomb was thrown into their vehicle. One of those who died was the driver for MDC's chairman, Morgan Tsvangirai, according to party spokesman Nomore Sibanda.

In Marondera yesterday, the mood was ugly as 200 young members wearing T-shirts saying "Vote Zanu-PF" marched through the town, brandishing clubs and sticks and threatening whites and journalists. Helicopters patrolled the situation in the nearby Macheke and Murewa areas, where armed Zanu-PF supporters were reported to be roaming. Police warned that Murewa was a "no go" area.

Hearing news of the abductions on farm-to-farm radios, the 46 farming families of the Macheke Virginia area evacuated their properties on Saturday night and fled to Marondera. At a meeting yesterday morning, most expressed the desire to return as soon as the police and army could assure them the situation was secure.

"We want to go back," said Elizabeth van Veen, 70. "We are very worried about our staff. They are very vulnerable now because these war veterans go in and rough them up. Our staff must be at the mercy of the war veterans. We all feel so helpless."

Jenny Luke, 42, said even after the abduction and beating of her husband, Gary, that she wanted to return to the family's farm. "I want to stay in this country, on our farm," she said in the hospital corridor. "We've put everything into our farm. We just bought it a few years ago and we are still paying it off. I don't know how this has all happened. It was very quiet and then it just blew up."

Tim Henwood, president of the Commercial Farmers Union, which represents Zimbabwe's 4,200 large-scale farmers, addressed the families. He said the Zimbabwe national army was going into the Macheke/Murewa area to restore order.

"These farmers want to go back to their farms, but we must wait until we are sure that the area is secure," said Mr Henwood. He said the threat of a killing had been present ever since Mr Mugabe ordered police not to take any action against the squatters. "When you are outside the rule of law, the danger every minute is very great. We've been asking for the government to uphold the law from the very beginning. Tragically now we've lost a life. We need the president to call for a return to the rule of law," he said.

"Zimbabweans, white and black, are sensible people. They don't like this violence. I hope we can return to normal very soon."

fields.headline: Turning back the clock
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe was once distinguished by its government's broad adherence to the rule of law

Zimbabwe: special report
Movement for Democratic Change
Commercial Farmers' Union
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe was once distinguished by its government's broad adherence to the rule of law
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe may not be remembered as a beacon of hope after his crude defiance of the Harare high court's attempts to uphold the rule of law, and his sad failure to condemn the politically charged murder of a white farmer and two black opposition activists at the weekend. But there was a time when he seemed a different kind of leader from the despots who held Africa in their grip as Zimbabwe won independence 20 years ago.

In a region afflicted by foreign-sponsored wars, growing unrest against apartheid and near economic collapse, Zimbabwe came to be viewed as an island of relative stability and order despite sporadic repression, most notably the army's murderous activities in Matabeleland. What generally distinguished Zimbabwe was the government's broad adherence to the rule of law.

Zimbabwe's prime minister turned president may have been an old-fashioned Marxist, but he abided by the constitutional settlement which allowed his former enemies - the white racists who once ran Rhodesia - to sit in parliament. The same constitution guaranteed multiparty politics for a time, and ensured much of the farmland remained in white hands.

The rulings of Zimbabwe's highest court were respected when they went against the government. Mr Mugabe wasn't happy about it, any more than he liked not being able to impose a one-party state or socialist economics. But, on the whole, there was something resembling the rule of law, for all the financial and political corruption.

Those days are past. Zimbabwe's president now freely threatens that "death will befall" his opponents. The police ignore court orders permitting anti-government marches, and arrest protesters while the ruling party's club-wielding private army bludgeon peaceful demonstrators. The government has brushed aside a judge's writ requiring the public release of an official inquiry into the atrocities in Matabeleland.

And now comes Mr Mugabe's open defiance of the high court's order to the police to remove thousands of poor blacks who have seized white-owned farm land. With the president's contempt for the courts came an implicit endorsement of political violence.

It sets Zimbabwe on a dangerous if well-trodden path in Africa. Mobutu Sese Seko dragged Zaire down the road to lawlessness three decades ago. The result was a nation plundered senseless and stripped of morality as many Zaireans discovered that the only way to survive was to behave like their leaders, extorting and stealing. Where they existed, the courts were so corrupt that parts of Zaire fell back on traditional forms of justice. Mobutu's successor, Laurent Kabila, has not provided a better example.

Things were little different in Nigeria which had a flourishing, credible court system and an abundance of respected lawyers. Successive military governments whittled away at the authority of the courts until the worst and most detested of Nigeria's dictators, General Sani Abacha, decreed that the law simply did not apply to his regime. No one could sue his government. The courts could not challenge or overturn his administration's decisions. The law continued to apply to everyone else, of course, and was liberally used to lock up opponents. Where it did not prove sufficient, Abacha's enemies were murdered by military agents, who believed the law would never be apply to them.

But the damage was done to Nigeria's standing long before Abacha came along. The arbitrary application of the law might have opened the way for some foreign businesses to bribe their way to contracts but it discouraged many that could have helped develop the country. From Cape Town to London, ordinary Nigerians are taken as criminals purely because of the reputation of their former governments.

Perhaps there is no better example of the consequences of the arbitrary use of law than in Rwanda. On the surface, the tiny central African nation was a model of order. Like apartheid South Africa, it had unjust, discriminatory legislation that consigned Tutsis to second class citizenship. The Hutu government argued that it was the law of the land and properly applied.

What wasn't admitted was the virtual impunity with which Tutsis could be abused and murdered. When the time came for genocide, it did not occur to many Rwandans that the law was relevant.

Reformist governments in Rwanda and Nigeria are working to establish the rule of law as a cornerstone of reconstruction. Yoweri Museveni showed the way in Uganda after the terrible years of Idi Amin and Milton Obote, helping to build confidence at home and abroad in the government.

The establishment of a legitimate administration in South Africa, governed by an exemplary constitution, has only highlighted Mr Mugabe's growing autocratic tendencies.

It is not too late to reverse Zimbabwe's decline. Nothing has gone too far. Not the economic decline, not the civil conflict and not the disregard for the law. But if Mr Mugabe drags his country toward anarchy for the politics of the moment, he will not find it easily pulled back again.

 chris.mcgreal@theguardian.com

webTitle: Seven die in Lisbon club gas attack

fields.headline: Seven die in Lisbon club gas attack
fields.trailText: Seven people were killed and 65 injured after two toxic gas grenades were thrown into a crowded Lisbon nightclub in the early hours of yesterday morning.
fields.body:
Seven people were killed and 65 injured after two toxic gas grenades were thrown into a crowded Lisbon nightclub in the early hours of yesterday morning.

The attack took place at 4.40am, when an unidentified assailant entered the club and threw the devices, said to be the size of small water bottles.

An unknown number of accomplices then cut the power supplies, plunging the club into darkness and shutting down the ventilation system.

More than 1,000 people, mainly immigrants from Portugal's former colonies, were in the Luanda club in the city's African quarter at the time.

There was speculation that inter-club rivalry or racial tensions may have been behind the attack. There have been several recent clashes in the area involving rival groups of youths of Angolan and Cape Verdian descent.

The gas has not yet been identified, but one theory is that it was pepper gas, which can kill through asphyxiation. An autopsy of the victims will be carried out today.

A spokesman for the police commissioner said that the victims - four men and three women - died of asphyxiation and from internal injuries after being crushed in the panic to escape what some witnesses described as "a cloud of gas".

"We still do not know what the motive was," the spokesman added. Six of the victims were black Portuguese, and the seventh was a Spanish woman. Their identities have not yet been released.

The injured were taken to three of Lisbon's main hospitals. Rita Peres, of the casualty department of the Sao Francisco Xavier hospital, said: "Twenty-three of the injured were brought here suffering from breathing difficulties and crush injuries. Six are being kept in for observation, but they are now out of danger."

Other clubgoers suffered facial cuts from broken glass as they they were pushed to the ground under the weight of dozens of people attempting to flee the club.

Police are examining video footage from closed-circuit television cameras inside the Lisbon nightclub. One source said that the suspects had been identified, but no arrests have been made.

"This was clearly a criminal act," said a Lisbon council spokesman, Vasco Franco. "It was a concerted attack, carefully planned and coordinated."

Carmo Paiva, a student who survived the disaster, said: "I was right in the middle when it happened. People were choking and there was panic. Everyone went for the same door, the main exit, but it was blocked by people."

There are some fears the attack at the Luanda may have been a macabre act to mark the anniversary of Portugal's worst ever nightclub disaster, exactly 13 years ago.

On April 16 1987, 13 people died at Amarante's Mea Culpa nightclub, in the north of the country, after it was burned down by arsonists while hundreds of people were inside. Armed men forced the clubgoers and bar staff on to the middle of the dance floor before pouring petrol and setting the club alight. Two people were shot when they tried to escape the inferno.

A rival club owner was later sentenced to 25 years in jail for the Amarante attack.

It has emerged that the Luanda has been the target of a number of attempted gas attacks in recent years. Its awning and glass doors give it the appearance of an innocuous grocer's shop. However the club - and its predecessors on the same site - have a notorious history. Formerly an ironmonger's, it has been deliberately burned down once and was also closed by the courts.

"This is not the first time this has happened," said Joao Brito, the club's former owner. "It has happened six or seven times before, but this is the first time that anyone has been killed.

"They throw tear gas or pepper gas and someone turns out the lights. Then you get a human domino effect. No one has ever been caught."

One local cafe owner claimed that he witnessed a fight outside the club shortly before the gas attack. He said police were late to arrive at the scene because they no longer patrolled the area, fearing confrontations with black youths.

Officials are to investigate exit procedures at the club after complaints from survivors that a crucial door could not be opened because of iron bars.

The club's licence was renewed after an inspection in January.
