webTitle: Visitors urged to escape to Colditz

fields.headline: Visitors urged to escape to Colditz
fields.standfirst: On the anniversary of its liberation, a new exhibition aims to lure tourists to the Nazi castle prison
fields.trailText: In a room looking on to the courtyard of Colditz castle, hangs a photograph of an irrepressible young man. Second Lieutenant Peter Allan's cap is set at a jaunty angle and a cigarette dangles from his mouth. Yesterday, the same man - almost 60 years older - looked around at the high castle walls, took a deep breath and said: "I've come home."
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Colditz, eastern Germany
fields.body:
In a room looking on to the courtyard of Colditz castle, hangs a photograph of an irrepressible young man. Second Lieutenant Peter Allan's cap is set at a jaunty angle and a cigarette dangles from his mouth. Yesterday, the same man - almost 60 years older - looked around at the high castle walls, took a deep breath and said: "I've come home."

He was the sole former second world war prisoner in a party of around 70 Britons visiting the castle for the unveiling of an exhibition intended to open a new chapter in its 950-year history.

Mr Allan, now 82, arrived at the castle, in eastern Germany, which was set aside by the Nazis for incorrigible PoW escapers, in November 1940. Despite many attempts - he once got as far as Vienna - he never broke free of Colditz's dour embrace until its liberation 55 years ago today.

To mark the anniversary, the town has put on display some of the more unusual finds made during the extensive refurbishment. In the past five years alone, the regional authorities have spent DM 12.5m (more than £4m) doing it up.

"Wherever you go, you find traces of escape attempts: tunnels, plans, saws and files," said the mayor of Colditz, Manfred Heinz. He was standing by a radio which French prisoners operated secretly from under the roof, and which lay there until builders stumbled on it in 1993.

Some 10,000 tourists, mostly Britons, visit the castle each year. But the mayor and tourist officials of the regional government in Saxony are aiming to increase numbers.

"The economic situation in Colditz is very bad," said Mr Heinz, of the liberal FDP party. "All the factories around here closed down after the fall of the Berlin wall and today the unemployment rate is 35%. We've got to take a new direction, and Colditz castle is special."

He reckoned that marketing could boost the number of British visitors to 40,000, and that a further 20,000 German tourists could also be lured.

In addition to wartime memorabilia, the exhibition includes artefacts from the castle's earlier history. In the cell where Winston Churchill's nephew, the war correspondent Giles Romilly, was imprisoned, there is an extract from Reinhold Eggers's book Colditz - the German story, which counterbalances another from PE Reid's classic, The Colditz Story.

Mr Heinz admitted that trying to raise the number of British and German visitors, while offending neither, would be tricky, and that the same guided tours could not be provided for both.

"To the Germans, I would want to show the role of the guards. Generally, the guards behaved fairly towards the prisoners, and it is a good thing to show that not all German soldiers were criminals. But I would not want to show them, for example, that the guards were regarded as inferior by the prisoners."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: At least 44 die in Congo blasts
fields.body:
At least 44 die in Congo blasts

The search continued in Congo yesterday for some of the dozens killed in explosions at Kinshasa's airport on Friday.

The city's governor, Theophile Bemba Fundu, said at least 44 people died, while it was feared that up to 100 were trapped.

There were conflicting explanations of the cause, ranging from a short circuit to a soldier dropping ammunition while unloading a plane.
AP, Kinshasa

Saudi invitation for Amnesty

Amnesty International has been invited to send an official to visit Saudi Arabia after accusing the kingdom of gross human rights violations, the interior minister, Prince Nayef, said.

Amnesty said last week that it wanted to send a delegation to the country, which enforces strict sharia law.
Reuters, Dubai

Manila robbers kill shoppers

Eight people were killed yesterday when robbers at a shopping centre in Manila hurled a grenade on to a crowded street in an attempt to escape police.

One of the victims was a security guard shot by the robbers. The seven killed in the blast included two children.
Reuters, Manila

Man surprises grieving family.

A Japanese shipbuilder came home from work at the weekend to find his family making arrangements for his funeral.

Police told the family that the man, 60, had died in a car crash, after his brother-in-law wrongly identified a body.
Reuters, Tokyo

webTitle: Secret CIA study reveals British role in Iran coup

fields.headline: Secret CIA study reveals British role in Iran coup
fields.standfirst:
London aided shah in 1953 to safeguard west's oil interests

More about Iran
fields.trailText: A secret CIA document shows that British intelligence played a pivotal role in a joint, covert operation to oust Iran's democratically-elected nationalist prime minister in 1953.
fields.body:
A secret CIA document shows that British intelligence played a pivotal role in a joint, covert operation to oust Iran's democratically-elected nationalist prime minister in 1953.

The classified history, revealed in the New York Times at the weekend, is the first detailed US government account of the episode to be publicised. The coup consolidated the power of the "vacillating" young shah, whose authoritarian, US-backed rule lasted 26 years until he was deposed by a militant Islamic - and anti-US - revolution.

The government report, "written by the CIA's chief coup planner", according to the newspaper, showed that the 1953 operation's success "was mostly a matter of chance", and that the CIA "had almost complete contempt for the man it was empowering, Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi, whom it derided as a vacillating coward".

The study of the CIA's first successful overthrow of a foreign government, written in 1954, was provided by a former official who kept a copy of it. Its author, Donald Wilber, a "gentleman spy" and expert in Persian architecture, died three years ago at 89.

The document shows the pivotal role that British intelligence played in planning the coup against Iran's prime minister, Mohammed Mossadegh, who sought to nationalise the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

While negotiating with Iran, Britain won the support of the major oil companies in imposing an effective global boycott on Iranian oil. At one stage, US and British intelligence officials met in Beirut to put the finishing touches to their strategy.

CIA and British intelligence officers also visited Princess Ashraf, the shah's influential sister, and she told her brother to follow the coup plans. One of the palace staff was said to be a British agent.

Another man, Asadollah Rashidian, allegedly approached the shah and invited him to select a phrase that would then be broadcast at prearranged times on the BBC's Persian language service as proof that Rashidian spoke for British intelligence.

The CIA operation, code-named TP-Ajax, was designed to maintain the west's control over Iranian oil. But the agency found the shah "a reluctant warrior" when it came to issuing royal decrees dismissing Mossadegh and replacing him with the more tractable General Fazlollah Zahedi, the newspaper said.

"The history says agency officers ... worked directly with royalist Iranian military officers, handpicked the prime minister's replacement, sent a stream of envoys to bolster the shah's courage, directed a campaign of bombings by Iranians posing as members of the Communist party, and planted articles and editorial cartoons in newspapers."

But "almost nothing went according to the meticulously drawn plans" on August 15 1953. Mossadegh had advance warning of the plot, Zahedi went into hiding, and the shah fled to Baghdad. It was only when Tehran newspapers published the shah's decrees, four days later, that popular support permitted a successful second coup. Two days after that, CIA officials moved $5m into Iran to help consolidate the government's power.

webTitle: Indian protests sour Brazil's birthday party

fields.headline: Indian protests sour Brazil's birthday party
fields.standfirst: Land disputes fuel anger over celebrations for 500th anniversary of Portuguese arrival in South America
fields.trailText: The first encounter between native South Americans and Europeans was recorded by Pero Vaz de Caminha, the official scribe of the Portuguese flotilla that accidently arrived on the coast of what is now Brazil on April 22 1500.
fields.body:
The first encounter between native South Americans and Europeans was recorded by Pero Vaz de Caminha, the official scribe of the Portuguese flotilla that accidently arrived on the coast of what is now Brazil on April 22 1500.

It started with an exchange of gifts. "[We] just gave them a red beret, a linen hood ... and a black hat. And one of them gave us a head-dress of birdfeathers ... another gave us a necklace of white beads," he wrote.

Five centuries later the descendants of the Indians who welcomed the navigators are mostly destitute, living on a strip of coast lined with hotels.

As the country prepares to mark the 500th aniversary of its discovery with a week of celebrations, controversy over the fate of Brazil's indigenous inhabitants threatens to spoil the party.

"We don't think it was a discovery. It was an invasion," said Neusa Mattos Oliveira, a Pataxo Indian who lives where the Portuguese first walked on South American soil. "If I went into your home, no one would say I discovered it. In 500 years we have lost the majority of our culture, and many of our relatives in the struggle."

At the time of the Portuguese arrival the indigenous population of what has become Brazil was 6m, comprising 1,400 tribes. Now there are 215 tribes left, made up of 350,000 people, according to the government's Indian agency. Most live with only the minimum sanitary, health and educational facilities. Many, such as the 6,000-strong Pataxo, survive by selling flour and handicrafts

Sensitivity over the issue has increased because two of the country's most historically important sites - Mount Pascoal, the first piece of land spotted by the sailors, and Coroa Vermelha, where the first mass was celebrated - are flashpoints in the battle between the Indians and authorities.

Coroa Vermelha, a small headland 10 miles north of Porto Seguro, is a Pataxo reservation. In return for using the land as the centrepiece of the official celebrations - to be attended by 3,000 dignatories including the presidents of Portugal and Brazil - the government has invested £3m to build a museum, shopping complex and landscaped pathways.

But the fragile peace between the government and the Pataxo broke down this month when military police invaded the reservation to destroy a monument that the Indians were creating as a counterpoint to a 12 metre steel cross.

"Steel is nothing to do with our culture," said Paje Hambe, the tribe's spiritual leader.

The action of the police has embarrassed President Fernado Cardoso, who admitted at a meeting with Indian leaders in Brasilia last week that it should not have happened. His security chief has now advised him to cancel the events planned at Coroa Vermelha.

Mount Pascoal, 40 miles south of Coroa Vermelha, has been claimed by the Pataxo for generations. In 1980 the government gave them just over a third of the area and turned the rest into a national park.

Last August, the Pataxo invaded the park, expelling staff and seizing the headquarters. Around 1,000 people now live at the site. It is as if a Native American group has taken over Plymouth Rock, the landing site of the Pilgrim Fathers.

"All our lives we have been here," said Aracari Pataxo Baixu, the tribe's deputy leader. "Our families are growing every day. Where are they going to live?"

The Pataxo's main opponents are not landowners but environmentalists, who argue that the Atlantic rainforest that covers Mount Pascoal should be protected from all human interference.

"Okay so the Indians were here before the white man, but the forest was here before even the Indians arrived," said Carmen Florencio, the departing head of the national park. "Our aim is to keep the biodiversity for ever.

"The problem is not that they are Indians. We see people as people, and they need to be removed."

But by yesterday, 1,000 Indians from all over Brazil had arrived in Porto Seguro as part of a march which will unite an expected 2,000 people, planned to coincide with the festivities on Saturday.

Unlike the meeting 500 years ago, there will be no exchange of gifts. The Indians will be bringing protest banners.

webTitle: I don't know much about art, but I know the way to Tate Modern

fields.headline: I don't know much about art, but I know the way to Tate Modern
fields.trailText: The London cabbie's much-vaunted brain, already bulging with the Knowledge and an opinion on almost everything, added another crucial section yesterday - the finer points of modern art.
fields.body:
The London cabbie's much-vaunted brain, already bulging with the Knowledge and an opinion on almost everything, added another crucial section yesterday - the finer points of modern art.

Hundreds of cab drivers became the first to sample the Rothkos, Monets, and Richard Longs inside the Tate Modern at the renovated Bankside power station, a month before the rest of the public.

Ostensibly the visit was to help around 300 drivers distinguish, for the benefit of their fares, the new Tate Modern from the Tate Britain and add yet another route to their famed hippocampus. But the visit also allowed the drivers to hone their critical skills.

Brian McKenzie from Oval, sitting in the seventh floor cafe with his daughter Laura, 12, and son Frankie, nine, was unimpressed. "A couple of the paintings I am not too keen on," he said. "There's one painting that looks like some body has cleaned their brush on the canvas. There's one [a Jackson Pollock] that looks like someone just flicked a lot of paint over it and ran a wheel over it and it doesn't say a thing.

"There's objects there, bits of metal welded together that I can't for the life of me see what they are supposed to be. These things are supposed to say something to you but perhaps they don't want to talk to me."

The Tate will probably not be banking on good publicity from Alan Hone, from Lee, south-east London, and Michael Austen, from Bromley. Standing in front of four large red and purple canvases by Mark Rothko, Mr Hone said: "If I had had a bad day I would have been suicidal having walked around in here. It's depressing."

Drivers were more impressed by Louise Bourgeois' spider sculpture, which was being installed by crane in the enormous turbine hall. "It is beautiful," said one, as a spider's leg was lowered to the rest of its massive metal body.

Andrew Tyson and his wife Jacqueline, from Bankside, were "really excited" by the building. "There's no point in recommending places if you've never been there yourself.

"I am not really a culture vulture and I don't know a lot about art but this is wonderful. I would tell my customers it was brilliant," said Mr Tyson.

Drivers were more impressed by Louise Bourgeois' spider sculpture, which was being installed by crane in the enormous turbine hall. "It is beautiful," said one, as a spider's leg was lowered to the rest of its massive metal body. Andrew Tyson and his wife Jacqueline, from Bankside, were "really excited" by the building. "There's no point in recommending places if you've never been there yourself. "I am not really a culture vulture and I don't know a lot about art but this is wonderful. I would tell my customers it was brilliant," said Mr Tyson.

fields.headline: Counting asylum votes
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: I have lived in the UK from the age of 10; unlike today's asylum seekers, my mother arrived here in the 70s. I am proud to say that she was a genuine "economic migrant", called in by the catering industry to contribute to the British economy. We now hold British passports.
fields.body:
I have lived in the UK from the age of 10; unlike today's asylum seekers, my mother arrived here in the 70s. I am proud to say that she was a genuine "economic migrant", called in by the catering industry to contribute to the British economy. We now hold British passports.

Racists do not discriminate between asylum seekers and the rest of the ethnic minorities settled in the UK. And why should they? There is no doubt that the increase in racial attacks against ethnic minority groups is linked to the government's racist asylum and immigration policies. I am comforted that a high profile figure such as Bill Morris is articulating the fact that these policies are not only affecting vulnerable asylum seekers but also the ethnic community in general.

Political parties are fully aware that asylum seekers do not have voting rights, but we should remind them that the great majority of ethnic minority members do.
Solange Valdez
London
Solvaldez@compuserve.com

 Baroness Jay claims it "beggars belief" that truck drivers don't know they have stowaways on board (Jay attacks union chief in asylum row, April 15). As unions, employers and transport workers have vainly tried to explain to a wilfully deaf Home Office, the opposite is true.

On articulated vehicles a trailer may be hauled by more than one truck during the course of a journey. Left unattended, while the driver has a meal, trailers are often entered, as French police turn a blind eye, via the roof. Drivers rarely load and never seal the trailers, which they are forbidden to open, on pain of breaking international customs laws, dismissal and invalidation of insurance. A classic double jeopardy.
Dave Young
Editor
Truck & Driver Magazine
mojotrux@ukonline.co.uk

 The term bogus implies criticism of people who have come to the UK because of poverty, racism, lack of employment, or being in a war-zone - but are short of the life-endangerment that would give them asylum in this country. It does fuel racism, as bogus suggests lying or being a fake.

What is needed is a neutral term for people who have left their countries for perfectly laudable reasons but don't fit "our" rules for asylum seekers. We suggest the term "inadmissible asylum seekers" for people who don't fit the current category. Do we have to insult them as well as exclude them?
Derek Smith, Becky Rees
London

 Jack Straw and Tony Blair have certainly not set out to encourage racism in this country, and they clearly just do not understand how Bill Morris could say their policies give support to racists. The Metropolitan police never, as a body, set out to be racist, but they succeeded in doing so without realising it. That is what the term "institutional racism" means.

The consequence of what Bill Morris is saying is that that term could now be applied to the government, as well. Realising it is the first step towards doing something about it. Waving the Macpherson report in the air to establish their anti-racist credentials shows that they are still in denial.
Francis Sheehy Skeffington
Wakefield

 The use by government of prejudicial and emotive language in relation to asylum seekers should have come as no surprise to Bill Morris. When facts get in the way of policy, this administration is as ready as the last to resort to emotion rather than argument. He need only think back to campaigns against single women, the unemployed, the disabled and benefit claimants.
T Todd
Abingdon, Oxon

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The March and February column headings on the national newspaper circulation table in today's pre-printed Media section (page 8) have been transposed. The percentage increases and decreases are correct.
fields.body:
The March and February column headings on the national newspaper circulation table in today's pre-printed Media section (page 8) have been transposed. The percentage increases and decreases are correct.

An exciting story appeared on page 6, G2, March 22: "Only the lightning reactions of an operator [on the Docklands Light Railway] prevented a man who had climbed down on to the track - to retrieve what looked like his shoe - from disappearing under a train." A man did get on to the tracks, the DLR press office says, but the train was not forced to stop. And there are no operators on the Docklands system.

Accompanying a review of a book on MI6, page 10, Saturday Review, April 8, photos of Kim Philby and Donald Maclean were swapped.

Above a story headed Kiddy see the future beyond Diamonds - Sport, page S5, April 10 - the player on the right in a picture of Kidderminster Harriers is not Paul Webb but Phil King. And the men are not celebrating their win over Rushden & Diamonds, but team-mate Ian Foster's successful penalty.

fields.headline: Hot under the collar
fields.trailText: The Evangelical Alliance is calling for children to be given a vivid picture of the "reality" of hell (Children 'should be told of hell', April 15) and is encouraging "evangelicals involved in education in schools to ensure that modules of Christianity include presentations on death, judgment, heaven and hell". Writing as a survivor of this kind of emotional abuse, I question the ethical and moral principles of this approach.
fields.body:
The Evangelical Alliance is calling for children to be given a vivid picture of the "reality" of hell (Children 'should be told of hell', April 15) and is encouraging "evangelicals involved in education in schools to ensure that modules of Christianity include presentations on death, judgment, heaven and hell". Writing as a survivor of this kind of emotional abuse, I question the ethical and moral principles of this approach.

Encouraging children to believe in hell as an actuality and that the only way to avoid eternal damnation is to embrace the views of this ignorant minority is, in my opinion, a form of child abuse and should be dealt with as such.
Phil McNally
Bolton
philb@unisonfree.net

 The evangelical demand that schoolchildren be taught the existence of hell calls to mind the old saw about Paradise being a place where the lovers are Italian, the cooks French, the police English, the mechanics German and everything is organised by the Swiss.

In hell, by contrast, the lovers are Swiss, the cooks English, the police German, the mechanics French and Italians do the organising. This is rather hard on the French, but evangelicals would doubtless agree that even hell cannot be perfect.
Leonard Stehn
London

 If the Evangelical Alliance really want to inhabit the middle ages and to deny the rest of us the benefits of the Enlightenment then they are perfectly entitled to go off into their little fantasy world. In the meantime would they please let the rest of us in the Church get on with living in the real world and in the 21st century.
Rev Paul Flowers
Bradford
paulflowers@lifeline.org.uk

 The authors of the report propose to take eternal bliss for themselves while others (worthy and not so worthy) are given cruel and disproportionate punishment. Anyone proposing anything similar within this life would rightly attract universal scorn and opprobrium.

The only large group perhaps deserving hell are those who agree that many others should go there. I forgive them. May their god, or any real god, forgive them also.
John Howard
Warwick

 I can never make up my mind as to whether hell is a multi-storey car park, a desolate out-of-town housing estate, or a religious hothouse.
Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford
touchsto@surfaid.org

fields.headline: At odds with reality
fields.trailText: The current cricket-corruption allegations are both sad and disturbing, but I wonder if Paul Weaver (Nothing new under the sun, April 12) was intentionally humourous when he claimed that Chris Lewis had been asked by an Asian betting syndicate to "persuade the England team to play poorly".
fields.body:
The current cricket-corruption allegations are both sad and disturbing, but I wonder if Paul Weaver (Nothing new under the sun, April 12) was intentionally humourous when he claimed that Chris Lewis had been asked by an Asian betting syndicate to "persuade the England team to play poorly".

A review of England's performance over recent years must question the sanity of those running Asian betting syndicates.
TG Jones
Stockport

 Perhaps it is time to redirect the well-known quatrain about journalists: "You cannot bribe or cause to err, thank God, the English cricketer. But, seeing what the man will do unbribed, there's no occasion to."
Hugh Eastman
Newton Abbot, Devon

webTitle: Sowing the seeds of a post office counter revolution

fields.headline: Sowing the seeds of a post office counter revolution
fields.trailText: Either the government or Alastair Campbell claim that the taxpayer will save £400m through the payment of benefits by electronic transfer rather than over the PO counter. How much is to be lost in the process? What cost/benefit analysis parameters were employed in this evaluation? How much increased travel will be incurred? How much less personal contact? What social damage may ensue?
fields.body:
Either the government or Alastair Campbell claim that the taxpayer will save £400m through the payment of benefits by electronic transfer rather than over the PO counter. How much is to be lost in the process? What cost/benefit analysis parameters were employed in this evaluation? How much increased travel will be incurred? How much less personal contact? What social damage may ensue?

Is this the brave new world, the creation of non-community through vastly reduced personal contact as online communications become more the norm? Post offices are now online. Shouldn't we be revitalising the still-public-sector PO network by installing ATMs in their walls, creating around them IT, advice and social centres that become a more thriving focus in the community?
Martin Goldman
Cambridge
martin@goldman.co.uk

 Your leader (April 14) rightly placed the future of rural banking services in the Post Office, but wrongly suggested that the cost of change should be paid by the exchequer. Rural bank closures are inevitable in the long run.

The concession we really need from the banks is not to keep unviable branches open indefinitely, but to perform a graceful withdrawal, giving Post Offices time to assume their banking functions, plus financial support to enable the change. Despite the advantages of the Horizon IT platform now being installed in all branches, there is no budget for post offices to meet the training, manpower and security costs of offering a full banking service to rural businesses and families.

The banks are simply shucking off the cost of their customer service obligations in rural areas. Why should postmasters and taxpayers pick up the cost? The banks should pay.
Nigel Burke
Head of policy, Countryside Alliance
nigel-burke@ countryside-alliance.org

 Your leader refers only to rural post offices. Yet many urban sub-post offices also derive at least 40% of their income from benefit transactions.

I have one of the poorest constituencies in Britain. Typically, the sub-post office is in a small parade of shops, serving a densely populated residential area. While other small shops have closed, the sub-post office thrives, both as a "social bank" and convenience store.

The government has already given an assurance that cash payments can continue for those who do not want automated credit transfer, but these remaining customers are unlikely to sustain the sub-post offices. The future lies, as you point out, in bringing sub-post offices into the new economy. As was clear, from those who lobbied me on Wednesday, people who run sub-post offices are keen to modernise. Through the Horizon project, in which the government is investing £500m, sub-post offices are getting online.
Joan Ruddock MP

fields.headline: In praise of women MPs
fields.trailText: Catherine Bennett (Why Tony's no ladies' man, April 13) asks why women are less satisfied with the government's performance than men, but belittles the very women who are centrally involved in improving women's lives - women Labour MPs. She perpetuates the myth that these women only care about image and appearance, and "have yet to utter one memorable or radical word".
fields.body:
Catherine Bennett (Why Tony's no ladies' man, April 13) asks why women are less satisfied with the government's performance than men, but belittles the very women who are centrally involved in improving women's lives - women Labour MPs. She perpetuates the myth that these women only care about image and appearance, and "have yet to utter one memorable or radical word".

How many parliamentary debates has Catherine Bennett attended, or select committees, or has she bothered to visit any of the constituencies of Labour women MPs? If she had, she would realise that Labour women MPs are working very, very hard, not just on behalf of their constituents, like all good MPs, but also in the House of Commons, where they have contributed largely to the policies which now enhance many women's lives.

There are 121 women MPs in the Commons compared to 538 male ones, and yet she expects this minority group of women to "make adjustments to the musty male culture of the place". Does she know how the Commons is run, or how the rules are changed, or what efforts are being made by many MPs - male and female - to change the culture of Westminster?

Has she also considered that it might be journalists who write superficial articles perpetuating these myths, that are partly responsible for women's apparent fall in support for Labour?
Val Price
Malmesbury, Wilts

 It doesn't matter how many women MPs we have, until the media (and especially its female writers) will accept the same level of innocuous averageness from female MPs as they are more than happy to accept from their male counterparts, women in parliament don't stand a chance.
Claire McCarthy
Cardiff

webTitle: Israeli minister faces sex assault charges

fields.headline: Israeli minister faces sex assault charges
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli deputy prime minister, Yitzhak Mordechai, should stand trial on charges of sexual assault after forcing himself on at least three women, including an employee, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Israeli deputy prime minister, Yitzhak Mordechai, should stand trial on charges of sexual assault after forcing himself on at least three women, including an employee, police said yesterday.

The recommendation that Mr Mordechai, who is also transport minister and a confidant of the prime minister, Ehud Barak, be charged with "debased acts carried out with force" - represents a far more serious charge than the original allegations of sexual harassment that were raised by a 23-year-old civil servant last month.

That is mainly because the unnamed civil servant's allegation gave other women the courage to come forward. In recent weeks, several women have given anonymous interviews to Israel Radio, accusing Mr Mordechai of abusing his position as a senior army officer and sexual harassing them while they were doing their military service.

In a country where women's activists have long argued that the compulsory military duty encourages a culture in which sexual harassers are rampant and go unpunished, there was praise for the police yesterday.

"We think it is very important to show that women are not serial complainers but that men are serial harassers," said Orit Sulitzeanu, a spokeswoman for the Israel Women's Network. "We think it is important that the police complete these investigations quickly, because it will give other women the courage to complain and know that they will be taken seriously."

Police said that they based their decision on evidence from two women who accused Mr Mordechai of assaulting them in his home in 1992, when he was a general heading Israel's northern command, and later as defence minister in 1996.

Yesterday, Mr Mordechai, who took a leave of absence while police carried out their investigations, continued to plead his innocence. He said he hoped that prosecutors would dismiss the accusations.

"I am innocent," he said in a written statement. "I plan to fight for justice, my innocence and my good name with all my strength."

Mr Mordechai, 55, helped to propel Mr Barak to power during last year's election for prime minister by rebelling against the then Likud leader, Binyamin Netanyahu, and provoking a split in the rightwing vote. On the eve of polling, he dropped out of the race in favour of Mr Barak.

fields.headline: Reginald Dunk
fields.standfirst: Arms-to-Iraq victim who triumphed over Whitehall cover-up
fields.trailText: Reginald Dunk, who has died aged 80, was a victim of one of the many, ill-conceived arms-to-Iraq prosecutions brought against British businessmen by HM Customs and Excise in the 1980s, and which later aroused the wrath of senior judges.
fields.body:
Reginald Dunk, who has died aged 80, was a victim of one of the many, ill-conceived arms-to-Iraq prosecutions brought against British businessmen by HM Customs and Excise in the 1980s, and which later aroused the wrath of senior judges.

The first move in what was to become a 17-year legal battle for Dunk was made in February 1983, when customs officers seized a shipment of 200 Sterling sub-machine guns at Tilbury docks. The shipment was supported by export documents, including an end-user certificate signed by a senior officer in the Jordanian army, stating that the destination of the weapons was Jordan.

But customs believed the true destination of the guns was Iraq, then covered by a government arms embargo because of the Iran-Iraq war. Dunk was marketing director of Atlantic Commercial, the arms dealing firm which had arranged the export, and seven customs officers quickly raided both his office and home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire. They searched everywhere, even rummaging through a drawer containing his wife's underwear. Other officers raided his daughter's London home and his son's house in Guildford.

Dunk explained that, although the guns had been ordered and paid for by the Iraqis, they were a gift to Jordan. He eventually pleaded guilty to exporting arms to Iraq and, in 1985, was fined £20,000. His associate, Alexander Schlesinger, was fined £3,000. But the two men only changed their plea to guilty after staff at the Jordanian and Iraqi embassies in London reneged on a promise to appear at the trial as defence witnesses.

The crucial reason for this diplomatic change of heart only emerged seven years later, in 1992, in documents presented to Sir Richard Scott's arms-to-Iraq inquiry. These revealed that, at the behest of Customs and Excise, senior British diplomats had agreed to have "friendly words" with the Iraqi and Jordanian ambassadors. The Scott inquiry heard how Patrick Nixon, a senior Foreign Office official, told a colleague: "I confess to innocent reluctance to connive at impeding the course of justice."

Later, when Scott put it to Sir Stephen Egerton, former head of the Foreign Office Middle East department, that the interference had been "disgraceful", Egerton replied: "I would say it was a bad show." Scott was not amused; in his report, he called the diplomats' action "thoroughly reprehensible", adding that the behaviour of customs officials deserved "greater censure".

Armed with this new evidence, Dunk and Schlesinger returned to court. In 1994, Lord Taylor, then lord chief justice, quashed their convictions, saying that what he called the "machinations" in the case "to prevent witnesses for the defence being available, coupled with the non-disclosure of what had been done, constituted such an interference with the justice process as to amount to an abuse of it". He added that the probability that a jury would not have accepted the evidence of the embassy staff was not the point. That should have been left for the court to decide.

Not surprisingly, Dunk had no intention of letting the matter rest there. The Foreign Office did not apologise - indeed, its officials involved in the case, who had been so roundly criticised by both Scott and Taylor, had since been promoted.

Five years later, in 1999, Dunk was awarded £2.1m in compensation. The sum, believed to be a record, was agreed by the home secre tary, Jack Straw, on the advice of an independent assessor, who said he had taken into account "the seniority of the government officers who were involved in the wrongdoing" and the irreparable damage which had been done to Dunk and his family.

Finally, at the end of last year, the Foreign Office - in an unprecedented move - paid a total of £125,000 to Dunk and Schlesinger. It was the first compensation claim arising out of the arms-to-Iraq affair where damages have been recovered from a Whitehall department criticised in the Scott report. However, the Foreign Office insisted it paid up "without any admission of liability".

Reginald Dunk was born in Barnsley and educated at Rossall school. After the death of his father, a successful builder, he left school at the age of 16 to become an apprentice in the trade. Over the next decade he built up a flourishing business in the north of England, constructing houses, schools and industrial premises.

He sold his business and turned to other initiatives, including a plan to convert Ardsley House, a Coal Board property near his hometown, into a luxury hotel. The ambitious scheme coincided with a recession in the mid-1970s, and his firm went into receivership. Unbowed, Dunk turned to commodity trading, buying and selling cement, coffee, metals, wheat, tea and sugar. He described this as "singularly unsuccessful", but recalled that he was frequently approached about supplying military equipment, initially in uniforms and spare parts.

During this period, he came into contact with a millionaire Dutch arms dealer, Alfred Wynschenk, whose company, Atlantic Commercial Corporation, dealt in surplus American small-arms. After Wynschenk died in 1978, Dunk took off on his own, using Wynschenk's formidable array of contacts - Atlantic Commercial had agents in Thailand, Switzerland, Yugoslavia and the Czech Republic. He was prospering - until the night of the customs raid.

D unk later described himself as a "litigation addict" and claimed to have written 1,000 letters about his case. "If you can stick it out and have a good case, you will win through," he once said. "You may not come out of it unscathed, but it may be worth it, just to know you have beaten the bastards." At the end of his laborious journey through the courts, he commented: "I may have lost a few battles in the process ... I haven't come out of it all unscathed, but I have won the war."

Reflecting on Dunk's eventual vindication, his lawyer, Lawrence Kormornick, said: "He never received an apology or an explanation from Foreign Officials officials. It has been a slow, winding, and expensive process. For him, it came too late."

Dunk is survived by his third wife, Audrey, a son and four daughters.

 Reginald Wormald Dunk, businessman, born December 16 1919; died March 21 2000

fields.headline: News wars
fields.standfirst:
Relatives court media in battle for custody of Elian Gonzalez

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The relatives of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez continued their media broadside this weekend by inviting a reporter into their home in Miami's Little Havana neighbourhood to watch the boy's reaction when his father telephoned.
fields.body:
The relatives of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez continued their media broadside this weekend by inviting a reporter into their home in Miami's Little Havana neighbourhood to watch the boy's reaction when his father telephoned.

According to a reporter from the Miami Herald, Elian, the only survivor of a shipwreck off Florida in November, seemed reluctant to speak to his father, and fidgeted throughout the conversation, only to blow kisses at the end.

The invitation was made to support the family's claim that no one is pre venting Elian from speaking to his father, who flew to Washington last week to demand custody of the boy.

Elian talked to his father for around 20 minutes on Saturday night. Afterwards he retreated into his room and the family told the reporter he was crying.

Elian's great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, who is leading the effort to keep him in the US, told the reporter: "I'm doing this because I want you to see we're not liars."

The family had earlier rejected a request to let a crew from the 60 Minutes news programme tape Elian talking to his father while the CBS anchorman, Dan Rather, was with the man, the Herald reported. They said a psychologist had advised against it.

In an interview with 60 Minutes yesterday, the boy's father denied claims that he had been abusive to his ex-wife and Elian.

webTitle: Shortage of agave gives Mexico's tequila makers the blues

fields.headline: Shortage of agave gives Mexico's tequila makers the blues
fields.trailText: Heads are throbbing in the western Mexican state of Jalisco - the heart of tequila country - and it is not just the drinkers who are feeling groggy. The producers are too.
fields.body:
Heads are throbbing in the western Mexican state of Jalisco - the heart of tequila country - and it is not just the drinkers who are feeling groggy. The producers are too.

"The boom came without anybody thinking it through properly, and now what? We are all left crying," said Jorge Ruiz, owner of the La Escondida distillery founded by his grandfather in 1920.

Total tequila production topped 190m litres last year - almost double the rate of 1995.

Heady with success, most producers apparently failed to plan ahead ... until they were shocked to discover that supplies were running out of the succulent blue agave plant that is used to make tequila.

"Nobody ever imagined that demand would reach these levels," said Ramon Gonzalez, the head of Mexico's tequila regulatory board.

Looking over the plantations that give this dry mountainous area a misty blue tint, the agave shortage does seem difficult to imagine. But the plants need between seven and 10 years to mature, and the spiky tufts on view are too young to produce the juice.

"It didn't occur to anyone to invest in planting agave seven years ago, when there was over-production and prices were rock bottom," said Mr Gonzalez.

The agave crisis kicked in a few months ago, sending prices spiralling. Producers are paying around 7,000 pesos (£464) for a ton of the plant, stripped down to a core which yields a sugary liquid that is fermented and distilled twice before becoming tequila. A year ago better material cost about a 10th of that price.

Consumers are already suffering the consequences, with some producers doubling their prices over the last year.

"With problems meeting demand, and tequila getting a lot more expensive, the risk is people will start drinking other spirits again," says Mr Ruiz. "Lots of small manufacturers will have to shut down."

This disgruntled tequila veteran has his survival strategy worked out. He will do everything he can to satisfy one regular European order, and sell anything left to the major tequila players, who are buying from smaller producers to keep open their new markets.

But many producers have an added problem. It is not just tequila's new popularity which has brought the shortage. It is also the education of the global palate to appreciate high-quality tequilas made from 100% agave, rather than the cheaper variety which has other sugars mixed in.

"As adolescents we used to empty our pockets and see what we could afford, and if we couldn't stretch to brandy or whisky we would get drunk on tequila. But now tequila is a must at any high-society wedding," said Mr Gonzalez.

Aside from cash-strapped young people, tequila in Mexico has traditionally conjured up images of moustachioed rancheros boasting of conquests, or sobbing over treacherous women. Today, connoisseurs of both sexes discuss the merits of different brands with an earnestness which was previously reserved for fine wines.

The statistics show an overall 300% rise in the production of pure agave tequilas in the last five years, and a 600% rise in exports. But the pure tequila requires more than twice as much agave as the mixtures; faced with the shortage, manufacturers are sidelining higher quality lines.

"The litres must be kept up, so the categories are being reshuffled. The industry is not going to die, but it is going to change," said Mr Gonzalez. Even Herradura, a major producer known for its top-quality brands, intends to introduce a mixed variety.

But the tequila industry will weather the storm, said Mr Gonzalez. What are needed are new regulations to enforce planned planting and break the problems with the supply cycle. Meanwhile, he said, the board will not even temporarily relax the rule requiring any product called tequila to contain 51% agave.

But while the chunky Mr Gonzalez might swear that a couple of shots of pure tequila a day, as prescribed by his doctor, drastically lowered his cholesterol level, he knows that even this nectar has limitations. "Shame about the liver," he chuckled.

fields.headline: T-shirts and taboos
fields.standfirst: Breakthrough has been a huge success, raising £15m for breast cancer research. But are the models who front its campaign the best people to promote awareness of this disease, asks  Anita Chaudhuri
fields.trailText: Breakthrough has been a huge success, raising £15m for breast cancer research. But are the models who front its campaign the best people to promote awareness of this disease, asks  Anita Chaudhuri.
fields.body:
Even by glossy magazine standards, Mario Testino's latest photo of pneumatic super-goddess Gisele is conspicuously suggestive. She pouts into his lens, her taut, perfect breasts straining beneath a skimpy T-shirt slashed at the midriff. Only if you look very closely will you be able to make out the tiny letters on the shirt: Breakthrough - Fashion Targets Breast Cancer

To date, the campaign, which has been endorsed by supermodels, fashion editors and top designers, has been a huge success, raising the £15m target required for the launch of a centre for breast cancer research. With Prince Charles as its patron, and the likes of Kate Moss, Twiggy and Jerry Hall among its spokesmodels, Breakthrough has succeeded in putting the disease, which claims 1,000 women's lives a month, on the agenda in a direct and upbeat way.

However, like any successful phenomenon, the backlash has already kicked in. Detractors are beginning to question the appropriateness of using pert-breasted nymphets to promote awareness of a disease which by its very nature ravages the female form. The argument clearly has some validity. If you have recently undergone invasive and painful reconstructive breast surgery, do you really want to be bombarded with images of smug supermodels wittering on about a disease which most of them have never had any direct experience of?

That, says Delyth Morgan, chief executive of Breakthrough, is missing the point. "We get loads of feedback from our supporters. Ordinary women feel that it's great that models and celebs are putting breast cancer on the map, that they're prepared to put a T-shirt on. It gives encouragement and support." In America, radical breast cancer charities have run adverts depicting photos of women's breasts after radical surgery. Morgan disapproves of such tactics. "That kind of approach frightens women, and might stop them from examining their breasts. Nine out of 10 lumps turn out to be non-cancerous and women should be aware of that."

Morgan is conscious that a backlash against Breakthrough is in full force, but she refuses to be cowed by it. Last year, when women in Wonderbras ran the London Marathon to raise money for Breakthrough, she was hauled over the coals by Jenni Murray on Woman's Hour. "The thing is, we're not a politically correct charity, and have never claimed to be. I felt like I'd been summoned to see the headmistress. The point about women wearing the Wonderbras was that they had all had mastectomies and they wanted to run in their bras. That's their choice and I don't think anyone can really say anything against that."

Spend five minutes talking to Morgan and it becomes very clear that she views Breakthrough as a feminist issue. "Six years ago when I joined the charity, people thought it was a lost cause. Breast cancer embraces two taboos, sex and death, and people didn't want to know. We tried to find ways of making the disease as upbeat and positive as possible." Certainly, as charity campaigns go, Breakthrough's has been defiantly girly. Apart from the supermodels, there is the pink ribbon month in October in tandem with Breast Cancer Care, the counselling charity, and there is also the Kiss Breast Cancer Goodbye initiative sponsored by Avon. This last campaign features free mini-lipsticks, with which supporters are invited to leave their lip print on a petition asking the government to match Breakthrough's fundraising pound for pound. It proved a great hit at last October's political party conferences, with Charles Kennedy, William Hague and Tony Blair all keen to try out Avon's autumn colours.

Which is all well and good. But there's no getting away from the fact that campaigns such as Fashion Targets Breast Cancer and Breast Cancer Awareness Month do tend to focus on celebrity breasts rather than the harsher realities of a disease for which there is as yet no certain cure. Marie-Claire magazine devoted its October issue to the disease and carried photos of topless celebrities waxing lyrical about their prized assets. To give the magazine its due, it did also carry an in-depth piece about how the disease had affected three generations of the same family, but it was the topless celebs that hit the headlines, not the disease. "Did we do the wrong thing?" ponders Liz Jones, the magazine's editor. "I don't know. I don't think so, because we got sacks of mail from readers which was very positive. Also, I wanted to address the issue in a celebratory way, to take the fear out of the issue. We've been hit over the head with scaremongering articles about the disease for the last 20 years. Personally, I am now terrified of examining my breasts. I wanted to say to readers, please don't be frightened. In any case, what's wrong with using celebrities. The disease can attack anybody, even the rich and famous."

Not everyone is that thrilled by the celebrity support, however. Miranda Vicente, 31, was diagnosed with the disease when she was just 23 and had both breasts removed. She subsequently made a documentary about having reconstructive surgery to help other women understand what the process was like. While she acknowledges that Breakthrough has increased awareness of the disease, she laments the lack of hard information that's getting through.

"Knowledge is power. I think that it should be talked about at school in connection with health education programmes. My daughter is nine and has lived through the disease with me. I want her to be fully aware of the risks. If only I had known what to look out for, I think that my situation would have been very different."

Neither is she impressed with the use of pouty poster girls. "Personally, I don't see the point of models looking gorgeous in the T-shirt; it's using sex and looking good to promote something that is the opposite of that. Breast cancer isn't about glossy images, and by associating the disease with that, it just distances it from normal people. It would be far better to use people in the ads who had direct contact with breast cancer. Then hopefully the public would be able to relate to it better. Awareness should be integrated into daily life, not put on a glamorous pedestal."

There is another side to the argument, though: that there is no better way of reaching a young audience than by using pop stars and models. Christine Piper had a double lumpectomy in December 1998 and since then has raised £18,000 for Breakthrough.

"Using Vogue models does not worry me. If they're willing to do it then it means that the message is getting across to young kids. Pop stars like the Spice Girls and Robbie Williams are particularly useful. My kids look at them and think, 'If it's OK for them to wear a T-shirt then it's OK for us too. And that all goes to spreading the message. I honestly don't think it matters how it's done as long as it gets out there."

Piper is compiling an anthology by people whose lives have been touched by the disease; contributors include Cherie Blair and Prince Charles, though she has yet to find a publisher.

She gets particularly cross with those who suggest that Breakthrough is misdirecting its message to the young when it is older women who are most likely to die of the disease. "When I was 12, my mother had breast cancer. No one told me anything about the disease, or that it could ever affect me. I remember going with her to St George's hospital for radiotherapy and seeing this big sign saying 'Danger: Radiation'. It was in the 60s during the space race and I thought it sounded very sci-fi and far-removed from real life.

"If only someone had told me more about the disease back then, I would have been more aware of the risks. It's not important that the kids wearing the T-shirts today might not experience the disease until they're in their 60s. The point is that they should know what to watch out for. Unfortunately knowledge was a luxury that I never had."

"The thing is, we're not a politically correct charity, and have never claimed to be. I felt like I'd been summoned to see the headmistress. The point about women wearing the Wonderbras was that they had all had mastectomies and they wanted to run in their bras. That's their choice and I don't think anyone can really say anything against that." Spend five minutes talking to Morgan and it becomes very clear that she views Breakthrough as a feminist issue. "Six years ago when I joined the charity, people thought it was a lost cause. Breast cancer embraces two taboos, sex and death, and people didn't want to know. We tried to find ways of making the disease as upbeat and positive as possible." Certainly, as charity campaigns go, Breakthrough's has been defiantly girly. Apart from the supermodels, there is the pink ribbon month in October in tandem with Breast Cancer Care, the counselling charity, and there is also the Kiss Breast Cancer Goodbye initiative sponsored by Avon. This last campaign features free mini-lipsticks, with which supporters are invited to leave their lip print on a petition asking the government to match Breakthrough's fundraising pound for pound. It proved a great hit at last October's political party conferences, with Charles Kennedy, William Hague and Tony Blair all keen to try out Avon's autumn colours. Which is all well and good. But there's no getting away from the fact that campaigns such as Fashion Targets Breast Cancer and Breast Cancer Awareness Month do tend to focus on celebrity breasts rather than the harsher realities of a disease for which there is as yet no certain cure. Marie-Claire magazine devoted its October issue to the disease and carried photos of topless celebrities waxing lyrical about their prized assets. To give the magazine its due, it did also carry an in-depth piece about how the disease had affected three generations of the same family, but it was the topless celebs that hit the headlines, not the disease. "Did we do the wrong thing?" ponders Liz Jones, the magazine's editor. "I don't know. I don't think so, because we got sacks of mail from readers which was very positive. Also, I wanted to address the issue in a celebratory way, to take the fear out of the issue. We've been hit over the head with scaremongering articles about the disease for the last 20 years. Personally, I am now terrified of examining my breasts. I wanted to say to readers, please don't be frightened. In any case, what's wrong with using celebrities. The disease can attack anybody, even the rich and famous." Not everyone is that thrilled by the celebrity support, however. Miranda Vicente, 31, was diagnosed with the disease when she was just 23 and had both breasts removed. She subsequently made a documentary about having reconstructive surgery to help other women understand what the process was like. While she acknowledges that Breakthrough has increased awareness of the disease, she laments the lack of hard information that's getting through. "Knowledge is power. I think that it should be talked about at school in connection with health education programmes. My daughter is nine and has lived through the disease with me. I want her to be fully aware of the risks. If only I had known what to look out for, I think that my situation would have been very different." Neither is she impressed with the use of pouty poster girls. "Personally, I don't see the point of models looking gorgeous in the T-shirt; it's using sex and looking good to promote something that is the opposite of that. Breast cancer isn't about glossy images, and by associating the disease with that, it just distances it from normal people. It would be far better to use people in the ads who had direct contact with breast cancer. Then hopefully the public would be able to relate to it better. Awareness should be integrated into daily life, not put on a glamorous pedestal." There is another side to the argument, though: that there is no better way of reaching a young audience than by using pop stars and models. Christine Piper had a double lumpectomy in December 1998 and since then has raised £18,000 for Breakthrough. "Using Vogue models does not worry me. If they're willing to do it then it means that the message is getting across to young kids. Pop stars like the Spice Girls and Robbie Williams are particularly useful. My kids look at them and think, 'If it's OK for them to wear a T-shirt then it's OK for us too. And that all goes to spreading the message. I honestly don't think it matters how it's done as long as it gets out there." Piper is compiling an anthology by people whose lives have been touched by the disease; contributors include Cherie Blair and Prince Charles, though she has yet to find a publisher. She gets particularly cross with those who suggest that Breakthrough is misdirecting its message to the young when it is older women who are most likely to die of the disease. "When I was 12, my mother had breast cancer. No one told me anything about the disease, or that it could ever affect me. I remember going with her to St George's hospital for radiotherapy and seeing this big sign saying 'Danger: Radiation'. It was in the 60s during the space race and I thought it sounded very sci-fi and far-removed from real life. "If only someone had told me more about the disease back then, I would have been more aware of the risks. It's not important that the kids wearing the T-shirts today might not experience the disease until they're in their 60s. The point is that they should know what to watch out for. Unfortunately knowledge was a luxury that I never had."  Fashion Targets Breast Cancer: 0870 333 0322. Breast Cancer Care's free helpline: 0808 800 6000. fields.headline: Clashes as protesters target IMF
fields.standfirst: Capital conflict:  Police use tear gas in massive show of force
fields.trailText: Thousands of anti-globalisation protesters placed the World Bank and International Monetary Fund under siege yesterday as their demonstrations closed down the heart of the American capital.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott  and  Jane Martinson  in Washington
fields.body:
Thousands of anti-globalisation protesters placed the World Bank and International Monetary Fund under siege yesterday as their demonstrations closed down the heart of the American capital.

Finance ministers and central bankers were bussed in under armed guard soon after dawn to avoid the human chains which later formed around the IMF's 19th Street headquarters. However, four finance ministers, including Laurent Fabius of France, failed to get into meetings.

Sirens and helicopters were used by police in a massive show of force designed to prevent a repeat of the riots that paralysed Seattle during the meeting of the World Trade Organisation in December.

Charles Ramsey, the Washington police chief, took to the front line as tension escalated between protesters and police officers from at least 15 law enforcement agencies, including the Secret Service. He defused a potentially violent stand-off by ordering his men, in full riot gear, to remove their gas masks.

Between 6,000 and 10,000 demonstrators squared up against police in streets cleared of traffic. Mobile phone-wielding organisers rallied their troops to close off streets in an area of about a square mile to the west of the White House. They tied themselves together using lengths of pipe and chains. At times aggressive, they sought to bar access to the meetings to all delegates and observers.

Although the protests were largely peaceful, there were several violent clashes as police officers used tear gas, pepper gas and batons and rode motorcycles at the crowds to disperse them. Laura Montgomery, one of the organisers of Mobilisation for Global Justice, said: "There was some aggressive pushing and shoving and tear gassing."

Tension had escalated after 600 people were arrested and the group's headquarters was closed on Saturday because of alleged fire regulation breaches.

The IMF's international monetary and financial committee, chaired by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, went ahead as planned. However, many of Mr Brown's team were unable to break through the barricades.

Inside the IMF building, politicians and bureaucrats said they understood the depth of feeling among the protesters, most of them students, but there was no turning back from globalisation.

Patrick Reinsborough, a 27-year-old demonstrator from San Francisco, said: "We are seeing a movement being formed in the US in connection with the global resistance to massive economic violence and ecological devastation around the world."

webTitle: How to avoid losing the plot

fields.headline: How to avoid losing the plot
fields.standfirst: Aeons of hunting and gathering have made women natural gardeners, a new report claims. Rubbish, says  Helen Dunmore
fields.trailText: I remember watching my grandmother take cuttings from a favourite geranium. She did it rapidly, thrusting the cuttings into soft, black soil. They took root from her sure touch. In her packed life (she was the mother of 12 children) she always found time to grow plants. Gardening knowledge lives in the fingers as well as the brain. It's built up slowly, until the gardener can tell by touch when to water and when not to water, and how to set a plant in the earth so that it will   spread its roots and flourish. Such knowledge brings a flow of pleasure into life which has nothing to do with how the job is going, and nothing to do with age or looks or status.
fields.body:
I remember watching my grandmother take cuttings from a favourite geranium. She did it rapidly, thrusting the cuttings into soft, black soil. They took root from her sure touch. In her packed life (she was the mother of 12 children) she always found time to grow plants. Gardening knowledge lives in the fingers as well as the brain. It's built up slowly, until the gardener can tell by touch when to water and when not to water, and how to set a plant in the earth so that it will spread its roots and flourish. Such knowledge brings a flow of pleasure into life which has nothing to do with how the job is going, and nothing to do with age or looks or status.

A new study by the British Psychological Society found that women are quicker at finding and correctly identifying plants than men. According to the co-author of the research, this shows that women are evolutionarily programmed to gather and forage for plants successfully. Such a conclusion is depressing. Subtle, valuable, acquired skills are downgraded.

Perhaps a more interesting question would be to ask what women get from knowing about plants. What makes us want to acquire and treasure this knowledge, bearing in mind that, in this country at least, gathering and foraging is usually called theft? In Britain, gardening is not about foraging in an unknown landscape. It is about enclosing a small part of the landscape and making it your own. I can think of a dozen women friends with jobs and children who garden passionately, because they find it gives them back so much more than the time it takes.

Time changes, in a garden. It calls for a kind of attentiveness which makes the gardener live in the moment. It silences the nagging drone of "things to do", the ever unrolling list which haunts most women's heads. Although gardening is full of hope for the future, it allows you to live in the present tense. There is this bush, here and now, which must be pruned. This is the way the secateurs cut, this is the scent of the prunings. You hear the click of the blades, feel the sun on your back, and notice a ladybird spreading its wings but not taking off. Everything else recedes. My gardening friends' windowsills are crammed with seed trays. They exchange cuttings, and go to plant sales. Most are urban women, working small patches, cramming in scent and colour. Every gardener seems to have a private dream. It might be the first fruiting of a Brown Turkey fig in a huge pot, or a scent of tobacco flowers in a summer dusk, or a pergola, or a pond with iris and marsh marigold. When someone shows you her garden, never be fooled by her attempt to seem offhand about the dream she has grown.

A garden is a secret place, no matter how open it may appear. Only the gardener knows where the sun falls at each season of the year, where the frost pockets are, where extra drainage is needed, where red-hot pokers will blaze against a sunny wall, where valerian will self-seed in stony ground. Only the gardener knows about her garden's failures. She remembers the compost that stank instead of rotting down to sweetness, the lily shoots eaten back to the soil by slugs, the blind bulbs, bolting lettuce and rain-sodden strawberries. But even failure is only temporary, in a garden. Gardening and child-rearing may have a lot in common, but there's a vital difference. With gardening, you can always start again.

A few weeks ago I moved to a new house. The garden is very small, but richly planted, and the soil has been well composted. Daffodils, primulas, violets and bergenia are just beginning to die down. Nubs of lily of the valley are pushing up. Passionflower, clematis and honeysuckle are coming into leaf. Between two paving stones are tiny blue anemones. It's so exciting to see what is there, to watch it emerge, to discover the shapes this garden makes, and to think about the way it may change in the future. I kneel down and peer at unfolding leaves to work out what they are. Some may call this evolutionary programming, but I prefer to call it pleasure.

fields.headline: Judging history
fields.standfirst: It took 62 days in court and more than 36,000 pages of evidence to discredit the historian David Irving. But Mr Justice Gray's verdict, when it came, was a tour de force. He speaks to  Clare Dyer
fields.trailText: It took 62 days in court and more than 36,000 pages of evidence to discredit the historian David Irving. But Mr Justice Gray's verdict, when it came, was a tour de force. He speaks to  Clare Dyer
fields.body:
"History is too important - far, far too important - to be left to the lawyers," wrote the author Robert Harris in the aftermath of the mammoth libel battle between Lord Aldington and Nikolai Tolstoy over the forced repatriation that sent thousands of Yugoslavs and Cossacks to their deaths in 1945.

Truth can be an elusive commodity in the courts, and that trial, like most, left many questions unanswered. Libel trials in particular rarely end with the feeling that the full story has been told. Irving v Penguin Books is a rare exception.

The painstaking, microscopic examination of historical evidence and the 334-page judgment by Mr Justice Gray have finally put to rest any lingering doubts about the scale and horror of the Holocaust. Yet this result is a by-product of the narrow task the judge set himself. He is at pains to point out that his role was not to decide what the Nazis did 60 years ago. He did not, therefore - as Penguin's QC, Richard Rampton, did - make the trip to Auschwitz. His job was to decide whether David Irving had deliberately manipulated and falsified the historical evidence and denied the truth of the Holocaust.

"What was at issue - it can't be said too often - was Irving's methodology and historiography, not what happened back in the 40s," says Gray. "It wasn't a question of deciding what happened. It's quite difficult to explain why it wasn't necessary to decide what happened. It was a question of seeing what evidence was available at the time and deciding whether the criticisms were justified in the light of whatever evidence was available." He had to look at whether the evidence was that the Holocaust had happened, not whether the Holocaust had actually happened. "If you think about it, it is actually a real distinction."

When we meet at 9.30am in his large, comfortable room in the back corridors of the royal courts of justice, Sir Charles Gray is already hard at work on his computer, two weeks into a less remarkable libel case which hasn't made it into the headlines. He can't speak about the issues in the Irving case because it may go to appeal.

He doesn't know why it fell to him, the most junior of the three judges who hear libel cases, to preside over what may well prove to be his case of a lifetime. Appointed to the bench less than two years ago, 57-year-old Gray had been a leading libel QC, but had no historical background; he read PPE at Oxford.

In the 1989 Tolstoy-Aldington case, he had a dry run of sorts as Aldington's silk: mass deaths, the second world war, the search for historical truth, high emotions against the backdrop of a sober law court. Rampton, as Tolstoy's counsel, was his opponent in that case. "The Tolstoy case was hard," recalls Rampton, "but this [the Irving case] was harder for me. I knew the broad outline but I had no idea of the detail. The worst thing for me was to have to go and visit Auschwitz."

For Gray, however, the forensic scrutiny of historical evidence distanced the court from the horror of the events. "There was a lot of emotion in Aldington but there wasn't in this because it was all expert evidence and that in a way distanced you from the actual events, which I think is a good thing." He sees a parallel not with the Aldington case but with a completely different type of libel action in which he appeared as a silk.

In 1994 he represented the Upjohn company in an action against an emeritus professor of psychiatry, Ian Oswald, over claims that the sleeping pill Halcion had dangerous side effects. That case, which took 62 days in court with exhibits running to more than 36,000 pages, also needed a mastery of complex evidence in an unfamiliar field. In the Irving case, he found it "very revealing" to discover how historians work. "You really examine individual documents very minutely and the use of original source material is extremely difficult and taxing."

Had the case been heard by a jury, as most libel cases are, we would have been denied Gray's tour de force, with its damning verdict on Irving as racist, anti-semitic and a rightwing pro-Nazi polemicist. The jury would simply have found that Penguin had or had not libelled Irving and that would have been that. In the event, both sides agreed the case was too complex for a jury.

"I just don't think it could have been fairly tried by a jury," says Gray, " because the mass of material - close to 10,000 pages of documents plus books - was just too big." He was able to produce his judgment quickly by spending two to three hours a day before the court hearings and the same time afterwards summing up the arguments as the case went along. "I think it's very important if anyone wants to read the judgment that they see not only what the findings are but what the arguments were."

Having one of the parties represent himself, as Irving did, is frequently a judge's nightmare. But Irving was far from a typical litigant in person. No lawyer could have managed such mastery over his material. "He conducted his case in a very impressive way," says Gray. "I really don't feel that he lost out because of not having representation.

"Where you've got a litigant in person it's part of the judge's duty to make sure he isn't disadvantaged. I certainly tried and I hope I succeeded in giving him every assistance with technical problems, and I hope he feels he wasn't disadvantaged." Rampton, who appeared against two penniless environmental activists in the long-running McDonald's libel case, agrees that Irving's lack of a lawyer wasn't a problem. "He knows his stuff, does Mr Irving."

Rampton says having Gray as his adversary in Aldington v Tolstoy was "the one ray of light" in the case. "He was a wonderful opponent. It was a very hard-fought case. He was a very good advocate and a fair one. I don't think in the whole of that very pressurised trial there was a harsh word between us."

Much of Gray's working life has been spent in the public eye, in one high-profile libel case after another. Apart from Aldington, he has represented Tony Blair's press spokesman Alistair Campbell, the cricketer Ian Botham, the actors Bill Roache and Jason Donovan - and, yes, he was the weapon Jonathan Aitken wielded against the Guardian, having dispensed with the promised "simple sword of truth". He will not comment on the Aitken case, but is known to have been as gobsmacked as anyone when it emerged that the former Tory minister had told a pack of lies to the court about his stay at the Paris Ritz. George Carman, the Guardian's silk in the case, says: "I'm sure he trusted his client. Who wouldn't, with a man of that background? I'm sure he was both surprised and shocked when he learned his client had committed perjury." At the bar, Carman crossed swords with him in around half a dozen cases, including the action against Channel 4 by journalist Jani Allan over allegations that she had an affair with Eugene Terre'Blanche, leader of the extreme right-wing South African AWB party. In his short time on the bench, say libel barristers, Gray has already shown his judicial qualities. Carman says: "It's very difficult for a judge who hasn't been there all that long to settle down to a case with international implications and deliver himself of such a masterly judgment. It's rare that a libel case has social, political and cultural implications. It was a major challenge of detail and complexity.

"I think he has the makings of a very good judge indeed, and I think that's the view generally of the defamation bar. He's not an over-zealous intervener. He listens very carefully and doesn't rush in where angels fear to tread."
