Apart from Aldington, he has represented Tony Blair's press spokesman Alistair Campbell, the cricketer Ian Botham, the actors Bill Roache and Jason Donovan - and, yes, he was the weapon Jonathan Aitken wielded against the Guardian, having dispensed with the promised "simple sword of truth". He will not comment on the Aitken case, but is known to have been as gobsmacked as anyone when it emerged that the former Tory minister had told a pack of lies to the court about his stay at the Paris Ritz. George Carman, the Guardian's silk in the case, says: "I'm sure he trusted his client. Who wouldn't, with a man of that background? I'm sure he was both surprised and shocked when he learned his client had committed perjury." At the bar, Carman crossed swords with him in around half a dozen cases, including the action against Channel 4 by journalist Jani Allan over allegations that she had an affair with Eugene Terre'Blanche, leader of the extreme right-wing South African AWB party. In his short time on the bench, say libel barristers, Gray has already shown his judicial qualities. Carman says: "It's very difficult for a judge who hasn't been there all that long to settle down to a case with international implications and deliver himself of such a masterly judgment. It's rare that a libel case has social, political and cultural implications. It was a major challenge of detail and complexity. "I think he has the makings of a very good judge indeed, and I think that's the view generally of the defamation bar. He's not an over-zealous intervener. He listens very carefully and doesn't rush in where angels fear to tread."

fields.headline: Up on the roof
fields.standfirst: The National Portrait Gallery's new extension is not only light, airy and quietly elegant. It also has a stunning view of central London, writes  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: The National Portrait Gallery's new extension is not only light, airy and quietly elegant. It also has a stunning view of central London, writes Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
It is hard to put a face to the National Portrait Gallery. Often thought of as some sort of annexe to the much grander National Gallery next door in Trafalgar Square, the NPG is a separate institution, and a very distinctive one. It does one thing and does it well: collecting and displaying portraits of British people from, effectively, Tudor times to the present day. This is who we are, it says - or at least how we look.

Now it has been extended and given new energy by Jeremy Dixon and Edward Jones, architects of the remodelled Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, a few minutes' walk from the NPG. But where the ROH is gracefully ostentatious, a diva of a building trying on frocks old and new, the NPG has retained its special, rather secret quality since being rebuilt. In fact, the new work can barely be seen from the street. The dramatic new three-storey wing fills much of the courtyard that separated the NPG from the National Gallery, but you would need a neck like a giraffe and a pair of opera glasses to spot it from the street.

It is all but invisible until the visitor goes inside the original building, a curious, not quite neo-anything Victorian design by the obscure architect Ewan Christian. The old wooden revolving doors have gone, replaced by a sleek new airport-style number by Dixon Jones. The purpose of this, say the architects and the NPG's director Charles Saumarez Smith, is to make the entrance a much lighter, more engaging space. It was last renovated by Roderick Gradidge, whose mission some 20 years ago was to highlight the building's heavy-handed Victorian design rather than to nudge it into the late 20th century.

Visitors who climb the stairs now are faced with a grand new pair of doors opening into the dramatic new extension. The sunlight that pours into the lofty atrium-like space is quite unexpected in a gallery that, for the most part, needs to keep light levels low. But it is this deliberate contrast between low-key galleries and highly animated new circulation space that makes the hidden extension both surprising and enjoyable.

The idea was to give the gallery a new hub and create a new route up and through the galleries. A long escalator rises through the atrium, through slants and chutes of bright daylight to the atmospheric gloom of the new Tudor and Elizabethan gallery, the world of Holbein and Henry VIII. Here the walls are lined, by interior designer David Milnaric, in a grey military cloth, while the magnificent portraits are lit precisely by tiny spot lamps. Light is not allowed to spill beyond the frames. The result is delightful: the richly coloured portraits glow.

One floor below is a balcony gallery hung from the floor above. It shows modern works in daylight, diffused by a set of angled white screens through which there are intriguing views of the atrium's rather complex geometry. What at first appears to be a tall rectangular box with an escalator climbing up it proves to be an irregular form of subtle, elongated angles.

The balcony screens are a happy accident. The architects intended a completely open balcony gallery, but the lighting levels would have been too high for the comfort of curators. Down below, between the entrance to the new extension and the balcony gallery, is an information room. Visitors can access the NPG's collection through computer screens.

And that's it? No. This furtive extension's two best secrets are its neat, wood-lined underground auditorium and its top-floor cafe, which offers a magnificent panorama of central London. There is no other view quite like it, and it is breathtaking. The main view is over the pepper-pot dome of the National Gallery, over Nelson's shoulder in Trafalgar Square and down to the Palace of Westminster. It is remarkable to see just how high above the river the National Gallery and NPG are. Such a view is priceless, and it is also an effective way of curing museum fatigue. After looking close-up at so many painted and photographed faces, the visitor's eyes and mind are given space to stretch and breathe.

What the new extension does for the gallery as a whole is to act as a kind of junction box, and it should work well. The architecture is quietly dramatic and simple, which is appropriate given that the rest of the building is fussy, ornate and a little cramped. The building was always a bit potty. Originally, visitors had to climb up to the third floor picture gallery. Offices and studios were set below. Today these are housed in a separate building across Orange Street to make way for the galleries. These were added to, quietly and elegantly, by John and Su Miller in the 80s. It seems no one has ever wanted to make much fuss at the NPG. The portraits speak for themselves. This is a gallery that offers a singular experience - although the way visitors will use the building now will be quite different from how it was before. They will find new routes through the building, and are now more likely to linger in the gallery. Entry is still free, and it is a fine place in which to hide away on a rainy afternoon.

The museum politics of the Dixon Jones extension are interesting too. In order to get the space Saumarez Smith wanted, his architects initiated a deal whereby part of the building would be given over to the National Gallery next door and vice versa. Museums and galleries guard their fiefdoms jealously, but a little to-ing and fro-ing between these neighbouring institutions has given both more of what they want and encouraged them to work more closely together.

This facadeless, though not faceless, extension is in a way symbolic of millennial public architecture in Britain: shy, retiring and a conversion or adaptation of an existing building. God knows what Henry VIII, Queen Elizabeth I and the rest would have made of such reticence. Even so, it is a fine foil to the opulent paintings it contains and, given the densely built-up location, which allows little or no room for forceful new architecture, this is reason enough to welcome its gentlemanly presence.

webTitle: Why we should all do our duty

fields.headline: Why we should all do our duty
fields.standfirst: Writ large in the USA
fields.trailText: Writ large in the USA
fields.body:
Three years ago New York, where I've just been, abolished the categories of occupations and professions exempt from jury service. A million new potential jurors were created. Virtually everyone now has to serve, including lawyers, policemen, doctors, Harvey Keitel, Mayor Giuliani himself, even judges.

With the mass of newly eligible lawyers, Manhattan juries have changed dramatically. In the summer months, when the academics are free to do their stint, juries are stuffed with PhDs. But what difference has this made? Surprisingly, perhaps, the anecdotal evidence is that all those extra brains, degrees and qualifications have made little difference to conviction rates, or even to the way juries conduct themselves. The bit I find hard to believe is that, on the whole, the lawyers and judges who have been on juries have not tried to dominate the deliberations, nor make a point about their special knowledge. Even more incomprehensibly, trials are not taking three times as long.

Perhaps the English system should have the same intolerance of avoiding jury service. Far too many are exempted or somehow get out of doing it. I look forward to a trial with a jury which includes the Lord Chancellor, Mayor Livingstone and George Carman.

Strange things are happening in the litigation against US tobacco manufacturers. A Florida jury has just awarded three ill smokers millions of dollars in compensation. The verdict triggers similar claims by up to 500,000 Floridians harmed by smoking. Big money. But that's not all. The same jury is to return in a few weeks with its decision on how much to award in punitive damages. And that could be many billions of dollars.

The result is a curious panic by, ironically, the anti-smoking lobby. They fear that if the manufacturers are ordered to pay too much in damages, they won't be able to continue to pay out the billions of dollars they owe under a previous settlement. And some of that money was earmarked for programmes stopping children from smoking. So, the new war cry is: for the sake of our children, please don't punish the tobacco companies too much. If the jury don't listen to that plea, the legislators will step in to lighten the burden on the poor old fag-makers. Bizarre.

The main controversy raging through the upper reaches of New York lawyerdom is about neither law nor making money. It's a sartorial question. How far should male lawyers abandon their traditional livery of suit and tie for a more informal uniform? It's an issue that has spread to US law firms in England. The new gear is known as "business casual" (not to be confused with casual, smart casual, or going-out clothes), and the problem is that no one seems to know exactly what's OK and what's going too far.

Not all firms are joining in this pathetic gesture at proving modernity and unstuffiness by way of chinos and cashmere sweaters. But the ones who have gone down the dressing-down path have a big problem, as evidenced by the before-and-after pictures in the New York Times. In suits, the partners of a top firm look confident, knowledgeable and aggressive. The same bozos in "business casual" look sheepish, awkward and timid. And oh, those colours. You wouldn't use these lawyers to sue a used-car salesman.

I normally take the view that what happens in the American legal world today, however absurd, reaches England 10 years later. This one won't.

Several ex-wives of senior judges have got together to bring a lawsuit, alleging that New Hampshire's old-boy network, which included judges as well as the women's own lawyers, prevented them from obtaining the best deal possible in their divorces. Two of the women claim they couldn't even get a good lawyer and had to take second-rate advice.

The proposed lawsuit follows a scandal in the New Hampshire supreme court which led to one of the judges resigning after allegations that he had improperly tried to influence cases heard by his colleagues - including his own bitter divorce. His wife's appeal to the supreme court ended in all the judges of that court refusing to sit on it. An independent inquiry revealed that lots of judges had tried, behind the scenes, to influence cases - not just divorce - from which they'd withdrawn because of conflicts of interest. The ex-wives' litigation, if it gets anywhere, promises to uncover further examples of injudicious male bonding.

fields.headline: Going live
fields.trailText: My most frightening moment as a presenter on live television came when Germaine Greer was reviewing a history of culture by Roger Scruton on Late Review. In a later transcript, Professor Greer's comments read: "Roger Scruton tries to write about Kant but he knows absolutely nothing about Kant." But transcripts don't show pronounciation. And this is not what I heard. I have since been told that the way in which a German "a" becomes a "u" has given generations of schoolboys an unexpected interest in German philosophers.
fields.body:
My most frightening moment as a presenter on live television came when Germaine Greer was reviewing a history of culture by Roger Scruton on Late Review. In a later transcript, Professor Greer's comments read: "Roger Scruton tries to write about Kant but he knows absolutely nothing about Kant." But transcripts don't show pronounciation. And this is not what I heard. I have since been told that the way in which a German "a" becomes a "u" has given generations of schoolboys an unexpected interest in German philosophers.

At the time, live on BBC2, I believed that Professor Greer had questioned Roger Scruton's comprehension of femininity in a manner which was somewhat direct but not entirely out of keeping with the vigour of her debating style. And because the German philosopher word is the most unforgivable expletive on live TV, I was preparing to apologise to viewers when she said the word a third time, adding a possessive apostrophe and a reference to the Critique Of Pure Reason.

That the rudeness was an illusion on that occasion sadly renders it ineligible for TV'S Naughtiest Blunders (ITV, Wednesday, 10pm), which promises "a series of four-lettered utterances from a variety of famous faces". Presented by Steve Penk (pictured), it's an adult version of Dennis Norden's It'll Be All Right On The Night shows. Like most shows featuring out-takes, it uses too loose a definition of broadcasting embarrassment.

The Blue Peter elephant remains a symbol of the risks of live TV - the possibility of a retake would have made the incident far less funny. On TV's Naughtiest Blunders, it's amusing when Martin Clunes gets sexually explicit on This Morning With Richard & Judy because the presenters look so terrified. But news reporters swearing when taped pieces to camera go wrong is no more interesting than other workplace cursing.

The most intriguing aspect of the show is that the expletives aren't bleeped. ITV is pushing back the language barrier. My dream is to arrange for Germaine Greer to discuss German philosophy with Richard & Judy.

fields.headline: Tomorrow's world
fields.standfirst: Futurecast, a new series of dramas on Channel 4, imagines what television will be like in 2012. It's all great fun, says  Mark Lawson. Just don't take the predictions too seriously
fields.trailText: Because memory is fallible and research tedious, it's easy for writers to get the past wrong. Historical novelists dread the gleefully pedantic letter pointing out that their beautifully described drowning was unlikely because the year in question had been one of catastrophic drought.
fields.body:
Because memory is fallible and research tedious, it's easy for writers to get the past wrong. Historical novelists dread the gleefully pedantic letter pointing out that their beautifully described drowning was unlikely because the year in question had been one of catastrophic drought.

Getting the future wrong is probably worse, though, because more people will notice. In 1989, Martin Amis published London Fields, set 10 years later. The novel correctly predicted many of the social neuroses of the real 1999, and there's one impressive accidental prophecy - the big television show of the pre-millennium year is a quiz game with a host who sounds oddly like Chris Tarrant - but, in this fictional Britain, mobile phones are exotic tools which only a technological elite possess.

In a week which sees the start of Futurecast (C4, Thursday, 9pm) - three dramas set in 2012 - mobile phones offer a good example of the difficulty of predictive fiction: we tend to extend what we can already see but many advances creep out of the dark. Writing London Fields during the Cold War at a time when portable telephones were in-car models the size of sewing machines, Amis anticipated a nuclear stand-off and communication from call boxes. What we got was Kosovo and signs in restaurants and theatres warning clients to silence their mobiles. These developments were unguessable; the risk of crystal-ball fiction.

Projecting forwards now from 2000, we're likely to make the same mistake. The smart bet seems to be a population carrying mobile video-phones and shouting, presumably, "Can you see me on the train?" Another default assumption would be the domination of the internet. It would be a brave science-fiction writer now who built a scene around a High Street shop rather than showing consumers choosing goods from a screen. And yet both these predictions may seem ridiculous by 2012. The futuristic writer looks up from the word processor to see newspaper stories of new fears over mobile phone radiation and a sudden sell-off of new technology stocks. Maybe 2012 will still have call-boxes and family butchers after all.

The three plays which make up the Futurecast series are specifically intended to explore the future of television. The opening drama - Kidnap by John Milne - shows a world in which television is transmitted purely through the world wide web. Because internet broadcasts are harder to protect than those from satellites or transmitters, the networks are at the mercy of cyber-pirates, who can hack into channels during live transmissions and take them over.

In a similar stretching of present trends, Milne assumes that Britain will be part of a European superstate. Public healthcare is provided by the EHS (European Health Service) but - and again you feel contemporary headlines being magnified - there is two-tier provision. The best treatments are available to the privately insured, while clients of the EHS die from similar illnesses.

That standby of science fiction - the cure for cancer - has been discovered through gene therapy but only private medicine provides it. Yet even some of the well-heeled are unable to arrange private insurance because genetic screening - now mandatory in the European Super State - has revealed that they will develop expensive conditions.

This proposition allows a thriller plot, in which an anarchist and the wife of an EHS cancer patient kidnap the head of the pharmaceutical company which pioneered gene treatment and stage live on internet television a debate about whether he should live or die.

The traditional problem of science fiction has been that it tends to over-estimate the rate of change. According to the novelistic prophets of the past, there ought to be hotels on Mars by now. A 70s BBC1 series called Plays For Tomorrow - in which Play For Today dramatists were encouraged to look ahead in anger - predicted, for the era which is now our present, electric cars, the complete breakdown of social order and everyone walking around in acrylic polo-necks.

Writer Milne and director Bryn Higgins are cautious visually. The vehicles and haircuts are more or less ours. But they present huge political, social and technological changes. A European health service in 12 years. Obligatory gene-profiling, we learn from a flashback, was introduced in 2004 which, in Westminster terms, is the day after tomorrow.

The date of these dramas - 2012 - has the same relationship to now as 1988 has. Many of the cars, clothes, songs and celebrities from back then still exist today. It would be interesting to know if Channel 4 - which commissioned these predictive plays - is working at boardroom level as well on the assumption that television will only exist on the internet in three Olympic years from now.

But, from the evidence of the first drama, it seems that the main weakness of Futurecast is that its predictions never do more than inflate the already visible. Its world is a kind of 2000 to the power of three. A few bold counter-intuitive guesses - letter-writing making a comeback in a culture tired of email and mobile phones, a sudden braining-up of culture bringing Chekhov and Ibsen productions nightly on ITV - would have been more fun.

In a similar stretching of present trends, Milne assumes that Britain will be part of a European superstate. Public healthcare is provided by the EHS (European Health Service) but - and again you feel contemporary headlines being magnified - there is two-tier provision. The best treatments are available to the privately insured, while clients of the EHS die from similar illnesses. That standby of science fiction - the cure for cancer - has been discovered through gene therapy but only private medicine provides it. Yet even some of the well-heeled are unable to arrange private insurance because genetic screening - now mandatory in the European Super State - has revealed that they will develop expensive conditions. This proposition allows a thriller plot, in which an anarchist and the wife of an EHS cancer patient kidnap the head of the pharmaceutical company which pioneered gene treatment and stage live on internet television a debate about whether he should live or die. The traditional problem of science fiction has been that it tends to over-estimate the rate of change. According to the novelistic prophets of the past, there ought to be hotels on Mars by now. A 70s BBC1 series called Plays For Tomorrow - in which Play For Today dramatists were encouraged to look ahead in anger - predicted, for the era which is now our present, electric cars, the complete breakdown of social order and everyone walking around in acrylic polo-necks. Writer Milne and director Bryn Higgins are cautious visually. The vehicles and haircuts are more or less ours. But they present huge political, social and technological changes. A European health service in 12 years. Obligatory gene-profiling, we learn from a flashback, was introduced in 2004 which, in Westminster terms, is the day after tomorrow. The date of these dramas - 2012 - has the same relationship to now as 1988 has. Many of the cars, clothes, songs and celebrities from back then still exist today. It would be interesting to know if Channel 4 - which commissioned these predictive plays - is working at boardroom level as well on the assumption that television will only exist on the internet in three Olympic years from now. But, from the evidence of the first drama, it seems that the main weakness of Futurecast is that its predictions never do more than inflate the already visible. Its world is a kind of 2000 to the power of three. A few bold counter-intuitive guesses - letter-writing making a comeback in a culture tired of email and mobile phones, a sudden braining-up of culture bringing Chekhov and Ibsen productions nightly on ITV - would have been more fun.

fields.trailText: The ancient art of yoga is exercise at its frugal, simple and economic best and, with Madonna as a recent covert, is once again fashionable. In Yoga: Head To Toe (Radio 4, 11am) Mark Tully, himself a practitioner of yoga, meets BKS Iyengar who brought the discipline of yoga to the west. Iyengar's acolytes praise the spiritual and medical benefits of working on your asana, and if they fail to convince listeners, then Iyengar's own remarkable biography - a tubercular child who wasn't expected to live but who's reached his 80s still spry and flexible - will have you signing up for a course.

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText:
Dan Aykroyd in 1941
(Steven Spielberg, 1979)
fields.body:
Dan Aykroyd in 1941
(Steven Spielberg, 1979)

Who? Podgy Canadian comedy actor, still best known as stooge of the late John Belushi. Absolutely huge in the 80s, when he starred in a number of good (Ghostbusters, Trading Places), bad (Dragnet) and truly terrible (My Stepmother Is An Alien) movies. He came to fame with Saturday Night Live where he worked alongside lots of people who were much funnier than him - Belushi, Steve Martin, Bill Murray, and Eddie Murphy to name just a few. Cult success for The Blues Brothers couldn't stop Aykroyd's career from bottoming out after the death of his funnier other half, culminating in the atrocity that was Blues Brothers 2000. Career rehabilitation seemed imminent with a great role as a hitman in Grosse Pointe Blank, but it was obviously not to be: Aykroyd can currently be seen hosting Psi Factor on the Sci-Fi channel.

The role: Sergeant Frank Tree, the rather inept military man in charge of defending California from possible Japanese attacks after Pearl Harbor.

Best line: He spends most of the film calling his soldiers a "bunch of foul-ups!" Bet you're laughing already.

Cringe factor: Nothing compared to his later work. And by that I mean Coneheads.

Other wannabes: Treat Williams as a sex-mad soldier, and John Candy as a hapless private.

Critical judgement: In a relatively benign assessment of one of the more critically reviled films of the late 20th century, Leonard Maltin says Spielberg's sole venture into broad comedy has "some excellent vignettes and dazzling special effects" before concluding that "on the whole [it] suffers from overkill".

Also not starring in: The Rutles, in 1978, as Brian Thigh.

1941, Sky Cinema, Saturday April 22, 2.0pm & 3.15am

fields.headline: Bridget Jones
fields.trailText: Bridget Jones, who has died of cancer aged 64, did more than anyone to establish the study of francophone Caribbean literature in British universities.
fields.body:
Bridget Jones, who has died of cancer aged 64, did more than anyone to establish the study of francophone Caribbean literature in British universities.

After a brief period post-1968, when it became fashionable to acknowledge the existence of texts from the French West Indies in the syllabuses of a few of the newer universities, very few students came across Caribbean authors in their study of literature in French. Today, Caribbean literature not only figures prominently in many French departments' programmes, but is a productive area of research in the UK and Ireland, largely as a result of the work of Jones, and those who worked with her, inspired by her knowledge, enthusiasm and untiring efforts.

Born Bridget Wheeler in London, she attended Mich- enden grammar school, from where she won a scholarship to Newnham College, Cambridge. She got a first in French and Spanish, and went on to do a PhD at King's College, London. Her doctoral thesis, Antonin Artaud: His Work And Literary Situation, though never published, was a pioneering work on an author little known in Britain at the time.

It was at Cambridge that she met Donald Jones, a Jamaican student of chemical engineering. They married in 1959, and four years later moved to Jamaica. Bridget immersed herself in the country's life, whether in her kitchen - the codfish fritters, rice and peas at their parties were legendary - or in her contribution to weekly arts programmes on the radio. After a year of schoolteaching, she joined the staff of the University of the West Indies, and became part of a team of young academics adapting syllabuses more closely tied to the Caribbean than had been possible when the institution was a college of London University.

Although she continued to teach 19th- and 20th-century French metropolitan literature, Jones was instrumental in developing an option in French Caribbean writing, which eventually became a compulsory paper for students doing a special degree in French, and supervised one of the first PhD theses on French Caribbean literature. She was an exacting teacher, and a generation of students widened its horizons by taking part in the readings and productions of French plays that she organised.

In 1982, Jones and her two sons settled in Britain, while Donald took up a post in Saudi Arabia. She continued to publish on francophone Caribbean literature in general, and the theatre and French Guiana in particular. She taught at the University of Reading in 1985 and 1986, and was appointed to the department of modern languages of the Roehampton Institute in 1988.

Her illness forced her to retire seven years later, but she continued to help former colleagues, encourage postgraduate students and publish until the end of her life. One of her works, Paradoxes Of French Caribbean Theatre (1997), a scholarly checklist of nearly 400 plays in French in Creole written or produced in the French overseas departments of Martinique, Guadeloupe and Guyane since 1900, on which she collaborated with Sita Littlewood, is a model of precision, and will serve researchers in the area for years to come.

In 1989, Jones was among the founders of the Association for the Study of Caribbean and African Literature in French. Young academics specialising in the area are unanimous in acknowledging the role her support has played in their careers. She also published with authority and finesse on writing from the English-speaking West Indies, and her own poems were published in anthologies both in the Caribbean and in this country.

Jones is survived by Donald and their two sons, Daniel and Matthew.

 Bridget Heather Jones (née Wheeler), academic, born November 20 1935; died April 4 2000

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
Batman
8.30am, Granada Plus
fields.body:
Batman
8.30am, Granada Plus

Despite the super-criminal early morning slot, this is essential viewing. A melange of on-screen cartoon exclamations, gloriously ridiculous effects (wall-climbing facilitated by turning the camera on its side) and great dialogue that's a long way from Bob Kane's original Dark Knight vision, Adam West and Burt Ward are still for many the definitive interpretation of the camp crusaders. The first guest star to perplex the dynamic duo is Frank Gorshin, in the green question-marked costume of The Riddler.

Elizabeth
(Shekhar Kapur, 1998)
8pm, FilmFour

Not entirely accurate, but a convincing picture of a dangerous time. Courtly intrigue is carried out with whispers in dark, stony corridors and the cold strike of the stiletto; around the young queen are politicians such as Chris Eccleston's Norfolk and Geoffrey Rush's Walsingham, while her lover, Joseph Fiennes's Dudley, lacks resolve. Cate Blanchett's Elizabeth rises above all this, creating a monarch reminiscent of Bette Davis in her regal authority.

Festen
(Thomas Vinterberg, 1998)
10.15pm, FilmFour

A wealthy Danish clan gathers for the patriarch's 60th birthday. Eldest son Christian (Ulrich Thomsen) has a speech to make: with horrifying revelations about his father. On the film's release there was much discussion of the Dogme creed under which Vinterberg made his film - hand-held cameras, natural lighting and all that - but aside from this it's intense and bitterly funny.

Shampoo
(Hal Ashby, 1975)
3.15am, Carlton Cinema

Satirical tale of the bizarre working life and loves of a womanising Beverly Hills hairdresser. It's a farce of blow-dries and blow-jobs, except that star and producer Warren Beatty (pictured) is much more than just a pretty face, and the numerous sexual adventures are part of a sly portrait of smug and faddish late-60s USA. Great fun, with, among the conquests, Julie Christie, Goldie Hawn and Lee Grant - who won an Oscar as the bored wife of philandering Jack Warden.

fields.headline: Malice in wonderland
fields.trailText: Well, here's a surprise, not to say a serious shock to the system. There is something well worth watching on Sky One. The Tenth Kingdom is like an enjoyable Gormenghast, an elaborate fantasy but much less pretentious and far more fun.
fields.body:
Well, here's a surprise, not to say a serious shock to the system. There is something well worth watching on Sky One. The Tenth Kingdom is like an enjoyable Gormenghast, an elaborate fantasy but much less pretentious and far more fun.

What we have here are creatures of the imagination escaping into the real world and back again. When characters from fairy tales burst into Central Park, their arrival is not as noticeable as you might expect. Prince Charming has been changed into an attractive dog called, what else, Prince; three thuggish trolls are indistinguishable from your run-of-the-mill mugger and the big, bad wolf is, demonstrably, still a wolf. Particularly when he catches sight of Virginia, the heroine. "Tasty or WHAT!"

It is difficult to convey in the modesty of print just how noisy a native New Yorker can be when he puts his mind to it. Memorably played by Scott Cohen, this well over-the-top wolf ("BORN TO GORGE!") is what you might call an Alan Rickman role. Or, put another way, damned hard luck on the hero.

The Tenth Kingdom, appropriately 10 hours long, was made at Pinewood (with a flurry of forays to Austria and France, which caused quarantine problems for Prince.) The cast are roughly half and half British and American and some of them, in a quiet way, take your breath away. When a lanky green Geordie said gloomily, "My name's Clayface, the Goblin", I heard myself saying, "Oh no it's not! It's Jimmy Nail!" You can play this pantomime game virtually indefinitely. The Tenth Kingdom isn't so straight-faced that you feel you shouldn't.

Simon Moore, who wrote it, shows all the signs of a child who once lived in the kingdom of his own head. There's plenty of pantomime, with particular reference to magic beans. Disney's Snow White is a strong influence, particularly the Wicked Queen, whose every appearance used to be greeted with a clatter of seats as a generation of children dived for the floor. And there are older, Grimmer legends like the Wicked Queen being forced to dance in hot metal shoes at Snow White's wedding.

The prince is Snow White's grandson, morphed into a dog by the the current Wicked Queen. "Happy ever after didn't last as long as we hoped," he said sadly. Labradors can do desolate, charming and dim. After that they're back to desolate. Prince does all these beautifully. Only a persistently wagging tail suggests that he hasn't quite grasped the seriousness of his situation. There are lines which struck me as unpushily funny. Prince is, naturally, rather officer-class. "Follow me!" he cried confidently. "The dog said 'Follow him,'" interpreted the heroine's father, who'd wasted a perfectly good wish learning dog-speak.

Talking of dogs, Lucinda Lambton's lurcher has died. She appeared in One Foot In The Past (BBC2) wrapped all in black. "Our beautiful dog, Flint, was killed here a few weeks ago. He died, thank heavens, a glorious death for a dog - in full and delirious flight, speared straight through the lungs and ribs by a long, sharp stick." Lucinda has been much missed and so, of course, is Flint. "He was a rough-haired lurcher whom I love with all my might and main. He was just two years old. It's a sorry and strange business constantly catching sight of him or, rather, thinking that you are about to catch sight of him."

In a power cut in a coal mine, you would know it was Lucinda. She is one of the last great alliterists and often gives adjectives a jolly good whack on the head to drive them home. If she goes overboard, it is a most distinctive dive.

She determined ("Huzzah and hurrah!") to raise an obelisk to Flint's memory. The master mason, a man with a mordant sense of humour, arrived with a dog of his own. "That's all we need, to run our dog over," he said, trundling the stone into place. Am I hallucinating or was that a topiary rabbit, all ears, beside Flint's grave?

She took us round a pet cemetery, which included a large family of rats. "Disraeli, a kind rat" and "Gladstone, a loving rat." You did wonder, albeit respectfully, why they were all called after politicians.

I remember seeing a gravestone to Major. "Born a dog. Died a gentleman." And another to Bill, a mule. "He done his damnedest. No angel could do more."

Guess their nationalities.

webTitle: Meet Caroline. Snoop around her flat, email her, then send her flowers

fields.headline: Meet Caroline. Snoop around her flat, email her, then send her flowers
fields.standfirst: David Teather on Freeserve's new interactive online soap: www.onlinecaroline.com
fields.trailText: She's 27, a travel writer, has a fashionable pad in west London, likes a drop or two of vodka and wants to be your friend. Meet Caroline, the Bridget Jonesesque star of a new 24-part drama made for the internet and coming to a PC near you.
fields.body:
She's 27, a travel writer, has a fashionable pad in west London, likes a drop or two of vodka and wants to be your friend. Meet Caroline, the Bridget Jonesesque star of a new 24-part drama made for the internet and coming to a PC near you.

Online Caroline is the first original programming of its kind to appear on Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, and tells the story of our eponymous heroine and her increasingly menacing boyfriend. The story, making a self-conscious nod to the milieu, is told through a simulated webcam set up in Caroline's fictional flat.

Viewers are invited to give as much personal information as they like and become a passive character in the drama. Daily emails from Caroline, commenting about and asking for advice on the events unfolding, become more intimate the more details you give. She will, for instance, make casual references to members of the viewer's family.

As you become her friend, alongside the daily three-minute webcam sequence you can dip into parts of her life, look around her flat, find out about her work, friends and boyfriend. An interactive element allows viewers to colour the events by deciding what Caroline wears or makes for dinner, with the aim of establishing a virtual relationship with the character.

Cassandras in the audience might find the idea of a cyber-friend confirms the more chilling view of the internet as a phenomenon which fuels a generation of socially inept people plugged into their PCs - a kind of adult Tamagochi which replaces real-life contact. For Freeserve it's a canny method of getting people back to its portal.

Online programming is not entirely new. MSN ran an internet soap for six months called Melrose. But XPT, the fledgling production company behind Online Caroline, believes the advent of unmetered web access could reinvent the internet's role as an entertainment medium.

"People have been looking for a long time at making entertainment on the web work, but there is a sense that the audience is now really there," says Tim Wright, who wrote the script for the drama. "Faster and cheaper internet access means there is a market for this kind of thing."

The cast of five is led by unknown actress Mira Dovrini and the entire series was shot over five days in the Notting Hill flat of Wright's team-mate Rob Bevan. They claim the series has cost the same to make as a low-budget hour of TV drama - between £60,000 and £100,000.

By the end of the second episode a number of plot mechanisms are in place. Should Caroline go to a job in Paris with her boss who clearly has other things on his mind? Is her boyfriend having an affair with her best friend Sophie? As the story develops the plot becomes more darkly comic.

Users can only see one sequence a day and are able to take a break. Smart technology means Caroline will automatically know which episode each of her friends has reached. The first episode aired this week but it's not too late to catch up.

The story deliberately flirts with voyeurism and carries a "live" flash on screen as well as a real-time date and time. Caroline may wave at the camera or, in one sequence, a character lifts the flap of his jacket to reveal the legend "you sad weirdo" written on post-it notes and stuck to the seat of his trousers - an in-joke perhaps.

"Sadness is scalable," Wright says. "Five minutes a day watching this is not too sad. If you explore every level and enter three different versions of your own character, then that might be pretty sad."

To which Bevan quickly adds: "It's no more sad than a lot of things people do on the net."

The interactivity of the web means there will be a huge amount of experimentation to find what will work in online programming and what won't. There are unlikely parallels in Caroline with the epistolary novels of the eighteenth century, when writers still playing with ideas of narrative constructed books as a series of letters. When Caroline is under stress, her emails become disjointed and shorter - as any English graduate will tell you the same technique was used by Samuel Richardson to demonstrate his heroine's breakdown in Clarissa.

The ambition, though, is to build a portal with a whole series of interactive programming. EastEnders it's not, but endgame for the likes of XPT will surely be when internet access shifts to the television set and the lines between online drama and conventional broadcasting, and budgets, begin to blur.

Online Caroline is the first original programming of its kind to appear on Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, and tells the story of our eponymous heroine and her increasingly menacing boyfriend. Viewers are invited to give as much personal information as they like and become a passive character in the drama. She will, for instance, make casual references to members of the viewer's family. fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Oliver Holle
fields.trailText: Age? 29
fields.body:
Age? 29

Who is he? CEO of Sysis and the inventor of votemonkey.com.

What's the clever idea? Votemonkey takes hot topics from politics, economics, society - any type of issue, essentially - and creates a game simulation where the surfer is put in charge. It's interactive, fun, thought-provoking and serves a real purpose because nowadays, especially in the London mayor elections, the old lines of voting don't work any more. It offers interactive content that increases user loyalty to the websites that are hosting these games - we are launching it with the Guardian and Freeserve. It increases customer loyalty and makes politics more fun, taking specific issues and bringing them alive.

What's the thinking behind it? The initial idea was we all had the same problem - too many issues, too little time and too little entertainment in politics. Within three weeks of launching it in Austria, we had nearly 100,000 people playing it - a perfect example of viral-marketing on the web. Each month we decide which is the hottest issue of the moment and think about how to create a game around that issue. We did a game about the millennium bug and the effects of the new Austrian government.

How does votemonkey work? It takes you through the main issues in the elections (such as the London mayor election) and helps you sort out which candidate fits best for you. You go to votemonkey.com and start the game. The game then asks you to choose your position and most important issues and at the end it proposes the candidate that matches your opinions or position most closely. If you're not satisfied with the real candidates you can go back to The Grinder - the second element of the game - where you can create your own fantasy candidate and match the candidates against your own one. The main purpose is entertainment, but it still has to be thought-provoking and get people involved in politics, as they start to rethink the issues.

Shortcomings? Some people might find votemonkey provoking because it tells you whom to vote for based on 20 or so questions. But it's entertainment. No other shortcomings really.

What's next? We are licensing our games internationally, but only for certain time periods and in certain regions. Votemonkey in the US will help Americans decide which president to select. In the UK there will be xmasagent.com where you answer several questions about someone you want to get a present for and it recommends a nice present for that person. We are developing multi-user games that can be played on-line as well as through your mobile phone (Wap and SMS).

webTitle: Why is my mail talking to me?

fields.headline: Why is my mail talking to me?
fields.trailText: Email used to be the simplest part of the internet user's experience. Just plain text, nothing more. Well, that's going out the window. Progress in the internet world means your email is about to get more vocal and visual.
fields.body:
Email used to be the simplest part of the internet user's experience. Just plain text, nothing more. Well, that's going out the window. Progress in the internet world means your email is about to get more vocal and visual.

Expect to receive an increasing number of email messages that arrive in HTML format - with photos, graphics, hypertext links to audio and video, etc - instead of boring text-only. And, in what is the latest internet trend, emails will talk to you.

One nifty piece of new software is going to be the cause of a lot of talking emails turning up in your inbox. TalkSender is a free application that web users download to their PCs, then they can use a PC microphone to record up to 60-second of voice message that gets emailed to a recipient. The recording plays when the email is opened.

You can expect to see technology like this take the internet by storm. It is pretty cool to be able to send a voice message via email - no typing required. TalkSender, which launched earlier this year, has been getting an average of 750 "fan letters" every day - as voice emails, of course - according to TalkSender.com co-founder and president Douglas Kim. (The most poignant ones are broadcast over the office intercom to give TalkSender employees a day-brightener.) What voice is doing for email, he says, is putting a personal touch into email communication.

Voice email technology is not only going to change personal email, it also is going to have a profound impact on commercial email publishing. TalkSender has a business program to help email publishers use its technology and email service bureaux to send out voice-enhanced email to large lists of subscribers.

Several other companies are operating in the voice email publishing space, catering to the publishing market. VoxEmail.com, for example, provides voice services to some major internet publishers, including DiscoveryChannel.com and America Online. Founder David Lawrence, an American syndicated talkshow host, says that publishers have barely scratched the surface of what's possible with voice email.

VoxEmail also limits the length of audio messages it sends out on behalf of clients to 60 seconds - to minimise the file size of the audio recordings, so that ISPs don't filter out messages because they're too large.

Lawrence thinks political candidates - who are well accustomed to creating soundbites - are the perfect users of mass-distributed voice emails. Wired American Democrats no doubt will soon get email with Al Gore's voice urging them to vote for him, or responding to a rumour spread by his opponent.

Voice email publishing is so new that most publishers haven't figured out what to do with it yet. Many are still trying to figure out how to collect more email addresses of their users, let alone incorporate audio into their email distribution, says Dan Murray, email marketing strategist for MessageMedia.

Murray's company has a partnership with another voice company, Evoke.com, which takes a slightly different approach to voice email. Its "talking email" system has senders pick up their phones and dial a free number to record their message which is then incorporated into the email. For the free public service, messages are limited to 30 seconds, and the phone call must be made within five minutes of creating the email.

Evoke also has a business version of the service, which can be used for sending large audio files. The actual file is not sent to each user, but rather emails include a link to the audio file which is triggered when the message is opened. The audio is "streamed" to the recipient over the web, so there's no wait to download a file.

This hybrid phone-PC system for voice email is a bit clunky, in that you have to use two devices to create a voice email. Systems that support recording directly on the PC are simpler to use, and are more likely to get used. TalkSender's Douglas Kim derides phone-PC voice email as outdated technology "that will never work."

Voice email publishing is a significant and promising trend. It adds a personal element to internet communication that plain text can't match - especially if the message is coming from a business. Also, proponents of voice email point to evidence that a human voice element to emails significantly increases the response rate for the message.

fields.headline: How to sell a castle
fields.standfirst: Forget the Millennium Dome. A trip to a Saxon fortress makes a far better day out. Liz Carslaw tells  Tom Twentyman  about marketing a tourist attraction
fields.trailText: Forget the Millennium Dome. A trip to a Saxon fortress makes a far better day out. Liz Carslaw tells Tom Twentyman about marketing a tourist attraction
fields.body:
"We have even been a question on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?" says Liz Carslaw, marketing co-ordinator at Leeds Castle. The contestant correctly guessed that the Leeds in question is a tiny village near Maidstone in Kent, although the exact location has caused problems for some. "There are open-air concerts here every summer, and one year a couple bought tickets and went up to Yorkshire," says Carslaw. "They realised their mistake, caught the first train south and got here just in time for the second half."

A native of Maidstone, Carslaw, 38, ventured slightly further afield at the start of her career, working for a London PR company where she rose from secretary to account executive. Her 30th birthday proved to be a milestone. "I'd been in the capital for a decade and just felt 'Stop the world, I want to get off.'" She changed direction completely, going to Rome where she spent the next four years as a freelance English teacher.

"I've always loved languages and already spoke French and Spanish from my college days as a bilingual secretary," she says. "Italy was a brilliant experience but eventually I felt it was time to return home and resume my career."

She headed back to London and, retracing her steps, ended up with the same PR firm, which had offered her three months work as a temp. But while the environment may have been familiar, Carslaw quickly discovered that in her absence technology had taken giant strides forward. "My boss didn't seem to want me to do a lot, which I found puzzling. He then asked how I was coping with all the emails he'd been sending." She discovered that there were about 20 waiting for her attention. "I felt really stupid. Until that moment, I honestly didn't know such a thing existed."

As the temporary assignment drew to a close, Carslaw began to wonder what she was going to do next. The commute from Maidstone was also becoming a chore, so she was delighted when her mother rang and said: "I've just seen your job in the local paper - marketing secretary at Leeds Castle." She started the job three weeks later, and admits, "It's everything I was waiting for."

First of all, however, she had to teach herself Windows. "Before I went to Rome I was using an Amstrad computer, and while I was away Microsoft just took over everything." Her typing and shorthand skills were still up to date, however, and it didn't take long to slot back in. "When I came to Leeds Castle they didn't know what email was either!" she says with a laugh. "We're still getting to grips with it."

The castle was originally a Saxon fortress built in AD 857, though centuries of improvement have added towers, turrets and a moat. It is one of the "treasure houses of England" - 10 privately owned historic homes marketed as ideal for family days out or group tours. With increasing competition from the Millennium Dome and other new attractions in nearby London, 40% of the castle's visitors are from overseas.

In 1998, two years after she joined Leeds Castle, Carslaw's job as marketing secretary had expanded and her job title was changed to marketing co-ordinator. Her main duty is as PA to Sandra Barrett, the marketing manager. "Everything else I do, such as liaising with our advertising agency or arranging photo shoots and visits, has to be fitted around that," she says. "Sandra refers to me as her ambassador, in that I represent her on-site and off. If someone is talking to me, they should feel as if they're talking to her."

Her boss, she says, believes in delegation and personal development, and where possible will give Carslaw her own major projects to manage. "Castle staff attend up to 10 exhibitions a year, and Sandra trusts me totally to run everything. She knows that I'm in control, whether it's booking the space, planning the promotion, or manning the stand itself."

Carslaw's latest task is choosing smart suits as a uniform for the 12 women in the department. "It's tricky, because our ages range from 24 to 60, we're all different heights and our sizes start at 10 and finish at 18. I need to buy a marquee as well - not that I anticipate contacting the same supplier for both!"

Part of the job is a willingness to work flexible hours, and Carslaw often finds herself working evenings and weekends. As the summer season begins in earnest, things will get even busier. She is on the rota, for instance, to spend part of the Easter weekend staffing an information point in the grounds. "You don't always get neat slots, or a 9 to 5 routine," she says resignedly. "But that's the nature of tourism."

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: • A DAY TO REMEMBER
fields.body:
 A DAY TO REMEMBER

Next Tuesday, April 26, is Administrative Professionals' Day, and it's your chance to create excitement about how invaluable you are. You could go for the bold approach and hang a banner over the office door, or perhaps you'd prefer discreetly to email all senior managers, suggesting they order flowers. Whatever you do, it's a great opportunity to highlight your contribution to the workplace. Try asking colleagues to consider where they would be without you! (See page 9.)

 TIME TO TAKE NOTE

Minute-taking is still a vital skill for today's secretary, but one that many PAs feel they need to develop, according to Manchester firm Sue Williams Training. The company was astonished at the demand for a recent minute-taking course, run alongside a number of IT courses. "Many PAs come to their position via a route that bypasses secretarial college - graduates come straight from university, for example - and may have excellent technical skills but not core secretarial skills," says a spokeswoman. For more details on courses, call 0161 839 2309.

 LEARNING FOR LIFE

It seems the message about life-long learning is getting through. New figures show that 85% of adults of working age in England now have a qualification equivalent to a pass at GCSE, according to the labour force survey. Education and employment minister Baroness Blackstone is delighted with the news. "Qualifications are not just for young people," she says. "They are vital in helping individuals meet their career goals."

 DELEGATES IN DISGRACE

Have you been shocked by the behaviour of delegates at an event you organised? Meetings agency Banks Sadler reports a worrying increase in bad behaviour among executives, ranging from trashed bedrooms to verbal abuse of staff. In a survey of 60 hotels, general managers said the worst offenders were younger graduates and, increasingly, women. webTitle: TV show asks entrepreneurs: Who wants to net a million?

fields.headline: TV show asks entrepreneurs: Who wants to net a million?
fields.trailText: Forget Chris Tarrant and phone-a-friend. With a new game show boasting the biggest guaranteed cash giveaway on British television, Channel 4 today lays down the challenge to the publicity seekers of the internet generation: who wants to be an e-millionaire?
fields.body:
Forget Chris Tarrant and phone-a-friend. With a new game show boasting the biggest guaranteed cash giveaway on British television, Channel 4 today lays down the challenge to the publicity seekers of the internet generation: who wants to be an e-millionaire?

The show invites members of the public who have never been involved with internet ventures to pitch an idea for a dot.com business. The winner will get £1m to invest, while another £1m will be shared among four runners-up.

A group of venture capitalists are providing the cash for the E-Millionaire Show. Adverts will run on Channel 4, and a website (www.emillionaireshow.com) went on stream this morning.

The show's producers are expecting thousands of applications this week. These will be whittled down to 15, who will have to pitch their ideas on a series of live game shows broadcast at peak time over a week in May and hosted by the newscaster Jon Snow. Five will go through to the final round.

Henrietta Conrad, the show's co-executive producer, said: "We're basically conducting a massive talent scout.

"We want to find a granny in Huddersfield who's got an idea but not the first clue how to go about it."

If the chosen business is a success, neither Princess Productions, the company making the show, nor Channel 4 will make a profit. The entrepreneur retains the largest stake in the company (33%), and a member of the audience wins a 1% shareholding. Viewers will be able to invest too.

The catch is that the winning business must agree to be trailed by a documentary crew, and the results will be broadcast to the nation a year later.

While ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has a maximum prize of £1m, there is no guarantee that any of the contestants will win. So far, the show's top giveaway has been £500,000.

fields.headline: Marauding White comes up roses
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 166-9 Yorkshire 167-6
Yorkshire won by four wickets
fields.trailText: Suddenly Craig White can do no wrong. To have predicted at the end of last season that the Yorkshire all-rounder not only had an England future but would also be named as one of the 12 contracted players would have been to invite cries of incredulity. On yesterday's evidence, the unexpected show of faith might just be the making of him.
fields.body:
Suddenly Craig White can do no wrong. To have predicted at the end of last season that the Yorkshire all-rounder not only had an England future but would also be named as one of the 12 contracted players would have been to invite cries of incredulity. On yesterday's evidence, the unexpected show of faith might just be the making of him.

White is not especially suited to April's pudding pitches, but he raided Lancashire for the best one-day figures of his career, five for 25, and even accentuated his new all-action image by having a spell behind the stumps when Richard Blakey temporarily left the field with a dislocated finger.

Most noteworthy of all, White was the only bowler not to bowl a wide. Forty-three were bowled, 26 by Lancashire. It was a damning statistic and, with defeat beckoning, Yorkshire's batsmen became increasingly conscious that they could edge towards their target just by remaining at the crease.

They finished with a flourish, Gavin Hamilton joining Blakey in an unbroken seventh-wicket stand of 64 in 13 overs.

Yorkshire will seek to solve their top-order shortcomings by promoting Blakey up the order this summer - he would have batted at No3 were it not for injury - and he will have quite a season if everybody feeds his square cut as charitably as Lancashire.

White's victims included Lancashire's captain, John Crawley, whose 45 was the smoothest innings of the day, and Sourav Ganguly, who made only five before he pushed to point.

Blakey was restored in time to hold a startling one-handed catch off White to dismiss Ian Austin in the closing rush.

After all the talk of Indian bookmakers, it was a relief to have cause once again to appreciate an Indian cricketer.

Ganguly might have had to concede attention in the past week to a miserable cast of corrupt bookies, sickly Bollywood actors and dodgy businessmen, but three top-order Yorkshire wickets suggested that his medium-pace will have its days.

The Australian Darren Lehmann was out second ball for nought and Michael Vaughan also failed to survive his first over.

This was all an improvement on Ganguly's Lancashire debut, against Nottinghamshire at Trent Bridge 24 hours earlier, when he made nought, failed to take a wicket, and generally looked as if 10 of Lancashire's new fleeces would not have spared him from hypothermia.

Yorkshire's batting order is far from settled and Chris Silverwood pulled out yesterday with a heel problem, adding to aggravating early-season injuries to Anthony McGrath and Richard Harden.

At 103 for six, they had looked bound for a second successive defeat. They could thank rare Lancashire generosity for their escape.

fields.headline: Cronje's stake raised to £85,000
fields.standfirst: Failed Bollywood actor and team-mates' tales add to game's tangled worldwide web
fields.trailText: The disgraced former South Africa cricket captain Hansie Cronje allegedly accepted an £85,000 bribe as his advance fee to fix matches, according to new evidence obtained by the Indian police.
fields.byline: Luke Harding in New Delhi and David Hopps
fields.body:
The disgraced former South Africa cricket captain Hansie Cronje allegedly accepted an £85,000 bribe as his advance fee to fix matches, according to new evidence obtained by the Indian police.

Cronje agreed to fix the now-infamous series of one-day matches between India and South Africa and was also approached by bookmakers seeking a deal over the two Tests between the sides in Bombay and Bangalore last month. However, he allegedly told Sanjay Chawla, the bookmaker implicated in the scandal, that fixing the Tests would not be possible. He agreed to collaborate only on the one-day games, police sources allege.

According to a statement by Rajesh Kalra, an associate of Chawla's who was arrested 10 days ago, the match-fixing conspiracy was hatched in December 1999 when Chawla flew to India from his home in London. The bookmaker told Kalra he had befriended Cronje and was planning to fix the matches scheduled to be held in March. He specifically said he was in touch only with Cronje, who would "coordinate" with the other players.

The money used to bribe Cronje was raised by Kishan Kumar, a failed Bollywood actor with underworld links, detectives allege. Kumar, who claims he is suffering from angina, was arrested on Saturday by the New Delhi police branch that investigates money-laundering. He has been charged with violating India's strict foreign currency laws.

Lawyers have suggested it is unlikely Cronje would be convicted were he to return to India to stand trial. They doubt whether proper permission was obtained by police before the phone used by Cronje was bugged by officers who were originally investigating an alleged extortion plot. This might allow Cronje to argue lack of due process.

In South Africa, though polls suggest the public remains unyielding in its support for Cronje, team-mates past and present are beginning to break ranks. Three former Test players, Andrew Hudson, Dave Richardson and Brian McMillan, have confirmed that the approach to Cronje from illegal bookmakers to fix a one-day international against India in Bombay four years ago - which was supposedly "dismissed out of hand" - actually entailed three team meetings before a bribe of $250,000 (£160,000) was finally rejected.

An additional one-day international, at the end of an arduous tour involving 23 internal flights, had infuriated the South Africans and Richardson recalled: "No one really wanted to play. For us it was a lot of money. Sure you should dismiss it out of hand. But when you're touring the sub-continent, these approaches are made often."

Hudson was one of those implacably opposed. "There were some saying adamantly no but there were some who were not indifferent to it."

In another development Derek Crookes, the South African off-spinner, has confirmed his astonish ment when he was asked to open the bowling against India in a one-day match in Nagpur last month, just as Cronje allegedly promised Chawla he would in the police tape recordings of negotiations between the pair.

"I was surprised when Hansie told me I would be opening the bowling," said Crookes. "Earlier on tour he told me I wouldn't be opening at all." He conceded 53 in six overs.

Further anguish for Cronje came with a sceptical assessment by Darryl Cullinan, the South African batsman, of the controversial circumstances surrounding England's victory over South Africa in the final Test at Centurion Park this year, one of the matches to be investigated by an independent commission of inquiry.

Cullinan, who described Cronje's enthusiasm to revive a rain-hit match with two forfeits as "entirely out of character", said: "I would like to think that Hansie was acting in the interests of the game and doing something for the public, but it went totally against the guy I know.

"I have known him for 15 years and played under him for seven years and it seemed an odd decision. He wasn't in the habit of giving anything to the other side or making a game of it."

Suggestions abound that some illegal Asian bookmakers were desperate to avoid what looked an inevitable draw. One current South Africa player said: "I knew about Centurion, but I didn't know anything about India."

Even Cronje's deep Christian faith has been questioned. Possibly his religious convictions caused him to reveal his links with the bookmaker last week, but new evidence suggests he knew his deceit had been uncovered. Shortly before his admission he was summoned to a meeting with the South African deputy minister of foreign affairs, Aziz Pahad, who told him that diplomats believed Delhi police possessed "sound evidence" that he had taken the bookmaker's money.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Lance Klusener sailed to South Africa's rescue after one of their worst weeks.
fields.body:
Lance Klusener sailed to South Africa's rescue after one of their worst weeks.

In front of a record Wanderers crowd of 31,500, the all-rounder smashed 52 not out from 50 balls as South Africa, reeling at 122 for six, won the third one-day international against Australia by four wickets to take the series 2-1.

Mark Boucher (55) was the calm presence at the other end as the pair added 87 from 96 balls. Earlier a 72-run stand between Andrew Hall (46) and Jacques Kallis (30) had threatened to come to naught as Shane Warne's leg-spin cast its familiar spell over the middle order.

Australia reached 205 all out after being 114 for six. Their captain Steve Waugh top-scored with 51. His South African counterpart Shaun Pollock said: "It's been a difficult week, but it's done wonders in pulling the team together."

 In the Benson and Hedges Cup, James Ormond reduced Durham to 12 for three and Anil Kumble chipped in with three wickets as Leicestershire won by 20 runs at Grace Road.

Derbyshire needed only 11.4 overs to win at Trent Bridge after bowling Nottinghamshire out for 94; Dominic Cork removed the top three batsmen, all lbw.

David Sales hit 64 not out as Northamptonshire beat Somerset courtesy of Duckworth-Lewis at Taunton, and Graeme Hick (55) led Worcestershire to victory over Glamorgan.
